column2: ALGIERS, July 24 -- Col. Houari Boumedienne has set about to mend relations with Soviet-bloc states whose support for his five-week-old regime is still lagging.

TOKYO, July 24 -- Conservatives lost their traditional control of Tokyo, Japan's capital and the world's biggest city, as the Socialist Party emerged today with the largest number of seats in the Metropolitan Assembly.

Harvey Cox, says a writer in the current issue of Christianity and Crisis, is the Reinhold Niebuhr of the present generation. Certainly Dr. Cox's first book is having something of the liberating effect in theological circles that characterized Dr. Niebuhr's early work.

WORKING with a Rockefeller Foundation grant of $77,900, the Minnesota Theater Company will set up a study course this autumn to train a dozen voice teachers who may be expected, after finishing the course, to pass on what they have learned to working actors.
BRUSSELS, July 24 -- Belgium is still without a government two months after the last Parliamentary elections.

LONDON, July 24 -- There is a clear relationship between cigarette smoking and sexual activity among boys and girls between the ages of 15 and 19, according to a three-year study of teen-agers in England and Wales.

MADISON, Wis., July 24 -Having found a hall, Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, Democrat of Wisconsin, will hold an unusual public hearing here July 30 to determine grassroots opinion on the war in Vietnam.

FOUR years ago signs at New York City Housing Authority projects admonished "Keep Off the Grass." Today, they refer to flowers. In 1963, the authority sponsored its first flower garden competition for tenants.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -President Johnson received today a report that excise tax cuts on automobiles and air-conditioners were passed on to consumers in mid-June.

EASTON, Md. -- This lovely town, the seat of Talbot County on Maryland's Eastern Shore, lies 215 miles from New York, via the New Jersey Turnpike and the Delaware Memorial Bridge. It is the perfect place to make one's headquarters while exploring the county's 602 miles of waterfront; it also affords the traveler a glimpse into America as it was three centuries ago.

THE "stone deserts" that typify downtown shopping areas of so many modern cities have been turned into "portable gardens'' in Copenhagen and Stockholm by the City Gardeners of these northern European capitals.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -Administration planners, convinced that most of the objectives of the Democratic party since, the New Deal have now been translated into law, believe that the chief task of the Great Society is to improve and perhaps radically alter the "environment" of American life and the "quality" of American lives.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Some Federal authorities are forecasting a emphasis shift of on enforcement of civil rights from the South to other parts of the country.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Johnson continued his intensive review of United States policy in Vietnam today.

OTTAWA, July. 24 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson is being both lauded and criticized for the new device he is bringing to play in Canadian politics. This is the periodic Federal-provincial conference that drew Premiers from Canada's 10 provinces to Ottawa this week.
I have just read the article by Israel Shenker and I was truly amazed by every sentence that is reported to have been said by the two Italian guides.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24 -- Mrs. Timothea Larr and Steve Worcester, two young persons with special talents for steering racing yachts, were the most successful skippers in the most successful Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week ever held.

CEDAR KEY, Fla. -- In this quaint and somewhat isolated seaside fishing village (population: 800), some things, have happened recently that will improve the facilities for fishing and boating enjoyment.
Work is about to begin to put together one of the biggest trade shows ever held.

AN important new record by Artur Schnabel, actually new in the sense that none of its contents had been released here before, has just arrived among Capitol's EMI imports. The disk comprises four works of Mozart: the Sonatas in A minor (K. 310), F major (K. 332) and B flat (K. 570) and the Rondo in A minor (K. 511).

EARLIER, John Le Carre wrote a couple of passable murder mysteries. "A Murder of Quality" has nothing much to do with spies, and is also rather routine. "Call for the Dead," though it concerns the murders of spies by spies, is not properly a spy tale.
DETROIT, July 24 -- A group of university officials and businessmen formed the American Academy of Transportation this week to find solutions to the nation's transportation problems.
LUENEBURG, Germany, July 24 (AP) -- A Communist East German border patrol boat was rammed and nearly sunk by a West German tourist vessel on the Elbe River yesterday, the police here reported today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 24 -- The nation's Governors will gather here tomorrow for the 57th annual Governors Conference. Their agenda will emphasize reapportionment, civil rights, education, antipoverty programs, tax-sharing and the inevitable ingredient, politics.

IN this book set in the last Glacial Age, Arkla, a bristly dog, and Ash, his young, cave-dwelling Cro-Magnon master, are an inseparable pair. Together boy and dog bait and beat a giant aurochs bull, turn a bison stampede, set a deer-hunting record and subdue a wolf pack.

STARDUST International Raceway, now being constructed on the western edge of Las Vegas, Nev., could become one of the finest "driver" courses in America. As the accompanying drawing indicates, there will be some extremely fast turns as well as some low-gear slow ones, while the sweeping backstretch and the long home stretch with a slight dogleg curve should produce maximum-speed performances.
Beginning next Sunday, a man buying a $1.60 restaurant meal in New York City will pay a total of $1.68. The same meal in Auburn will cost $1.66; in Jamestown, $1.63.

SCIENTISTS are so much better known for their experiments than for themselves that they aren't ordinarily thought of as men and women. That, nevertheless, is very much what they are. I have been finding this out since shortly after the attack on Hiroshima when, as a writer, I was seized with a somewhat anthropological urge to acquaint myself with the -- to me -- unfamiliar tribe who were transforming everyone's lives, including their own.

THE advances of the jet age are about to provide domestic air passenger with a belated travel bonus. The 40-pound limit on free baggage, which was instituted 27 years ago when two-engine DC-3's were the mainstays on domestic flights, is soon scheduled to go the way of those illustrious craft.
A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally stabbed early yesterday in a street fight with a sailor near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the police reported.

RICHMOND, July 24 -- The filing deadline for candidates for Governor of Virginia in the November election passed here yesterday, with four candidates apparently qualified to run. Among them is George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- When Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen emerged from a session of the Senate Judiciary Committee two weeks ago, he was asked if Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York was unhappy about taking sides on the issue of reapportionment for state legislatures.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 25 (AP) -- An American sought in connection with the fatal shooting of Jack E. Ryan, chief American advisor to the Vietnamese police, was arrested early today, informants reported.
Most constitutional experts agree that, when Arthur J. Goldberg replaced Felix Frankfurter on the Supreme Court in October, 1962, the course of the Court's rulings changed.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A five-cent commemorative postage stamp, ordered Tuesday by President Johnson to honor Adlai E. Stevenson, will be issued Oct. 23 in Bloomington, Ill., where Mr. Stevenson was buried this week.
Last month a committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies strongly urged that the industry do more to assist college educators in marketing, advertising and related fields.

I DID not especially like the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill "Mahagonny," currently being given at the Stratford Festival in Canada, but I keep on thinking about it; and that, of course, is a tribute to its strength.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -President Johnson named Joseph A. Califano Jr. today to be a special assistant to the President.

JOHN K. GALBRAITH performed a public service in your lead review of May 16 in setting the record straight on the victory of Keynesian economics. The nation owes to a small group of American economists the advances of the new economics and its acceptance by the Government and other.
ALBANY, July 24 -- New York State voters will face more constitutional amendments and propositions on Nov. 2 than have been put on the voting machine in at least a decade.

Knee-high socks in bright colors and patterns are one of the popular items for fall in sportswear departments, resident buying offices report. The style came on strongly last fall, and is expected to be even more popular this year.
A 17-year-old schoolboy from the Bronx shared honors with three elders yesterday in a track and field meet at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox survived crippling injuries to two pitchers and snapped a five-game losing streak by defeating the Los Angeles Angels, 8-5, today with the help of a three-run homer by Jim Gosger, a rookie.

DETROIT, July 24 -- American Motors Corporation executives were so confident a year ago that their new 1965 models would stem a bothersome decline in sales that they flatly refused to discuss any other possibility.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (Reuters) -- Six national religious groups announced today at the end of a two-day meeting that they had formed a joint religious council.

The decisions on maritime subsidies embodied in a report issued Friday by Commerce Secretary John T. Connor contained stark warning to the American merchant marine and its 48,000 seamen, experts in the industry believe.
MIAMI, July 24 (AP) -- Fidel Castro predicted tonight that next year Cuba will harvest 6 1/2 million tons of sugar cane. He told 5,000 champion cane cutters:
A new printing paper mill at Anderson, Calif. A computer factory in St. Paul, Minn. An automated oil refinery operation control center at Billings.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 24 -With water in Gatun Lake -through which ships float across the isthmian hills -- down to within less than half a foot of its record low for July, the maximum draft for vessels permitted to transit the Panama Canal will be restricted to 34 feet 6 inches effective Aug 1.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- A leading Soviet policy-maker warned today of the presence of an "American military icebreaker" lingering in the Arctic waters off the northern soviet coastline.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 -- An international jury has given the $20,000 award for design for rebuilding the city of Skoplje, Yugoslavia, to the architectural firm of Kenzo Tange of Tokyo and the Town Planning Institute of Zagreb.
HONG KONG, July 24 -- The United States' military build-up in South Vietnam has been so swift that shortages have developed.

One of the disappointing developments in the new Africa is failure of the attempt to create an East African Federation of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda, former components of British Africa. This seemed a practical possibility only two years ago and was widely regarded as a pilot project for regional cooperation and unity in a continent menaced by "Balkanization."

MOSCOW, July 24 -- The public trial of a young British intellectual charged with subversion has given vivid evidence of the confusion still present in the minds of loyal Soviet Communists about foreigners.
Like the Queen of England, Casey Stengel is having two birthdays this year -- an "official" one today and the real McCoy next Friday. He will be 75 years old both times.
More Americans each year have stopped talking about the heat and have done something about it.

At about 6 P.M. last Wednesday, President Johnson's top advisers on Vietnam left his office and, before the coffee cups could be cleared away, 11 spokesmen for American education were ushered in. The President was reported to have expressed his sorrow that so much of his energy had to be spent on military conflict.

SAIGON, Sunday, July 25 (AP) -- A district headquarters and outpost only four miles from Saigon were attacked by the Vietcong early today. A United States military spokesman said. Radio contact with the post was lost, and it was believed to have been overrun.
State Controller Arthur Levitt is being urged by upstate Democratic leaders to run for the State Court of Appeals this year.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 24 -- A review of last week's training movies here this morning added conviction to the coaching staff's assurance that the New York Giants will be a much stronger football team this season than last.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- The piloting contest held today off Stamford Cows Buoy was won by Comdr. George Rawak of the Greenwich Power Squadron in his boat Bold Queen. He had a percentage error of 10.1.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 24 -- As the Dominican conflict entered a fourth month, there were persistent reports here today that at least a partial agreement between the disputants might be expected shortly -- perhaps in the coming week.

NEWARK, July 24 -- A semi-official committee of civic, business and professional leaders in Newark and Essex County urged today that the metropolitan New York-New Jersey area develop a unified program for air-pollution control.
The argument of Joseph W. Reilly, S.J. [letter July 18] that the Dirksen amendment should be passed is questionable.
The world is mourning the loss of its truly great -- Adlai E. Stevenson.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.L., July 24 -- Royal Dutch, a 5-year-old bay gelding who was a washout until less than six months ago, won the green jumper championship today at the Hampton horse show.
A New Haven Railroad engineer and two firemen were treated for smoke inhalation yesterday after fire broke out in the engine of a Boston-bound train in the Bronx.

A RESPITE from summer heat can be found in cool, shady areas where tree foliage is so dense that direct sun never penetrates. In such retreats the lack of flower color can be overcome by the judicious use of low-growing plants with variegated foliage.

GLADSTONE, N.J., July 24 -- Bert de Nemethy, Prix des Nations (jumping) coach of the United States Equestrian Team, stood in the middle of a makeshift ring the other day, alternately grimacing and gaining approval.

AACHEN, Germany -- Although this ancient city, once the capital of Charlemagne's empire, is easy to reach, it is usually overlooked by Americans who come to Germany. This summer, however, residents here are trying to correct this oversight, and visitors to Aachen are seeing one of the largest collections of materials about Charlemagne and his empire ever assembled.
SALEM, N.H., July 24 (AP) -- Sister Carol, a 9-1 shot, led all the way in the $15,000 Manchester Handicap today at Rockingham Park before a crowd of 18,045.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -The Supreme Court will follow the example of the White House and Congress tomorrow by allowing a book on its activities to be sold on the premises.

CAIRO, July 24 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser, in an effort to reduce the friction between Egyptian Christians and Moslems made an official appearance at a Christian church ceremony today, his first since taking power.

FOR a moment it looked like an invasion from New Zealand. First it was announced that the 150-voice Christchurch Harmonic Society would appear in the Handel and Haydn Society's International Choral Festival in Boston.

YONKERS, July 24 -- A Congressional subcommittee opened hearings today on the future of the Hudson and quickly learned from witnesses that while everyone professed an abiding love for "America's most majestic river," there was bitter conflict over how it should be saved.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 24 -- Tony Vincent of New York, who is seeking his third straight title, swept into the final round today of the United States men's 35-years-and-over clay court tennis championships at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

An oil drilling rig soaring 50 stories will soon be drilling the ocean floor of the Gulf of Mexico. About half of the structure, which rises 505 feet from a base or mat foundation big as a football field, will be below water, 75 to 100 miles off shore.

MEXICO CITY -- Central America, which has been busy for the past five years putting together its own Common Market, now appears ready to consider ways to build tourism into a significant addition to the area's integrated economy.

THE third annual exhibition of the Association of Heliographers at Lever House, Park Avenue and 54th Street, offers proof of the group's continuing vitality. Organized early in 1963, the group demonstrates in its present show its capacity to develop in new directions, both individually and as a group.
PARIS, July 24 -- "General de Gaulle has graciously accepted an American apology. You can see how generous he is."

Performances of the Royal Marines Tattoo, at Madison Square Garden from Sept. 30 through Oct. 10, will benefit a number of charities. Leaders of society will be joining the Daughters of Scotia and St. Andrews Society to applaud the pipes and drums of the Scots Guards and Royal Scots Greys, the bands of the Royal Marines and the Fiji Military Forces and a mock battle between the Commando Motorcycle Squad and James Bond's Aston-Martin.
CLEVELAND, July 24 -- In the last few days, political campaign buttons proclaiming "I'm with you, Ralph" have been appearing in Cleveland.
I would like to applaud Henry Fairlie's recognition that "the idea of empire is useful" in explaining Soviet, Chinese and American foreign policy ("A Cheer for American Imperialism." July 11 ).

MOSCOW, July 24 -- There's been a nagging feeling in many quarters in the last five months of tension over Vietnam that relations between the Soviet Union and the United States need not be quite as bad as they seemed. These doubts have come to a head in the last two weeks amid vague indications that something is about to give.

BONN, July 24 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has indicated to W. Averell Harriman that the Soviet Union wants to resume a policy of cautious cooperation with the United States despite the Vietnam conflict, diplomatic sources said today.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 24 -- The British invasion, a recent byword in American music, might loosely apply to the Newport Folk Festival.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 24 -- Ray Kaufman of Manhasset Bay took the lead after two races in the Long Island snipe sailing championship series today, winning both races in the event being conducted on Hempstead Harbor by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- Ronald Reagan tried this week to assess his political popularity on northern and central Californians.

Two months ago in Columbus, Ohio, the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., the largest Presbyterian body in the nation, with 3 million members, took the first step toward updating its doctrinal tenets since the church was founded in 1706.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. opened his Northern campaign here today with a whirlwind tour to build support for a march he will lead on city hall Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Charles de Gaulle, the enfant terrible of Western world international politics, has won most of his publicity for his actions and attitudes in the military sphere, particularly his aversion to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
" I don't know. I can tell you I wasn't keen. I was sorry he asked me."
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 24 -W.C. Handy might be wailing the Urban Renewal Blues if he were alive today.
Federal officials accepted yesterday Mayor Wagner's invitation to hold immediate discussions on the feasibility of building atomic plants to desalt sea water for the city's use.

KASTRI, Greece, July 24 -The white villa set in a spacious walled garden in this elegant village 10 miles from Athens belies the name chiseled in its gatepost. The villa is called Galini, which means "calm."

TUCKERTON, N.J., July 24 -- Lawbreakers in the Raritan and Sandy Hook Bay areas this summer may find it prudent to borrow the strategy of Kentucky's moonshiners fleeing from the "revenooers" and head for the hills.
The Johnsons, the Humphreys and the Kennedys have been invited to the Wagners' wedding reception tomorrow afternoon.

Your editorial of July 13 on the voting-rights bill in Congress in effect opposes giving the right to vote to all those who do not speak and read English. At least you apply it to Spanish-speaking American citizens in New York.

TRADING upon the sensational as it pops up in life or in books is something our agile film makers have always notoriously done. It is part of their boasted achievement of "keeping abreast of the times."

THERE are people who maintain that New York in the summertime has a certain humid charm. These are usually residents of the upper East Side who think Park Avenue looks romantically empty on an August weekend, or the tourists who wander through Manhattan's streets tie-less and sandaled -- a condition no New Yorker would be caught dead in -- and thereby stay comfortable enough to survive.
RIGA, Latvia, July 24 -- Latvian government officials declared today that Moscow's new farm-recovery program would provide their republic with first exportable butter surplus in many years.

Recent news items about the safety of motor vehicles suggest the value of some clarifications and perspectives. The subject is a large one, but certain things can and should be said in fairness to the manufacturers, interested safety personnel and driving public.

HUBERT H. HUMPHREY is apparently sustained in the Vice Presidency, as he has been during a busy lifetime, by modified Calvinist view that he owes the world a living and, unless he hustles without pause, he might be accused of defaulting on the debt.
Presbyterians and Roman Catholics will get together for the first time Tuesday in Washington to discuss "future relations.''

THE American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., experienced a new kind of therapy last week. Though feeling in the corporate pink, it was invited to put out its arms for transfusions and to trust the doctor that the last thing he had in mind was surgery.
For two hours yesterday Representative Adam Clayton Powell turned a hot, congested slum street in Harlem into an official chamber for a Congressional hearing on the antipoverty program.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Gary Player shot a seven-under-par 64 over the Lakewood Country Club course today and took a 16-stroke lead after three rounds of the National Challenge Match.
MOSCOW, July 24 (UPI) -- Angry Soviet truck drivers have won a "cabbage war" by besieging Government officials with a noisy, horn-blowing demonstration, it was reported here today.

SILVERSTONE, England, July 24 (UPI) -- Chris Amon of New Zealand won the 150-mile Martini Trophy auto race today after the world champion, John Surtees, dropped out on the seventh lap when his Lola developed engine trouble.
A SHORT exhibition match between two famous pairs will wind up the Greater New York Bridge Association's Brooklyn Sectional Tournament at the New York Hilton tonight.

A tree house -- that snug, above-the-world retreat of childhood -- remains a nostalgic memory for most adults. But a Connecticut couple with two children, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Allen Parsons, recently recreated the spirit of one with their home on a rocky ledge at the top of a hillock in New Canaan. Their architect was Hugh Smallen.
Masons and the Knights of Columbus, who less than a generation ago eyed one another with suspicion, shared a day at the World's Fair yesterday.

A nationwide campaign to reduce general aviation accidents through safety education was announcad yesterday by the Federal Aviation Agency and the Flight Safety Foundation, a private, industry-sponsored organization.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- A lawsuit that may change the course of historical research is coming to a quiet climax in Pennsylvania.

THE man behind the wheel of a Ferrari is either a race driver, skilled, hardened and professional (and he'd better be), or else he is a man who cares enough, and is rich enough, to spend $14,000 or more on high performance, personal transportation, and wants the world to know it.
Last month about 37,000 graduate engineers were added to the nation's technical manpower pool by colleges and universities.

THE cub reporter, that legendary figure of print journalism, has finally made the TV scene. Traditionally the networks have raided newspaper offices and local radio and television stations for promising reportorial and editorial talent.
DESIGNED to eliminate the need for frequent changing of blades, here is an all-purpose utility knife which can be "sharpened" ten times by simply breaking away the dull edge each time.

COWES, Isle of Wight, July 24 (UPI) -- Gordon Ingai brought Caprice of Huon across the line first today and won the Queen Victoria Challenge Cup as Australian yachts took the first three places in the Household Brigade Regatta.

CLARENCE DARROW (1857-1938) brought to the American scene a passion for justice and a belief that the criminal might not be the enemy of society but its victim. Using the courtroom as a classroom, Darrow taught the nation to seek out the underlying causes of crime and to accept society's responsibility for protecting the oppressed -- the laborer, the small businessman, the political outsider, the Negro.
A Harlem physician was charged with homicide yesterday in the abortion death of the 24-year-old daughter of socially prominent parents.

I was delighted to read the letter in your International Edition of July 15 [New York Times, July 11] signed by four of my colleagues in the Political Science Department of M.I.T., supporting the policy of the Administration in seeking to counter Communist aggression in South Vietnam.
LEOPOLDVILLE -- "He is always silent; but when he speaks it is to save the nation."

STOWE, Vt. -- This quiet and quaint community, long famous as a winter resort, is making a concerted drive to attract summer visitors in increasing numbers. The word "concerted" is used advisedly, since musical concerts are among the lures being offered this season.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) -- Willie Davis's two-base error enabled Lou Brock to score the tie-breaking run in the 10th inning tonight, giving St. Louis a 3-2 victory over Los Angeles.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN completed his Cello Symphony, a sort of concerto for cello and orchestra, in 1963. As was the case with his Sonata for Cello and Piano, the Symphony was conceived for the Soviet cellist Mstislav Rostropovich.
CINCINNATI, July 24 (UPI) -- Susie Maxwell shot a six-under-par 66 today for a 133 total and a four-stroke lead in the $10,000 Buckeye Savings invitation golf tournament.
NORFOLK, Va., July 24 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard called off today a search for seven men from Maine aboard a trawler that exploded last night when a World War II torpedo exploded in her fishing net.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -Space officials have been left with more curiosity and fewer answers than usual by law weekend's flurry of space launchings by the Soviet Union.
A hitherto unpublicized study prepared for the Government on the outlook for the nation's survival in the event of atomic war has become the subject of widespread disagreement among scientists.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Johnson, it was disclosed today, is a bowling enthusiast.

PORT HURON, Mich., July 24 (AP) -- Rain squalls and a stiff wind spurred a record field of 165 boats today as they headed north in the 41st annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac yacht race. The 235-mile race is expected to end at Mackinac Island Monday morning.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva was greeted by a tumultuous popular reception and some political headaches today on his return from a visit to four Western European countries.

ILYA EHRENBURG'S panorama of his life and times -- six large volumes covering the quarter century preceding the Russian revolution and the nearly 50 years since -- is now completed. The last chapters of Volume VI, carrying the story up to the early post-Stalin period, have been published in the April issue of the Moscow journal, Novy Mir.

ATLANTA, July 24 -- When civil rights leaders learned last summer that one of their volunteer workers was a Harvard Crimson staffer they urged him to "start a little paper in the Mississippi Delta this fall that will be fair to us."

CARDIFF, Wales, July 24 (UPI) -- Ralph Boston, the world broad-jump record-holder, gained revenge today for the loss of his Olympic title to Lynn Davies when he decisively outjumped the Welshman to win the Welsh Games title with a British all-comers' record of 26 feet 10 inches.

WELL, all right. India is a strange country and known to be a poor one. Still there is a difference between the good intentions of foreigners concerned with India and good literature concerned with either India or children.
MONTREAL (Canadian Press) -- Francis Glorieux, a Montreal texitle manufacturer, has been in Canada for 14 years, but he remains a Frenchman.

CAIRO, July 24 -- In Rome it was the ides of March that Caesar was warned about. In the Arab world they say it is during the dog days of summer, especially the burning heat of July and August that rulers must be most on guard.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 24 -- Charles Slicklen of North Hempstead earned a second shot at the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship today by defeating James Bostwick of Piping Rock 1 up, in the semi-finals at the Nassau Country Club.

Last week's flow of second-quarter earnings reports from metal producers reflected the booming demand for steel, aluminum and copper. In almost every instance, the major producers reported sharp increases in sales and earnings.
SUMMER is an ideal time to hybridize African violets. Although working with house plants at this outdoor garden season may lack appeal, hybrid crosses made now will produce seed pods for winter.

" If you people would take the lead in these matters; if you took the initiative in trying to make automobiles safer for the millions of people who buy and drive them, there would be no need for hearings like this."
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Dr. and Mrs. Murray Tuckerman and their four children left their home in suburban Whitemarsh village this week for a year of European touring.

It seems it was only yesterday, and, in fact, it was as recently as last year that the Metropolitan Opera Ballet lived its life solely in the "Aidas," "Traviatas," "Fledermauses," etc., of the opera repertory. During the past winter season, the dance ensemble began to emerge from operatic confinement and to move toward a more independent existence.

ONE hundred and fifty years after his death in 1814, at the age of 74, it is perhaps ample time for the Marquis de Sade to be welcomed into the public domain. For a world conscious of its own absurdity and the imminence of its possible destruction, the intransigent imaginings of the Marquis de Sade may perhaps be more salutary than shocking.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 24 -- A mining boom of enormous proportions has struck Western Australia.

ITHACA, N.Y. -- There are days when Cayuga Lake lies like a giant peacock tail folded down between the hills, or, again, its sulky green surface may be dappled with purple shadows. Diverse as the moods of the lake are the pleasures awaiting a visitor to Ithaca and this section of the Finger Lakes country.

ELY, Minn., July 24 -- Residents of this northwest community took advantage today of the presence of Lynda Bird Johnson and Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman to protest his policies on the Boundary Waters Canoe Area.
" It was a pretty bad week." "Blame it on investors' uneasiness over Vietnam. They are waiting until they learn what the Government plans to do in Southeast Asia."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- California is setting out on a social experiment that Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg, the new United States representative at the United Nations, says deserves to be emulated throughout the country.
MOUNT KISCO, N.H., July 24 -- A drive to rid stores of pornography and a drive to prevent censorship will collide head-on here Monday.

NAMALU, Uganda, July 24 -- The proud savages of Karamoja, caught between an advancing tide of disease on one side and of civilization on the other, stand uneasily at the end of the lonely nomadic trail they have followed for ages.

One day 13 months ago at Shea Stadium, Jim Bunning was absolutely perfect: He pitched the only perfect game (27 men up, 27 down) the National League has had in 85 years. Yesterday on the same mound he was not perfect, but still absolutely too good for the New York Mets.

WHAT I have chosen to call (for lack of a better term) the "gothica" -- the highly feminine suspense-romance of the du Maurier-Holt-Stewart school -- is proliferating these days very nearly as rapidly as the spy novel; and I'm not sure that this department can (or indeed should) keep up with all the new publications, particularly the paperback originals.

NO one dispute that Pal Benko of New York is the most active grand master in the United States. Perhaps, too, he is busier all year round than any chess player on the globe. His latest success is the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club.
KINGSPORT, Tenn., July 24 -- Kingsport Press, Inc., one of the nation's large book producers, reports that its employment has passed the 2,000 mark and its expansion programs are "on schedule."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI) -- C.V. Whitney's Port Wine raced to his fourth straight and richest victory of his career today when he captured the $156,500 Hollywood Juvenile Championship for 2-year-olds by a length under the careful guidance of Willie Shoemaker.
IN his review of my book, "Challenge for the Pacific" (June 27), John Toland paid me some compliments, for which I thank him. He also raised some objections which need to be answered.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia tonight decided to further devalue the dinar. The new full rate, starting Monday, will be 1,250 dinars to the United States dollar instead of the former rate of 750.
A Federal grant to help the city prepare a comprehensive plan to develop outdoor recreation areas is expected to be announced tomorrow.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 24 -- Carnegie Grant, long in tooth, his sun-scorched skin peeling off his face like cellophane, shaded watery - blue eyes and said: "You can't make a fool of the Old Course, and since I've been a little boy I've seen them try."
Apparel retailers, utilizing promotions of summer merchandise and whatever early fall deliveries they can muster, have been continuing to register gains in volume.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 24 (AP) -- The Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan sat in the back seat of an expensive automobile, parked in a North Carolina cow pasture, and predicted:

Christian Science Monitor: A nation which has shown its readiness to do all that needs doing in Vietnam is not a nation whose resistance-readiness elsewhere either Moscow or Peking is likely to underestimate. Indeed, if they are shrewd -- and there is every rason to believe that they are -- the men in Moscow and Peking will realize that America's involvement in Vietnam will make the latter all the readier to quash any threat elsewhere.
LISBON, July 24 -- Portugal's National Electoral College will assemble tomorrow to reelect Rear Admiral Americo Deus Rodrigues Tomas President of the republic.

THE 1965 Kodak TeenAge Movie Contest is announced by the Eastman Kodak Company. Any 8mm or 16mm film, of any length and on any subject, can be entered, and films may be the work of individuals or groups.

CLEVELAND, July 24 -- Sam McDowell, the Cleveland Indians' young left-handed pitcher, is said to be headed for great things in baseball. No one in the crowd of 48,777 at Municipal Stadium could dispute that tonight as the 22-year-old blanked the New York Yankees, 3-0, on five hits.

BALTIMORE, July 24 -- Boog Powell's leadoff homer in the eighth inning broke a 1-1 tie tonight and the Baltimore Orioles went on to a 3-1 victory over the American League-leading Minnesota Twins.

It is devoted to the World War II memorials that were given over to the busy chisels of sculptors blessed by the society, and it is an altogether appalling document.

The New York Times is to be commended for its July 18 editorial entitled "Better Day for the Migrant," which looks ahead to the time when the nation's migratory, farm laborer will enjoy the benefits and protections now extended to other American workers.

LONDON -- A kaleidoscopic festival, bringing to Great Britain the widely contrasting arts of the entire British Commonwealth, from symphonic orchestras to steel bands and from modern and classic ballet to Tanzanian stilt dancers, is to be launched here and in three other British cities on Sept. 16. It continues through Oct. 2.

BOGALUSA, La., July 24 (UPI) -- Mayor Jesse Cutrer quickly accepted today a request by Negro leaders for negotiations aimed at solving some of this city's chronic racial problems.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 25 -- A Congressional subcommittee was exposed for six hours today to what one of their guides called "the horrors of the Hudson." Oil slicks, dead fish, garbage, detergent bubbles, beer cans and other debris rode the majestic bosom of the river as seven members of the National Parks and Recreation Subcommittee of the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs boarded the power cruiser Firefly here this morning.

OTTAWA, July 23 -- John C. Doyle, a silky-mannered mining promoter, said today he had fled to Canada so he could continue his legal fight, rather than begin a United States jail sentence on July 15.
Corporate underwriting activity will be more active this week than it was last week.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 -- Governor Rockefeller removed himself today from consideration for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 -- Charles Pasarell completed his one-man conquest of the Australian Davis Cup team today and stands as the new hope of American tennis.

KAPCHORWA, Uganda, July 25 -- In the foothills of Mount Elgon, thickly clad with deep-green coffee trees and drooping fronds of banana and plantain palms, the women make a gay picture at dusk as they stride along paths, water jugs balanced atop their heads, in bright ankle-length gowns of saffron and magenta.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 -- George Sustendal, sailing Philip Dollin's maroon sloop, Mabel, out of Sea Cliff (L.I.) Y.C., won the annual crew race of the International Class on Long Island Sound today.

After many years of neglect, suddenly the Hudson River Valley has become the object of much solicitude. The protracted controversy over the Consolidated Edison Company's plan to build a hydroelectric power plant on Storm King Mountain generated a great deal of interest in the subject. Although conservationists and nature lovers lost that battle before the Federal Power Commission, they succeeded in calling attention to the woeful absence of legal protection for a great national heritage.
Dr. Jesse Williams 2d, accused of homicide in the abortion death of a socially prominent young woman Friday morning, was held without bail yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP) -- Dick Schofield's two-out single in the eighth inning drove in the winning run today as the San Francisco Giants beat Milwaukee, 2-1, for their third straight victory over the Braves.
As some companies have discovered, there are ways to profit from the World's Fair without sponsoring pavilions.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The tempo of President Johnson's review of Vietnam policy slowed today.
ELY, Minn., July 25 (AP) -- Lynda Bird Johnson thinks northern Minnesota is beautiful country, but the flies are worse than in Texas.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright charged today that the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company had called off negotiations to build a synthetic rubber plant for Rumania because of "unusual competitive pressures" and a "nuisance boycott campaign by an extremist political organization."

PATRAS, Greece, July 25 -- Ioannis Coutsocheras, one of Greece's poet-politicians, set out to meet the people today. He met them from morning to night from Athens, which he represents in Parliament, to Patras, 150 miles away, his native area.
President Johnson has restated, in an interview, United States determination to continue its policy on Vietnam.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 25 -- A sharp ideological cleavage was forming in revolutionary ranks today as a rebel leader charged that the extreme left had refused to join the April 24 revolt and had even tried to obstruct it.

The sound of 39,288 voices singing "Happy Birthday, Dear Casey," wafted over Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon. But the guest of honor Charles Dillon Stengel, was in Roosevelt Hospital with a fractured left hip that will require an operation and at least three weeks of hospitalization.

Seven persons were burned in an explosion aboard a 21-foot cabin cruiser at Vidal's dock, 521 City Island Avenue, City Island, the Bronx, at 4:50 P.M. yesterday. Patrolman William Cockburn of the 45th Precinct said the explosion occurred as the boat, named Chippy, was starting up after loading fuel.

Aggressive and radical political groups -- even those considered "anarchic" by the public -- must be brought into the contemporary political process if the so-called Great Society is to bring about moral as well as economic gains, according to a leading Protestant.

HARTFORD, July 25 -- Bill Casper, a golfer who follows a special diet, won the $70,000 Insurance City open today after a one-hole, sudden-death playoff. Casper beat Johnny Pott at the Wethersfield Country Club with a 20-foot berdie putt after both had tied at 274 for 72 holes.
The Transport Workers Union has drawn up demands for a new two-year contract that would add more than $100 million to the cost of running the city's transit system.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 25 -- A head warder in a South African prison has complained officially to his superiors about brutality and corruption.
Heat and humidity produced a combination over the weekend that was capable of making most New Yorkers distinctly uncomfortable.

Submarine research, rescue and engineering vehicles that can creep along the Continental Shelf or plungeto the bottom of the deepest canyons in the ocean are now in operation or are being constructed by at least five nations.

The jet engine that will power the advanced F-111 movable-wing tactical fighter being developed for the Air Force and the Navy has completed its official ground endurance tests, the manufacturer, Pratt Whitney Aircraft, announced yesterday.
The Transport Workers Union has drawn up demands for a new two-year contract that would add more than $100 million to the cost of running the city's transit system.

Leading observers of the mortgage market expect the trend of interest rates and term on conventional type mortgages for homes to remain steady over the near term, despite the slowdown in the increase savings deposits.

SEATTLE, July 25 (AP) -- Civil Rights workers, calling themselves "Freedom Patrols," followed policemen on the streets here today in a surveillance demonstration stemming from the slaying of a Negro by an off-duty officer.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 25 -- The Baroque Comedy Workshop is one of the instruments for serving both the second Stanford Summer Festival and the interests of the university's curriculum. For the workshop contributes to the theme of this year's festival -- the Mozart era -- and provides Stanford's drama department with a good reason for tackling 18th-century comedy.
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- Grass skirts are out at 24 Sussex Drive unless Prime Minister Lester Pearson has a change of heart.

RYE, N.Y., July 25 -- Craig Harmon of Wykagyl won the 46th Westchester amateur golf championship today by defeating Doug Ford Jr. of Knoll-wood, 5 and 4, in the scheduled 36-hole final at the Apawamis Club.
WINNETKA, Ill., July 25 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. tonight carried his campaign in the North to all-white suburbia.
PARIS, July 25 -- There are no state-run sobering-up stations in France, only some private ones run by anti-alcoholism groups.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth of San Antonio, Tex., sank a 20-foot putt for a birdie on the last hole today and won the Buckeye Savings Association golf tournament by a stroke. Miss Whitworth overtook Susie Maxwell of Oklahoma City who had a four-stroke lead going into the last round.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI) -- Jim Lefebvre and Jeff Torborg drove in two men each in a five-run fifth inning today as the Los Angeles Dodgers snapped a four-game. losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

MADRID, July 26 -- Spain issued a new postage stamp today depicting the columned courtyard of the historic Toledo synagogue. This was looked upon as a new step by the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco toward greater religious freedom and tolerance.
Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Miss Barbara Joan Cavanagh were married yesterday in a simple single-ring ceremony by Cardinal Spellman in his private chapel.

Despite the fact that he had to take up to avoid contact with a rival on the stretch turn, the Wheatley Stable's Queen Empress registered a decisive victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Bold Ruler had a three-length margin over Jacques Wimpfheimer's Petite Rouge, who had one length on the Templeton Stable's Ballet Rose in the six-furlong sprint.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 26 -Dr. Roger W. Heyns, vice president for academic affairs at the University of Michigan, was named chancellor of the Berkeley campus of the University of California today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 26 -- Charles T. Matthews, an assistant district attorney who bolted the Republican party to run for Suffolk County prosecutor on the Democratic ticket, resigned from his $9,500 part-time position today.

The Continental Insurance Companies reported yesterday an adjusted operating income in the first half of 1965 of $22.2 million, or $1.77 a share, compared with $9.7 million, or 77 cents a share, in the first half of 1964.

It might be mid-December as far as the Metropolitan Opera House is concerned. Its rehearsal studios, normally silent at this time of the year, are resounding with the voices of the 32 young singers in the Met's new national company.

Two young children -- a brother and sister -- were struck by bullets from a sniper's gun yesterday afternoon as they played in a Bronx playground a few feet from where their mother was sitting. The girl was injured seriously, the boy slightly.
MIAMI, July 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba announced today a sweeping purge of what he described as "small bourgeois" elements in his administration.
Prices drifted down in slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

MEXICO CITY, July 26 -- Eighteen high school boys and girls from Scarsdale, N.Y., and other places in the United States prepared today to start a belated Mexican vacation after a month of helping an isolated community of 120 fellow Jews.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate confirmed today the appointment of James P. Coleman, former Governor of Mississippi, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The vote was 76 to 8.

The American Express Company has leased space for two new travel information and reservation offices in the midtown area and has sublet the five-story building at 647 Fifth Avenue that the company has occupied since 1973.
LONDON, July 26 -- The sensitive London commodity markets are beginning to feel the effects of the war in Vietnam.
Ten soft-spoken, superpolite youngsters, who could not always check their impulses to bow to their elders, saw New York yesterday.

The stock market seemed anxious to please everybody yesterday. Some popular averages finished higher than the session before and some finished lower. Volume of 3.79 million shares was nothing to get excited about, but compared with recent turnover thinness, it was nothing to sneeze at, either.

BALTIMORE, July 26 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People protested today the appointment of James Murray as director of a panel recruiting people to administer the multimillion-dollar medicare program expected to pass Congress soon.

ATLANTA, July 26 -- Two national civil rights organizations vowed today a "massive united invasion upon segregation" in Americus, Ga., unless Sumter County officials meet five Negro demands within 24 hours.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday a new high in first-half earnings.
Some leading commodity-futures prices pushed ahead yesterday, in the squalls of worry about the darkening Vietnam situation Copper, wool and soybeans were among the strong risers.

TOKYO, July 26 -- Japan's eight principal shipping companies have signed an agreement with the Japanese seamen's union that union crews will not sail to North Vietnam or handle military cargoes for South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -The F.B.I. report ranked New York 42d among 184 metropolitan areas surveyed in per capita crime.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 -- Tennessee Williams cannot get "The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore" out of his system. Undaunted by its two failures on Broadway, he keeps struggling with it, as its chief character, Flora Goforth, fights against oblivion.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- The crew from American Yacht Club at Rye, N.Y., captained by 17-year-old Beth Learson, was the top qualifier for the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship today in the three-race elimination series held by the Riverside Y.C. Miss Learson scored 43 points in heading the 16 contenders for the Founders' Trophy.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) -- Bill White hit a two-run homer and Dick Groat a two-run double today as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 7-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

PARIS, July 26 (Reuters) -Britain can expect success in her efforts to reduce her international payments deficit, but the goal of establishing payments equilibrium by the end of next year is a difficult one, according to a survey published today.

The validity of the F.B.I.'s figures was disputed by Dr. Sophia M. Robison, professor emeritus of the Columbia University School of Social Work. Dr. Robison, who is recognized as one of the leading experts in the nation on crime statistics, said:

GREENSBORO, Ala., July 26 (UPI) -- Four hundred civil rights demonstrators were turned back by policemen using tear gas today. Shortly afterward they took up an all-night vigil outside a Negro church.

FAIRFIELD, Conn, July 26 -- The New York Giants signed their head football coach, Allie Sherman, today for a decade of future service. Sherman, who is 42 years old, was given a 10-year contract by Wellington Mara, the team's acting president.
WEST BABYLON, L.I., July 26 -- A fleet of 250 yachts opened the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week today.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner began their married life yesterday with a special blessing from Pope Paul VI, the congratulations of Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, and a number of small gifts with special religious significance.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that progressive Republicans should step up efforts to generate enthusiasm for their ideology and that this activity "will produce the man to run for President in 1968."

It was already close to standing room only when the big, blue Chevrolet truck carrying the portable stage and sets for the premiere of the 1965 Theater in the Street season rolled to a halt last evening at Tompkins Park, in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 26 -- James F. (Pud) Galvin, whose son said, "he was lucky to earn $300 a year in his best baseball season," became the 102d former major league peronality to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- In the first three weeks of operation, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has received a number of complaints and inquiries about sex discrimination.
The program presented in the French-American Festival at Philharmonic Hall last night provided a heartening display of the expressive power of American music when it is at its best.

Your July 6 editorial praising the revival by the City Planning Commission of its original plan for a Cross-Brooklyn Expressway, following the line of the Bay Ridge division of the Long Island Rail Road -- as an alternative to a Moses proposal for a new connection with the Nassau highways that would pour traffic into the East Midtown Tunnel -- brings to mind a sequence of events that deserves an historical footnote.
The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its profits in the quarter ended June 30 were the highest for any second quarter in the company's history.
BRUSSELS, July 26 -- Prospects that the Common Market crisis will be resolved before October, which were never great, virtually vanished tonight.
" On a Clear Day You Can See Forever" went into rehearsal yesterday at the Mark Hellinger Theater, with the premiere scheduled for Oct. 16.
WHITE PLAINS, July 26 -- A program for giving $1.1 million in surplus Government food to needy residents of Westchester each year was adopted unanimously today by the Board of Supervisors.

If in his letter of July 18 Prof. Emeritus Overton H. Taylor's description of "extreme, hysterical and wholesale opposition to the Johnson Administration's foreign policy" is intended as a characterization of the scholar-participants in the historic Washington teach-in, I must say that he has been tuned in to a rather extraordinary wavelength.
Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx County Democratic leader, threw his support yesterday to the mayoral candidacy of Controller Abraham D. Beame.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -The Treasury-bill rate declined substantially at today's auction compared with a week ago, the Treasury disclosed tonight. It was the second consecutive week of sizable decline.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 -Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon shattered today an effort to obtain bipartisan support for Administration policy in Vietnam at the annual Governors Conference.
GRANVILLE HICKS has written his autobiography, in part, for his own posterity. All may profit from his candid and unadorned cautionary tale.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation's annual report on crime said today that crime rates were soaring in America's suburbs and among its young people.

VILNA, Lithuania, July 26 -Historic sites visited on a Sunday outing in the vicinity of this Lithuanian capital provided a stark reminder of the recent past as well as of the distant past of the disputed region.
Genesco, Inc., the widely diversified apparel and retailing complex, announced yesterday the election of Erwin L. Klineman and Alexander Lerner as members of its board of governors.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that American Motors Corporation of Detroit had granted illegal price discounts to four companies selling its electric appliances under "Kelvinator" and "Leonard" brand names.

Senator Jacob K. Javits has filed in the United States Senate a proposal substantially identical to the well-known "Dirksen Amendment," which would alter the Constitution to permit states with bicameral legislatures to organize one house upon the basis of geography rather than equality of population.
Steel production in the United States fell 1.4 per cent last week to the lowest weekly level of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, July 26 -- It is a traditional Chinese belief that the best way to protect a nest egg is to convert it into gold. Communist China has been doing just this with a heavy series of purchases on the London gold market over the last few months.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 26 -Palmer D. Farrington, former Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, was indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury on three counts of bribery.

Philip Morris, Inc., had the highest revenues and earnings for any quarter in its history in the three months ended June 30 and record results for the half-year, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president of the major tobacco and diversified company, reported yesterday.

Directors of listed companies on the New York Stock Exchange face an unusually crowded calendar this week. More than 85 concerns are scheduled to hold dividend meeting, and Wall Street observers hope, the board rooms will produce as rich a harvest of increases as was sheafed in the first six months of this year.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 26 (AP) -- The defending champion, Carol Sorenson, rallied after taking a bogey on the first hole and shot a one-under-par 71 today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the women's Trans-Mississippi amateur golf tournament.

Earnings of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc.; and its three subsidiaries advanced in the first half of 1965, compared with the year-ago period. Sales of the parent company and one of the subsidiaries declined, while those of the other subsidiaries advanced.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., July 26 -- Joe Purcell, the former merchant marine captain, who retreated to this quiet Delaware River village 10 years ago and opened a bait and tackle shop, which he named "Snug Harbor," is one angler who can look at crabgrass and see roses.
A big cardboard box full of jewelry, part of the return from an empire built by Helena Rubinstein on cold cream and dreams, will be auctioned in mid-October.

NEW ORLEANS, July 26 -A Federal judge watched in anger today as the Justice Department presented motion picture evidence that Bogalusa, La., policemen had ignored his injunction to protect civil rights demonstrators.
Anthony J. Casella received a police shield yesterday from Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick and became the first trainee to advance to probationary patrolman under a new program.
MARSHALL GREEN, who presented his credentials as Ambassador to President Sukarno of Indonesia yesterday, is a 20-year man in the Foreign Service with extensive experience in Far Eastern affairs.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- President Johnson today nominated Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, to a Federal judgeship.
Justice J. Irwin Shapiro of the Queens Supreme Court yesterday dismissed an indictment against a man once convicted of murder, thus freeing him.

A Federal judge imposed fines totaling $150,000 yesterday on four major manufacturers of steel forgings and a steel trade association after allowing them to change their pleas from not guilty to no contest on price-fixing charges.

S.G. Warburg Co., Ltd., the London merchant bank with roots in international finance that date back to 1798, has established a subsidiary in New York. The new affiliate, S.G. Warburg Co., Inc., will provide financial advice and assistance to American companies doing business in Europe and European companies active in the United States.

The Pennsylvania Railroad is further diversifying its activities through the 51 per cent acquisition of stock in the Arvida Corporation, a Florida real estate developer. The transaction involves about $18.3 million.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 26 -- Frank Cardi dropped a 15-foot birdie putt on the home hole today for a 34, 33-67 to tie Jim Turnesa for the first-round lead in the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Rockaway Hunting Club.
LONDON, July 26 -- In three to four years, the Abbey in Abbey 2870, a London telephone number, will be replaced by 222.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Representative William B. Windall, Republican of New Jersey, criticized today what he called the avalanche of accounts of the inner workings of the Kennedy Administration.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Senate passed a bill tonight providing for the withholding of funds from communities that refuse to act to end racial imbalance. Additional money will be given to communities that act to end racial imbalance.
Directors of the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized the issuance yesterday of $100 million of 35-year debentures.

The Welfare Department's running dispute with its employes over added summer work took on new urgency yesterday when four social workers were suspended. They were accused of having refused to do the work assigned to them.
At least the petroleum part of a proposed American built petrochemical complex in Rumania is moving ahead as planned.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The United States Information Agency has canceled a public-opinion survey in Pakistan following an objection by the Pakistani Government, a U.S.I.A. spokesman said today.
FREEPORT, L.I., July 26 -Cigar smoke curled skyward and fresh breezes blew mosquitoes across the ring tonight as boxing moved outdoors on the South Shore for the first time in 10 years.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- S. Hurok, the American impresario, completed negotiations today to present the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra and the Bolshoi Ballet in New York next season. The ballet has visited the United States before, but this will be the Philharmonic's first appearance.

A five-member advisory committee for the Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation and Physically Handicapped was named yesterday by State Senator Harry Kraf, Bronx Democrat and chairman of the legislative group.

A contingent of young New Yorkers traveled to Edgartown, Mass., over the weekend to help with Thursday's annual luncheon and fashion show benefitting the Boys Club of Edgartown. It will take place in the Harborside
LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- Britain and Ireland will study the possibilities of concluding a free trade agreement, it was announced tonight.

Six Puerto Rican women, recipients of welfare funds, listened patiently in a spotless office in a storefront on the Lower East Side, as a staff member of Mobilization for Youth read to them from a budget suggested by the Welfare Department.

The nation's luggage and leather goods industry -- encouraged by the excise-tax repeal and enthused over consumer reaction to its fashion merchandising approach -- expects a sales increase this year of at least 7 per cent.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of J. Edmund Bull, Bernard F. Ginnity and William T. Loveland as vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- The Senate passed today and sent to the House a compromise Omnibus Housing bill including a program of rent subsidies for low-income families.

Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that the Rev. Theodore E. McCarrick, a priest of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, had been appointed president of the Catholic University of Puerto Rico.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 26 -- Senator George A. Smathers today attacked critics in both parties who have opposed President Johnson's Vietnam policy.

Two love poems by Ernest Hemingway are published in the August issue of Atlantic Monthly, now on the newsstands. He wrote them to Mary Welsh in 1944, two years before they wore married. At that time they were both war correspondents in Europe.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 -Virtually all the harried politicians who serve as governors of American states like the idea of the so-called Heller Plan, but many have different ideas of what it is or ought to be.

DETROIT, July 26 -- The qualities that distinguish life in the city are being so widely dispersed that the nation's municipalities are losing their identities, the elected officials of many of them were told today.
James Talcott, Inc., commercial financing and factoring concern, announced yesterday the election of Kenneth B. Wackman as president.
BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP) -- Home runs by Don Mincher and Harmon Killebrew led the American League-leading Minnesota Twins to an 8-2 victory tonight over the Baltimore Orioles.
TRIEUTHANH, South Vietnam, July 19 -- In this part of the world, Maj. Samuel Shalala has been dubbed "the unusual American" by his superiors.

MIAMI, July 26 (AP) -- A banker's widow and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers, pleaded not guilty today to first degree murder charges in the bludgeoning and stabbing of the banker, Jacques Mossler, 69 years old, of Texas.
The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company reported a 23 per cent increase in half-year earnings on a sales gain of 7 per cent, the company announced yesterday.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 26 -- Peter Snell, the winner of three Olympic gold medals, the holder of two (formerly four) world records and one of history's most successful middle-distance runners, retired today from competition.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A chill wind is tugging at one of the concepts of the New Economists -- that consumers invariably will spend most of the additional income which accrues to them through tax reduction. This was the theory on which the Administration decided to pile abolition of certain excise taxes atop the easement of the income tax for individuals in the middle earnings brackets.

Nothing is final in politics, of course, but Nelson A. Rockefeller has conclusively taken himself out of consideration for the Presidency in 1968. In a television preamble to the annual Governors Conference at Minneapolis he even went beyond 1968, saying he was out of contention for the White House "forevermore."

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels scored four runs in an eighth-inning rally started by Lou Clinton's triple and went on to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 6-2, tonight behind the six-hit pitching of George Brunet.

PARIS, July 26 -- Britain's proposal for treaty against further dissemination of nuclear weapons was reported to have been sharply questioned at a meeting today of the Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

While the proposal of Transit Commissioner Gilhooley to combine in a single agency all the various instrumentalities now concerned with transportation in New York City is a forward-looking suggestion, in my opinion it does not go far enough.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, July 26 (Reuters) -- President Alphonse Massamba-Debat of the former French Congo announced tonight the arrest of 18 members of a commando group that he said had landed here on a mission of sabotage and murder.
Wes Westrum sat in a swivel chair yesterday, behind a black name plate that read "Casey Stengel," and announced his first decision as interim manager of the New York Mets.
HOUSTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Joe Torre paced Millwaukee's attack against Bob Bruce of Houston and Wade Blasingame shut out the Astros on five hits tonight as the Braves scored a 6-0 victory.
The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation has announced the election of Linn B. Bowman as president. Formerly operations vice president, Mr. Bowman succeeds Ernest J. Howe, who has retired.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., a large supermarket chain, increased its net income in the 52 weeks ended May 1 by 20.3 per cent above the preceding year, despite a setback in the first fiscal quarter, when a strike closed down stores in the Baltimore area from April 17 to July 19, 1964.

ALBANY, July 26 -- Parochial school pupils will be permitted to attend special public school classes financed entirely by the Federal Government, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, ruled today.
MOSCOW, July 26 -- A delegation of American Orthodox rabbis has received assurances from Soviet Jewish leaders that three specific grievances of the Jewish community here are being redressed.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's Brooklyn tournament that ended on Sunday night provided two surprises. The first came when the Open Team championship was captured by one of the youngest teams ever to win such an event in New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 -- The Security Council declared today that human rights were being violated in the Dominican Republic and that the cease fire it called for in May was broken on July 16 and 21.
The Police Department angrily denied yesterday that it had been lax in enforcing revocation orders of the State Motor Vehicle Department against uninsured motorists.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman arrived here today for a private visit and for talks with President Tito.

Mayor Wagner's plan to rename First Avenue for Adlai E. Stevenson was criticized yesterday by a Republican Councilman at Large as "ill-advised, impractical, improper and against the best interests of our people."
The Federal Government granted $100,000 to New York City yesterday to help it develop a master plan for recreation. The city will add $75,000 to that amount.
The National Foreign Trade Council predicted yesterday the United States deficit in international payments would drop to $800 million for 1965, the lowest level in eight years.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 26 -- Between the National and American Leagues, there will be 880 jobs available in professional football this season, good jobs paying at least $7,500 each. About 1,500 athletes are vying for such employment and it is a dog-eat-dog kind of competition for rookies and seasoned players alike.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, getting a pair of two-run homers off Jim Maloney, increased their National League lead to two games over second-place Cincinnati tonight by beating the Reds, 5-4.
PRAGUE, July 22 -- A recently published survey of what Czechoslovaks like to buy abroad listed shoes. It was one more sign that something had gone wrong with their country's economy.
Five visiting Japanese Christian leaders urged the United States yesterday to pave the way for negotiations on Vietnam by stopping air attacks in that country and halting "direct intervention."

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Three healthaid bills won Senate approval by voice votes today and were sent to the House. The measures represent a compromise between differing versions passed previously by the Senate and House.

WASHINGTON, July 26 --Arthur J. Goldberg was sworn in today as United States representative at the United Nations by one of his fellow justices from the Supreme Court, which he is leaving reluctantly.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -The median wage increase obtained by workers in major labor settlements in the first half of 1965 appears to have outstripped the Government's guideposts for noninflationary agreements.
BANGALORE, India, July 26 -- The motto of the Congress party conference that ended here yesterday should probably have been: "People who meet in glass houses should not throw stones."

Eastern Air Lines applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for permission to fly direct from major cities in northeastern United States to Hawaii and to cities in the South Pacific and Southeast Asia through its Mexico City route.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 26 -- While Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd has been methodically constructing the South African system of racial separation, his eldest daughter, Anna, has been working among Africans as a missionary for the Dutch Reformed Church.
NEWARK, July 26 (AP) -About 75 teamsters today picketed the Twentieth Century Taxicab Association, Newark's largest cab company, in an attempt to organize its drivers.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King led a march on City Hall today to challenge "those who now wallow in the mire of petty politics."

A United States track team of 35 men and 21 women left last night to oppose the Soviet Union team on Saturday and Sunday. No one would predict the anticipated victory, but there was universal optimism.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -President Johnson established today a 19-member national crime commission to study all aspects of crime and the administration of justice.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -President Johnson is nearing the point of decision in his review of United States policy in Vietnam, a White House source said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 -- The Vietcong continued their harassment of the Saigon area today. Six minor actions within 25 miles of the South Vietnamese capital were reported.
NEW SHREWSBURY, N.J., July 26 -- "We're treated like adults, that's the key thing."
Expectation of further deflationary measures by the government caused prices to retreat along a broad front on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
Alum was thrown into dwindling Croton Reservoir yesterday in hopes it would clear the drinking water for New Yorkers whose faucets have been running brown.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -The Administration rolled up a surprising 77-vote margin today in winning a crucial preliminary skirmish in its fight to repeal state "right to work" laws.

" Before the Revolution," the Italian film that opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, was reviewed in The New York Times by Eugene Archer when it was shown at the second New York Film Festival last September.
The Canadian dollar scored its best gain in several weeks yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz yesterday officially stepped into a maritime strike that has paralyzed eight of the nation's major subsidized steamship companies.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 26 -- Mayor J. Edward Fox moved tonight to rally the citizenry to rid local stores and stands of what he called pornography.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Following are the remarks by President Johnson at the swearing-in of Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court as United States representative at the United Nations. Mr. Goldberg's reply to Mr. Goldberq's reply to Mr. Johnson and his letter to members of the Supreme Court:

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 -The Governors of New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania formed a Mid-Atlantic Governors Conference today to coordinate their efforts on water conservation and other problems.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia, seeded first and second, respectively, were seemingly unperturbed by their surprising losses to Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico in the Pennsylvania championships in sweeping through first-round opponents with ease today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.
DETROIT, July 26 (AP) -Changeover shutdowns cut into domestic car production last week as the nation's manufacturers prepared for conversion to 1966 models.

A few hours before his wedding yesterday, Mayor Wagner quietly disposed of some old political business: he appointed and swore in Daniel S. Weiss, a former City Councilman, as a $25,000-a-year judge of the Criminal Court.
LONDON, July 26 -- Two public-opinion polls showed Reginald Maudling tonight as the popular favorite for the Conservative party leadership.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 16 -- President Sukarno today accepted the credentials of Marshall Green the new United States Ambassador, read him a short speech denouncing American policy in Vietnam and then allowed a demonstration in which Mr. Green was asked to "go home."

The American Express Company said yesterday that it earned $7,346,000, or $1.65 a share, in the first six months of this year. In the period last year, the company netted $6,524,000, or $1.46 a share.
Wes Westrum, the 42-year-old pitching coach of the New York Mets, was named interim manager of the team yesterday by Casey Stengel, who will undergo surgery this morning for a fractured left hip.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 26 -The Suffolk Board of Supervisors today asked the Federal Aviation Agency to consider two eastern Long Island airports as possible sites for a major jetport.
President Johnson's proposed legislation to eliminate most billboards from the nation's major highways is likely to run into a roadblock in Congress, at least in this session.

PARIS, July 26 -- Publicity was once the naughtiest word of all in the 25 or more French haute couture houses. As the Paris fall collections started today, it was clear that the couture's old collective phobia for secrecy is disappearing.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 26 -- The cost of living in Indonesia, which has soared to record heights over the last four and a half years, is now winging upward once more.

It isn't often in the women's fashion industry that an act of deliberate confusion is undertaken. In Seventh Avenue's wild rush to clothe millions of women, the confusion that keeps garment makers' pulses racing and blood pressure rising is a fact of life.
Earnings in the second quarter and the first half of this year were the highest in the 39-year history of United Air Lines.

" I HAVE only a tiny apartment in Forest Hills," Jean Tolan said, explaining why she had gathered 50 television producers, directors, actors and advertising executives at Candlewood Lake for a party Saturday.

James D. Finley has been elected chairman of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., one of the textile industry's largest diversified companies. He succeeds Wilbert J. Carter, 62, who has asked for early retirement, for reasons of health.
James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, has given his preliminary approval to the Community National Bank and Trust Company of Richmond to begin operations.
THE head decorator at Abraham Straus, Gerda Clark, tries to straighten out decorating terminology for the store's shoppers in six model rooms that go on display today.
THE head decorator at Abraham Straus, Gerda Clark, tries to straighten out decorating terminology for the store's shoppers in six model rooms that go on display today.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 26 (UPI) -- Mario Savio, who was sentenced to jail today, was one of 773 persons arrested in the Berkeley administration building last December. He was convicted of trespassing and resisting arrest.

Persons prominent in politics and in New York social circles filled the narrow chapel in Cardinal Spellman's residence yesterday for the wedding of Mayor Wagner and Miss Barbara Cavanagh. Later they joined other guests in the Cosmopolitan Club ballroom for the wedding reception.

" Sean O'Casey: The Man I Knew," by Gabriel Fallon, will be published by Little, Brown on Aug. 10. This biography of the Irish author and playwright is by a man who was a friend of O'Casey when he was writing his plays and associating with William Butler Yeats, Lady Gregory, George Bernard Shaw and Barry Fitzgerald.

Pity the poor United States Ambassador in countries like Indonesia. Marshall Green, fresh out of Washington and drinking champagne toasts with President Sukarno, was at the same time being greeted with signs reading, "Go home, Green," and shouts and jeers from several thousand youths. Even as Mr. Green was handing in his credentials, Mr. Sukarno was lecturing him on what he considered wrong with American policies toward Vietnam and Malaysia.

LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) -- England, needing 191 runs in four hours for victory, was forced to struggle for a draw today in a tense finish against South Africa in the first of three cricket tests at Lords. The final score was South Africa 280 and 248 runs; England 338 and 145 for seven.
WARSAW, July 27 -- Poland's chief economic planner proclaimed today that customer demand and industry profit must henceforth guide the country's economy.
