Negotiations between the central bank of Uruguay and a number of commercial banks here on the recasting of an estimated $50 million of debt owed to the banks are expected to be reopened soon, possibly as early as next week.
A sweeping realignment on the top executive level of the Peabody Coal Company was announced yesterday, along with a six-month earnings report that showed sharp gains over 1964 levels.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Congress sent to the White House today a complex, multibillion-dollar housing bill.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 27 -- A 26-year old patrolman was knocked to the ground here last night by 10 Negro youths who fled with his night stick and walkie-talkie radio when he fired a warning shot, the police said today.
The Philadelphia School District, which covers the entire city, sold $28 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank and Drexel Co.
NEW ORLEANS, July 27 -- Two civil rights workers testified in Federal Court here today that they were recently arrested in Bogalusa, La., after being struck by whites during racial demonstrations.
The New York Jets will expose Joe Namath, their expensive quarterback, to a bunch of eager-beaver rookies of the Boston Patriots tonight in a high school stadium at Lowell, Mass.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- The New York Mets gave it the old college try today after learning that Casey Stengel had pulled through his hip operation all right, and almost won one for the old man.
The successful public offering yesterday of $150 million worth of 4 7/8 per cent sinking fund debentures focused Wall Street interest on Montgomery Ward Co., Inc.
TOKYO, July 27 (Comtelburo) -- The Government's Economic Policy Council decided today on a new series of measures to stimulate the economy and rehabilitate depressed business.

TRENTON, July 27 (AP) -- A member of the State Water Policy and Supply Council disputed today an assertion by State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., the Republican gubernatorial candidate, that there was undue delay in reaching decisions on new reservoirs at Round Valley and Spruce Run.

DETROIT, July 27 -- The beginning of a major national research effort to define and find solutions for the mounting human and technological problems of the nation's cities was announced here today. Vice President Humphrey said it would employ the techniques of "space and defense research."

ATHENS -- Classical Greek tragedy, as written by Sophocles and analyzed by Aristotle, requires certain elements and characters to produce the essential conflict on which it is inevitably based. All these elements and characters are represented in the classical Greek tragedy now being played in Athens's broiling streets.
BRUSSELS, July 27 -- Belgium's longest government crisis since World War II ended tonight.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 27 -- Some 200 residents of this Westchester County community met here tonight to protest plans to build a branch of the State University on an old estate here.

TOMMY JACOBS maintains that playing golf on the touring circuit is like going to the office every morning. "It's just like any other job," he says. "Instead of selling automobiles or a house, you turn in a score. Sometimes you make a sale, sometimes you don't. Maybe you are under par, maybe you're not."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- A major shakeup came tonight in the top management of the financially pressed Sperry Rand Corporation a few hours after its management turned back attempts by stockholders to force the retirement of its president.
This may sound like a broken record, but Foote, Cone and Belding, Inc., has come up with another major account.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 27 -- The first actual jail sentence for any of the University of California sit-in demonstrators began this afternoon as a favor to the prisoner.
The Martin-Marietta Corporation, manufacturer of aerospace equipment, announced yesterday the election of Joseph E. Muckley and William B. Bergen as directors.

LEE, Mass., July 27 -- It is Spanish dance time at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and with the Alba-Reyes Ballet Espanol on hand to supply the atmosphere and art, the Ted Shawn Theater will be an especially lively place during the company's week-long engagement here.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Don Mincher's two-run homer lifted the Minnesota Twins to a 9-5 victory over Washington tonight after the Senators took the opener of a double-header, 10-7, with the help of Mike Brumley's first two home runs of the season.
Mayor John J. Burns of Binghamton was elected by acclamation yesterday as Democratic State Chairman to succeed William H. McKeon.

Casey Stengel underwent what his doctor called a "perfectly successful" operation on his broken left hip at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday and the New York Mets' manager, who will be 75 years old Friday, was expected to be on his feet by next week.

More than 850 antipoverty organizations in eight of the city's poorest neighborhoods are being invited to send delegates to a series of conventions next month, designed to guarantee a place for local groups in the campaign against poverty.
BRUSSELS, July 27 -- France was reported today to have agreed to widen a bit her limited participation in the European Economic Community.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 27 -- Quintuplets -- four girls and a boy -- were born tonight to the wife of a fish-and-chips shop owner, W.W. Lawson. The infants were said to be resting well in incubators at the National Women's Hospital.
BABYLON, L.I., July 27 -- Calm almost canceled the second day of racing for the 250 skippers competing today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 27 (AP) -- The United States track and field forces got a mixed-up reception in the Soviet Union today, sweating through 2 1/4 hours of red tape. Then, following a formal reception, most of the athletes were flown to this Ukrainian regional capital for their big meet Saturday and Sunday.
The stock market moved up in the morning and went down in the afternoon yesterday, with prices generally closing at their low points of the day.

The surprise appointment of John W. Gardner as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare is another demonstration of President Johnson's newfound ability to look in unconventional places to find the indisputably right man for an important job at the moment that job most needs doing right. In the department's short, twelve-year history, five Secretaries have struggled with indifferent success to transform a collection of bureaucracies into a cohesive unit.

Representative William F. Ryan, one of the four major candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination, completed his ticket yesterday by naming Melvin Dubin, Queens businessman, as his candidate for Controller.
The Military Sea Transportation Service, the ocean transportation arm of the Department of Defense, has been ordered to clamp down in information concerning the movement of its transports.

Allied Chemical Corporation's nitrogen division announced new price schedules yesterday for its industrial-grade ammonium nitrate, representing an across-the-board increase of $2 a ton over last year's schedule.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn allowed only four hits tonight, but suffered his ninth straight defeat as Bob Purkey, backed by four double plays, pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
SAN ANTONIO, July 27 (AP) -- Navy Lieut. Comdr. Alan L. Bean, one of he nation's astronauts, underwent an operation for removal of his gall bladder and appendix today.
MIAMI BEACH, July 27 -- The nation's personal injury lawyers are preparing to bring an increasing number of suits against automobile manufacturers for unsafe design and construction of cars.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen Leslie of St. Petersburg, Fla., a woman boss in a man's business, is the new president of the 175,000-member National Federation of Business and Professional Women.
DALMAHOY, Scotland, July 27 (UPI) -- Ramon Sota and Angel Miguel each fired three-under-par 69's for a 138 today to give Spain the victory in a one-day, 11-nation golf tournament.
HONG KONG, July 27 -- Communist China caustically criticized the Soviet Union today for its stand on the Vietnamese situation.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The expected announcement tomorrow of the President's plans to meet the Vietnamese crisis may involve the call-up of Reservists of all four services.

The Government filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to recover damages from six textile companies accused of trying to fix prices and rig bids in sales of glass fiber fabrics used in the aerospace and missile programs.
A city antipoverty program is enabling men who only six weeks ago were on relief or in low-paying jobs to qualify as drivers of heavy-duty trucks at $132 a week.

AMERICUS, Ga., July 27 -- The United States Justice Department initiated court action today and about 650 Negroes began an all-night demonstration in an attempt to free four Negro women from the Sumter County jail.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 -- The nation's Governors pledged their support today to a cooperative effort to improve the quality of American education.

WESTPORT, Conn. -- "It really is remarkable," Tammy Grimes is reported to have said of The Remarkable Book Shop in Westport, Conn., when she bought a $25 book titled "Birds of Prey" there during her recent stint at the Westport Country Playhouse.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 27 -- Finishing with a 34, 32 -- 66, Gene Borek of Pine Hollow won the Long Island Professional Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship by two strokes with 203 at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The House approved the final version of the Administration's medicare-Social Security bill today by a vote of 307 to 116.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell opened today what he said would be a nationwide investigation of de facto school segregation in the big cities, beginning with Chicago and its Superintendent of Education, Benjamin C. Willis.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz today urged representatives of striking maritime workers and eight shipping lines to intensify efforts to solve their 42-day-old dispute.
Ten Japanese newsboys, all new to the Western World, toured the World's Fair yesterday and viewed its offerings with fresh wonder.
The situation in Vietnam cast an ever-increasing shadow over commodity futures prices yesterday.
HOUSTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves continued to thrive on Houston pitching tonight, slamming 15 hits off three hurlers en route to a 7-1 triumph.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 (AP) -- Jim Gilliam drove in four runs with a homer, double and single, and Maury Wills stole his 70th and 71st bases tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds, 9-7.
OTTAWA, July 27 -- The walkout of letter carriers and postal clerks that has tied up mail services in Canada's largest cities appeared to be ending today.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The Chief Rabbi of Moscow, Yehudi-Leib Levin, said today that Jewish delegations and private tourists from the United States would be welcome in the Soviet Union "if they come in a spirit of peace and unity."

Wall Street analysts, concerned over an information dim-out throughout the business world as a result of a lawsuit involving the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, were told yesterday that corporate officials in general could be expected to become more talkative.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Senate-house conferees on the voting rights bill broke off negotiations today when House members balked at a compromise proposed by the Senators.

The appointment of John W. Gardner as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare moves education into the limelight of a department where, for political reasons, health and welfare have thus far dominated the scene.
Donald McNeill and Mrs. Pauline Betz Addie, former national champions, have been voted into the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame for 1965.

CAIRO, July 27 -- Mustafa Amin, a prominent Cairo newspaper editor who was arrested last week, has confessed that he worked for the United States Central Intelligence Agency, official Egyptian sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States has allowed its two-year-old stand-by borrowing agreement with the International Monetary Fund to lapse and may have to borrow little or nothing from the fund in the future.

WASHINGTON July 27 (AP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge's nomination as Ambassador to South Vietnam was approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today after he gave members a briefing that lasted nearly three hours.

Twelve new members have appointed to the governing committee of the urban redevelopment division of ACTION Council for Better Cities, a nonprofit organization devoted to physical improvement of urban areas.

Tens of thousands of teenagers in New York City are holding summer jobs who might otherwise have been without work, because of the response to the Youth Opportunity Campaign started by President Johnson last May.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- Official delegations representing the Roman Catholic Church and the United Presbyterian Church met here today in an atmosphere of cordiality to start a series of conferences on Christian unity.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Officials of the Internal Revenue Service acknowledged today tapping the phones of their own agents and others suspected of crime. They conceded that in some cases they might have been "overzealous."
Mayor and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, smiling and waving, left yesterday for their honeymoon on an island off Florida.
I want to comment on your July 22 editorial "Those Midtown Garages," with which I completely disagree.

Sutton Towne, Inc., a diversified real estate company, has named Raymond Babtkis, a broker who specializes in store locations, as a vice president. He will be in charge of the company's store-leasing division.
SELMA, Ala., July 27 (AP) -- A civil rights leader predicted today that Negroes would try to enroll in a new private white school in Selma if state funds are used for tuition grants.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- (AP) -- A bill to permit the use of Federal highway funds for development of mass transit systems in metropolitan areas was introduced today by two big-city Democrats.

The winners in the Glen Alden-McKesson Robbins battle are the McKesson stockholders who will receive $49 a share for stock tendered in response to an offer made by the Glen Alden Corporation two weeks ago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 -- The pattern of Saigon politics changed slightly today when Nguyen Xuan Oanh, the Harvard-educated economist whom Americans call Jack Owen, was abruptly removed from his post as Governor of the National Bank.
Stockholders of the Bulova Watch Company at their annual meeting yesterday previewed equipment that astronauts will use en route to the moon.

Orders for machine tools, which went down in April and declined again in May, advanced sharply enough in June to wipe out the losses and move on to higher ground. The level of incoming orders is a high for the year as well as sharply above the level of July last year.

PRAGUE -- The coming reform of Czechoslovakia's economic system gives substantial powers to the central bank, heretofore -- in the standard Communist pattern -- largely under the thumb of the state planners.
PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- Dr. Edward H. Litchfield resigned today as chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Treasury said today that the new British financial measures "give another clear indication of the determination of the British authorities to take the actions necessary to restore equilibrium in the British balance-of-payments position by the end of 1966."

TRENTON, July 27 (AP) -- The State Health Department reported today that for every one of the 97 cases of mosquito-borne St. Louis encephalitis that was recognized during last year's epidemic, 38 other persons had been infected but did not know it.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- W. Averell Harriman outlined United States Policy on Vietnam today to the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, Marko Nikezic.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson singled home Russ Snyder with a run in the 10th inning that gave the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

" Mr. Gillray: The Caricaturist." by Draper Hill, which was published in England this spring by Phaidon Press, is being distributed in the United States by New York Graphic Society. It contains 147 plates. James Gillray, a Scotsman who was one of the first political cartoonists, worked in London during the reign of George III.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, ended Senate hearings today on a bill to limit mail order sale of firearms and predicted that legislation would be ready for the Senate by the end of August.

THE Washington Region of the Sports Car Club of America has had a long string of successes in its production of endurance races, both at 6 and 12 hours. The one over last weekend, a 4 to 10 P.M. contest for modified and production sports cars, was in the usual pattern.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (AP) -- Willie Stargell doubled and scored on Donn Clendenon's single in the 10th inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates gained a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies for a split of their double-header tonight.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 27 -- The 18-year-old son of a socially prominent retired admiral was killed in an auto accident as the result of "his own intoxication," Fairfield County Coroner Isadore L. Kotler ruled today.
LONDON, July 27 -- Edward Heath, a tough professional politician with reformist ideas about Britain's future, appears certain to be the new leader of the Conservative party.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today a bill to authorize a long list of flood control, river and harbor projects that are expected to cost about $2 billion.
The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a sharp increase in second-quarter and first-half earnings.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 27 (AP) -- Carol Sorenson, complaining that she was playing "real sloppy golf" successfully opened the defense of her Trans-Mississippi amateur title today.

The John Birch Society, the ultraright-wing organization, and its founder, leader and ideologist, Robert H.W. Welch Jr., a retired candy manufacturer, are the subjects of a 90-minute television program being released this week over the National Educational Television network.
The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the first six months of 1965 rose to the highest half-year level in the history of the company.
Most 5-year-olds like policemen because policemen fight bad guys. Five-year-old Marion Licari loves Traffic Patrolman William Cannon because he smiles at her.

The city's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control said yesterday that "prophets of doom" at recent City Hall public hearings had misled the public by giving the impression that "atmospheric conditions in New York City were far more perilous than the facts indicate."
Persons packing baggage for an airline trip any time after Saturday may be understandably confused.
The Rainbow Room, the temple of elegance and style 65 stories up that was the setting for an open revolt in 1938, is once again the backdrop for an underground uprising.

ATHENS, July 27 -- Sources close to former Premier George Papandreou conceded today that the most likely solution to the present Government crisis was a center-right coalition without Mr. Papandreou and possibly headed by Stephen Stephanopoulos, former Deputy Premier.

World shipbuilding rose to another record during the second quarter of this year with 1,709 merchant vessels aggregating 11,059,606 gross tons under construction at the end of June, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

SHE presides over a place in Mount Kisco called Haywire House, which got its name from her husband's cable address, and a Fifth Avenue apartment where a Finnish cook turns out delectable French meals.
Thomas F. McMahon has been named a senior investment counselor in the New York offices of Moody's Investors Service, Inc. He had been with the First National City Bank.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 27 -- Everything went according to form in the second round of the Eastern grass court singles championships today as the eight seeded men and seven seeded women won at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for the first half and the 12 months ended June 30. Sales volume of electricity, gas and steam also ran ahead of comparable 1964 levels in both periods.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 27 -- Officials of eight towns and villages along the east bank of the Hudson River gathered here today to express varying degrees of concern, vexation and outrage over Governor Rockefeller's proposal to run a six-lane expressway through their waterfronts.

BOSTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics twice built healthy leads and just survived home run barrages, including three wallops by Tony Conigliaro, for 7-3 and 10-8 victories tonight over the skidding Boston Red Sox.
James L. Wilcoxen of Deal led 19 other New Jersey section qualifiers into the metropolitan amateur golf championship yesterday with a 34, 35 -- 69 at the White Beeches Golf Club.

MARKLE, Ind., July 27 (AP) -- A Wells County motorist and his four children were killed tonight in a two-car crash at a Northern Indiana intersection where his parents were killed in a traffic accident nearly six years ago.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 27 -- A former member of the Nassau County Attorney's staff and another lawyer have been indicted for bribery in a county land purchase.
Today is the day of decision for the J.C. Penney Company on whether it will go into the insurance and mutual funds fields through its proposed acquisition of the Channing Financial Corporation.

In recent news articles in your esteemed paper, including that of July 18, you give erroneous impressions regarding the recent stand of the United Republic of Tanzania in the East African Common Market.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 -- Fighting continued tonight in Chaudoc Province between Government militiamen and a company of Vietcong that the militia unit had come upon in a "search-and-clear" operation.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Administration is taking steps toward insuring that both sides in the Vietnam conflict abide by the principles of the Geneva Convention in treating prisoners of war.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Tradition was followed today and Adlai E. Stevenson's chair in the White House Cabinet Room was sold.
Carmine G. De Sapio has decided to attempt a political comeback. He will announce today or tomorrow that he will run again for Democratic district leader in Greenwich Village.
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company awarded yesterday $30 million of debentures to a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and White, Weld Co.
A total of $200 million of corporate bonds and debentures came to market yesterday, and almost all appeared sold by late afternoon.
CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) -- Pedro Gonzalez drove in three runs with a single and a double and led the Cleveland Indians to a 7-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

BONN, July 27 -- Defense Minister Pierre Messmer has ordered French members of the integrated staff at supreme headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to boycott preparations for a joint military exercise this autumn.
BARTLES CORNERS, N.J., July 27 -- A dump truck with nine tons of dairy feed is being held as collateral here following a collision between the truck and a sports car.

LONDON, July 27 -- Last Friday afternoon, the day after Sir Aleo Douglas-Home's resignation as leader of the Conservative party, Edward Heath was not on the telephone or in the Parliamentary lobbies canvassing for votes.

WARRENSBURG, N.Y., July 27 -- There's an invasion somewhat resembling a gold rush taking place in the western Adirondacks. The target for enterprising prospectors is the Moose River area, where brook trout are being taken with impressive results.

PARIS, July 27 -- France is determined to retain full control of her economy and will not accept dictation from the international civil servants working for the European Economic Community, Premier Georges Pompidou declared tonight.
Dramatic evidence of the strength of the national economy and particularly of the boom in the automotive industry came yesterday in the latest profit statement of the General Motors Corporation.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 27 (AP) -- More than 50 taxi drivers protesting grievances touched off an anti-American street demonstration today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 27 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority invites bids today on coal for its steam-power plants, and for the first time included land reclamation among contract requirements.

GREENSBORO, Ala., July 27 (UPI) -- About 30 civil rights workers maintained a vigil at a police barricade tonight despite a steady drizzle. They said they would remain until they are allowed to continue a march to the courthouse that was broken up yesterday with tear gas.
Merck Co., Inc., big pharmaceutical and chemical company with headquarters in Rahway, N.J., reported yesterday that it had record sales and earnings for the three and six months ended June 30.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27 (UPI) -- One of racing's rarities occurred in the fifth race at Monmouth Park today when there was a dead heat to win a dead heat for third.

The Tartan Stable's Western Warrior, with Heliodoro Gustines in the saddle, won the 1 1/8-mile T.V. Lark Purse worth $10,000 on the turf course at Aqueduct yesterday and thereby restored the faith of a host of form players who had just about given up on that method of picking race horses.
PALMYRA, N.Y., July 27 -- On a pine-fringed hill called Cumorah near here, the story of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon) came spectacularly to life tonight.

President Johnson's apparently successful effort to give his labor allies the extra legal power they want without engendering an abrasive Congressional battle has had its predictable effect of shutting out any real consideration in the House of what changes in labor law would be good for the country and not just unions.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Johnson will report to the nation tomorrow on the results of the Administration's intensive review of United States policy in Vietnam. The White House would not say whether the President would announce any major decisions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 -- Pledges in excess of $500 million are already in hand for the proposed Asian Development Bank, five members of the touring consultative committee of the projected institution announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Johnson announced today the resignation of Anthony J. Celebrezze as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and named John W. Gardner to replace him.

Three small children fell from high windows in separate accidents in Manhattan and Queens yesterday afternoon. Two boys were killed. A 16-month-old girl survived, although she was seriously injured, when her fall was broken by a clothesline.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to lose ground yesterday as traders waited for the government to announce new deflationary measures.

PARIS, July 27 -- Like most Frenchmen, 35-year-old Jean Pommarede, who designs for Jacques Heim, doesn't know what the word camp means. But as of today he is the leading exponent of it in French high fashion.
" Of course, we're in the summer doldrums," a Securities a Exchange Commission official said yesterday. "We haven't had a really complicated stock fraud in at least a week."
MILWAUKEE, July 27 (UPI) -- The Clark Oil and Refining Corporation reported record sales and earnings for the first half of 1965.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Johnson signed today the first piece of legislation to result from the Surgeon General's report of 1964 linking lung cancer and other diseases to cigarette smoking.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Fred C. Foy, chairman of the board of the Koppers Company, Pittsburgh, was appointed today by President Johnson as chairman of the National Export Expansion Council.
The Federal Maritime Commission has submitted legislation designed to protect cruise tourists from financially irresponsible operators.
The New York City Central Labor Council plans to endorse a mayoral candidate in the September primary.
Leading Negro business and professional men asked four mayoral candidates last night what they intended specifically to do to bring full rights to Negroes.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 -- Those who came to the 1965 Governors Conference looking for Presidential timber have had a hard time seeing the woods for the trees. There are seventeen Republican Governors dashing about Minneapolis in various degrees of useful activity, but of these the only one who has impressed anyone here as being in the Presidential class announced he would never run again.

THE race for the 1965 McKenney Trophy, awarded to the bridge player winning most master points in the year, is an old story with a new twist. Barry Crane of Van Nuys, Calif., who was second in each of the last four years, is in second place again at the half-way mark, the American Contract Bridge League announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A Senate Interior Subcommittee completed today a hearing on a bill to establish a National Recreation Area on the upper Delaware River in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

Directors of the Cities Service Company voted yesterday to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis, effective Sept. 29. The board also announced its intention of placing the new stock on an annual rate of $1.50 subject to shareholder approval of the split. That would be comparable to $3 on the current shares, which yield $2.80.
A Queens philanthropic organization and the city Department of Real Estate are cooperating on a pilot project to rehabilitate a group of Manhattan slums that had been abandoned by their owners.
The first four productions at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, the new home of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company at 150 West 65th Street, were announced yesterday.
RIGHT now hundreds of thousands of tourists are pouring through Italy, peaceful invaders who swarm from Agrigento in Sicily to the Valle d'Aosta in the Alps.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 27 -- For contributing $250 each to the United Hospital Fund of Port Chester, 168 amateur golfers will have the privilege of teeing off tomorrow with 56 pros in the pro-amateur prelude to the $100,000 Thunderbird Classic invitation golf tournament at the Westchester Country Club.
A Brooklyn grand jury found yesterday that a young white policeman who shot and killed a Negro ex-convict in Brooklyn July 15 had "acted in a lawful and justifiable manner in defense of himself."
The Borden Company showed the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half-year in its history for the periods ended June 30, Francis R. Elliott, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 3.875 per cent.
New York City began solving its brownish water problem yesterday, but Mayor Richard B. Purdue of Ossining immediately accused it of not doing enough about the greenish water problem.
NEW HAVEN, July 27 -- The Board of Education charged today that the grades of students at this city's largest high school had been deliberately raised in recent years to help them get into college.
LONDON, July 27 -- Tough austerity measures were introduced today to speed deflation and to convince foreign creditors of the nation's determination not to devalue the pound.
The British pound and Canadian dollar improved yesterday in activing dealings on foreign markets here.

SEATTLE, July 27 (UPI) -- Air France's first 707-320C all-cargo jet was delivered to the airline today by the Boeing Company in preparation for the inauguration of jet cargo service between Paris and New York Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Representatives of the American Medical Association urged the House Commerce Committee today to reject President Johnson's proposal for a network of regional medical centers.
Vito Battista, the perennial conservative Republican candidate who is now running for the mayoral nomination, invaded Wall Street yesterday with an elephant and a monkey.
MONTREAL (Canadian Press) -- That venerable institution -- the boisterous and sprawling French-Canadian family -- is falling apart at the scams, a social scientist says.

Smith-Greenland Co., Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of two senior executives. They are Edwin M. Berdy, who was named director of research and marketing, and Daniel E. Charnas, who joins the agency as a senior vice president.

Zero Mostel, who plays Tevye in "Fiddler on the Roof," is moving to television. He and Carol Burnett will appear on a special one-hour comedy variety show to be televised early next year by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- President Johnson has repaid a debt of hospitality that dates back to his Navy days in Australia during World War II.

A correspondent for a Copenhagen newspaper at the United Nations plunged to his death yesterday morning from an apartment building at 45 Tudor City Place. His body landed across First Avenue from the headquarters of the world organization.
DENVER, July 27 (UPI) -- Cookie Gilchrist, traded to the Denver Broncos in the offseason said today he never had intended to play football in Denver.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The disarmament conference reconvened today at the Palais des Nations after a 10-month recess, with the United States and Soviet delegations agreeing that time was running out for curbing the nuclear danger to world peace. But they strongly disagreed on how this danger should be restrained or averted.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Office of Education has accepted school desegregation plans from 24 districts in Mississippi. This is considered an important advance for school integration in the Deep South.

TOKYO, July 27 -- Having too many American players is giving the great Japanese game of besuboru a "foreign look," professional club owners have agreed. Besuboru is also played in the United States under the name of "baseball," an Anglicized version of the word.

RUMSON, N.J., July 27 -- Miss Charlotte DeCozen of Westchester scored a 41, 39 -- 80 today and took the first-round lead in the 32d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association shore tournament at the Rumson Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- United States Air Force jet fighter-bombers, attacking at low level, destroyed one antiaircraft missile site 40 miles west of Hanoi and damaged another early today, the Pentagon said. It was the first attack on such sites in North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner has found that J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., unlawfully discharged 69 employes for trying to unionize several company plants. The board recommended the workers' reinstatement with back pay.

Presuming that politics follows its traditional course in Great Britain, a future Conservative Prime Minister has been chosen. The victory of Edward Heath in tomorrow's scheduled run-off vote appears to be a certainty with the retirement of Reginald Maudling from the race.

ASHLAND, Ore., July 27 -- The country's oldest Shakespearean company opened its 25th season in its open, multi-storied Elizabethan-style playhouse at Lithia Park here last night. The ticket sale had been the heaviest in its history.
The New York Yankees split a double-header with the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium last night. New York won the first game, 4-3, and lost the second, 3-0.

Your editorial and news article [Times, July 10] mentioning the proposed Delaware Expressway through central Philadelphia stated only one of the reasons for the decision by state and Federal highway officials to depress and, we hope, to cover six blocks of that highway.
The Ford Foundation yesterday announced 13 fellowship awards for administrative interneships in the performing arts.
Two men were shot by an off-duty detective last night after they allegedly stole $3,000 worth of camera equipment from a parked car and tried to escape in a taxi.

The moderate tone of President Johnson's speech yesterday and the news that he did not plan to call up the Reserves took some commodity dealers by surprise yesterday. As a result, in the scramble to sell and take profits, quite a few futures prices tumbled.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -Juan Carlos Pugliese, the Economics Minister, announced last night that out-of-court settlements for four foreign oil companies had been nearly agreed upon, following 21 months of negotiations after the annulment of contracts with 13 private oil companies.
AMERICUS, Ga., Thursday, July 29 -- A white teen-ager was shot in the head from a car early today three blocks from a night-long civil rights protest rally in the rain.

MRS. DOROTHY ALBIN of Eynesford, Kent, England, probably is known to more Welsh Corgi folks than any other person -- but not by her first name. "Nobody ever calls me Dorothy," she said. "I'm always called Dickie.
BONN, July 28 -- The West German Government announced today it would clamp down on state and local government efforts to raise money through the sale of bonds.
The President's measured speech to the nation yesterday could leave no doubt about the seriousness of the situation in which this country finds itself today in respect to the war in Vietnam.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 28 (AP) -- An Iraqi Air Force plane bombed and strafed a Turkish border town today, killing, a man and wounding 10 other persons, the Turkish Interior Ministry said.
Young Audiences, Inc., has received two grants that will enable the organization to send live chamber music programs to schoolchildren in areas with out previous experience with live music.
LONDON, July 28 -- Edward Heath took charge as leader of the Conservative Opposition today and moved immediately to increase the pressure on the Labor Government.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its board of governors had expelled from membership Jay Lewis Rubin, an allied member and general partner in Freeman, Rubin Co. of San Antonio, Tex.

MILWAUKEE, July 28 (UPI) An Illinois manufacturer bought the sunken Dutch cargo ship Prins Willem V. for $85,000 today and announced plans to raise the vessel, it possible, for use as a worldwide floating warehouse for his fire-extinguisher business.
TRENTON, July 28 (AP) -- The State Institutions Board rejected a proposal today to modify New Jersey's policy on birth control information.

VIENNA, July 28 (AP) -- Bulgaria announced today a shake-up of the political security apparatus, curtailing the functions of the Minister of Interior and setting up a watchdog State Security Committee on the Government level.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 28 -- Last year's student demonstrations on the University of California campus were described as bad academic manners today by the man who will be the new chancellor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28 -- President Tito discussed the Vietnam crisis today in separate talks with Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India and W. Averell Harriman, the special envoy of President Johnson.
ROME, July 28, -- "Where is the life that late I led? Where is it now? Totally dead -- "
New duties were assigned yesterday to top financial executives of the Northrop Corporation, a Beverly Hills, Calif., manufacturer of electronic equipment and aircraft.

KEARNY, N.J., July 28 -- Top-seeded Cal MacCracken of Tenafly, N.J., and fourth-ranked George Ball of Roslyn, L.I., scored easy victories today and advanced to the semi-finals of the New Jersey State seniors tennis tournament at the Arlington Players Club.
ROME, July 28 -- Pope Paul VI reproved today the extremes of "radical reformism" and of reactionary resistance to change in the Roman Catholic Church.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 28 -- Premier Levi Eshkol spoke of his predecessor, David Ben-Gurion, with a shrug.

CAIRO, July 28 -- In the first local editorial on the appointment of Arthur J. Goldberg as United States Ambassador to the United Nations, the newspaper Al Gomhouria today called the choice "extremely logical since Zionists are the ones who direct American policy."
Ten Japanese newsboys on a week's visit to this country were received at City Hall yesterday by Deputy Mayor John V. Connorton.
LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- A 150 million ($420 million) plan for modernization of Britain's ports was submitted to the Government today.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 28 (UPI) -- Ecuador's week-long Cabinet crisis ended today with selection by the military junta of a new government essentially civilian in character.
The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company has joined the growing number of companies that have changed to a new trademark.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Big-city mayors who have been formulating antipoverty projects and telling the poor about it later were put on notice today to brace for a change.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- A Federal suit challenging the constitutionality of the exemption of church-owned businesses from Federal income taxes was dismissed today.
ATLANTA, July 28 -- The United States Army's new Airmobile Division, ordered to Vietnam today by President Johnson, has already begun to move.

ROCHESTER, July 28 (AP) -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today Governor Rockefellers decision not to seek the Presidency in 1968 was "essential and very wise" if he expected to be re-elected as Governor.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP) -- Dick Schofield and Jim Davenport drove in two runs apiece in a five-run second inning today to lead the San Francisco Giants to an 8-5 victory over the St. Louis Cards.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -President Johnson today named his long-time friend Abe Fortas, the Washington lawyer, to succeed Arthur J. Goldberg on the Supreme Court.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 28 (AP) -- Barry Goldwater underwent surgery this afternoon to repair an old injury to vertebrae in his neck. Doctors said the ailment essentially was a pinched nerve.
President Johnson's statement on Vietnam had little effect on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The market opened slightly lower and continued on the same level throughout the trading session.
In your July 7 editorial "Water Metering Started Again" you stated that every family unit in every residential building should be individually metered.

WASHINGTON, July 28 --The United States has asked the United Nations to employ its "resources, energy and immense prestige" in finding ways "to halt aggression and to bring peace in Vietnam," President Johnson said today.

Fred C. Trump is negotiating with several persons on the future of the Steeplechase Park property he recently purchased. Irving Rosenthal, owner of Palisades Amusement Park in New Jersey, visited the Coney Island park last week.
PARIS, July 28 -- Mrs. David K.E. Bruce, who is the wife of the United States Ambassador to Britain, came to admire a strictly cut narrow gray wool coat with a chinchilla collar.

The Government, in common with many another unfortunate, is losing a lot of money at the race tracks. The big loser is the Internal Revenue Service, and the amount was estimated yesterday to be "millions of dollars" a year.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 28 -- Editorial comment by the educational TV network has led KLRN-TV of Austin-San Antonio to decline to run a 90-minute documentary on the John Birch Society, Robert F. Shenkkan, the station manager said today.

" The History of the Jews," by Poul Borchsenius, a Danish Lutheran pastor, will be published by Simon and Schuster on Aug. 31. Pastor Borchsenius participated in the underground movement that helped smuggle the Jews out of Denmark in World War II.
C.W. Cook, president of General Foods Corporation, told 700 stockholders at their annual meeting in the Americana Hotel yesterday that the company expected 1965 to be "another year of growth."

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 28 -- W.B. Wanninayake, the Finance Minister, introduced a bill in the House of Representatives today to give legal effect to recent agreements reached between the Government of Ceylon and three Western oil companies -- Shell Esso and Caltex -- on compensation for their assets and installations here that were seized by the former leftist government nearly four years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today the awarding of three contracts totaling $42 million for material needed to produce new silverless dimes and quarters.

The Civil Aeronautics Board told the nation's airlines yesterday that they were making too much money and should start passing some of it on to the consumer in the form of lower fares and better service.
OUT of Katherine Anne Porter's voluminous novel, "Ship of Fools," which was a big prize-winning best seller in 1962, the producer and director Stanley Kramer has fetched a powerful, ironic film.

YONKERS, July 28 -- With the shifting of harness racing from Nassau County to Westchester tomorrow night, post time for the first race at Yonkers Raceway will be 8 o'clock, a half-hour earlier than at Roosevelt Raceway.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began exerting pressure yesterday on former members of the Police Department who have refused, despite immunity, to answer grand jury questions concerning alleged links between gamblers and policemen.

Joseph Schaffel, formerly manager of Alexander's Department 'Stores' Fordham Road store in the Bronx, has been named manager of the chain's new Manhattan store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue, which is scheduled to open next month.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- Fred Whitfield hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning to give the Cleveland Indians a 4-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
GENEVA, July 28 -- Soviet officials saw in President Johnson's new military measures tonight another serious obstacle to an agreement on nuclear arms control.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 29 (AP) -- Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, the Premier, today hailed President Johnson's announcement of an additional American troop build-up as evidence of United States determination to see that the war against the Communists is won here. Marshal Ky addressed the nation over the Saigon radio.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second largest producer of steel, reported yesterday a substantial rise in second-quarter sales and earnings.

Twenty-four city high school students are spending six weeks this summer as medical research assistants in local hospitals under a program conducted by the New York Heart Association and the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Luci Johnson, the President's 18-year-old daughter, has started a summer beautification project of her own. She's lost 15 pounds and wants to lose five more.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 28 -- The state will proceed with its plans to build a mixed-traffic superhighway from New York City to Beacon, Joseph P. Ronan, administrative deputy of the State Department of Public Works, declared today.
New York State will sell $70 million of highway contruction bonds at competitive bidding Sept. 8 in the first sale of tax-sustained general-obligation bonds during the Rockefeller Administration.
Alexander Graham Bell's invention took on a new look yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Most members of Congress received President Johnson's statement on the Vietnam crisis today with a sense of relief. First, there was general satisfaction that the President had decided to increase the draft and postpone a decision on calling up reserve units.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Treasury announced today a refunding of $7.3 billion of securities due in August, offering holders the choice of an 18-month note of a 3 1/2-year bond.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 28 -- Charles Pasarell, hailed as the salvation of American tennis only last weekend, became just another player today.
The Board of Elections rejected yesterday a proposal by Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane to use the city's mobile registration vans for enrolling certain voters for the Sept. 14 primary.
Assaults, muggings and other felonies on the subways have decreased about 60 per cent since April 7, when 800 policemen were assigned to patrol all trains and stations from 8 P.M. to 4 A.M.

DALLAS, July 28 -- The first Davis Cup tennis tie to be played in the Southwest will start here Saturday between Mexico and the United States in a newly set up public park stadium that is largely sold out.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 (AP) -- The Ohio Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a $32,000 libel award to a Negro woman who had been termed an "Uncle Tom" in a newspaper account of a speech by former Gov. Michael V. DiSalle.

A 20-year-old Florida woman who works at the World's Fair was beaten yesterday morning by a man who followed her home from a bus stop, but another passenger chased the suspect and alerted the police, who captured him.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Stepped-up draft calls may make it more difficult for young Americans to be deferred from military service. Selective Service Director Lewis B. Hershey said today.
About 1,000 retail stores in Brooklyn are being asked to close for a half-hour on Monday to protest the 1 per cent sales tax increase, which becomes effective Sunday.

LONDON, July 28 -- Reginald Michael Hadow, head of the Foreign Office news department, was appointed Ambassador to Israel today. He will probably take up his post, his first ambassadorial appointment, in October.
Businessmen reacted cautiously yesterday to President Johnson's request for an emergency appropriation of possibly more than $1 billion for the Vietnam war.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Following is the text of a letter from President Johnson to U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations:
LONDON, July 28 -- Prof. Ernst Boris Chain, a Nobel winner, today denounced as a "monstrous political trick" the recent prosecution of the leading members of Italy's principal health institute.
MARCO ISLAND, Fla., July 28 -- Barbara Cavanagh Wagner said today that if her new husband, Mayor Wagner, wanted to run for office "I would certainly help him to campaign."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 -- The chief United States military spokesman in Saigon said today that he had been instructed not to bring to his press briefing representatives of the pilots who took part in the strike against missile sites northwest of Hanoi yesterday.

As all students of baseball know, a left-handed batter is at a disadvantage against a left-handed pitcher. Furthermore, any kind of a batter is at a greater disadvantage against any kind of a pitcher when the count is no balls and two strikes.
The British pound scored a solid advance in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The Canadian dollar also continued to show improvement.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that his arm was still a bit sore after a weekend bowling contest at Camp David, Md., with Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.
The J.C. Penney Company and the Channing Financial Corporation announced yesterday that their boards have approved a memorandum of understanding calling for acquisition of Channing by Penney.

The recent Court of Appeals decision recognized the legality of any "quickie" divorce obtained in a foreign country by New York domiciliaries as long as one of the parties established abroad even a one-day synthetic domicile to meet the technical acceptance of the matrimonial suit by the foreign court and the other party acquiesced therein.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -The moderate increase in the war effort in Vietnam announced today by President Johnson will impose no noticeable strain on the national economy, high economic officials said today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- The terrace of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Lodes's Dunemare Lane home will be the setting on Aug. 5 for the annual Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue fashion show, a benefit for Guild Hall. Should it rain, the collection of fall and winter fashions will be shown at the Maidstone Club.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- House and Senate conferees reached a compromise today on the closing of military installations.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz continued efforts today to settle the 43-day-old maritime strike that has idled more than 100 United States ships.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The United States announced today its first "normal" drawing from the International Monetary Fund, taking $300 million in five European cur rencies.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- President Johnson's order increasing United States military manpower in South Vietnam to 125,000 raises the American commitment by more than 100,000 men since January. At the beginning of 1965 United States forces in South Vietnam stood at 23,000 men.

Fleet taxi owners in the city petitioned the National Labor Relations Board yesterday to set aside the results of union-representation elections held last week in their 37 garages and to order a new vote.
Four social workers who were suspended by the Department of Welfare on Monday for alleged "insubordination" were reinstated yesterday after a departmental hearing.

A successful combination was reunited in the $27,950 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, when Mike Venezia rode Determined Man to victory by a neck over the favored Kilmoray. The last time the jockey and the horse worked together -- three-months ago -- they won on the same track.

HOUSTON, July 28 (AP) -- Dennis Menke batted in two runs with his fourth homer and a single and Ty Cline collected three hits as the Milwaukee Braves gained a 6-4 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 28 -- The Chief Minister of the Transkei the first "native homeland" established by the South African Government, today urged Africans living in urban areas to demand their rights.

BRUSSELS, July 28 -- The president of the European Common Market's Executive Commission expressed an attitude of flexibility today on the issue regarded in some quarters as the real one in the present Common Market crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Government-sponsored birth control is beginning to take hold in India and gives promise of success in other developing countries, Ambassador Chester Bowles told a Senate subcommittee on population control today.
The Consolidated Edison Edison Company was faced at a City Hall public hearing yesterday with a demand that it remove its power generating plants from New York City by 1975.
Wall Street heaved a sigh of relief."
SIX new small appliances were introduced yesterday by Braun Electrics America, Inc., as additions to a line that has won museum recognition for its design quality.
LOWELL, Mass., July 28 -Joe Namath, the rich rookie quarterback, had a good if not gaudy debut for the New York Jets tonight.

LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation announced today that it had asked American and British aircraft manufacturers to submit plans for a subsonic airliner accommodating up to 250 passengers.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to the Administration's medicare-Social Security bill, 70 to 24.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday new highs in net income and operating revenues for the quarter and for the 12 months that ended June 30.
The nation's electric power production rose 4.4 per cent in the week ended July 24 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
A $2.5 million campaign against public apathy in the nation's fight against crime will be undertaken by the National Council of Crime and Delinquency.
DALMAHOY, Scotland, July 28 (UPI) -- Rain washed out most of the "Little Ryder Cup" golf matches today, and Britain was declared the victor over the United States, 27 holes to 12.
Christmas arrived yesterday at Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. Gaily-wrapped gift packages were scattered all over the Concord Hotel, and will be until Aug. 7th.
The stock market made its biggest one-day advance in two weeks yesterday as Wall Street seemed to find much more reassurance than cause for alarm in President Johnson's comments on Vietnam.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 28 -- Discontent among governmental employes of the military-civilian junta was on the rise today as salary checks were delayed for the third day.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 28 -- The Brookhaven Memorial Hospital announced today that no maternity cases would be accepted until further notice owing to two confirmed cases of infants with symptoms of diarrhea.
WASHINGTON, July 28 --President Johnson announced today that United States military strength in South Vietnam would be increased from the present 75,000 men to 125,000 "almost immediately."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Spokesmen for three organizations urged a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today to reject President Johnson's bill to abolish the national origins quota system of immigration.

New York City urgently needs a comprehensive outdoor recreation program. The announcement that two Federal agencies will each grant the city $50,000 to help finance the drafting of a master plan is most encouraging, particularly since it constitutes a precedent for Federal aid to urban recreation.

WITH Casey Stengel in the hospital, Yogi Berra not in charge of the Mets, Johnny Keane quietly dying inside, Red Schoendienst going nowhere and Walter Alston rehired for the 12th time, it is as good a time as any to examine that peculiar profession, managing a major league baseball team.

LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- The Earl of Avon, the former Sir Anthony Eden, said today that Communist China might come to regard a neutral Vietnam as a solution to the present impasse there and preferable to the armed United States presence in South Vietnam.

DETROIT, July 28 -- The mayors of many of the nation's cities asked overwhelmingly today for the defeat of Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen's proposed constitutional amendment limiting the effect of the Supreme Court's one-man one-vote decision.
Michel des Vallieres, vice president of the Midland Capital Corporation, has been elected a director of the Northern Instrument Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission cleared the way today for common ownership of television stations and community antenna television systems.
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -The Moscow radio said tonight that President Johnson was taking "a colossal risk" in increasing American armed strength in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- President Johnson's news conference today moved some of those present, including his wife, to the verge of tears.

CHICHESTER, England, July 28 -- Light is dark and dark is light. That is the clue to the presentation at the Chichester Festival Theater of a pair of fine one-act plays, one somber and old, one uproaricus and new.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 28 -- The quintuplets born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lawson are thriving in their incubators, authorities at the National Women's Hospital here said today.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its worldwide affiliates had estimated earnings in the first six months this year of $505 million, down $32 million, or 6 per cent, from the $537 million cleared in the first half of 1964.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored three runs in the seventh inning tonight and went on to defeat the Los Angeles Angels, 5-1.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 28 -- A long course was the order today as a spanking sou'wester prevailed on the third day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta. The wind held steady at 12 to 15 knots and the committee sent the fleet over a 6.9-mile triangular course.
The city's Art Commission has approved a preliminary plan for a 2.34-acre park that will be part of the Lincoln Center complex.

HUBBARDTON, Vt., July 28 -- "I don't know how to explain it," said Eldon G. Bird, who owns a general store on the west end of Lake Hortonia. "Anglers have been taking northern pike and bass out of the lake this summer with almost anything.
Government bond dealers late yesterday afternoon described the Treasury's plans for refunding $7,268,000 of notes as "attractive" to the holders of the maturing securities.
GREENSBORO, Ala., July 28 (UPI) -- The police broke up a three-day civil rights demonstration today by arresting 300 persons for obstructing traffic.

Debs Myers, executive secretary to Mayor Wagner, will leave city service Saturday to return to the post from which he has been on leave as executive vice president of the Thomas Deegan Company public relations consultants.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -The House handed organized labor its biggest victory in years by voting today to outlaw state "right to work" laws. The vote was 221 to 203.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the country's biggest rail line, served notice yesterday it was planning to discontinue ferrying fruit and vegetables across the Hudson River from New Jersey to New York.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 (AP) -- Don Schwall loaded the bases with three walks and Alex Johnson followed with an infield single, driving in a run in the 14th inning that gave the Philadelphia Phils a 1-0 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

LIMA, Peru, July 28 -- President Fernando Belaunde Terry warned a United States oil company today that Peru would nationalize its petroleum properties by expropriation if an amicable transfer is refused.

The overwhelming vote of approval in the Senate yesterday for medicare brought a long struggle to a triumphant close. Only President Johnson's signature is now needed to make this historic measure into law.

George A. Christie, chief economist for the F.W. Dodge Company, had a comforting word yesterday for producers of building materials and other businessmen whose bread and butter is the contruction industry.

CAIRO, July 28 -- A West German citizen who testified yesterday that he had spied for Israel said in an Egyptian security court today that he knew that some letters he had sent to German rocket and aircraft experts here had contained small amounts of explosive.

The New York Times in a July 15 editorial "The War Against Poverty" quotes me as saying that "we must shed the illusion that there is a war against poverty. There is merely a BB shot against poverty."

TORONTO, July 28 -- The American Natural Gas Company of Detroit, once an opponent, has become an ally of Trans-Canada Pipe Line, Ltd., in an attempt by the Toronto company to build a $200 million Canadian natural gas line through the United States.

A BRITISH concern called Goods Chattels sprang into being a year and a half ago in London, with the aim of bringing a bit of color into the flat and the manor house. About 60 per cent of the decorative accessories and occasional furniture the com-imported for wholesale distribution were from this country.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., the nation's largest air carrier, raised its revenues and earnings to new highs in the second quarter and half year ended June 30.
BOSTON, July 28 -- Everett Knowles, whose right arm was torn off and re-implanted three years ago, is back in the hospital with a break in the same arm.

IS there a paying public for outdoor ballet in New York? Ask the Metropolitan Opera Ballet. For its Lewisohn Stadium debut last night an audience estimated at 12,000 showed up to see a program of Michael Fokine's "Les Sylphides" and his "Polovetsian Dances" from "Prince Igor," Anton Dolin's "Pas de Quatre" and excerpts from Marius Petipa's "The Sleeping Beauty."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew's 22d home run and five straight singles by Tony Oliva sparked the American League-leading Minnesota Twins to an 8-1 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
Abraham Lincoln once said, "To sin by silence when they should protest makes cowards of men."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 -- North Vietnam has begun to prepare its people for possible involvement in a full-scale war with the United States.

CROTON FALLS, N.Y. -- The art of the table has very much of a double meaning in the lives of Harold and Trudi Sitterle. The couple are ceramists who create objects for dining, including a pepper mill once selected for its good design by the Museum of Modern Art, and both of them have a penchant for creating dishes in the kitchen.
The Internal Revenue Service has chipped the sugar coating off life-insurance company offers to grant attractive discounts on premiums paid in advance by policy holders.

The rate of unemployment among Negroes in large cities is rising to the level of the national average for the whole labor force during the depression, a civil rights official told a conference on youth employment yesterday.

The Avco Delta Corporation, a wholly owned finance company subsidiary of the Avco Corporation, announced yesterday it had completed placement of $34.75 million of long-term notes with institutional investors.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -New York City may be forced to adopt universal metering as a condition of its further use of Delaware River water.
The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision, has supported its Chief Justice's defiance of a Federal court ruling on confessions.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- The New York Mets of the future tangled with the Chicago Cubs of the present today and the results were strictly out of the past -- the Mets lost a double-header, 7-2 and 9-0.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The remaining pictures of Mars taken by Mariner 4 on July 14 and slowly transmitted to earth, are to be made public at the White House tomorrow morning.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28 (UPI) -- H.R.C. Elser's Genies Pride took the lead at the last hurdle today and went on to score a half-length victory over Sacred River in the S17,050 Mid-summer Hurdle Handicap at Monmouth Park.
JOHN CURDO of Chelmsford, Mass., adhered to his best form and topped the 78-man field with a score of 6-0 in the recent Central New England Open at Fitchburg, Mass.

ALBANY, July 28 -- At Summerlane, a private school in Roscoe in the Catskills, the pupils don't have to go to class unless they want to. This caused State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. to ponder today whether the youngsters were getting as good an education as those in public schools nearby.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 --With two prominent Republicans dissenting, the nation's governors today pledged their support to President Johnson's actions in the Vietnam crisis.
Victor Borge disclosed yesterday that he was planning to appear in his first musical comedy in this country, "The Great Adventure," from a novel and play by Arnold Bennett.
BOGALUSA, La., July 28 (UPI) -- Rain and a Federal judge gave Bogalusa civil rights workers setbacks today.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's news conference yesterday afternoon in the East Room of the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Mrs. Arthur J. Goldberg read at her husband's news conference today the prayer of an ancient Aztec chieftain, sent by Adlai E. Stevenson to her and her husband in 1957.
The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency said here yesterday that it would approve Buffalo's urban renewal program because the city adopted a housing code.
Although it was a choice made largely on personal grounds, President Johnson's selection of Abe Fortas for the Supreme Court gives every promise of proving an excellent appointment.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- Sammy Ellis pitched a four-hitter tonight as Cincinnati snapped Sandy Koufax's 11-game winning streak and salvaged the third and final game of their series against the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-1.
A spokesman for independent banana importers yesterday urged that future maritime labor contracts contain provisions that Would prevent the loss of perishable cargoes when sudden strikes are called.
After a nervous opening, prices on the London Stock Exchange moved quietly ahead during yesterday's trading.

MIAMI BEACH, July 28 -- The Federal Government should go beyond counting casualties of automobile accidents and develop an active highway safety program, the president of the American Trial Lawyers Association said today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -The President's military plans for Vietnam were widely regarded in the Pentagon and by many on Capitol Hill as a temporary or "stop-gap" measure, with a decision on partial mobilization postponed for several months.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Arthur J. Goldberg began a new career today as United States representative at the United Nations with an 80-minute discussion of major problems with the Secretary General, U Thant.

ATHENS, July 28 -- Former Premier George Papandreou, whose popularity with the average Greek voter appears to have risen since King Constantine removed him from office July 15, will face a more critical electorate tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -John W. Chancellor, White House correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company, was named by President Johnson today to head the Voice of America.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Army killed today the Mauler air defense missile project, which has cost $200 million.
LONDON, July 28 -- There was uncertainty and unrest in London today over the Government's harsh new measures to deflate the economy and defend the pound.
WASHINGTON, July 28 --The president of Mothers Opposed to Meddling in Schools (M.O.M.S.) and Representative Adam Clayton Powell engaged in a shouting match today.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has apparently decided to exclude Harlem from the list of communities in his Northern civil rights crusade.
OPPORTUNITIES to block the declarer are sometimes missed in situations of this kind:
BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- Home runs by Carl Yastrzemski and Lee Thomas powered the Boston Red Sox to a 6-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The United States Coast Guard was accused today of presenting an inaccurate picture of safety conditions on the nation's inland and coastal waterways in its attempt to extend its regulatory powers over diesel-powered craft.
WITH or without consent, American Presidents are copiously advised. All citizens have ideas on high policy matters. Under our system, they express them resonantly.
AARON COPLAND took the helm of the New York Philharmonic's French-American Festival last night in Philharmonic Hall to conduct a concert version of his opera "The Tender Land."
Representatives James H. Scheuer and Jonathan B. Bingham of the Bronx are planning to support City Council President Paul R. Screvane for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 -- Roosevelt Raceway's most successful spring-summer meeting was concluded tonight with a $158 daily double, an $822.40 twin double and a $124.60 exacta.

A lot of people who rarely went to beaches before because they were "too far away" or "too packed" are now whisking across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Staten Island's polluted but uncrowded shores.

WARSAW, July 28 -- The arrest of a prominent young instructor and a graduate student at Warsaw University has underlined a problem that the Polish Communist party faces in the orientation of contemporary youth.

David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has sounded out city business leaders on the possibility of establishing a nonpartisan weekly newspaper as a forum to discuss issues during the mayoral campaign.

Television is taking note of President Johnson's program to eliminate civic ugliness and the decay of urban and suburban areas. Yesterday the National Broadcasting Company announced plans for an hour-long documentary, "America the Beautiful," which will seek to arouse public interest in overcoming the problems of undisciplined growth.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 28 -The 28th official stop on the nation's golf tour reaches here tomorrow. It is known as the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament and brings one of the biggest shows on turf to the metropolitan area.
WHITE PLAINS, July 28 -- The town of Greenburgh filed suit in State Supreme Court today for equal representation on the County Board of Supervisors as defined in recent reapportionment decision.
LONDON, July 28 (UPI) -- Her Majesty's Post Office seems to have goofed.
Two melees were quelled by the police last night in front of a Harlem tenement and a Brooklyn housing project.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday several top-level management changes and the establishment of a major new department in the bank's organizational structure.

Leading the opponent's suit in a no-trump contract can be an effective tac tic. It may be a pure bluff, made in the faint hope that the defenders will concentrate on other suits for the rest of the hand.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Older Federal prisoners should have the same opportunity as youthful offenders to work outside prison walls, open bank accounts and visit ailing relatives, Attorney General Nicholas Deb. Katzenbach said today.
HARRISON, N.Y., July 29 -- The contestants in the Thunderbird tournament agreed today it would be difficult to find greener pastures than those of the fairways of the Westchester Country Club.

Three new leases have been made at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center for space totaling 14,000 square feet. Two of the leases are for new stores and the third for expansion of a store in the Garden City center.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Johnson made an unusual personal appearance today to sign a $35 million loan for Central American integration.

ATHENS -- The air over Athens is now so hot it has a tangible and burnished look. It even smells like the inside of an oven. Around Constitution Square, tourists droop in their care chairs like wet Dali watches.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 29 -- Man-in-the-street reaction to President Johnson's Vietnam program showed a better understanding of the situation, but not too visible an increase in belief we must be involved in solving the problem.

ORLEANS, Mass., July 29 -- It was only 10 A.M. but the last of the 15 drive-it-yourself aluminum fishing boats at the Goose Hummock shop here was about to be rented -- all Charlie Tipke had to do was persuade a young wife from upstate New York that sea worms did not bite.
The Federal Communications Commission gave the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation the go-ahead yesterday in its plan to purchase Press Wireless, Inc.
The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the second quarter and the first half of this year.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 -- President Johnson apparently clarified for many persons here the reasoning behind United States involvement in Vietnam, but failed to rally concerted support for the troop build-up.
The American Stock Exchange showed strength, both in volume and prices yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The United States lost $313 million of gold in June and another $75 million this week, the Federal Reserve System disclosed today.
The city's Commissioner of Markets stirred a furor among merchants yesterday by ordering them to put price tags on all articles sold at retail.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 29 -- Sworn statements by two white warders and two African ex-convicts describing electric-shock tortures in a South African prison were published tonight by The Rand Daily Mail.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Johnson's momentous news conference, at which he announced the dispatch of 50,000 more troops to South Vietnam, was as important for what he did not do as for what he did.
ALGIERS, July 29 -- Algeria today became France's junior partner in the future exploitation of vast oil and gas resources in the Sahara.
The 11 members of the Michael Candal family of Harlem received a $2,200 reward yesterday for honesty -- and patience.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- It comes as a mild surprise to many persons to learn that Lewis Blaine Hershey is still director of Selective Service.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday its highest second-quarter and first-half earnings since 1959.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 29 -- By January this will be a city with three TV towers.

CAIRO, July 29 -- The Government-owned newspaper Al Gomhouria charged today that a "major dream" of the United States Central Intelligence Agency was to wreck the regime of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and replace it "with a stooge and traitor regime" that would do its bidding in the Arab world.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- High Congressional sources believe the attitude of influential Senate Democrats confirmed President Johnson in his decision to move cautiously in expanding the Vietnamese war.

NEWARK, July 29 (AP) -- "We are here tonight to let our state know where our citizens stand on a police review board. We are against it," a white Newark resident told some 4,000 cheering demonstrators tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 29 -- Gov. John H. Reed of Maine won the chairmanship of the National Governors' Conference today by two votes, after a battle that closed the four-day session on a note of bitter partisanship.
Strange things happen to the New York Yankees on Ladies' Days. They win.
The package fee plan proposed by the New York Stock Exchange last December has been quietly and effectively shelved, informed Wall Street sources believe.
NEW ORLEANS, July 29 -- Except that the children laugh in the wrong places, the audience at a performance of the Free Southern Theater might be in church.
PATERSON, N.J., July 29 -- Wayne Dumont Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, said today that Prof. Eugene D. Genovese of Rutgers should be dismissed.

The decision by the Delaware River Basin Committee to order universal metering by all communities that want to continue using its water is obviously designed to prod Mayor Wagner. How much more prodding is needed to induce New York City to do something it ought to have done long ago out of enlightened self-interest? Universal water metering has been urged here for more than a century.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- President Johnson's report on Vietnam brought man-in-thestreet and editorial reaction that fell considerably short of unanimity for or against Administration policy.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 29 -- The number of players with clean 4-0 scores in the United States Open Championship at the University of Puerto Rico was reduced to six after completion of the fourth round here today.
The New York Civil Liberties Union will seek to have declared unconstitutional a city ordinance requiring the "conspicuous display" of a large American flag by street speakers.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Johnson will fly to Missouri tomorrow to sign the medicare bill in the presence of Harry S. Truman, the White House announced tonight.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 29 -- Municipal Judge Rupert Crittenden was accused today of imposing "vindictive sentences" on defendants in the sit-in demonstrations last December on the University of California campus here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29 -- Following is the text of today's letter from the Secretary General, U Thant, to President Johnson:
