GREENSBORO, Ala., July 29 (UPI) -- New mass arrests that swelled the two-day total to 420 resulted today when Negroes again defied police orders and attempted to march on the Hale County Courthouse.

The Ford Motor Company has decided to step up its drive to pump new life into its subsidiary, the Philco Corporation, in an effort to get the company back into the top rank of appliance manufacturers.

Consolidated net income of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation for the first six months of this year increased to $23.451.000, or $1.23 a share, from $23.175.000, or $1.21 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The Police Department is going to try even harder to make friends with the people and community groups.

LAKE BLUFF, Ill., July 29 (AP) -- Jane (Peaches) Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., moved into the semi-finals of the national girls' 16-years-old-and-under tennis tournament today by routing Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., 6-0, 6-0.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan confirmed last night that he had considered a proposal this week to ransom the DeLong star ruby, which was stolen last October from the American Museum of Natural History.

James Joyce's "Ulysses," one of the most celebrated and complex novels of modern literature, will be made into a film by Walter Reade-Sterling and the British Lion company. A six-month shooting is scheduled for next spring in Dublin and Gibraltar under the direction of Joseph Strick.
NEW ORLEANS, July 29 -- Most man-in-the-street opinions agreed with President Johnson's Vietnam discussion.
A Hong Kong company believes its may have the answer to a "retail vacuum" in this country.
Sea and river water will be used to fight major fires in the city starting this fall, if the water shortage remains acute. The salt water would replace fresh water drawn from hydrants.

DALLAS, July 29 -- There is no lack of confidence in either the Mexican or United States camp about the outcome of the Davis Cup tennis match in the final round of the American Zone starting here Saturday.
Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday that the 350-acre island park in Lower New York Bay that will be formed by joining Hoffman and Swinburne Islands would be named for the late Bernard Baruch.
AMERICUS, Ga., July 29 -- Two Negroes, one of them active in the civil rights movement, were charged with murder today only hours after a white man was slain in this racially troubled city.
Sharply higher earnings were reported yesterday by Texaco, Inc., for the quarter mid six-month periods ended June 30.
Two Queens men were arrested yesterday on charges of slaying a Greenwich Village photographer last March 11.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 29 (AP) -- Foo Ping-sheung, vice president of the Judicial Yuan (Council), Nationalist China's highest legal body, died of a heart ailment today at the age of 69.

A youth crossed the grassy courtyard of Yale Divinity School the other day, carrying a notebook and copies of "Franny and Zooey" and "1984.' He was too young to be a regular Yale student, and he was a Negro, still a comparative rarity at some Ivy League schools.
CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, July 29 -- A brigade task force of the United States 101st Airborne Division debarked at this port today for combat duty against the Communist Vietcong.

GENEVA, July 29 -- Italy's Foreign Minister, Amintore Fanfani, sought today to broaden the scope of the disarmament conference here into one that might lay the foundations for an East-West detente and understanding.

LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- Prime Minister Wilson said tonight that President Johnson's decision to make a substantial increase in United States troop strength in South Vietnam was "inevitable." He indicated that he deeply regretted that this was necessary.
BOSTON, July 29 -- Interviews in downtown Boston reflected wide support for President Johnson's Vietnam policies.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP) -- John Romano drove in five runs with two homers tonight, pacing the Chicago White Sox to a 9-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The victory halted Chicago's three-game losing streak.
Rochester's festering slum of Upper Falls, the scene of Negro riots last year, is scheduled to be cleared of its clusters of crumbling shacks, factories and houses.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Civil Rights organizations filed 31 job discrimination complaints today against 16 employers in the South, four locals of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and one employment agency.
PARIS, July 29 -- It was Christian Dior day today and even the taxi drivers knew it. No other designer was crowded into the day because Chanel suddenly postponed her show until tomorrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Johnson declared today that the family unit had collapsed among an alarming number of Americans, particularly Negroes.

BONN, July 28 -- The young West German soldier was idly flicking the pages of a cheaply printed pamphlet that had just arrived in the mail when his eye fell on a full-page photograph of a naked woman, voluptuously posed.

MONTREAL (Canadian Press) -- Some 1,000 Port of Montreal grain handlers on strike against the National Harbors Board marched 10 miles through the city today in a demonstration protesting the breaking off of negotiations in their wage dispute.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- Ray Culp pitched a two-hitter tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated Pittsburgh, 5-0, and extended their scoreless-inning string over the Pirates to 23.

MRS. ARTHUR J. GOLDBERG, who, with her husband, the new United States Representative at the United Nations, will be moving into their official residence in the Waldorf Towers within the next two weeks, is wondering what she can do about an attic and basement back in Washington.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 29 -- This center of big-time yachting activity, more often than not the location for the major events of the New York Yacht Club's annual racing cruise and the place where the America's Cup matches are held when there are any, was not much more than a springboard today.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- A nuclear scientist sued today for $10 million in damages for the death of his cocker spaniel, which, he said could detect the presence of nuclear fallout in the atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Sargent Shriver is urging the Government to adopt a firm policy of cutting the unemployment rate to 3.5 per cent next year.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Consumer prices, heavily influenced by a reduced supply of meat and vegetables, rose by one-half of 1 per cent in June, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Today's publication of the Mariner 4 pictures of Mars was not only a ringing triumph for American science and technology, but a crowning achievement for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, which carried out the project.

ALBANY, July 29 -- Governor Rockefeller named five members to a new Tri-State Transportation Commission today in the continuing effort to find a smooth, fast and easy way of getting into and out of New York City.
Eighty young men swore allegiance to the United States as soldiers here yesterday.
About 10 per cent of the cases of female infertility result from a failure to ovulate. It is these cases that can be treated with a gonadotrophin hormone complex from the pituitary gland.

CINCINNATI, July 29 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed today the conviction of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on a charge of jury tampering, for which he had received an eight-year prison sentence and a $10,000 fine.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- President Johnson said today that nothing had been more sustaining to him than the pride and patriotism expressed in letters from the wives and mothers of men serving in Vietnam.

WATERLOO, Iowa, July 29 (AP) -- The president of the Rath Packing Company said today that the proposed acquisition of the Needham Packing Company of Sioux City had been terminated by an Iowa Supreme Court.

JINJA, Uganda, July 28 -- Much has changed and much remains the same in Jinja since July 28, 1862, when John Hanning Speke stood here at Ripon Falls making no effort to contain his excitement at having found the source of the White Nile.
BALTIMORE, July 29 -- Ogden Nash, labeling Manhattan "a verminous vault," is singing the praises of Baltimore, where he returned to live several months ago.

CAIRO, July 29 -- The dispute over the West German aircraft experts working here deepened today with the disclosure that the Government of the United Arab Republic was for the time being preventing 200 of them from leaving the country until they were replaced.

A group of 20 American home economists returned last night from a tour of the Soviet Union and reported that they were harassed and berated by the Russians because of United States policies in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Administration plans to increase its active-duty military forces by about 330,000 men, official sources said today.

Synanon Foundation, the non- profit program for rehabilitating narcotics addicts, has rejected a city offer of funds to expand its work here, because of "controls and regulations'' that would have been imposed on the foundation.

A nationwide public opinion poll taken hourly on Wednesday after President Johnson's news conference on Vietnam showed a shift from overwhelming endorsement of the President's actions to endorsement tempered by a heavy "I don t know" trend.

John V. Lindsay posters were being torn down yesterday in Catskills communities by irate local officials who denounced flying squads of Lindsay partisans for flouting their ordinances concerning political promotions.

When the overture begins for the stage show at Radio City Music Hall, the spotlight shines on Peter Bordonali, a 14-year-old guitarist from Miami, who plays the solo, an arrangement of two Lecuona pieces. He is one of the youngest performers to appear at the Music Hall and the first guitarist of any age to play there in years.
WHITE PLAINS, July 29 -- Governor Rockefeller was assailed today by conservationists for resisting Federal participation in planning to preserve the scenic beauty of the Hudson.
An intriguing tale of adventure, product promotion and possibly personal tragedy has just reached here from Afghanistan.
Tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows as well as concerts and movies, sold at box-office prices in five Macy's department stores, amounted to $814,000 for the fiscal year that ended in February.

The first live television transmission from the Soviet Union to this country is scheduled for noon tomorrow, when the American Broadcasting Company begins coverage of a track and field meet in Kiev. United States and Soviet athletes will compete.
AREA A -- Bluefish are abundant northeast of Manasquan Inlet. Mackerel, sea bass, porgies and blackfish are also available there. Sea bass are reported plentiful from Asbury Park to Sandy Hook.

I wholeheartedly subscribe to the spirit and substance of Prof. Norman Dorsen's July 20 letter urging the repeal of the infamous loyalty-oath requirement of the National Defense Education Act of 1958.

Trading volume for sugar dropped to half the previous day's business yesterday. The range of prices was only five to seven points for world sugar compared with 30 points on Wednesday. The market, in short, was mixed and featureless.
Three drug and cosmetic companies yesterday reported increases from last year in first-half earnings and sales.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29 -- Federal District Judge Herbert W. Christenberry held the two top police officials of Bogalusa in contempt of court today for failing to protect civil rights demonstrators from racist assailants.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 29 -- Pat Schwab demonstrated today how uncertain golf can be by leading the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament with a 66. Forcing the international stars and leading money-winners to step aside, the 250-pound instructor from the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J., smashed par by six strokes at the Westchester Country Club.

NEWARK, July 29 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, with the help of the State Department, will hold a representation election for more than 700 unlicensed seamen assigned to the Humble Oil Company's tanker fleet.
In a strongly worded decision the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upset the conviction of five hijackers because of errors in the judge's charge to the jury.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- The amazing Mets broke a four-game losing streak today by pounding out a 14-0 victory over the even more amazing Chicago Cubs, who committed six errors.

The State Supreme Court has ruled that a group of Staten Island ferryboat workers who participated in the ferrymen's strike last May were not entitled to wage increases and other benefits provided in the contract that they did not sign.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- A heated exchange erupted in the House today over President Johnson's nomination of Abe Fortas to the Supreme Court.
Four hundred persons protesting American policy in Vietnam picketed silently late yesterday at the Army recruiting and induction center at 39 Whitehall Street.
The British pound and the Canadian dollar continued to improve on foreign exchange markets here.

Russell E. Train, whose resignation as a judge of the United States Tax Court was announced yesterday by President Johnson, will become the president of the Conservation Foundation on Monday. He will succeed Samuel H. Ordway Jr., who is retiring.

ATHENS, July 29 -- Former Premier George Papandreou won the support today of the Deputies of his Center Union party on the immediate issue of bringing down the government that replaced his when King Constantine removed him from office two weeks ago.
The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots complained to the Government yesterday that it was the forgotten union in the 44-day maritime strike.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Conferees of the Senate and House reached agreement today on a bill to insure Southern Negroes the right to vote that was guaranteed them by the 15th Amendment 95 years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
Wall Street, with its fears of a full-scale war in Vietnam at least temporarily allayed, got behind the stock market yesterday and pushed up prices substantially along a broad front.

A hearing on 1,961 challenges of ballots cast in the union-representation election last week in 37 fleet taxi garages will be held Monday at the National Labor Relations Board, 16 Court Street, Brooklyn. The outcome could affect representation in 15 garages. A union victory is safe in 22 others.

STOCKHOM, July 29 -- Quintuplets, three boys and two girls, were born early today in a hospital at Falun, central Sweden. Two of the boys died within a few hours and the third boy and one of the girls died later in the day.

The July 22 editorial "American Honor in Vietnam" quotes President Johnson's recent press conference statement on that vexing subject: "Our national honor is at stake." The Times editorial suggests that if this is so, "then the struggle is a war to the finish, whatever the cost."
MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI) -- Four American Methodist ministers preached tonight to an emotional, overflow congregation in Moscow's only Baptist church.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 29 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax of Los Angeles, the top pitcher in the majors with 17 victories, has suffered a flare-up in his arthritic left elbow, the Dodgers' team physician said today.
DEAL, N.J., July 29 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of the Cedar Brook, (L.I.) Country Club won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 32d annual New Jersey Shore tournament today with a 54-hole total of 236.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Johnson and his top military and foreign policy advisers briefed 49 state and two territorial Governors tonight on the Administration's policies in Vietnam.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. will lead a civic campaign to reinstate proportional representation as the method of electing New York City councilmen.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales in the week ended July 21 amounted to $5.27 billion, 2 per cent below the level on the preceding week but 8 per cent higher than the total in the corresponding week of 1964.

MIA RIA, Thailand, July 25 -- The young man stood uneasily beside the wooden bed platform on which he had unrolled his sleeping mat. He kept touching the heavy silver band he wore around his neck and nervously fingering the silver buttons on his short, red-trimmed jacket.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended July 24 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1964.
BERLIN, July 29 -- In a daring escape a young East German couple and their 9-year-old son climbed down a rope from a downtown Government building to freedom in West Berlin early today.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Man-in-the-street reaction to President Johnson's Vietnam report was mixed, while The Detroit Free Press said that the President "wants to do as little as possible but as much as necessary."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A heavy, perhaps fatal, blow was delivered today to the possibility that there is or once was life on Mars.

A Brownsville physician known for his kindness and generosity to patients who lived in the rundown Brooklyn area, was shot and killed yesterday by two holdup men who invaded his office at 2081 Pacific Street.

Van Cliburn will play MacDowell's Piano Concerto in D minor in the final program in the New York Philharmonic's French-American series tomorrow night at Philharmonic Hall. He will replace Andre Watts, who had been engaged for the program.

Wayne Neville Morgan, who describes himself as the representative of a group of American corporations offering to lend the Government of Uruguay $130 million, said yesterday that the offer of his syndicate was still good.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- No objections were raised to the appointment of Thurgood Marshall as Solicitor General at a surprisingly placid Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing today.

Prospects appeared dim yesterday for any immediate reductions in air fares as a result of the Civil Aeronautics Board statement Wednesday urging airlines to use more of their recent profits to lower fares and better service.
MIAMI, July 29 (UPI) -- A former Governor of Cuba's Camaguey Province arrived here by yacht tonight after escaping a Castro prison camp and drifting on a 4-by-4-foot raft for 12 days.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 -- Political and religious factions in Saigon today praised President Johnson's announcement of an increase of 50,000 troops to the United States force in Vietnam. They felt that this would be only the beginning of a new American military build-up here.
The operator of a recently opened sidewalk cafe in the Times Square area was told yesterday clean up its "honky-tonk atmosphere" by noon today or have his license revoked.
The Times July 19 editorial on the unhappy developments in Greece is factually correct yet leaves the reader -- at least this reader -- with serious misgivings.

BEFORE the weekend is over, the Russians will make their greatest discovery since the disclosure that Stalin was not as innocent as Shirley Temple. They will learn that Randy Matson, as almost everyone in America knows, is really Superman.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 29 -- Col. Miguel Angel Hernando Ramirez, one of the organizers of the revolt of last April 19 that overthrew the junta headed by Donald Reid Cabral, fled the Dominican Republic tonight, it was reliably reported.

Three of the five leading candidates for Mayor vied with each other yesterday at City Hall in offering solutions for New York's worsening air pollution problem. They appeared before the City Council's special Committee on Air Pollution.

The candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination, who have been concentrating much of their fire on Representative Joh V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal, are now attacking each other with increasing bitterness.
Most Government-bond prices declined yesterday as dealers revised their thoughts about the Treasury's August refunding offer.

The compromise arrived at by House-Senate conferees on the voting rights bill makes final passage possible next week. This is important because no further time should be lost in registering Negroes to vote in coming elections.

PAPPAGALLO Shoes has gone into the sneaker business and has upgraded rubber- soled footwear to the extent that Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman-Marcus are going to carry them. They will cost $.5.50, slightly more than the usual price.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 29 (AP) -- Two American Olympic champions -- Edith McGuire and Wyomia Tyus -- will go for a triple Saturday and Sunday that could lead the United States to its best women's showing against the Soviet Union in their annual track meet.
City Planning Commissioner Lawrence M. Orton, in his letter in The Times of July 26, rather than your earlier correspondent Harris L. Present, misses the point about universal water metering.
Governor Rockefeller asked the Port of New York Authority yesterday to give him a "definite recommendation" before next January on a site for a proposed fourth jetport for the metropolitan area.

WHEN Robert Payne isn't writing scholarly biographies, learned histories, poetry, translations from the Chinese or fiction he is traveling somewhere and gathering material for a book about his personal adventures among artistic masterpieces, ancient ruins and far places.

" When the New Deal Was Young and Gay, F.D.R. and His Circle," by Charles Hurd, will be published by Hawthorn on Sept. 13. This is an account of the first four years of the Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933-36.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., who at 21 is a first voter this year, has affiliated with the Reform wing of the Democratic party by joining the Lexington Democratic Club on Manhattan's East Side.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 29 -- For two hours and two sets today Roy Emerson not only was not the world's No.1 tennis player, there was some doubt that he was the No. 1 player in the Eastern grass-court championship.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Federal Government won a major battle in the House today in its dispute with the city of Woodside, Calif., over erecting several utility poles for high-voltage electric wires.

YONKERS, July 29 -- Dartmouth proved he could go 1 1/4 miles -- a distance he had never before attempted -- with plenty to spare tonight as he captured the $100,000 Hilltop Trot that topped the reopening program at Yonkers Raceway.

COWES, Isle of Wight, England, July 29 -- Crack offshore yachts from eight countries will start competing tomorrow in the first of four races for the Admiral's Cup of the Royal Queen Racing Club. The British team will defend the trophy, with challenges coming from the United States, Australia, the Netherlands, France, Sweden, Germany and Ireland.
Another East Side Hotel has been marked for demolition.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, urged a Congressional committee today to endorse legislation that would bar construction of United States vessels in foreign shipyards.
A Long Island man, described as one of the country's top bookmakers, collapsed and died yesterday morning fleeing from Federal agents who had arrested him at his home.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (AP) -- Profits of the National Exhibition Company, the corporate name of the San Francisco Giants baseball team, fell 56.5 per cent last year even though there was almost as much gross revenue as in 1963.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Chicagoans expressed deep concern over the Vietnam situation. Many feared it would grow worse but voiced solid support for whatever course the nation's leaders decide must be followed.
BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored five runs in a seventh-inning rally featured by Frank Malzone's pinch double and gained a 6-4 victory today over the Kansas City Athletics.
Improved sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the first six months of 1965.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A somewhat bewildered Congressional subcommittee has completed three days of hear ings on reforming the world monetary system today, having heard 10 witnesses and 10 different proposals for reform.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Republicans outspent Democrats for political broadcasts in the 1964 general election campaign, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.
Eastern Air Lines and Mackey Airlines, a Florida-Bahamas carrier, submitted yesterday to the Civil Aeronautics Board a merger agreement.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 29 (AP) -- Jean Bryant of Greenville, S.C., scored her third upset and moved into the semi-finals of the Women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.
Quadrangle, the winner of the 1964 Belmont Stakes, will be retired from racing and will be sent to his owner's breeding farm at Upperville, Va.
PARIS, July 29 -- "De Gaulle gave the house away but saved the furniture."

SAIGON, South Vietnam July 29 -- A Navy pilot who was downed over North Vietnam yesterday told a tense story today of hiding in 14-foot-high grass while American aircraft made strafing attacks to keep North Vietnamese away from him until a helicopter flew inland to rescue him.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 29 -- At least half of the classes will crown series champions tomorrow when the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta completes its fifth day of sailing. The other half of the classes in the fleet of 250 will probably go down to the final day.
Business loans at the 14 weekly reporting New York City banks declined $89 million in the week ending July 28, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The election of Dr. Harry A. Towsley to the board of the Gerber Products Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Fremont, Mich.
Prices fell slightly in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, despite minor improvements near the close.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the six and 12 months ended June 30.
BRUSSELS, July 29 -- Pierre Harmel, Belgium's new Premier, pledged his Government today to a program of active social welfare measures with special attention to the problems of individual regions.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 -- Two large combined United States and South Vietnamese military offensives were under way tonight in an attempt to keep the Vietcong forces off balance during the middle of the monsoon season.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has earmarked $7.65 million for loans to provide low-cost homes for Negro families in the South and Middle West.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- All but 448 of the 5,129 school districts in the South and border states have indicated they will have desegregated classrooms this fall, the Office of Education announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, assured President Johnson today that he would continue to work for a peaceful settlement in Vietnam "by all the means at my disposal."

Man- in- the- street samplings across the nation yesterday indicated that Americans generally supported President Johnson's reasoning regarding the increased build-up of resistance to Communism on the Vietnam front.

A group that includes Edgar Bronfman, president of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, has apparently changed its mind about acquiring a substantial block of the Paramount Pic tures Corporation. A source close to the film company said the group had approached some long-time holders of Paramount about the possibility of acquiring their stock, but added that "nothing has come of it."
American business has completed its most prosperous half year in corporate annals.
Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo said yesterday that New York City's water system would be fluoridated by Sept. 7.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 30 -- Five series titles were clinched today, the next to last day of competition in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual cruise week regata. The fleet is at Bellport tomorrow with 20 class championships still on the line.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 -- Turkey asked today for an early meeting of the Security Council on charges that the Government of Cyprus had violated the rights of Turkish Cypriotes by amending the electoral laws unconstitutionally. The meeting is expected to be called Tuesday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 30 (AP) -- Pegasus 3, soared into orbit today atop the last of the Saturn 1 rockets.
Ever heard of the Henry Goldwater-Miller Bridge? A traffic sign in the Bronx seems to point the way to a span with that unlikely name.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senate confirmation of Abe Fortas's appointment to the Supreme Court seemed likely today, despite scattered sniping from Republican and right-wing sources.

TORONTO, July 30 -- A Detroit housewife is talking. "When I picture a Canadian family, I see it similar to ours. But I would think they have less than we have. I can't imagine them owning two cars and two tele vision sets."

NEW ORLEANS, July 30 -- A Federal judge told police officials of Bogalusa, La., today that if they wanted to purge themselves of civil contempt they had to draw strict rules for handling civil rights demonstrations and see that they are enforced.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Canadian and American finance ministers said today that they would "consult with ministers of other nations" before making any firm decisions on the American suggestion of a world conference to seek improvements in the international monetary system.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Johnson's request for creation of a new Cabinet-level Department of Housing and Urban Development won approval today from the Senate Government Operations Committee by a vote of 9 to 4.

WOODRIDGE. N.Y., July 30 -- A helicopter sent from New York City to aid in a search for a 9-year-old Brooklyn boy missing for two days from Camp B'nai Belz neat here crashed early this morning. Its pilot and a state trooper excaped with minor injuries.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation said today it would request bids from various United States manufacturers for five synchronous satellites and transportable earth stations to develop a space exploration communications system.
Persons over the age of 64 had better keep up payments on the health insurance policies they own if they want protection in the 11 months until Federal medicare benefits become available next July 1.

BRUSSELS, Saturday, July 31 -- Belgium's new Premier, Pierre-Charles-Jose Marie Harmel, is softspoken and polite, but he did not hesitate to shoo photographers out this week when he felt they had taken enough pictures of the first official meeting of his Cabinet.
For two hours Thursday night and again last night, 180 juvenile offenders, jeering and cheering, watched Tomy Farragut try to make up his mind whether to drop out of school.
The nation's first frequency modulation master antenna has been constructed atop the Empire State Building at an estimated cost of $30,000.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation indicated yesterday its willingness to accept terms set down by the Federal Communications Commission in its bid to acquire Press Wireless, Inc.
LONDON, July 30 -- William Warbey, a left-wing Labor Member of Parliament, called tonight for the resignation of Prime Minister Wilson as party leader because he had broken three election pledges.
WARSAW, July 30 -- The state has accused three Polish writers of slandering Poland, either in exile publications or in talks with Western newsmen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 -- Vietcong forces jabbed effectively at South Vietnamese Government positions today while Vietnamese and American units were searching unsuccessfully elsewhere for Communist troops to fight.
A squabble involving overweight meter maids arose yesterday between the Traffic Department and a union official.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 30 -- President Johnson flew to Independence today and signed the medicare-Social Security bill in a moving tribute to former President Harry S. Truman.
London, July 30 -- Britain acted dramatically this week to demonstrate to her international creditors her intention not to devalue the pound.

ATHENS, July 30 -- A stormy emergency session of the Greek Parliament broke up tonight in uproar and confusion, with its acting president declaring that the Government of Premier George Athanasiadis-Novas had fallen and that Parliament was adjourned.
There is not much to say about the Metropolitan Opera's production of Puccini's "Tosca" at Lewisohn Stadium last night, except to wish it would always sound so well indoors as it did in the open.

WHITE PLAINS, July 30 -- Among the hazards of living in a modern community that must be endured are neighborhood noises that include even gunfire, State Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled here today.
SPARTA, N.J., July 30 -- State and local health officials continued today to investigate an outbreak of infectious hepatitis here that has afflicted 15 persons in the last 10 days.
TORONTO, July 30 (Canadian Press) -- Ontario Premier John P. Roberts announced tonight that a Royal Commission would be set up to investigate the affairs of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service said today pollution of Lake Erie was "endangering the health and welfare" of people in New York, Ohio. Pennsylvania, Indiana, Michigan and other' states.

LENOX, Mass., July 30 -- Charles Munch was back at Tanglewood tonight to lead the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and even for this veteran conductor -- he was 13 years the orchestra's musical director -- it was a great evening.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 30 (AP) -- The United States Forest Service announced today plans for what it described as the largest timber sale in its history, an offering of 8.75 billion board feet of timber in southeast Alaska.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 30 -- Tension over the Cyprus situation has been increased by events of the last eight days -- not so much on the island as abroad.
In his July 21 column on balanced ethnic tickets Tons Wicker observed that John Lindsay's fusion drive includes a Jew, a Catholic and a "wasp."

PARIS, July 30 -- After Guy Laroche came Antonio del Castillo, Pierre Cardin and Gabrielle Chanel, and the day ended with a tiny collection by Emmanuel Ungaro, who may turn out to be the best Courreges copyist in Paris.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Pentagon said today that a small number of jet planes would be turned over to the South Vietnamese Air Force.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Premier Eisako Sato called today for measures to spur Japan's lagging economy and to raise living standards.

Led by industrial issues, the London Stock Exchange ended its trading week yesterday with modest gains.

ALBANY, July 30 -- The right of the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner to make driving instructors attend driving school themselves before they can be licensed to teach was upheld today by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

Isidoros Pantelaros stood on his favorite Harlem corner yesterday selling hot dogs and cold drinks and pointing with pride to a freshly painted second-hand school bus parked behind his red and white pushcart.

Net income of National Airlines, Inc., for the fiscal year ended June 30 climbed 91 per cent to $15,055,000 from the $7,862,000 earned in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The steady decline in the number of babies being born in this country continued through May, the United States Public Health Service reported today. The drop started in 1958.

Government bond prices slipped yesterday for the second day following the Treasury's announcement Wednesday of plans for refunding $7,268,000,000 of notes coming due Aug. 13.
The American Stock Exchange put on its best performance in three weeks yesterday as most stocks advanced in active trading.

More than six years have elapsed since the Sleeping Bear Dunes in Michigan and the Oregon Dunes on the Pacific Coast were first presented to Congress as national lakeshore and seashore proposals. Since then, many objections have been resolved, compromises made and due protection has been provided for private property rights. Recent Congressional hearings revealed widespread recognition of the desirability of preserving these spectacular shoreline areas for the enjoyment and inspiration of the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A 65-year-old man complains of pains that his physician suspects may be symptomatic of cancer.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A Negro laborer accused of killing Mrs. Mary Pinchot Meyer, a Washington artist and society woman, was acquitted of murder charges today in the United States District Court here.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 30 (AP) -- A crew of surveyors found two bodies today and the Austin police said they probably were the University of Texas coeds who disappeared 12 days ago.
Vito P. Battista, who hopes to challenge Representative, John V. Lindsay for the Republican mayoral nomination, won a skirmish with the Board of Elections yesterday.

New York tomorrow joins the many states that have had to resort to the retail sales tax to underwrite the expanding services of government. The rate will be 2 per cent but, when combined with local sales taxes, the accumulation will go as high as 5 per cent -- in New York City. This is the equivalent of Pennsylvania's, the highest in the nation.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (AP) -- A young mother smiled happily from a hospital bed today, a week after she seemingly died on an operating table.

PROFESSIONAL football, now a television attraction for nearly six months out of the year, returns to the tube this week with a series of pre-season exhibition games. NOT long before her death, Elizabeth I was seen dancing alone in her chambers to the sound of a pipe and drum. It was a fitting close to her Life, for she had danced in the face of all adversity. Elizabeth was a paradoxical Queen: coarse and sensitive, tender and cruel; but with a political brilliance unknown to her sex.

Boston Herald: The President clearly is not a warhawk. He is committing us to a holding operation, and his objective is to bring the enemy to the peace table with the least possible bloodshed and heartbreak. We can only hope that his judgment and his purpose will be vindicated by events.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Next week on the Senate floor there will be fought the climactic battle in the war set off 13 months ago by the Supreme Court's "one man, one vote" ruling on state legislative apportionment. At issue will be a Constitutional amendment allowing one house of a state legislature to be apportioned on factors other than population, providing the voters approve the plan framed by the legislature.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- The two-story brick building near the banks of the Dnieper River in the old quarter of Kiev was crowded with worshippers last Passover. Even with ageing men standing in the aisles the one orthodox synagogue could hold no more than about 500 people, and Kiev has a Jewish population of 225,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 -- A national Governors' Conference is a curious melange of family outing, political convention and public policy semnar. The 57th annual meeting of state executives, held in Minneapolis this week, was an opportunity to gauge the Governors' taste in recreation, their political temper and their degree of optimism or despondency over the future of the Federal System.

Gardner, president of the Carnegie Corporation, as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
