Federal officials are coming here Wednesday for exploratory talks on one of the city's key long-range water plans -- the construction of atomic plants to desalt sea water.
Japan Air Lines announced yesterday drastic reductions in trans-Pacific air cargo rates.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Aug. 1 -- The 72-year-old leader of Jerusalem's most orthodox religious sect, the Neturei Karta, has split the community by deciding to marry a 45-year-old convert to Judaism.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 1 -- The two New Yorkers -- William Lombardy, a grand master, and Bernard Zuckerman, a master -- moved into the lead with scores of 6 1/2 points in the seventh round of the United States Open Chess championship at the University of Puerto Rico here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 -- The Vietcong peppered 15 Government posts south of Saigon with mortar and small-arms fire early today, inflicting light to moderate casualties. The Communist troops also fired on five locations elsewhere in the country in one of the war's heaviest series of brief strikes.
George H. Gribbin, chairman of Young Rubicam, Inc., has announced that he will retire from that post and give up his administrative duties with the agency.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Bill Freehan scored from second on Don Buford's error in the ninth inning today as the Detroit Tigers beat the Chicago White Sox, 2-1, and gained a split in a double-header. The White Sox won the first game, 1-0, behind the three-hit pitching of Joe Horlen.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Cary Grant and Dyan Cannon, a 27-year-old actress, were secretly married in Nevada last month.
A last-minute fight began yesterday to block the opening of bids for construction of the controversial subway tunnel between Manhattan and Queens.

ATHENS, Aug. 1 -- In Pyrgi, on the island of Chios, the residents plan a resounding thank you to a New Yorker, Isidors Pantelaros when his gift school bus arrives. Now if only the neighboring village of Armolia would do something about that narrow street, all would be well.
About 500 state tax agents will go out over the state today to explain how the new sales tax works.

ABOARD THE ICEBREAKER NORTHWIND AT SEA, July 30 -- In the last five days an American scientific expedition to the Soviet Siberia has made an encouraging start in gathering information in the Kara Sea -- one of the few remaining major bodies of water for which no reliable data are available to United States oceanographers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A Congressional subcommittee recommended unanimously today that the Government henceforth publish balance-of-payments statistics both in their present form and in a new form proposed by a high-level review panel that reported earlier this year.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- The United States delegation at the Geneva disarmament conference expects some successes despite the unfavorable prospects for an agreement with the Soviet Union to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Any changes in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should be toward greater integration, not less, according to a report prepared by some United States experts.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 1 -- A new drive to thin out the political- prisoner population will open tomorrow.
Prof. Arnold J. Toynbee, the historian, has urged the United States to accept defeat in Vietnam, to withdraw and to permit South Vietnam to become Communist.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Cigarettes gave their final performance on British television last night. The Government's ban on televised advertising of cigarettes went into effect today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Many causes are cited for the seemingly unending economic woes of Britain, but what could be a key explanation is seldom mentioned. It is, quite simply, the level of income taxes that the Briton has to pay.

Senator J.W. Fulbright has taken another useful initiative by bringing up the long-dormant Soviet-American consular convention for Senate consideration and possible ratification. We agree with Secretary of State Rusk that the treaty should be approved since it will "help normalize relations and reduce frictions" between Moscow and Washington at a time when every means of improving the atmosphere of Soviet-American diplomacy is useful.

North Americans have been fascinated and often dismayed by the political activities of Latin-American university students. Yet, they are only doing more violently what students in the United States have been doing in recent demonstrations and teach-ins.
WATERLOO, Iowa, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartansburg, S.C., fired a par 72 despite stiff winds and won the Waterloo women's open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 214.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 1 -- The Minister of Justice, Balthazar J. Vorster, has predicted a number of court actions over newspaper articles charging brutality in South African prisons. Most of the actions would be against the newspapers themselves rather than reporters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- United States Government sources here indicated today that Robert Kimball, an American aid official held in connection with a double slaying here July 23, probably would be tried by a South Vietnamese court.
BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Bob Smith of Sacramento, Calif., and George Boutell of Phoenix, Ariz., gained the final of the Western amateur golf tournament today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Evidence mounted today that the new Soviet leadership intends to abolish, or at least greatly modify, the system of regional industrial management introduced by Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1957.

STRATFORD, Ont., Aug. 1 -- This is the year of "The Cherry Orchard." The Moscow Art Theater brought New York its production of Chekhov's masterpiece last February. This summer the play is in the repertory of the Minnesota Theater Company at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, and of the Stratford Festival here.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Edward Heath's rise to the leadership of the Conservative party gives a small additional glow to a London address already rich in political and literary associations.

MILLINOCKET, Me., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The name "Robbie," scratched with a rock or stick on the smooth bark of a white birch, raised hopes today that a 17-year-old retarded diabetic and his little brother would be found in wilderness near the base of Mount Katahdin.
Air passengers arriving in New York yesterday greeted new free baggage allowances with a minimum of confusion and a maximum of ease.
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Jack Nicklaus treated par with contempt today as he shot a 68 and won the $100,000 Thunderbird golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 270.
The new medicare law could be the economic salvation of many of the 19 million Americans over age 64.

A tired but inquisitive sea-lion that jumped into a dredging barge 10 miles off Coney Island on Saturday was tentatively identified early today as l one of 15 that escaped during the last month from a Maryland marineland.

A tired but inquisitive sea-lion that jumped into a dredging barge 10 miles off Coney Island on Saturday was tentatively identified early today as l one of 15 that escaped during the last month from a Maryland marineland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball indicated today that the United States did not rule out entirely the possibility of a new cessation of air raids on North Vietnam if there was any sign that such an action would elicit favorable counter-measures by Hanoi.

GEORGETOWN, Colo., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A 72-year-old man from Madison, Wis., and his 77-year-old wife set out this morning to scale Colorado's 14,005-foot Mount of the Holy Cross even though a storm yesterday dumped heavy snow on the Rockies.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Too many people are using their vacations along the coast of the Black Sea, the Soviet Riviera, as an excuse for drinking sprees, a Soviet newspaper complained today.

The newest showpiece of Italian shipyards, the $46 million Raffaello, made her maiden entry into New York harbor yesterday, with paint missing from her bow as a result of heavy seas. The Italian Line's luxury liner received the traditional welcome that is extended to all new ships when they enter the port for the first time.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -A jury that since April has been hearing evidence against four sponsors of Krebiozen was dismissed today until further notice while mistrial motions were studied.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Philip H. Hoff of Vermont said today that a delegation of 10 Governors, including George Romney of Michigan, a Republican, and John Connolly of Texas, a Democrat, would visit South Vietnam in the fall.
Dr. Bill Miller, a Columbus (Ohio) veterinarian who does push-ups with his five children on his back, beat Bruno Sammartino, the wrestling champion, last night at Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Labor Government announced new measures today to restrict immigration to Britain from Commonwealth countries.
IT doesn't take a detective to figure out Harry Saltzman's game and to calculate what's brewing in his British spy film. "The Ipcress File."
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 -If they ran a 200-mile-an-hour subway express from 42d Street to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., today's attendance at Monmouth Park probably wouldn't have been anything special.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 2 -- A pert Pekingese took best-of-show honors last night at the 37th annual Santa Barbara show and became the first Pekingese winner since the first show in 1920.
The last time that Don Smith the 49-year old president of Wolverine Aluminum Corporation, flew into New York from his Lincoln Park, Mich., office, the American Stock Exchange laid out the red carpet.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Jose Miro Cardona, president of the Cuban Revolutionary party at the time of the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, criticized today Mr. Schlesinger's recently published views on the aborted invasion attempt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Administration bills to help curb local crime and to ease Federal prison laws won speedy House approval today and were sent to the Senate.
TSINAN, China -- In a red-roofed pavilion on the lake you can sit among the willow trees where the wandering Tu Fu often drank his wine and wrote his bitter poems.
The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers warned yesterday of the possibility of a strike against the Long Island Rail Road because of what it called management's failure to repair faulty equipment.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Premier Eisaku Sato told the Diet (Parliament) today that the Japanese Government was "not entirely satisfied" with the fact that United States B-52 bombers, after taking shelter on Okinawa from a typhoon, made an attack in South Vietnam.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 2 -- The inside story of the Moby Dick disaster, as revealed for the first time by Ishmael, in the manner of Theodore Sorensen and Arthur Schlesinger Jr.:
Government bond prices continued to ease yesterday as the subscription books were opened for the Treasury's $7,268,000,000 refunding of notes coming due Aug. 13.
THE big-game season for New York State is scheduled to get under way on Oct. 25 in the Adirondack Mountains and the Northern Zone counties. This season for deer and bear will end on Dec. 7.
The city and Consolidated Edison decided yesterday to let the skeletons in a sealed room under Washington Square continue their rest.

The discount on the price of the British pound for future delivery, compared with the price or immediate delivery, continued to widen yesterday, deepening the concern of both foreign-exchange traders and commercial users of sterling about the currency's future.

The Senate has reached a unanimous-consent agreement to vote tomorrow on taking up the proposed constitutional amendments to reverse the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote decision on legislative reapportionment. Nevertheless, it is still possible that a baby filibuster on this issue may develop if Senator Dirksen goes through with vague hints of insistence on extended debate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- It is the North Vietnam Government, not the Vietcong, that holds the key to peace, Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated today.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the election as a director of Charles F. Myers Jr., president of Burlington Industries, Inc.
EDGEWATER, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Edgewater Colony, Inc., a simple but idyllic bungalow community of 26 acres on the steep and wooded west bank of the Hudson River, has decided to sell out.

There was consternation backstage during the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Verdi's Requiem last night at Lewisohn Stadium. But in front, under the capable direction of Kurt Adler, the Requiem was strong, calm and under perfect control.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Auto industry change-over shutdowns and the start of 1966 model production overlapped this week as the nation's car makers headed toward records.
The Traffic Department balanced the scales yesterday in the dispute involving two overweight probationary meter maids. One will be kept on the job and the other will be allowed to resign.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- The present $9 billion annual sales level for home furnishings could be doubled in 10 years, the first all-industry home furnishings conference was informed here today. This potential total excludes appliances.
THE United States lost a track and field meet to the Soviet Union last weekend at Kiev and strange things have happened since.
The private papers of Adlai E. Stevenson will be deposited at Princeton University and will not be accessible until a family-chosen biographer has finished with them.

ALLENDALE, S.C., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Thirty-eight persons, including nine whites, were arrested today as state troopers and local officers broke up a threatened all-night sit-in demonstration at the Allendale County courthouse.
The rain that fell in the Middle West over the weekend brightened farmers' prospects but dampened the ardor of some commodity futures buyers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Treasury bill rate rose this week after a dip in the two preceding auctions, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 2 -- A new layout for old Saratoga was on view today as the 102d season of thoroughbred racing began. In place of the antiquated, compressed grandstand area that once was the neglected extension to the small confines of the clubhouse section, a 500-foot addition has been constructed which has done wonders for the place.
The State Department has refused to allow Bobby Fischer, the 22-year-old United States chess champion, to play in an international tournament in Cuba later this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara ordered today a 10-man special panel formed to serve as a watchdog on expediting supplies to the augmented United States forces in Vietnam.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 -- The first elections since President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz took power last December indicated today that his Administration had the country's political machinery well in hand.
IT used to be that you went to the Catskills, otherwise known as The Mountains, to do just plain nothing. But times have changed.
Operations of the Ogden Corporation in the first six months this year resulted in record earnings of $4,009,000, equal to 78 cents a share, Ralph E. Ablon, president, reported yesterday.
A survey of 52 investment companies shows common-stock purchases totaling $739 million and sales of $647 million during the turbulent second quarter of 1965.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Jesse Gonder's pinch-hit double in the fourth inning drove home three runs tonight and led the Milwaukee Braves to a 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

In your July 26 editorial "Plan for the Hudson" you quite rightly point out the need for the preparation of an integrated plan for the Hudson River, in which the Federal Government, the states of New York and New Jersey and the bordering counties and municipalities would all be involved.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported yesterday a July net income of $2.4 million, compared with $2 million in the same month last year. On a share basis the month's results were equal to 27 cents, compared with 22 cents in 1964.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- Lord Chalfont, head of the British disarmament delegation, appeared confident today that he four NATO members taking part in the Geneva conference would find a forumla for a nuclear non-dissemination treaty that might meet Soviet objections to proposed joint nuclear forces in the Western alliance.
ATLANTA, Aug. 2 (UPI) -Gov. Carl E. Sanders asked civil rights leaders today to halt racial demonstrations and keep "outside influence" away from Americus.

The United Fruit Company reported yesterday, for the three months to June 30, a net profit of $5,065,000, or 63 cents each on the 7,972,925 common shares outstanding. Gross income was $108,275,000. The results compare with a net income of $3,628,000, or 45 cents each, on the 8,022,925 shares outstanding in the similar period of 1964 when gross income was $95,541,000.
Sales of department stores in the New York area rose moderately in July from the 1964 level after declining in the preceding months, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday.
Jazz echoed over City Hall Park yesterday as Edward Kennedy (Duke) Ellington was given the city's Bronze Medal for his contributions to music over a period of four decades.
GREENSBORO, Ala., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Voter registrars answered civil rights complaints today with an accelerated registration procedure and an easier literacy test.

SOMERVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A boycott of Negro schools spread to Fayette County today and a civil rights leader said about 80 per cent of the pupils enrolled in the 36 schools stayed away from opening-day classes.

WHILE Yves Saint Laurent was unveiling his fall line yesterday in Paris, the man who purchased controlling interest in the house of Saint Laurent almost a month ago remained busily at work in his New York office. "We think there's enough strain on Mr. Saint Laurent without us putting in an appearance," Richard Salomon, president of Lanvin-Charles of the Ritz, Inc., said in an interview.

DENVILLIE, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, seeking a record sixth title, won the qualifying medal in the 40th Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship today at the Rockaway River Country Club.

The clink of small coins into tax boxes in retail shops across New York was almost drowned out by the grumblings of customers and shopkeepers yesterday, the first regular business day under the new 2 per cent state sales tax.

I read with interest the July 14 letter by Milton E. Jacobowitz, Democratic leader of the 21st Assembly District, Queens. Mr. Jacobowitz (referring to Rockaway) quite correctly points to "a storm-eroded beach, rotting boards and rusty nails in the boardwalk, a new school waiting three years for a playground to be built, a double-fare subway, and jet planes zooming low over miles of new slums thrown up by the last unplanned urban renewal."
The United States and Canada are on the verge of widespread theater expansion. Wherever one visits in both countries one notes a ferment of new ideas and activities.

While retailers by the thousands inspected the latest in jewelry and other items for fall selling at the annual show of the Retail Jewelers of America at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday, others took up problems of management in distribution.
YONKERS, Aug. 2 -- Bonjour Hanover sloshed through a couple of inches of mud considerably easier than did her eight rivals in the La Paloma Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ted Savage's double sparked St. Louis to a two-run seventh-inning rally tonight that gave the Cardinals a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 2 -- A struggle to soften the judgment of history on Henry Clay Frick, one of Pittsburgh's great industrial tycoons, was renewed here today by a battery of lawyers and the late "coke king's" determined daughter.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the white-only admission policy at Girard College was "very tragic.''

MARION, Mass., Aug. 2 -- There was a new crop of winners on today's New York Yacht Club cruise run from Padanaram -- sailed with great dispatch in the best wind the event has had since it began last Friday.
Herman Badillo, the Commissioner of Relocation, has agreed to seek the Democratic nomination for Bronx Borough President on the slate headed by City Council President Paul R. Screvane.

May we congratulate you upon the excellent editorials which appeared in The New York Times on July 7 and July 19, respectively, under the captions "Water Metering -- Studied Again," and "What Drought Hath Wrought."

IN the last two months W. Averell Harriman has had perhaps the toughest assignments of his long career as roving ambassador. He has had to explain to Latin Americans the actions of the Johnson Administration in the Dominican Republic and to Russians the President's decision to escalate the war in Vietnam.
A plot on which five tenements now stand, at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 52nd Street, has been sold to John A. Dilliard Associates as a building site.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 2 -- Mrs. O. Waring Mellick and Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr., both of Round Hill, tied for the medal in the 40th Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship today. They will receive duplicate medals.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Pete Ward's two-run single and clutch relief pitching by Hoyt Wilhelm tonight gave the Chicago White Sox a 2-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

" I SAT up with my maiden aspic last night," a harried hostess related recently. Fortunately, this is not an essential step in the preparation of aspic-glazed or set dishes, a highly prized group of foods for summertime dining.

A water shortage such as New York City is undergoing after four years of drought inspires a great many "solutions" that turn out to be mirages when fully examined. A long pipeline to bring water from Niagara Falls has been found, for instance, to have objections other than astronomical cost. It would run into opposition from the New York State Power Authority, which depends on Niagara water for power. So does Ontario, of course.

Dr. James B. Conant has won an important round in his campaign to introduce some element of cohesion into the chaotic management of the nation's public education. The Governors, at their annual conference, accepted with unexpected fervor his proposal -- first put forth in his book on "Shaping Educational Policy" a year ago -- to establish an interstate compact on education.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2 (AP) -- America's military chief declared today that United States air strikes reaching within 35 miles of Communist China's border definitely were not intended to test Peking's reaction.

HAS the growing use of video tape, instant replay and just plain old-fashioned television made baseball umpires more cautious, lest they be second-guessed? It probably has made some ballplayers like Joe Pepitone, Ross Moschitto and Pedro Ramos even more fastidious about their appearance.
The stock market sat back and did virtually nothing yesterday, disappointing many investors who expected last week's advance to continue in the wake of reduced apprehension over Vietnam.
The heavens gave rain yesterday, but not enough to change the city's critically low water supply.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 2 -- Westchester officials, who have been irked for three months by lack of direct word from the state about its selection of a site for a county branch of the State University, were sharply critical of the choice when they received official notification to day.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 2 -- The ninth annual horse show of C.W. Post College will take place in the show rings on the campus here from Aug. 26 through Aug. 29. Mrs. William L. Matheson, equestrian, and the daughter of Charles V. Hickox, is president of the show.
WARSAW, July 31 -- No one traveling from Poland to Czechoslovakia may legally convert Polish zlotys into Czechoslovak crowns at the frontier.
American book publishers were asked yesterday to join in a study of the economic consequences of proposed revisions in the copyright law and of technological changes.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Jimmie Hall, a pinch-hitter, walloped a home run in the bottom of the ninth inning today to give the Minnesota Twins a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
The director of the New York State Miss Universe pageant announced yesterday that this year's title holder, Miss Gloria Jon, had been removed.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Authorities in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Kansas were deluged last night and early today by reports of unidentified objects seen flying in the sky.

YESTERDAY'S glamour is today's cornball, by rule, and ordinarily nothing looks funnier than those snapshots of that girl who seemed so pretty in that dress that looked so good at the time. But the Museum of Modern Art, never an institution to accept a rule without questioning it, has turned this one inside out with a new exhibition called "Glamour Portraits."

Tom Wicker's application, in your issue of July 23, of President Kennedy's distinction between the shadow and the substance of prestige is helpful and well-reasoned. I would, however, extend the discussion.
AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 2 -Twenty-three civil rights demonstrators were arrested and two were assaulted today while picketing a downtown supermarket.
International Nickel Company of Canada. Ltd., reporting record earnings, raised its quarterly dividend yesterday.
DALLAS, Aug. 2 -- Arthur Ashe gained today the victory that sealed the conquest of the Mexican Davis Cup Team and stands as the transcendant figure of the American Zone final.
In Europe, trading on the London Stock Exchange was quiet but fairly active demand for selective issues produced some price increases.
The Duke Power Company reported yesterday gains in its operating revenues and net income for the six and 12 months ended June 30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods in June were unchanged from the May level in Contrast to earlier reports of a 2 per cent decline, the Commerce Department reported today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- United States-Yugoslav relations are on the upswing this week, in the view of most observers here, despite deeply opposing views on such issues as Vietnam.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The S.S. Kresge Co. reported today records for both sales and profits in the first six months of this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- It's not the things, it's the people in the White House that fascinate the tourists.

Special meetings of the stockholders of Food Mart, Inc., and Shop Rite Foods, Inc., have been called for Sept. 22 to vote on the proposed purchase of Shop Rite of substantially all of the assets of Food Mart.

PALERMO, Sicily, Aug. 2 -Italian authorities announced today that they had arrested nine leaders of an international gang linking the Sicilian Mafia and the American Cosa Nostra. A tenth was seized tonight.
" Oliver!," the musical derived from Dickens's "Oliver Twist," reopened last night at the Martin Beck Theater.
Mrs. Esther James yesterday collected $19,115.54 of the more than $53,000 that Representative Adam Clayton Powell owes her for having called her a "bag woman" -- or graft collector -- five years ago.

CAIRO, Aug. 2 -- Two defendants in the West German "spy trial" declared their innocence today. A housewife pleaded not guilty to having spied against the United Arab Republic for Israel and a businessman denied having relayed defense secrets to his company.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The pluckiest designer in the French haute couture is a 71-year-old Irishman, Capt. Edward Molyneux, who sits among his guests when he shows a collection like a gentle, dreamy host at a very proper tea party.

A strike in the Southern Kraft division of the International Paper Company from June 11 to July 3 reduced second-quarter earnings by 14 per cent and held half-year profits to the level of the period a year ago, according to the mid-year report issued yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- The Tokyo Stock Exchange, buoyed by the Government's announcement last week of new measures to spur the nation's sagging economy, continued today its most pronounced rally of a discouraging year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 2 -- An Afrikaans minister read himself out of the clergy of the principal Dutch Reformed Church in South Africa today by taking a post with a group that believes the answer to the country's racial problems can be found in the Biblical injunction to seek justice.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Massachusetts House killed a proposal today to exempt physicians and pharmacists from most provisions of the state law barring dissemination of birth control devices and information.
MIAMI, Aug. 2 -- The Florida East Coast Railway, plagued by strikes and sabotage, began carrying passengers today for the first time in 30 months.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- The American Motors Corporation, afflicted with lagging business while the automobile industry is enjoying record prosperity, slashed its dividend in half today to 12.5 cents a share.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- Expenditures in the Vietnam war effort, even if relatively modest, were viewed today as perhaps preventing a business lag in 1966 and possibly even resulting in a little pickup.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- In a move to stop the rising highway death rate, the House approved today legislation to require that every state have a traffic safety program by 1968 or lose Federal road-building money.
MIAMI, Aug. 2 -- An experiment began today to determine the feasibility of pumping water from Florida's largest lake to alleviate drought conditions in the Everglades National Park.
Mary Martin will appear in a two-character musical, "The Fourposter," based on Jan de Hartog's successful comedy, during the 1966-67 season.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The store buyers loved Yves Saint Laurent today as they have never loved him before They said his new fall collection was his best. The press win see it Friday.
William Z. Cline has been named executive vice president of the Foundation for Modern Art, the fund-raising arm of the Gallery of Modern Art. Mr. Cline was also named controller of the gallery.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday it would place all its foreign petroleum operations under a single management to be provided by an expanded Mobil International Oil Company division.

ATHENS, Aug. 2 -- In a weary, sometimes faltering voice, Premier George Athanasiadis-Novas asked the Greek Parliament tonight for a vote of confidence while a crowd of several thousand outside shouted for his downfall.

The Upjohn Company announced yesterday a reduction of 10 per cent in the price to pharmacies of its oral antidiabetes agent, Orinase. The cut, effective at once, was the third such reduction to retailers by the company since it introduced the product in 1957.

THIRTEEN months ago, Stephen Shadegg, regional director for the Western states in Barry Goldwater's 1964 Presidential drive, published a controversial book called "How to Win an Election." His new book is a kind of sequel to that manual because its title could have been "How to Lose an Election."
An East Harlem youth, who portrayed an East Harlem hoodlum in a film dealing with gang warfare, was charged yesterday with the fatal stabbing of a 16-year-old boy during a melee on a door stoop.

HOUSTON, Aug. 2 -- The Alley Theater of Houston tonight unveiled models of its new home, an architectural marriage of the modern and the medieval, containing a classic proscenium stage and an arena theater.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 2 -The executive committee of Mississippi's American Legion called yesterday for a Federal investigation of a Mississippi Freedom Democratic party newsletter urging Negroes to defy the military draft.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Edward Heath, new leader of the Conservative Opposition, and Prime Minister Wilson clashed angrily tonight in the final minutes of debate on a Tory motion of no confidence.

LOMZA, Poland, Aug. 2 -- The wall of Lomza is simple and gray, neither handsome nor historic. Nominally, it borders property of the Roman Catholic Church along a main square of this town, but now more than anything else it marks the division between church and state in Poland.
Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor asserted yesterday that "a healthy United States Merchant Marine can make substantial contributions in solving our balance of payments problem."
The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation, restaurant operator and food producer, announced yesterday the election of Carl F. Nitto as a vice president and a director.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Senate agreed today to hold a round of preliminary voting Wednesday on a constititional amendment on legislative reapportionment. Opponents of the measure left the way open, however to stave off a showdown.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 -- Liberation radio, the clandestine transmitter of the Vietcong, regularly tells guerrilla insurgents that most of the American people support their struggle.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- President Johnson spent the day at his LBJ Ranch today, winding up a Texas weekend with telephone conferenccs, a ride on the range and a cruise on the lake that bers his name. He left tonight to fly back to the capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -Representative Gerald R. Ford, House minority leader, said today that President Johnson's criticism of "one of the prominent members" of the Republican party was "the possible result of a misunderstanding."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Cyprus sent a complaint to the Security Council today accusing Turkey of meddling in the island's internal affairs and threatening its territory.

BERLIN Aug. 2 -- East Germany called on the Western powers today to pull out of West Berlin, the last area of Allied control, at a ceremony marking the 20th anniversary of the signing of the Potsdam declaration.
RICHMOND, Aug. 2 -- A Virginia educational television station has canceled a controversial documentary film on the John Birch Society.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A picture of John Fitzgerald Kennedy as a hot-tempered, demanding boss, impulsive, forgetful of belongings, careless about money, has been drawn by his secretary.
A new three-year labor agreement providing 27 cents an hour in wage increases for 12.000 painters was announced yesterday by the Association of Master Painters and Decorators of the City of New York.

The coincidence of a crisis in Greece and a move by President Makarios of Cyprus to destroy the electoral provisions of the 1960 Treaty of Guarantee is too convenient to be accidental. So now there is still another Cypriote crisis for the United Nations Security Council to take up today.

" Our Private World," the Columbia Broadcasting System's first evening television soap opera, will be discontinued Sept. 10. As ratings go, it failed to bring happiness to C.B.S. and the sponsor, the Procter Gamble Company.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 2 -- Yale University emerged here today as the school that precipitated an inquiry that resulted in the suspension of a principal of a high school where marks of 162 students reportedly had been raised to help get them into college.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 3 -- Thirty B-52 bombers from Guam struck yesterday at suspected Vietcong installations in central Vietnam's Quangtin Province about 350 miles northeast of Saigon.

CHANSON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A loudspeaker warning to clear out went unheeded and United States Marines and Vietnamese troops found a woman and two children among 25 persons they killed in an assault that overran this Vietcong-dominated village today.
The office of the Controller of the Currency disclosed yesterday that preliminary approval had been given to the Chase Manhattan Bank to convert to a national bank from a state chartered bank.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Two persons were killed and at least 10 were injured in a wind-driven forest fire that seared a 20,000-acre area of the French Riviera last night and early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance disclosed today plans to speed training and increase combat power of certain Army Reserve units in case "a call-up of reserves should become necessary."

The Zenith Radio Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings in the second quarter and first six months this year in its history, Joseph S. Wright, president of the Chicago-based company, announced yesterday. He also noted that sales for the six months were the best for any half-year period.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals rehired Red Schoendienst today as manager, ending reports that he would be replaced.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 2 -Negro leaders from Southern communities already visited by the militant civil rights movement -- places like Birmingham and Selma, Ala., and Albany, Ga. -- are now asking the National Urban League for help in obtaining lasting change, the league's director said today.

Several nursing homes once closed as "houses of horror" have "slipped away" from the city's new Hospital Code by reopening as residential hotels for the elderly, a Senate subcommittee was told yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Delaware River and Bay Authority levied a $2,00-a-day fine today on the contracting syndicate building the piers for the new Delaware Memorial Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk today gave the back of his hand -- diplomatically but with a noticeable chop -- to Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., who had written that he had an "irrevocably conventional" mind and that he had been marked for dismissal by President Kennedy.
Directors of the Standard Products Company are planning to make a tender offer to its shareholders in an attempt to block the American Steel and Pump Company from acquiring a 54 per cent control.
The operations of Zim Israel Navigation Company's fleet of 63 vessels will be divided between two companies, Nathan Hacohen, vice president for passenger operations, said yesterday.
Companies that doubt the determination of a woman ought to talk to Mrs. Robert F. Sanders of Costa Mesa, Calif.
Your July 27 obituary on Eugene Burdick unfortunately prolongs a misinterpretation of "the ugly American" which has gained acceptance in recent years.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Eugene Scott of St. James L.I., the winner here two years ago, gained the second round of the Nassau Bowl invitation grass court tennis tournament today with an easy victory over Jim Stephens of Riverside, Conn.
TOKYO, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- North Vietnam tonight ruled out any United Nations intervention in the Vietnamese war. It said the United States must first stop sending troops to Vietnam.

IN regular rubber bridge, game contracts in minor suits are rare. It is nearly always easier to make nine tricks in no-trump than to make 11 tricks in clubs or diamonds, so less than one game contract in 10 is properly played in a minor.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The month-long National rifle and pistol matches started today at this Lake Erie military base as more than 2,000 of the nation's best pistol marksmen went to the firing line to compete for national individual and team honors.
PARIS, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- The Bank of France repeated today the French call for an examination of the international monetary situation.
Leading police officials from all parts of the country sat down here yesterday at a forum to get "criticized very frankly" on their role in the civil rights movement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A union official, posing the possibility of a new rail crisis, asked a Senate group today to force talks with railroads on the use of firemen in locomotives.
American law-enforcement officials said yesterday they would follow any leads to criminals in this country resulting from the arrests of Mafia leaders announced by the police in Italy.

The Board of Education will seek to recruit, retrain and place in the city's public schools 500 experienced Negro teachers who have lost their jobs as a result of desegregation of schools in the South.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -The police arrested about 65 integrationists tonight who marched to Mayor Richard J. Daley's home on Chicago's South Side protesting school policies.
Some unusual ideas in merchandising are expected to prove a boon to makers of notions this year.
Dull was the word for yesterday's trading on the American Stock Exchange. Volume fell below the million-share level and the trend of issues was anything but inspiring.

Holders of more than 2 million shares of the Lone Star Steel Company's 3.9 million shares of common stock have tendered their stock for purchase by the Philadelphia Reading Corporation at $22 a share.
United States steel production inched up two-tenths of 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A bus and three cars collided on Route 46 during the rush-hour today, hospitalizing four persons and stalling traffic for an hour.

" Call Me Neighbor, Call Me Friend," by Philip A. Johnson, which Doubleday will publish on Aug. 20, is a history of racial integration in a Chicago suburb. The author took over the pastorate of the Salem Lutheran Church in 1949. Two days later a Negro family bought a house in this all-white, lower-income suburb and riots broke out.
BONN, Aug. 21 -- A spokesman for the United States Army in Europe acknowledged today that the Army had started to transfer troops from West Germany to Vietnam on a "volunteer" basis.

The Roman Catholic weekly review America, edited by Jesuits, has applauded the appointment of Arthur J. Goldberg as chief United States representative at the United Nations.
The Art Dealers Association of America is ready to test in the courts the legality of the city's controversial new regulation requiring the price-tagging of all items sold at retail.
A series of 12 panels, debates and seminars will be offered to the public at the third New York Film Festival at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

On July 26 President Johnson established a National Crime Commission to study every aspect of crime in the United States, with the ultimate purpose of preventing crime and increasing respect for the law. [Editorial July 27.]

The Citizens Union gave its support yesterday to the $350 million World Trade Center planned for Manhattan's lower West Side.

DENVILLE, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Mark A. Porter of Riverton the defending champion and the tournament medalist, led the way today into the quarter-final round of the 40th annual women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship at the Rockaway River Country Club.
A proposal to create a Federal Water Commission, comparable in its powers to the Federal Power Commission, has been put before Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen said today that Vice President Humphrey had been lobbying against his legislative reapportionment amendment. He disclosed he had asked President Johnson to ask Mr. Humphrey to stop it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- President Johnson received an award today as a "profound speaker and champion of free speech" and then proceeded to demonstrate his prowess at considerable length.
The new-car sales boom is continuing to roll on.

Vinnie Smith, the first-base umpire, became a casualty in the fourth inning when he twisted his left knee and had to be carried from the field on a stretcher. He will be on crutches j 24 hours. The other umpires[ muddled through by some shifting to cover the "action" bases,

HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- Both Peking and Hanoi are maintaining public positions of inflexible opposition to negotiations on Vietnam despite new peace moves under the aegis of the United Nations and a number of nonaligned nations.

The Transit Authority received yesterday a single bid of $56,464,038, more than double the original cost estimate, for construction of the controversial Manhattan-Queens subway tunnel under the East River.

An ingenious California engineer has proposed building a high-speed pneumatic subway that would take passengers from Boston to Washington in an hour-and-a-half. He also suggests a similar New York metropolitan transport network that would get commuters to White Plains in twelve minutes and to Staten Island in seven minutes.
The leasehold on the 25-story office tower at 1350 Broadway, at 35th Street opposite Macy's, has been purchased by the real estate partnership of Lawrence A. Wien and Harry B. Helmsley.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led 5,000 chanting and singing demonstrators tonight to protest the segregated policies of Girard College.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers made eight hits and nine runs in the fifth inning tonight to overcome a four-run deficit and rout the Cleveland Indians, 12-7.
Sterling advanced yesterday on foreign exchange markets here despite the British Government's announcement of a sharp drop in its gold and currency reserves in July.

PALISADES PARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- William J. Dorgan, Republican who was defeated by four votes as incumbent Mayor last November, was returned to his post today by more than 200 votes in a special election.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Roy Emerson and Chuck McKinley, two of the famous names in amateur tennis, made their debuts in the Nassau Bowl grass-court tournament today and advanced to the third round in somewhat relaxed fashion at the Nassau Country Club.

GREENSBORO, Ala., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Less than half of the 93 Negroes who have taken Alabama's new simplified voting test here made a passing mark, the chairman of the Hale County Board of Registrars said today.
A boy who appeared to be about 11 years old robbed a Bronx cab driver of $24 early yesterday morning as an accomplice, about 25, held a knife to the driver's neck, the police reported.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Jacqueline Goldberg, 20 years old, the original leader of the controversial free speech movement on the University of California campus, was praised today in Municipal Court by the university officer who, in effect, had suspended her.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The International Federation of Business and Professional Women refused today to take a stand on trade boycotts for political purposes asked by South African delegates.
WHO starts all those fashion fads that are supposed to be rampant in American colleges?
Amateur boatmen who would like to navigate something a little different will have a chance to bid for two city ferryboats, each capable of carrying more than 2,300 passengers.

Vernon Law, the 35-year-old elder of the Mormon Church, part-time Idaho banker, and full-time tormenter of the New York Mets, pitched his third straight shutout against the Mets last night for the Pittsburgh Pirates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- A high-level delegation including members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and a White House aide will leave Thursday for Brazil to discuss United States-Brazilian relations, the State Department announced today.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Margaret Smith of Australia, a winner in three divisions of the Baden-Baden tennis tournament last week, began the defense of her women's title in the German international championships today by defeating Pare Diepraam of South Africa, 6-1, 6-0.

THE first stage of the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile international rally was completed yesterday, with a run from the Westchester County Airport near White Plains to Stowe, Vt. Today the field of more than 50 cars is proceeding to Mont Gabriel, about 40 miles northwest of Montreal in the province of Quebec.
Playboy Clubs International has bought 400 acres near Lake Geneva, Wis., for construction of a $5 million resort that will include a 150-room hotel with dining rooms and showrooms for conventions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Former Gov. Stephen L.R. McNichols of Colorado testified today he had been the target of smear tactics aimed at stopping his cooperation in Federal investigations of the officials of a closed bank.
YONKERS, Aug. 3 -- After four consecutive programs of minus pools at Yonkers Raceway, the string of deficits was snapped tonight.

The management of Allied Mills, Inc., has mailed a letter to its stockholders stating it would recommend neither acceptance nor rejection of a tender offer made by Continental Grain Company last week for 413,000 shares of Allied Mills' stock.

TO the untutored eye, those $30 seersucker whatchamacallits in Henri Bendel's windows look like grim grannies' bathrobes. In fact, they're just one more bit of evidence that North Africa is the newest site of interest on the fashion map.
A $3.6 million program to transform 36 shabby brownstones on the West Side into an unusual low-income housing development will begin today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor confirmed today that the United States showed a surplus in its international payments in the second quarter of this year, but he cited several influences that might unbalance the nation's foreign accounts for the rest of the year.

AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 3 -- A group of 12 white housewives and business leaders charged publicly today that name-calling and intimidation within the white community was blocking efforts to negotiate a peace with Americus Negroes.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 -- Murray Stein, a husky, bespectacled, gimlet-eyed man with a flashing grin and a hardy Brooklyn accent, is a leader of the Federal Government's campaign against contamination of the nation's waterways. He is also one of the nation's notable diplomats-without-portfolio.
MARION, Mass., Aug. 3 -- Today was a day of no competition for the sailing squadron of the New York Yacht Club cruise, but the powerboat division engaged in a predicted log race on Buzzards Bay.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Turkey accused the Government of Cyprus today of having produced an "explosive" situation on the island by taking a series of steps toward union with Greece in violation of the Constitution.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 3 -- The New York Giants hit with drive and dedication for 60 minutes this morning, but it proved to be one of those drills that exasperate a coach. No one looked very good and the concerned coach, Al Sherman, said: "This outfit has got to begin to shape up, to operate like a team. We've got a long way to go."

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- One fat pitch in the fourth inning cost Mel Stottlemyre and the New York Yankees the ball game in the opener of a three-game series against the Chicago White Sox in Comiskey Park tonight. The final score was 3 to 2, a fact that delighted most of the 25,570 fans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- President Johnson named Charles Mann today as director of the United States aid mission in South Vietnam. He will replace James S. Killen Jr.
The London Stock Exchange continued firm in quiet trading yesterday, despite another sharp drop in Britain's gold and hard currency reserves during July.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Harold F. Johnson, the retired international lawyer and economic adviser who gave $6 million to start a new college in Massachusetts, is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Amherst.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 3 -- Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. ruled today that persons who engaged in civil disobedience while demonstrating for civil rights did not have immunity from arrest and punishment by local authorities.

The Southern Counties Gas Company of California, a subsidiary of the Pacific Lighting Corporation, awarded $40 million of first mortgage bonds yesterday to a syndicate managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
When Dr. Martha J.B. Thomas, 39-year-old chemist and holder of 7 patents, went to Detroit a few weeks ago to receive an award as the "Woman Engineer of the Year," three little girls clapped loudly.

A midtown travel agent was arrested on charges of grand larceny yesterday in connection with the sale of airline tickets to Europe.
An administrative aide to Representative Adam Clayton Powell who was a campaign worker for President Kennedy was named yesterday as campaign director of Puerto Ricans-for-Lindsay.
The public got its first look at the heat-scarred Gemini 4 yesterday, when the spacecraft arrived at the World's Fair.
COWES, England, Aug. 3 -- The Australian have done it again Caprice of Huon, captained by Gordon Ingate, won the Britannia Cup today on the second leg of the Admiral's Cup contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance told Congress today that it would be "detrimental to the national security" not to go ahead with the Pentagon's plan to merge the Army Reserves into the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Administration seems to be settling down for a long war in Vietnam. Neither the fears of military disaster nor the hopes of a negotiated peace are as prevalent now as they were in June.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Near the head of the stretch, early arrivals were happily setting up shop on the grass at white tables under green-striped aluminum umbrellas that cost Monmouth Park $99.50 apiece.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 3 -- Eight months after receiving notice that its days were numbered, the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard is in the market for skilled help.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Legislation that would largely immunize stock exchanges against antitrust prosecution was suggested to Congress today by the Securities an Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The House gave final approval today to the voting rights bill and sent it to the Senate. The vote was 328 to 74.
Paul R. Screvane, candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, named two Reform Democrats yesterday to run on his slate for nominations in the Bronx.

" Paris Journal 1944-1965," by Janet Flanner, will be published by Atheneum on Nov. 8. Miss Flanner is known for her letters from Paris to The New Yorker over the signature "Genet." William Shawn, the editor of the magazine, has selected some of these to form this book.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The chairman of the Rutgers University board of governors said today he would not censure or dismiss Prof. Eugene Genovese, who describes himself as a Marxist and Socialist.
BONN, Aug. 3 -- Willy Brandt, said today that if he became Chancellor of West Germany next month, he would promptly start a "dialogue" with the Soviet Union on a German peace settlement.
Two issues of gas company bonds totaling $45 million were offered to investors yesterday, both at a yield of 4.70 per cent. By late afternoon, an estimated $33 million of bonds remained unsold.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- With only one dissenting vote, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a long-delayed consular treaty with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A major advance that may reverse the present slowdown in economic development aid to underdeveloped areas was observed by officials today in several little-noted decisions of the 14 leading donor nations.
While Wall Street analysts ponder the course of the stock market, a number of large brokerage houses are on the move to enlarge their office facilities in major cities.

Alexander's new nine-level store, soon to be opened at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue, will have its 200-car parking garage run by a division of the Hertz Corporation, a competitor in the car rental field.

Details of a proposed $19 million Hunter College Graduate Center were announced yesterday by Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane. The 16-story structure, an addition to Hunter College, will rise on a site at 904 Lexington Avenue.

A number of major performers were announced yesterday for forthcoming shows. Eddie Bracken will return to Broadway in the musical comedy, "Hot September." Coral Browne who appeared in the London production of "The Right Honourable Gentleman," will do the same part here.
MADRAS, India, Aug. 2 -- From 8:30 A.M.to 5:30 P.M. every weekday Balakrishna Sastri pores over the inked figures in the account books of the State Bank of India.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Ambassador Harriman met with Prime Minister Wilson for half an hour today before leaving for the United States.
The Big Board looked like a school blackboard yesterday: fractions everywhere. From a price standpoint it was easily one of the most inconclusive sessions on record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- A "dramatic upward shift in income distribution" by 1975 will mean that almost one out of every three customers shopping in a furniture store will represent a family with an income of $10,000 or more a year.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Two men prominent in this resort area died tonight when one shot the other then turned the gun on himself, the police said.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday two grants totaling $216,000 for the study of Federal and private antipoverty campaigns.

The strike against leading shiplines ended its seventh week yesterday in an atmosphere of deepening gloom.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 -- The possibility of legal skirmishing between the State of New York and the Federal Government arose today as the Department of Health, Education and Welfare opened formal proceedings to abate the contamination of Lake Erie.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Civil rights demonstrators, determined to continue marches on Mayor Richard J. Daley's home, appealed today for Justice Department protection.

A new architectural partnership to be known as Diamond-Sanko has been formed by Harold E. Diamond and Alex Sanko. The firm will have offices at 36 Richmond Terrace, Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Consumer installment credit showed another substantial increase in June, but the growth rate was smaller than earlier this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WARSAW, Aug. 3 -- Fiat, the Italian auto maker, is quietly blanketing the car market in Eastern Europe, such as it is.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 4 -- The United States Marine Corps commander in South Vietnam said today that he was deeply grieved by the deaths of four children and a woman during a marine attack Monday on a village controlled by the Vietcong.
The end of a huge construction tower that has meant three years of noise, dirt and bedlam to residents along 13th Street and Avenue of the Americas, was welcomed yesterday.

THE most select pair tournament in the world is undoubtedly the Tournament of Champions held each summer in Deauville, France. The organizers take great pains to obtain the strongest possible eight pairs. This year the field included five world champions and five former world champions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Last January President Johnson put a moratorium on Federal purchases of new file cabinets and ordered a reduction in purchases of new office furniture and typewriters.

It is too bad that the common law did not develop a protection of confidential communications between the head of state and his inner circle confidants. In the doctor-patient, lawyer-client and priest-penitent relationship there is a secrecy surrounding the expressions of doubt and worry.

Three leading private New England colleges and a state university announced yesterday that they would join in the creation of a new coeducational liberal arts college in western Massachusetts made possible by a $6 million gift from a single donor.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 3 -- Some of the leading exponents of modern dance in the country have converged on this town under Pike's Peak to pay tribute to the woman who taught and inspired them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Defense Department has sharply increased its draft quotas for September and October as a result of President Johnson's decision to send 50,000 more troops to South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today a bill to establish the Herbert Hoover national historical site in West Branch, Iowa, as part of the national park system.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Mary Wilson, 15-year-old high school girl from Rome, N.Y., who stowed away on the Queen Elizabeth to visit the graves of her English ancestors, had her dreams shattered today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The House Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 27 to 4, reported out today a bill providing for major reforms in the nation's immigration laws.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- President Johnson, acting on a complaint from Roy Wilkins, today ordered Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara to determine why so few Negroes attend the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md.

ALLENDALE, S.C., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A Federal Government representative posted bond today for 37 civil rights demonstrators arrested in the Allendale County Courthouse while protesting voter registration practices yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, said today that "impeachment" talk was stemming from President Johnson's prosecution of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Johnson declared today that those who advocate either all-out war in Vietnam or total withdrawal are equally misguided and equally insensitive to the United States' role in Southeast Asia.
North American Life and Casualty Company achieved new highs in most categories of its operations during the six months ended June 30.
" Candide," the comic operetta version of Voltaire's satire, by Leonard Bernstein and Lillian Hellman, may be revived by the New York City Opera.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- "Score one for Mr. Wilson." This was the general judgment today on the clash in Parliament last night between Edward Heath, the new leader of the Conservative Opposition, and Prime Minister Wilson.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 -- The forthcoming visit of a high-level Washington mission here raised strong diplomatic speculation that President Johnson was studying a trip to Brazil to renew the United States commitment to the Alliance for Progress.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 -- A United States mili-i tary spokesman confirmed to-: day that United States para-] troopers from the 173d kirbomel Brigade, operating in Phuoctuy Province last Sunday, had fired! accidentally upon Vietnamese Government troops.

A 39-year-old woman ended a five-day hunger strike at the United States Line's Pier 76 yesterday after she was assured that a union picket line would be lifted today so that her works of art could be taken from a ship.

CAIRO, Aug. 3 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser, acting on a suggestion by the leaders of Yugoslavia and India, has started quiet, informal soundings of Communist China and North Vietnam on the prospects for peace negotiations in the Vietnamese war, informed sources disclosed today.
" People sweep things up and send the pieces to us," Mrs. Joseph Ternbach said the other day as she and her husband showed before and after photographs of restored works of art.

NAHA, Okmawa, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A United States Army general court-martial trying Capt. Sanford Wolfson of Plainfield, N.J., ruled today that there was no evidence the doctor feigned mental illness last January to avoid performing his duties at an Army hospital in South Vietnam.

The Chesapeake Ohio and the Baltimore Ohio railroads' plans for exercising control over the Western Maryland Railway were endorsed yesterday by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner in Washington. The full commission must give its approval before the ruling can become effective.

The Metropolitan Opera, with an ear to plane traffic over Lewisohn Stadium, has been enticing airline pilots to the Met's summer concerts at the stadium. The purpose is to have pilots experience for themselves the distraction caused by passing planes, as well as to have them enjoy the opera.

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen seems determined to confront the country with a new crisis in the featherbedding dispute that forced Congress in 1963 to pass the first compulsory arbitration law in the nation's labor history. The arbitration panel decided that 90 per cent of the firemen's jobs in diesel engines were unneeded and ordered their gradual elimination under a plan geared to protecting the displaced workers against hardship.
Selling in the last hour and a half wiped out most gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and weakened the list in quiet trading.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Brilliant Dunce and Michael J. Toppa, 2-year-old colts with unimpressive credentials, were listed today as probable starters in Saturday's $100,000-guaranteed Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Leo Cardenas's throwing error with the bases loaded in the 11th inning paved the way for a four-run inning for the San Francisco Giants and a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 3 -- Master Bernard Zuckerman of New York, by defeating Grand Master William Lombardy of New York in the eighth round of the United States Open Chess Championship last night, assumed the lead in the 163-man field.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has elected Nicholas E. Mezey, James T. Phillips Jr. and John Reis Jr. as vice presidents, it was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Gates, chairman.

A high-level mission representing the Government of Uruguay will meet today with a number of leading commercial banks here in an effort either to settle or recast an estimated $50 million of Uruguayan debt.

ATHENS -- It is no coincidence that another crisis is developing in Cyprus just while Greece is tormented by acute political agony. The Greek Cypriote community and mainland Greece are intimately linked. In fact, the left-wing officers' conspiracy whose existence exploded the trouble here was first uncovered among Greek forces in Cyprus.

BAOTRAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 -- In recent days in Haunghia Province there have been popular demonstrations against both Vietcong terror and artillery fire by forces of the South Vietnamese Government.
A Brooklyn tattoo artist was charged yesterday with violating a Health Department ban against the ancient practice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Johnson asked Congress today for $1.7 billion in extra defense appropriations to strengthen United States military power in the war in Vietnam.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Fifty persons who were arrested during a voting-registration protest yesterday, including 11 who were identified as Columbia University students, were freed on $200 bail each today.

Ron Hunt will end 84 days on the disabled list today and rejoin the New York Mets, who have been disabled even longer than that and who suffered their second straight shutout at the hands of the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday. The score yesterday was 3-0.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The eight delegations of the nonaligned and neutral powers at the disarmament conference met today but carefully avoided becoming involved in what they considered primarily a United States-Soviet problem.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Twice as Gay, one of the better 3-year-olds of last season, demonstrated at Monmouth Park today that if an amateur handicapper goes back far enough in the past-performance charts, he can often find a winner.

VIENNA, Aug. 4 -- A 23-year-old tractor driver, leaving his machine behind, and a 27-year-old railway engineer, bringing his locomotive with him, were reported today to have escaped from Hungary into Austria. The locomotive was returned to Hungary later in the day.

The World Bank has approved a loan equivalent to $15 million to the Port of Singapore Authority to cover foreign exchange costs in expanding the Malaysian port. The project consists of construction of four additional deep-water berths and other facilities.
It was a day full of welcome at the World's Fair yesterday.
A patrolman shot and captured a suspected burglar in Ozone Park, Queens, early yesterday morning after the suspect attempted to run him down with his car, the police reported.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 -- The prospect of arresting the degeneration of Lake Erie within eight years gained substance today as representatives of five states discussed the diverse problems of the lake's pollution.

MONT GABRIEL, Que., Aug. 4 -- Gail and Richard Plunkett of Centerport, L.I., won the first stage of the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile international rally in their British-made Triumph. So they were in the forefront of a field of 50 cars that made the run from Stowe, Vt., to this magnificent mountain top today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- New York State's total farm income for the first five months of this year increased $19 million compared with a similar period last year.
Five securities dealers, a trader, three salesmen and two brokerage houses were accused yesterday of having conspired to carry out a fraud that cost 200 investors $400,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The Association of American Physicians and Surgeons urged its 16,500 members today not to cooperate in the Federal Government's Medicare program.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Syphilis among teen-agers has risen 230 per cent since 1956, the United States Communicable Disease Center reported today. It appealed for an intensified fight against the disease.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Johnson greeted thousands of college students on the south lawn of the White House today and tried to persuade them that he was as young in spirit, if not in years, as they.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- "Mr. Buckley, why are you running for mayor of New York?"

SAIGON, Thursday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Vietcong commandos, blasting their way into a jet-fuel storage complex near the Danang base during the night, destroyed an estimated million gallons of fuel destined for bombing missions against the Communists.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- A nurse accused of killing a Roman Catholic priest wrote letters to Pope Paul VI and a Cardinal complaining she had been "tormented by Catholics and their collaborators" for four years, a witness at her preliminary hearing said today.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Every weekday morning since July 16 residents of this community have been picketing the Urban Renewal office here to protest living conditions in the 36-acre West End urban renewal area.
The Amerada Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of 1965 a record net income of $28,602,210, or $2.24 a share. Gross operating income was $101,262,247.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Joseph P. Kennedy "played neither so large a role in his son's undertakings as he sometimes liked to claim, nor so small a role as he sometimes preferred to pretend," according to a close aide of John F. Kennedy.

COWES, England, Aug. 4 -- Sixty-five yachts are expected to take part in the New York Yacht Club Race tomorrow. This is the third of the four races that count toward the Admiral's Cup point total -- in which Britain has a commanding lead, with Australia second, the Netherlands third and the United States fourth.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Brooks Robinson doubled home two runs and Jerry Adair drove in the deciding run tonight in the eighth inning as the Baltimore Orioles scored a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Angels in the first game of a double-header.
The National Distillers Company will celebrate Bourbon Month in September by taking a mild swipe at competitors.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- A pure shipper and an experienced New York campaigner shared the honors in the Schuylerville Stakes today. JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 4 -- A commission of inquiry has found "dangerous implications" in a year-old experiment that permitted the upgrading of black workers in South African gold mines.
The London stock market took on a distinctly brighter appearance yesterday after a cautious start when sentiment was still affected by the depressing July reserves report.

YONKERS, Aug. 4 -- This season's crop of 2-year-old pacing colts apparently is loaded with potential champions. It would not be surprising if they took turns beating one another as the campaign progresses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Dutch passenger-freighter Friesland, struck yesterday by its Pakistani crew of 40, remained at berth today as negotiators argued wearily in three languages.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4 -- Saudi Arabia has massed 5,000 national guardsmen and an unspecified number of her regular army troops along her border with Yemen to face a threat of attack by Egyptian troops in Yemen, reports from Jidda said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, held out little hope today that the Soviet Union would use its influence to persuade North Vietnam to seek a negotiated settlement of the Vietnamese war.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. (AP) -- The Department of Justice filed an antitrust suit in United States district court here today to block a proposed merger of Pennzoil Company and Kendall Refining Company, two major producers of Pennsylvania crude oil.

A crate of discarded automobile radiators, manifolds and oil pans, tractor seats, broken rake heads and other bits of steel scrap welded into works of art were unloaded from the strikebound freighter American Ranger yesterday.

How inadequate enforcement can repeal traffic reform is painfully reflected in the demise of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes's admirable plan to speed up crosstown travel in mid-Manhattan. TRENTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court extended the theory of implied warranty to the automobile rental business today.

The books and records of the producers of Barbra Streisand's concert Sunday at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium were turned over yesterday to License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo. Brazil, Ecuador, Nicaragua and Chile will be the beneficiaries of investments totaling $5.75 million approved yesterday by Adela, an international private investment organization.

Attorney General Nicholas de B. Katzenbach recently sounded an enlightened and encouraging note before a Senate subcommittee when he called for a more humane and effective alternative to the prevailing practice of jailing inebriates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Ignoring Nazi pickets and bomb threats, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. moved into Washington's ghettoes today and told crowds of his admirers that economic freedom was the new cry of the civil rights movement.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., in a report filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday, disclosed its net earnings from operations in the six months to June 30, plummeted to $2,225,000, or 16 cents a share, from $10,849,000, or 79 cents a share in the first half of 1964.
A slim young Scot will open the John Stephen boutique next Thursday in Dayton's Minneapolis -- if he ever gets there.

Three oratorios by Handel will be given by the Amor Artis Chorale in its 1965-66 series at Town Hall. One of them, "Susanna," is listed by the chorale as a first New York performance. The others are "Semele" and "Esther."
President Johnson has named George E. Reedy as a special White House trouble-shooter in the 50-day strike of officers in the merchant marine.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Fifty tenants of a luxury East Side apartment house who sought to invoke the recently enacted rent strike law reached an agreement outside of court with their landlord yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Frank Sinatra and lfia Farrow, a 19-year-old actress, sailed today aboard a chartered 168-foot yacht amid rumors that they intend to marry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Philco Corporation has been approached by Indonesia to supply three transmitters worth $3 million, according to United States officials here.

Sales and earnings of the General Aniline Film Corporation in the first six months this year were the highest for any half-year period. Jesse Werner, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Doctors are agreed on the value of a long vacation from the tensions of American life provided the body is taken to a compression clinic for a thorough checkup immediately after the return home.

United Artists and the Columbia Broadcasting System plan to develop a television drama series from the film "Lilies of the Field." A Negro would be the star, as in the 1963 movie.
