Sugar traders kept their eyes on Syria yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Cristobal Balenciaga could be compared -- although the image is hardly elegant enough for the grandest figure in the French haute couture -- to a mountain goat who keeps on leaping. He never trips and he never stops.
A 39-year-old house detective at the New York Hilton was arrested early yesterday as the leader of a gang that had extorted a total of $100,000 from "rich playboys and executives."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Dick Stuart drove in four runs, two on his 19th homer, as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs tonight, 7-2.

OXFORD, England, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Patricia Neal, who suffered three near-fatal strokes in February, gave birth to a 6-pound 7-ounce daughter today and was virtually overwhelmed with messages applauding her courage.
AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 4 -- An informal biracial committee began meeting here tonight, without city or county authorization, in an attempt to end the city's racial crisis.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- President de Gaulle's 23-month-old anti-inflation plan has worked well but French predictions of a coming "spontaneous" economic ursurge appear optimistic, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development asserted today.

A grand jury investigation into an alleged plot to shake down a Cosa Nostra racketeer widened yesterday on the basis of a newly discovered list left by a former convict and informer who predicted his own death at the hands of a law-enforcement officer.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Loyo Mayo, the youthful spare member of the Mexican Davis Cup team, offered enough of a challenge for the first set to Roy Emerson of Australia in the Nassau Bowl invitation tennis tournament today to warrant the belief that he would be representing his country in the international matches in the near future.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 4 -- Premier Moise Tshombe said today that his differences with President Joseph Kasavubu had been "exaggerated by the press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities said today authorities should take firm steps to prevent peace and civil rights demonstrators from entering the White House and the Capitol this Weekend.

A founder of the National Repertory Theater has charged that the company has been denied permission to perform "You Can't Take It With You" and "The Skin of Our Teeth," the Pulitzer Prize-winning plays, and other American comedies.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Ministry of Defense called attention today to a certain delicate matter of morale that seemed to be getting out of hand: lonely hearts correspondence between servicemen and girls they have never met.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called today for the elimination of "self-defeating, discriminatory shipping restrictions" on wheat sales to Soviet bloc nations.
New-car sales in July smashed all records.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Somebody messed up the newly laid concrete in a spot just outside the White House offices today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House tonight the Voting Rights Bill of 1965. The vote on final passage was 79 to 18.
A decline of 467,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 4 -- Few men in the 140-year history of Americus have been accepted as quickly and rejected as fast as Warren Candler Fortson. Mr. Fortson, prime mover in the formation today of a biracial committee to try to settle a Negro voting dispute here, is the target of segregationists who want him ousted as Sumter County Attorney.
A slow response from Brooklyn antipoverty groups is forcing the city to delay its first community convention for grass-roots leadership in neighborhood campaigns against poverty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that it had added guards in its main building to prevent sexual attacks on women in offices, halls, stairways and elevators.
Plans are under way for a New York Art Biennial at the New York Coliseum starting in 1967.
MRS. LYNDON B. JOHNSON, who professes no desire to be known as a fashion leader and who swears her dressmakers to secrecy, may yet become one.
STOWE, Vt., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Eight Trapp Family Singers were reunited on stage tonight for the first time in a decade. Two of the original members were unable to be present.
Activity in the stock market quickened yesterday as many Wall Street analysts saw new inflationary tendencies stirring in the economy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate defeated tonight a proposed constitutional amendment to permit one house of a bicameral state legislature to be apportioned on bases other than population.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- There were jitters, wild rumors and unsettled markets in the London financial district today following the huge gold loss reported yesterday by the treasury.

A middle-aged couple, their children grown and married, had lots of extra space in their comfortable one-family home. So they decided to do their part for international relations by taking in three foreign students as boarders.
The Fifth Avenue Association charged yesterday that the Transit Authority's proposal to offer bus service on Park Avenue from 46th to 125th Street would "add nothing but chaos."

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which served notice last week that it would not renew its lease with the city for Piers 27, 28 and 29, were fruits and vegetables are received, said yesterday it would continue to make deliveries, but by other methods. The lease expires March 31.
PARIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Carlo Ponti's first wife has become a French citizen, raising the possibility of a solution to the marital tangle of the film producer and Sophia Loren.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Co., closed for five weeks by a strike, reported net profits of $45,133 for the first half of 1965, compared with $89,253 for the first half of 1964.

In the August issue of Grey Matter, just out, Grey Advertising, Inc., questions the motives of a recent proposal by Mrs. Esther Peterson that children be trained in consumer economics in high school or even in junior high.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Government economists now expect the stepped-up efforts in Vietnam to require an increese in defense spending of only $2 billion to $3 billion above last January's budget estimate for the current fiscal year, it was reported on good authority today.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Edward Heath, the newly elected leader of the Conservative party Opposition, announced his shadow cabinet tonight.

Displaying the same power and ball control that brought an easy victory in the first meeting, Polonia Bytom of Poland won the International Soccer League championship last night by beating the New Yorkers, 2-1, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Gabriel (Flash) Elorde of the Philippines won a fight at Madison Square Garden last night and touched off a 20-minute riot by spectators who disagreed with the decision.
GARDINERS ISLAND, N.Y. -- The weather was threatening, but the timing couldn't have been more fortuitous.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell has ignored another legal effort to force him to open his financial records to see whether he can pay the remaining $34,000 he owes a Harlem widow for a defamation judgment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The House passed today a compromise authorization bill for $1.7 billion in military construction. The bill would also give Congress a stronger hand in blocking future shutdowns of military installations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Johnson put squarely into the hands of the State Department today the responsibility for clearing all Government-financed social science research programs conducted abroad.
Government and corporate bond prices declined yesterday, largely on concern over the outlook for the British pound.
The American Steel and Pump Corporation, which has bid for more than 51 per cent stock control of the Standard Products Company, is making another offer to Standard Products stockholders.
Negotiations in the 51-day maritime strike were bogged down yesterday on a single major issue, despite White House intervention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Johnson told the Government today to go ahead with water desalting programs "as if you knew you were going to run out of drinking water in the next six months."

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 5 (UPI) -- George Lincoln Rockwell said yesterday he was dissociating himself from the American Nazi party he heads to run for Governor of Virginia as a candidate of his own White Constitutional party.

AREA A -- Bluefish are scarce, but fluke, striped bass and kingfish are being taken in the surf from Long Branch south. Good-sized mackeral are plentiful in the Brielle area. Head boats around Barnegat Bay are doing well on ling. Tuna are reported 20 miles offshore, along with a few marlin.

The danger of salt water from the ocean sliding into the water supplies of Philadelphia and Camden abated a bit yesterday, but it still remained worrisome. Recent rains have pushed back the tidal salt front in the Delaware River a full mile.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 5 -- A woman motorist who contends her hand was accidentally yanked so violently by a toll collector that she suffered permanent injuries was authorized in state supreme court here today to press a claim by suing the East Hudson Parkway Authority.
Commercial and industrial borrowing from New York City banks rose sharply in the week ended Wednesday, reversing a downward trend that had persisted for four weeks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 6 -- A Vietcong mortar attack that wiped out 40 per cent of a United States petroleum storage depot near the Danang Air Base early yesterday will not hamper United States air strikes, officials said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Representative Ford said tonight that "the honest thing" for President Johnson to do would be to ask Congress to declare war on North Vietnam.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- A high-level United States mission arrived here today for a four-day review of relations with Brazil and the state of inter-American cooperation.

Manufacturing and petroleum companies in the United States expect to increase their overseas capital spending by 18 per cent this year, but many concerns have revised their plans to comply with the Government's program to curb the dollar outflow.

Fifty-nine ships were welcomed on maiden arrivals in the port of New York during the first half of this year. This compared with 42 in the 1964 period, William F. Giesen, general manager of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, noted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The House passed a bill today that would continue until mid-1967 a special tax on capital raised in the United States by foreigners.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The Town of Mount Pleasant, which is fighting Governor Rockefeller's proposed waterfront route for a Hudson River Expressway, authorized a "reexamination" tonight of the zoning of Rockefeller acreage in the town.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- When Bob Gardner, the six-time winner, had to withdraw from the metropolitan amateur golf tournament, it was generally believed that John Baldwin would fall heir to the title.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 -- Significant progress in the nationwide effort to overcome water pollution was registered today.
ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 5 -- Foreign Minister Alex Quaison-Sackey is flying to Washington with a special message on Vietnam from President Kwame Nkrumah to President Johnson.

Apparently acting on out-of-date information, three jewel thieves invaded a Brooklyn home early yesterday and discovered that most of what they expected to find had been taken by burglars seven months ago.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5 -- A United States military spokesman outlined today for the first time some of the combat rules set down for American marines fighting in South Vietnam.
ATHENS, Aug. 5 -- Premier George Athanasiadis-Novas called on King Constantine today and submitted his resignation after his defeat in Parliament early this morning.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 5 -- The Australian, Gordon Ingate, scored another outstanding victory today by winning the New York Yacht Club Cup by 5 minutes 50 seconds on corrected time in his 13-year-old Caprice of Huon.
A small, independent oil lighterage company in New York harbor yesterday flied a $3 million damage suit against Humble Oil and Refining Company Inc., for alleged violations of antitrust laws.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 5 -- A bright idea is making the traditionally wonderful Copenhagen just that little bit more wonderful this year. At least for ballet fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a $1 billion pay increase for the military services. But it made substantial changes in the pattern of the raises set up in a bill already passed by the House.
AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 5 -- A former Georgia legislator, J.W. Sewell, was charged here today with assaulting a civil rights worker.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- A lightly-played daughter of Bold Ruler, the Bohemia Stable's Cestrum, defeated another daughter of the same sire, Queen Empress of the Wheatley Stable, a 7-10 favorite, in one division of the Test Stakes today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A cutback in bank lending to foreigners equaled by itself the entire improvement in the United States international payments position in the second quarter of this year, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Junior Race Week on Manhasset Bay ended on a windless note this morning. After a 1-hour-40-minute postponement, William B. Laub of the host Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, the race chairman, canceled the scheduled competition.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 5 -- The Government of the Sudan and rebels in the south traded new warnings and ultimatums today, formally reopening the prolonged and often vicious hit-and-run war that was never really suspended.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 5 -- The rebellion in the southern Sudan is being kept alive by the interference of outside powers, Premier Mahgoub, declared here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Rich Allen's two-run triple in the fifth inning tonight carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

ANCHORAGE -- Efforts to improve the economies of Alaska and western Canada to their mutual advantage are being pressed by promotional groups on both sides of the boundary. However, they are finding the going tough, despite small signs of headway.

The election of Lester B. Johnson as executive vice president for financial and legal activities was announced yesterday by the Celanese Corporation of America. Mr. Johnson formerly was treasurer of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
LISBON, Aug. 5 -- The Salazar Government has proposed the development of a vast Portuguese-speaking community stretching from mainland Portugal to Brazil and including Portuguese Africa.
The State Supreme Court directed Representative Adam Clayton Powell yesterday to explain why he should not again be cited for contempt for ignoring an order to be examined as a judgment debtor.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax gained his 19th victory tonight striking out 12 and allowing seven hits as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 6-3.
The National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's largest producer of processed packaged foods, is heading toward another record breaking year.

The Concrete Industry Board is accepting entries in its annual award competition for new concrete structures. Submissions from New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties will be accepted until Sept. 1.

You rejected [editorial July 22] the idea of a long-range, off-street parking program, part of which would provide peripheral parking and increase the patronage of mass transit facilities by motorists using the outlying lots and garages.
SAIGON, Aug. 5 -- Americans were working today on emergency measures to replace two million gallons of fuel lost in the Vietcong raid on the Danang storage area.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- A long, arduous, frequently tumultuous session of Parliament came to a close today with many legislative pledges of the Government unfulfilled.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Siegfried Herrmann of East Germany ran the 3,000 meters in 7 minutes, 46 seconds tonight, bettering the pending world record of 7:49 set by Michel Jazy of France five weeks ago.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York proposed yesterday new civilian-controlled machinery to insure full investigation, an impartial hearing and fair disposition of charges of abuse of authority by the police.
Low prices and vast supplies have been plaguing sugar and cocoa producing nations recently. Yesterday, there were developments that pushed sugar futures prices down and cocoa futures up.
Record sales for July were reported yesterday by Sears, Roebuck Co., the J.C. Penney Company and Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., three of the nation's large chain-store and mail-order organizations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A State Department spokesman said tonight that word had been received that Mr. Quaison-Sackey was on his way here, but that it was not known when he would arrive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal Power Commission established today a permanent system for regulating producers of natural gas. The unanimous decision could open the way for lower gas rates and millions of dollars in refunds to consumers.

Igor Cassini, desk-deep in the problems of getting out Status, his "critical journal of elegance," said yesterday: "The greatest difficulties were not with the writers and artists but with all the people who were convinced the magazine would never appear."
The biggest deal in Wall Street yesterday was one that never got off the ground -- a proposed secondary offering of 565,000 shares of Pan American World Airways, Inc.
Federal Bureau of Investigation agents raided a "fast-moving crap game" yesterday on the City of Keansburg, bringing Monmouth racegoers back from Atlantic Highlands to New York.
I was interested in former Judge Florence Shientag's letter published Aug. 4 relative to ill-timed memoirs, and entirely agree with her. [Editorial August 5.]

AT a time in world history when a generation of aged men has been relinquishing political power to younger hands, 77-year-old George Papandreou of Greece is fighting one of the most crucial battles of a remarkable 50-year career.
Sterling for future delivery continued to decline yesterday but the spot rate advanced.

RON SWOBODA leaned out of the New York Mets' clubhouse door in his baseball pants and a T-shirt and tried to get the attention of the nice-looking, blond woman who was standing near the door in Philadelphia's Connie Mack Stadium waiting for her son.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Ensign Roger Staubach of the United States Navy today was designated as the starting quarterback for the College All-Stars against the Cleveland Browns here tomorrow night.
The fight among major contenders for the Democratic nomination for Mayor is being directed from four headquarters that are as dissimilar as their four candidates.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 5 -- Dennis and Sally Ann Koelmel of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., were the over-all leaders today as the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile international rally went through its third stage. The Koelmels had turned in consistently fine scores in their Plymouth Barracuda as they paced the field of more than 40 cars.
The licenses of three real estate men have been suspended by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo for "blockbusting" -- trying to induce panic selling of houses -- in three areas of Queens.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 6 -- A reborn and prosperous Hiroshima today solemnly marked the 20th anniversary of the man-made cataclysm that stamped the town's name indelibly in history.
Command of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, whose skipper died Tuesday on the Atlantic will be assumed tomorrow by Capt. Heinz Vollmers, the company announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- London financial markets continued to act nervously today, with sterling under additional pressure and the price of gold rising to its highest level since November, 1961. Prime Minister Wilson in the strongest terms yet tried to spike rumors of sterling devaluation.
YONKERS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A 17-year-old youth, accompanied by a minister, surrendered to police today to face charges of burglarizing a firearms store. He escaped from custody two days ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Johnson is beginning to make Franklin Roosevelt's early legislative record look like an abject failure. He's getting everything through the Congress but the abolition of the Republican party, and he hasn't tried that yet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Paying tribute to a conservation-minded Congress, President Johnson signed today a bill that authorized a start on a giant irrigation project for North Dakota.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the latest week ended July 31 were both considerably above the corresponding week of 1964. Continued high industrial productivity was the main factor in the improved year-to-year report.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- The star actress in James Baldwin's Negro folklore play "The Amen Corner," has captured the sympathy of the Israeli press -- offstage.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The United States, Britain and France all found fault with the Government of Cyprus today in the Security Council for recent action to suppress constitutional guarantees of the Turkish Cypriote minority.
Stock prices on the London Exchange rallied sharply yesterday in rather active dealings. The advance was influenced by a further rise in the price of gold and rumors of currency devaluation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 5 -- Pal Benko of New York retained the lead in the United States Open Chess Championship by defeating Robert Byrne of Indianapolis in the 10th round at the University of Puerto Rico here last night.

Even in the best of Greek circumstances George Papandreou is a politician who makes little sense as a statesman. Thus the current effort to enshrine him as the savior of Greece lacks only a taxidermist disguised as a sculptor, but inevitably working with putty and stuffing instead of Pentelic marble.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Rev Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said after a one-hour meeting with President Johnson tonight that he would submit to the President a series of proposals to halt "increasing segregation" in the North.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 5 -- Opposition politicians clashed with riot policemen in Seoul today while marching in a funeral procession for a fellow politician who had burned him self to death in protest against the treaty establishing normal relations between Japan and South Korea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Retail sales rose to $5.51 billion in the week ended July 31, 5 per cent above the preceding week and 8 per cent above the comparable 1964 week, the Commerce Department estimated today.
DENVER, Colo., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Three major figures in the collapse of the Brighton National Bank, 12 miles north of Denver, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury.

IT was dark in the town of Dong Xoai, and they were strumming guitars and singing "I wanna go home." They were American soldiers who had returned to the destroyed town 55 miles away from Saigon and were helping the Vietnamese start life over again.

A police investigation into the slaying of two children in Queens continued yesterday as an alleged "peeping tom" was arraigned in Criminal Courts after he was apprehended outside a house six blocks from where the children lived.
A full-page ad that ran in three major newspapers yesterday attracted some attention and comment.

Ron Hunt returned to the New York Met line-up at Shea Stadium last night after 12 weeks spent recovering from a fractured shoulder. He promptly plugged up one leak, but the rest of the dike (and Wes Westrum's managerial interlude) continued to crumble around him.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 -- Lawyers for a high school principal suspended here in a grade-raising investigation conceded today that students were given "the benefit of the doubt" on the transcripts sent to colleges.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., and its three publicly-owned subsidiaries have negotiated a $50 million revolving credit agreement with the Bank of America and 10 other leading United States banks, James J. Ling, chairman and chief executive officer, said today.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- A Government committee called today for complete reform of the chaotic, dissension-ridden dock industry in Britain.
There was little comment yesterday from the natural gas industry on the effect of the Permian Basin decision of the Federal Power Commission.
New York City's Central Labor Council, representing a million organized workers, is not going to endorse any candidate in the Democratic primary election of Sept. 14.
A man stabbed three persons on a Bronx subway station platform yesterday and was killed by a passing train.

YONKERS, Aug. 5 -- Cardigan Bay, having escaped from being locked in along the rail, rallied four-wide through the stretch and won the $50,000 Dan Patch Pace at 1 1/2 miles tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The New Zealand ace, benefiting from a near-perfect drive by Stanley Dancer, overtook Fly Fly Byrd in the final 30 yards and proceeded to beat the younger horse by three-quarters of a length.
Boxing, Harry Markson said yesterday, will continue at Madison Square Garden. But he hopes that future customers will refrain from "excessive exuberance.'"
The Chase Manhattan Bank has set up an international advisory committee to provide the bank with counsel on its rapidly growing international activities.

The noble sport of professional prizefighting took one more step toward final degradation -- and we hope legal abolition -- in the twenty-minute rioting by spectators after the Elorde-Narvaez bout at Madison Square Garden. The crowd, or the partisans of Frankie Narvaez at least, didn't like the decision. So they set about making a shambles of the Garden.

BARNEGAT LIGHT, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Bobbing in a choppy sea 800 feet off Island Beach State Park today, three men in a motorboat tossed overboard plastic fronds they hoped would save the state's shoreline and revitalize its fishing industry.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bob Gibson, who had lost twice to Bob Bruce this season, out-dueled the Houston Astros right-hander tonight, pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to their third straight victory, 3-1.

" Affairs at State," by Henry Serrano Villard, will be published by Thomas Y. Crowell on Sept. 20. James Reston, Associate Editor of The New York Times, has written an introduction to the book, which tells the story of the Foreign Service in the last 40 years.

Louis Banks, executive editor of Fortune, will succeed Duncan Norton-Taylor as the magazine's managing editor. The appointment, effective Aug. 16, was announced yesterday by Hedley Donovan, editor-in-chief of Time, Inc., publisher of Fortune.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- After the wild 13-inning game between the New York Yankees and the Chicago White Sox last night, sanity returned today to Comiskey Park in bright sunlight.
An installer of X-ray equipment has been found guilty in the first prosecution under the radiation-protection section of the Health Code, the City Health Department announced yesterday.

Columbia University announced yesterday the appointment of Sarah Faunce as Curator of Artistic Properties, a newly created post for the care, display and cataloguing of a widely scattered 1,500-object collection.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today two appointments to the National Selective Service Appeal Board and named a new chairman for that body.
The Curtis Publishing Company reported yesterday that it had cut its deficit in the first half of this year by 34 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey said today that the State Department had concluded that diplomatic immunity did not cover traffic offenses in the United States by foreign diplomats.

DENVILLE, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Mark Porter of Riverton and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the 40th annual Women's New Jersey State golf Association championship.

James Daly, a 27-year-old plainclothes man, was identified yesterday as the policeman who was named in the shakedown story of an ex-convict. The story had pictured a policeman and a Federal narcotics agent as conspiring to shake down a Cosa Nostra racketeer.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Fred Talbot hurled a six-hitter to record his 10th victory of the season tonight as the last-place Kansas City Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5-1.

The election of Mort S. Abelson of Newark as president of the Retail Jewelers of America, Inc., was announced yesterday following the close of the annual convention and trade show of the group at the New York Hilton Hotel.

" TELL me how you like it, Mike. You're going to have to see me in it for six months," the tall girl with dark hair and a Texas drawl said as she stepped out of a Seventh Avenue fitting room. She was wearing a black and white tweed, hip-length jacket over a black dress.

Dr. Alvin M. Weinberg, director of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has charged that some of the new mathematics and science curriculums now being widely introduced into United States schools are "dangerous."
The election of Curtis M. Klaerner as a vice president was announced yesterday by the Socony Mobil Oil Company.
A young former junior executive pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to plotting to sell a million-dollar secret plan of one major company to its greatest rival.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The disarmament conference commemorated today the second anniversary of the Moscow nuclear test ban treaty with a unanimous statement saying that "we consider more urgent than ever further progress in disarmament."
Pan American World Airways has asked permission of the Civil Aeronautics Board to increase the free baggage allowance for passengers on flights between the West Coast and Hawaii.
Proceeds of the opening of the New York Film Festival at Philharmonic Hall on Sept. 7 will go to the New York Civil Liberities Union. The evening's film will be announced next week.
OTTAWA, Aug. 5 -- A Government offer of increased salaries failed today to end a two-week mail delivery tie-up in Montreal.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Sam McDowell gained his 12th victory of the season tonight as he pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 5-2 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Cancellation of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's 1965-66 season was announced today by the Orchestral Association, which hires the ensemble's 103 musicians.

ATHENS -- Ulysses managed to sail successfully between Scylla's dreadful cliff and the whirlpool of Charybdis, but it is by no means certain his descendants will be equally adroit in pursuing a course between political extremes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico suffered today his second setback since he distinguished himself with successive victories over Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia to win the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Aug. 5 -- Much more water will be needed to abate pollution than to provide for all consumptive uses by the end of the century, a water conference of Western states, was told today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants moved into second place in the National League tonight, slamming five homers, including two by Willie Mays, while walloping the Cincinnati Reds, 18-7. The victory completed a sweep of the three-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara will probably be called to a special Senate hearing to answer a charge that the Army is in danger of serious equipment shortages, Senate sources said today.
ROSENDALE, N.Y., Aug 5 -- Free speech and a controversial issue -- should the local constabulary be disbanded and its second-hand car sold -- produced a jammed town meeting here last night.
Two important district leaders on Manhattan's lower East Side are reportedly ready to switch their support to Controller Abraham D. Beame in the Democratic mayoral race.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins scored an 8-5 victory over the Washington Senators today, increasing their American League lead over the idle Baltimore Orioles to 5 1/2 games.
I must take strong exception to your July 28 editorial on Controller Abraham D. Beame. If I believed for a minute that Controller Beame could be bossed by anyone, I would not be in this campaign.
Cheektowaga, a town just east of Buffalo in Erie County, sold $1,233,0000 of bonds yesterday in a close competitive sale in which the winning bid was only 11 cents away from the second bid.
A preliminary agreement for the acquisition of Spiegel, Inc., by the Beneficial Finance Company was announced yesterday.

The Enjay Chemical Company, a division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, has announced the appointment of Donald L. Baeder as manager of its plastics division. He succeeds Stephen L. Wythe, who has been reassigned.
Persons who undergo open-heart surgery frequently experience temporary madness while recovering, according to psychiatrists and surgeons from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- Brazil's revolutionary regime reacted sharply today to the nomination of Marshal Henrique Teixeira Lott, former War Minister, as candidate for Governor of Guanabara State.
Heavy buying of gold stocks roiled the stock market yesterday, but no definite price trend developed during a day of mixed trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A long-feared crisis of teen-age unemployment has not developed this summer.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 5 -- The mystery of how the Colombian economy has managed to remain afloat during the last several months of Government paralysis apparently has been solved by foreign financial experts who have been fascinated by the situation here since the first of the year.
In a shift of high-level textile industry posts, Herman D. Ruhm Jr. has been elected president of Greenwood Mills, Inc., the selling company for a group of South Carolina mills.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 5 -- A light-air drag from Provincetown that was one of the longest as well as slowest events of the New York Yacht Club cruise developed victories today for Bill Luders's Storm in the third division and Bob McCullough's Inverness in the second.

The armed services have estimated that additional appropriations of more than $12 billion will be needed over a period of several years to finance the war in Vietnam and to remedy existing or potential military deficiencies. President Johnson requested this week $1.7 billion more for the current fiscal year's budget to{ meet some of the{ extraordinary costs{ of the Vietnamese{ war.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- R.H. Sikes, recently of the rookie ranks, led the field with an eight-under-par 64 after the first round of the $125,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic today.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- In the face of the worst water crisis in its history, New York City reduced its leak-detection personnel from 84 to 50 last month.

The short but wordy war touched off by Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta's ultimatum that everything sold at retail must bear a price tag "at the point of display" has ended, as most wars do, in compromise. Mr. Pacetta, probably sadder but wiser by now, was "misunderstood."

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug 5 -- John J. McCloy, for years a trustee of the Rockefeller Foundation and now chairman of the board of the Ford Foundation, appealed today for European philanthropy along the international lines of the great American foundations and in cooperation with them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Crown Zellerbach Corporation issued a report today saying it had complied fully with the civil rights act in its pulp and paper manufacturing plant in Bogalusa, La.

Carl T. Rowan, who recently resigned as director of the United States Information Agency, will become a Washington columnist for the Chicago Daily News and Publishers Newspaper Syndicate beginning Sept. 1.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5 -- More than half a million refugees from war and floods have crowded into Vietnamese Government resettlement camps, causing extensive security problems.

The Government charged yesterday that two corporations and three insurance associations here had conspired through the use of pools to monopolize the $125 million-a-year aircraft insurance business in the United States.
BERLIN, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- The West Berlin police are on the trail of racketeers who make their money by organizing escapes from East Berlin across the Communists' wall.

A filmed tour down the 2,300-mile Volga River in the Soviet Union will be televised in color either next month or early in October by the Columbia Broadcasting 'System. A network production unit has been filming life in towns along the river for three weeks and will continue for two more.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Aug. 5 -- The Neshoba County Fair is a Mississippi institution that has defied heat and boredom for a week every August since 1890.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Abe Fortas, who has been nominated to the Supreme Court, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that it was "absolutely essential" for the police to have adequate time to interrogate persons suspected of crimes.
A sharp price drop in Syntex overshadowed a generally mixed market on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
The Wolverine Aluminum Corporation weighed in yesterday with a formal application to be delisted from the American Stock Exchange and yet another blast at the exchange's specialist system.
Representative John V. Lindsay charged yesterday that the city's antipoverty program was "a cruel hoax" designed "to keep the clubhouse politicians in control."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The Ghanaian diplomatic mission to Hanoi returned with the impression that North Vietnam was willing to talk peace but that Communist China was not, according to African delegates who are in close touch with Ghanaian affairs.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Radio astronomers have found that cloud-shrouded Venus's surface is dry, probably sand or porous rock, and much too hot for any known form of life -- up to 675 degrees.

A Criminal Court judge ruled yesterday that a minstrel could wander and strum any place he wanted in Washington Square Park unless the Parks Department posted signs confining the playing of musical instruments to a specific area.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Two realty companies that sold 120 acres of park land to the Town of Hempstead were accused by two Nassau County officials tonight of having made an "enormous" $770,000 profit because of private assurances from town officials.

The sixth annual Montreal International Film Festival begins week-long sessions tonight. The event is being held at the 2,500-seat Loew's Cinema. Theater, where more than 15 features from 12 countries will be shown noncompetitively for screen representatives and filmmakers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Johnson will revive a historic and dramatic custom by going to the Capitol at noon tomorrow to sign the voting rights bill.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- The effect of the Federal Power Commission's decision on gas rates in the Permian Basin will be felt most heavily in California and the Southwest, industry sources said today.

ALLENDALE, S.C., Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The Rev. Charles A. Webster Jr., a part-time Government racial consultant, was called back to Washington today for talks about his statement that he had posted jail bonds for racial demonstrators in the name of the Government.
PALERMO, Sicily, Aug. 5 -- A Palermo judge conducting an inquiry into the Italian underworld today initiated extradition proceedings against four men believed to be in the United States.

The Senate has safeguarded the one-man, one-vote principle by laying to rest the Dirksen amendment on reapportioning state legislatures. There was clearly not the broad support in the country which alone could justify overruling the Supreme Court and rewriting the Constitution. Senators Paul H. Douglas of Illinois and Joseph Tydings of Maryland, who led the successful fight to block this proposal, have served the public interest.

The Association of American Physicians and Surgeons has started down a dead-end street. It has advised its members not to serve on committees established to implement the new Federal Medicare program and to refuse to execute or sign forms for patients seeking reimbursement under the new plan.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., pinpointed yesterday the location of two new stores it plans to build in Brooklyn and Yonkers. On the eve of the opening of its Manhattan flagship store, the big ready-to-wear chain also announced a 150,000-square-foot addition to its Rego Park, Queens, store.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 5 -- There are no racial barriers in hiring procedures in private industry here and "religious groups are strengthening ties of understanding," according to a report of the Community Relations Committee today to Mayor Robert H. Mulreany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Gerald R. Ford has asked President Johnson for a conference to discuss an implication by the President that the House Republican leader was responsible for disclosing details of a confidential White House discussion on Vietnam.
Bond prices continued to fall yesterday as Wall Street remained jittery over the outlook for the British pound.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- Massachusetts moved today to the threshold of outlawing racial imbalance in its public schools. A bill penalizing communities refusing to end imbalance is expected to become law early next week.

CHATSWORTH, Calif., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Fifteen persons, including Jan Berry, a rock 'n' roll singer, were injured today when a railroad engine crashed into the rear of a flatcar on a movie location scene.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Aug. 5 -- Philadelphia has hired its first Negro policeman.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 5 -- Kim Hyung Wuk, director of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, said today there were indications that North Korean Communists were preparing Vietcong-type guerrilla activities in South Korea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today a goal of adding five years to the life expectancy of the average American within the next decade.

YONKERS, Aug. 5 -- Louis Gino Lombardi, 45 years old, founder and conductor of the Putnam Civic Orchestra of Putnam County, and his wife, Margaret, 28, were killed here today in an accident on the Saw Mill River Parkway north of Odell Avenue.

PELINDABA, South Africa, Aug. 5 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd led his country into the nuclear age today and told the black African states of the north that they would be welcome to come along.

ASK any publisher, any bookseller, any librarian. Readers of new books are not nearly as interested in current fiction as they were a generation ago. There are popular bestsellers, of course. But regular buyers and borrowers of books are interested in only a few of the novels now being published.

A 10-year deadlock between the city and representatives of its firemen has resulted in soaring deficits in the Fire Department pension fund, going from $3.2 million in 1954 to $128 million on June 30, 1964.

SOME 3,000 bridge players, many of them from New York, are today converging on Chicago for the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships. For nearly all these enthusiasts the tournament lasts for 10 days, beginning tonight with the Nationwide Charity Game.

The General Dynamics Corporation showed a slight drop in earnings for the first half of this year, reflecting a sales decline from the period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Roger Lewis, president.
LISBON, Aug. 6 -- Lisbon's Criminal Court for Political Affairs was asked today to acquit, for lack of evidence, all 31 students on trial for "subversive activities."
The 20th anniversary of the dropping of the first atomic bomb on Hiroshima was commemorated here yesterday in a variety of ways.

A joint venture has been formed by Canada Illinois Tools, Ltd., a Canadian subsidiary of Illinois Tool Works, Inc., of Chicago, and Union Carbide Canada, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation.

For nearly a century Negroes in the rural South have been afraid to vote; nothing more clearly epitomized their status as second-class Americans. Congress and the President have now put the full authority of the Federal Government into a concerted effort to register Negroes and protect them in their right to vote; nothing more clearly bespeaks the nation's determination to do away with second-class citizenship.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships began here tonight at the Palmer House Hotel with the Nationwide Charity Game. This was the focal point of more than 200 games throughout the United States and Canada.

The assistant director of security at the World's Fair, attempting to stop an after-hours private birthday party in the Belgian Village early yesterday morning, drew his pistol to protect himself from menacing guests.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Johnson signed today the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and announced steps to bring about its quick and vigorous enforcement.
Directors of Automatic Retailers of America, Inc., increased the company's quarterly dividend yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -The Cincinnati Reds lashed four home runs tonight but had to call on Jim Coker for a pinch-single in the 11th inning for the winning run in a 5-4 decision over the National League leading Los Angeles Dodgers.
PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Perkins Bass, Republican national committeeman, charged today that books written by two of President Kennedy's top aides "may be weakening the national security."
The blame for the $128 million deficit in the Fire Department Pension Fund rests on the city, the president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association declared yesterday.
Striking marine engineers and their employers returned to the bargaining table yesterday for the first time in a week.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A phalanx of sheriff's deputies and policemen led a slow-moving troop train today through a crowd of 200 persons protesting United States policy in Vietnam.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The University of Kentucky outlined a project today to study tobacco from the seed to the ash to find out whether smoking is harmful to health.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A House Republican group declared today that, despite "his brave talk," President Johnson's aims in Vietnam point to "coming surrender.''
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Following is a summary of the main provisions of the Voting Rights Act signed today by President Johnson:

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Chuck McKinley and Gene Scott, the second and fifth ranking players in the country, reached the semi-finals of the Nassau Bowl invitation grass tournament today. They will meet tomorrow, after Roy Emerson of Australia and Cliff Buchholz of St. Louis play the first match at 1 P.M. The semi-finals will be for the best of five sets.

Twenty years after the first atomic bomb exploded over Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945, New York time, studies of fallout residues show that the physical, as well as the political, environment of the world has been permanently altered.
WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 6 -- (AP) -- Canada took the first-day lead over Mexico and the United States today in the biennial Americas Cup international amateur golf matches.

The first test of the new state law authorizing rent strikes has clarified nothing, but it has indicated how pervasive the war against poverty can become if the warriors have enough ingenuity. The law was designed to give the poor an effective weapon for compelling slumlords to live up to the requirements of the housing code.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 6 (AP) -- A Federal District Court is expected to issue a permanent injunction prohibiting Old Colony Securities of Toronto from selling Norart Minerals, Ltd., stock of the United States, a Securities and Exchange Commission official said today.

ATHENS, Aug. 6 -- Signs of disunity appeared today in former Premier George Papandreou's Center Union party while consultations on who should be the next Premier of Greece continued at an accelerated pace.
Four men charged with operating a crooked dice game for race-track enthusiasts were held here in balls totaling $14,500 yesterday by United States Commissioner John B. Garrity.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, Aug. 6 -- Arthur J. Goldberg conferred for more than an hour today on the Vietnam crisis with the six elected members of the Security Council without any suggestion from any participant for a solution.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The leading money-winner in the history of thoroughbred racing, Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's Kelso, will seek to add to his bankroll of $1,918,784 tomorrow.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Yves Saint Laurent showed his fall collection to the press today at the tail end of the French couture shows, and it was the brightest, freshest and best he has ever done. After several seasons of a bad slump, Saint Laurent has bounced back higher than ever.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 -- Thousands of brightly colored lanterns floated on the rivers of Hiroshima tonight as the city, in a cheerful mood, closed a day of remembrance for its atomic bomb casualties.
Civil rights leaders predicted yesterday that the new Voting Rights Act would bring up to a million new Negro voters to the polls in the South by next Election Day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Pentagon said today that it was still uncertain whether the Air Force raid on presumed surface-to-air missile sites near Hanoi July 27 was as successful as pilots originally reported.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- The Sudanese Government is starting strong army action to quell violence in the south in a deepening split with Negro separatists there.

" On the Track of Unknown Animals," by Bernard Heuvelmans, will be published by Hill and Wang on Aug. 19. The book was first published in France in 1955 and is now translated and abridged by Richard Garnett. The author is a zoologist who believes that there may still exist animals unkown to naturalists.

UTICA N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Police Department here, reorganized a few years ago in the wake of a state-ordered inquiry into vice and crime in this city, was rocked today by the arrest of Three policemen and a former patrolman in connection with a payroll robbery a week ago. A fourth patrolman was suspended.
A two-year effort to find ways of protecting and enriching human values in a technological society has been started by the National Council of Churches.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 -- New York State told Vermont today it was clearing the air and water pollution at Ticonderoga. Residents of Shoreham, Vt., a few miles to the northeast, had protested the pollution.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- State troopers will continue to escort speeding foreign diplomats off the New Jersey Turnpike despite a State Department ruling that speeding would not be covered by diplomatic immunity.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange improved slightly yesterday although trading slackened in anticipation of the weekend.

MADRID, Aug. 6 -- A five-company Spanish oil consortium known as Hispanoil was reported today to have won international bidding to enter into partnership with the Kuwait National Petroleum Company for the exploration of a rich 3,575 square-mile are in western and southern Kuwait.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A Government report on Canada's worst air crash said today the probable cause was a series of mechanical events that led the pilot to put his plane into a dive from which it could not recover.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- A capacity crowd of about 3,500 swarmed over the campus of C.W. Post College tonight to hear the New York Philharmonic play in the great green and yellow striped tent that is housing, for the third season the Long Island Festival.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first six months of 1965. Revenues totaled $152,259,319 against $149,219,524 in the six months ended June 30, 1964. Net income rose to $7,262,729, equal to 97 centsI a share, from $6,706,422, or 90I cents a share, on fewer out-I standing shares, in the like 1964] period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Office of Education reported today that it had accepted 3,455 voluntary school desegregation plans, court orders and statements of civil rights compliance up to Aug. 3. The statements were filed by school districts in the 17 Southern and border states.

Six officers of the North German Lloyd passenger liner Bremen carried the coffin containing the body of Capt. Gunther Hossing down the vessel's gang-plank yesterday as the ship's band played "Ich Hatt Einen Kamaraden" (I Had a Comrade.'')

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 -- Michigan, Ohio and Indiana approved today a program for cleaning up Lake Erie, whose deterioration through pollution has long alarmed public officials, conservationists and scientists.

Those campaign posters in the subways picturing Representative John V. Lindsay striding past some garbage cans and bearing the quotation, "He is fresh and everyone else is tired," drew some criticism yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Aides of Representative Reuss were trying to reach him tonight with the news of his son's arrest.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, replied today to critics of his wage-price "stabilization" policy with new figures to show that France was headed for an economic upturn this fall.
The Atomic Energy Commission yesterday issued a license to First Atomic Ship Transport Corporation for commercial operation of the nuclear ship Savannah. The license is good for three years.
WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- "I'm here because in the next few years I want a job," Jose Quintero, noted director of Eugene O'Neill plays, told 20 young playwrights here the other day.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Lloyd Liebler of Portsmouth, Va., 14 years old, continued his bid to become the youngest winner of the United States Golf Association's national junior championship today by winning two matches to gain the semi-final round.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) Aug. 6 -- Mograbi Hall in Tel Aviv rang tonight with the cheers of Israeli Communists. Two days ago another Communist group convened with similar enthusiasm in Habimah Hall.

BONN, Aug. 6 -- An agreement between West Germany's Lufthansa and the Soviet Union's Aeroflot airline to exchange landing rights is being help up by the United States, diplomatic sources in Bonn said today.

The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the Police Department ordered investigations yesterday into the death of a 20-year old grocery clerk last week, allegedly caused by a policeman at Coney Island with a billy club.
The director of the city's antipoverty office said yesterday that city funds would be used temporarily to repair three badly deteriorated tenements on West 154th Street in Harlem.
Grain traders yesterday accepted with equanimity the report of a record soybean crop. In fact, soybean futures prices rose.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 6 -- India and Uganda called today for concerted efforts by the non-aligned countries to find a peaceful solution in Vietnam.
The British pound fell sharply yesterday in heavy trading on foreign exchange markets here. It dropped 13 points to $2,7904.
The London stock market continued to improve yesterday, firming at the close. Strength centered in the blue-chip issues, but the entire market was steady.
Vigorous opposition to United States policy on Vietnam was voiced yesterday at a "grass-roots" meeting on foreign policy here.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Tony Cloninger gained his 15th victory of the season tonight as he pitched the Milwaukee Braves to an 8-4 triumph over the Houston Astros. Gene Oliver's homer and two-run double paced the victors' attack.
The Itek Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to sell 60,000 of its common shares to Time Inc., for $2.01 million, or $33.50 a share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Harold Brown won Senate confirmation today as Secretary of the Air Force.

In a move to protect the public against ticket "scalping" in the concert field, License Commissioner Joseph DiCarlo said yesterday that he planned to extend to concert performances the license department's rules on the resale of theater tickets.

Television ratings go up and down, but industry income goes up and up. The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that the television broadcasting industry had a profit in 1964 of $415.6 million before taxes, an increase of 21 per cent from the previous year.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 6 -- Charles Perkins, an aboriginal student at Sydney University, instigated the kidnapping of a 6-year-old Indian girl at Sydney Airport tonight to dramatize the opposition to Australia's racially discriminatory immigration policy.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- R.H. Sikes held the lead in the $125,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic with a 36-hole aggregate of 135 today as Jack Nicklaus came within a stroke of overtaking him.

Aside from bank and insurance stocks, the over-the-counter market fails to serve up the dominant companies in many large industries. One notable exception is the brewing group and Wall Street traders waxed enthusiastic yesterday over the recent surging performance of these stocks.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Rutgers University has refused to dismiss a history professor who said at an April teach-in on Vietnam that he "welcomed" a Communist Vietcong victory.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The College All-Stars bowed to the Cleveland Browns, champions of the National Football League, 24-16, tonight before a crowd of 68,000 at Soldier Field.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The participants in the New York Yacht Club cruise, with six races behind them and one to go, rested at anchor today with not much more to do but anticipate tomorrow.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The pound remained weak but stable today after several days of heavy selling prompted by fears of devaluation.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- The Texas A.F.L.-C.I.O asked Gov. John Connally today to leave the Democratic party unless he is able to support the national party platform.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6. (AP) -The Chicago White Sex, taking advantage of a couple of mental blunders, pounded out 15 hits and whipped the Cleveland Indians, 11-5, today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 7 -- The political front of the Vietcong guerrillas in South Vietnam has asked North Vietnam for active assistance against United States forces in the South and for preparations to send men into battle, the Hanoi radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Spokesmen for two shipping groups today asked Senate approval of a House-passed bill to permit foreign flag ships to move empty containers between two ports in the United States.

James D. Clark (letter, July 31) is not the first to be bitten by a faulty concept. He is probably quite correct in assuming that anthropologists will never agree (about anything), but they do come very close to agreement about the meaning of "Anglo-Saxon."

WEST POINT, Miss., Aug. 6 -- The son of a United States Representative from Wisconsin was charged with manslaughter here today after a state investigator who was searching him in the Clay County Jail reportedly died of a heart attack.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 6 -- Marshal of the Army Henrique Teixeira Lott said today that his controversial candidacy for Governor of Guanabara state would prove whether democracy was to be a farce or a reality in Brazil.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Wayne Causey and Joss Tartabull got three hits each as the Kansas City Athletics crushed the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6 -- The United States command reported today that more than 3,000 Vietcong were killed in July, the highest number of casualties the Communist guerrillas have yet lost in a month.
DENVILLE, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair won the 40th annual Women's New Jersey State golf championship at the Rockaway River Country Club today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Christine Truman, who regained her place as Britain's leading woman tennis player this year, was scratched today from the Wightman Cup singles matches, dealing a blow to the British girls' slim hopes of beating the United States.
The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh the election of David L. Matthews as a vice president. The appointment becomes effective Sept. 1.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The fundamentalist International Council of Churches asserted today that it was gaining ground not only in the United States but also in Asia and Africa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- The White House gave a short but sharp reply today to the suggestion of the House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, that President Johnson do the "honest thing" by declaring a national emergency or war on Vietnam.

The New York Mets scored three runs in the ninth inning last night that almost upset the Chicago Cubs, almost halted a four-game losing streak and almost defeated Larry Jackson for the first time in four years.
AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 6 -- County officials named three Negro voting clerks in a surprise move today and registered more than 300 Negro voters.
SEATTLE Aug. 6 -- Fendall W. Yerxa, former news editor of The New York Times Washington Bureau, has been appointed professor of communications at the University of Washington.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Hans Wright, a 29-year-old Australian archery champion, won the American amateur title today with a final score of 3,684 in the 81st championship of the National Archery Association.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A Trans World Airlines jetliner whose eventual destination was New York narrowly averted a collision today with three Italian Air Force jet fighters. Some of the 62 passengers were shaken up but there were no injuries among them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Johnson saw Ghana's Foreign Minister, Alex Quaison-Sackey, for 15 minutes today -- long enough to receive a letter from Presi dent Kwame Nkrumah and to assure Mr. Quaison-Sackey that the Ghanaian President would be safe from United States bombs if he decided to visit Hanoi.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, today rejected a protest from the Soviet Union about his settling of $1.5 million in claims for damages suffered by Belgians during the United Nations operations in the Congo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who started his northern tour here two weeks ago and led a march of about 15,000 on City Hall, is expected by some civil rights leaders to return to Chicago for a conference with Mayor Richard J. Daley.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 6 -- India decided today to impose food rationing on her city dwellers.

A British industrialist held out hope yesterday that his country's economy might be back in balance by the end of next year if the Government's present restrictive program is "carried out with a modicum of wisdom."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Two United States-made submarine chasers of the Chinese Nationalist Navy were attacked and apparently sunk today by Chinese Communist warships off the Island of Quemoy.

Patrolman Robert V. Gardner of the Elizabeth Street Precinct refused yesterday for the second time to sign a waiver of immunity before a grand jury investigating changes of collusion between the police and gamblers.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Twins scored six runs in the sixth inning tonight and went on to defeat the Red Sox, 9-3, and stretch their American League-lead to 6 1/2 games.
CROSSE ILE, Mich., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A Great Lakes freighter rammed the Grosse Ile pivot bridge today, spilling two automobiles into the 30-foot-deep channel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The broadcast of the Vietcong statement is regarded here as a sharp warning to the United States that North Vietnam is ready, if sufficiently provoked, to send more of its army strength into the South.

BONN, Aug. 6 -- An unemployed dental technician who nursed delusions that he would be ruler of Germany by 1985 and reunify the country by 1990 confessed today to having committed the recent anti-Semitic swastika smearings in Bamberg.
OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- The Government used 700 volunteer workers and army personnel today to start the mail moving in Montreal, where postal workers have been on strike for more than two weeks.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., continued on the acquisition route yesterday with the approval by its directors of the taking over of Knox Glass, Inc. in which it already has a 35 per cent interest.

The stock market ended a week of trading yesterday just about where it was when the week began. But many Wall Street analysts were far from disappointed by the lack of significant price changes since Monday.
It was Verdi's "Rigoletto" at Lewisohn Stadium last night, the Metropolitan Opera's penultimate presentation in its first outdoor season, and the last complete opera in concert form.

WARSAW, Aug. 6 (AP) -- United States track and field forces, still reeling from their defeat, by the Soviet Union, will oppose Poland tomorrow in the start of a two-day dual meet that Coach Brutus Hamilton describes as touch and go.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- R. Buckminster Fuller, inventor of the geodesic dome, was granted a patent this week for a modified version that he calls the Monohex. The design was followed in the Cinerama Theater recently built in Hollywood.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- City officials proposed today that the United Nations International School be erected on a platform to be built 550 feet into the East River.

Providing pensions for public employes is an enterprise that costs the city upward of $300 million a year and that has piled up more than $4 billion in reserves. The plight of the Firemen's Pension Fund is a sobering example of what a mess the whole system has become. During a ten-year period this fund's deficit has grown forty-fold. In 1954 it was $3.2 million; at last audit it was more than $128 million.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, said tonight that the Internal Revenue Service had acknowledged that it had used hidden recording devices and two-way mirrors in "bugged" conference rooms.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Jim King and Mike Brumley each hit two-run singles as the Washington Senators rallied for five runs in the eighth inning today and defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 6-4

New Jersey has several serious problems. It has to make up its mind whether it is going to impose an income tax or a sales tax or continue to starve essential public services. Its schools are underfinanced, its rivers are polluted, its commuter railroads are in deep trouble.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 8 -- Pope Paul VI marking the 20th anniversary of the destruction of Hiroshima, prayed today for the banning of atomic weapons and "the terrible art that knows how to make these arms, to multiply and store them for the terror of peoples."

LANGHORNE, Pa., Aug. 8 -Jim McElreath of Arlington, Tex., driving John Zink's rearmounted Offenhauser, won the 125-mile race for Indianapolistype cars on Langhorne's paved mile today. He averaged 104.857 miles an hour.

WEST POINT, Miss., Aug. 8 (UPI) -- James M. Shellow, a Milwaukee lawyer who came here to aid the son of a Wisconsin Congressman charged earlier with manslaughter, said he was in a house that was hit by shotgun blasts today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- A five-run seventh inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 6-4 triumph over the Chicago White Sex today in the first game of a scheduled double-header. The second game was rained out.
George C. Wiswell Jr. plans to go to work one day later this month wearing a suit identical to that worn by Maj. Edward H. White 2d when he floated in space.
DORTMUND, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard predicted today that his Christian Democratic Union party, campaigning on the prosperity it has brought West Germany the September elections.

ATHENS, Aug. 8 -- Four Athens newspapers have been charged with harming United States-Greek relations by printing allegations of terrorist action by American intelligence agents in Greece.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., Aug. 8 -- The peak of summer here comes with the muffled thunder of horses' and ponies' hooves at the annual Litchfield Horse Show.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 8 -- Several Southern states may pass civil rights laws patterned after a model act that was unveiled yesterday by a group of state legal experts.
BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 8 -- An Ivy League civil rights project is being denounced by some of its former Negro supporters as being too aggressive, too militant, too loose in sexual behavior.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8 -Aside from uniformly exquisite jewel collections, elaborate evening gowns and an agreement that both shall be worn to dinner at least six nights a week, fashion is an individual matter in aristocratic old Newport.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The police arrested 36 young demonstrators early this morning as they sought to block an entrance to the White House.
MIAMI, Aug. 8 -- A 125-foot cargo vessel was found drifting 100 miles south of here by the Coast Guard today, and a boarding party discovered three of the eight-man crew shot dead.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A New York team was among the leaders in the mixed team championship, which attracted a record entry of 172 teams. This was the largest entry for any team event ever played.
Two big municipal bond refunding issues totaling about $100 million are expected to be the highlights of the investment banking business this week. Both will be negotiated sales.

Nine months after the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Staten Island opened with the promise of a last chance for a new, improved suburbia in the greater metropolitan area, the dreams of beauty and better living are mired in mud.

DENVER, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- A 47-year-old Navy veteran, who had lived 34 days with a transplanted liver, died here today. The time he survived was believed to be a record. The previous record for survival after a liver transplant is believed to be 23 days.

On the basis of developments thus far at the Geneva disarmament talks, a dismayed world must view skeptically the delegates' declaration that they all now regard further disarmament progress as more urgent than ever. The statement marked the second anniversary of the limited nuclear test-ban treaty, but nothing in the proceedings supports these fine-sounding words.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -The Rev. Billy James Hargis pledged today to seek a court test of the nation's tax exemption laws if the exemption enjoyed by his ultraconservative Christian Crusade was revoked.
WARSAW, Aug. 8 -- Under a gray and threatening sky today, 30,000 Poles serenaded the swiftest woman in the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The State Department is preparing a new solution for an international problem that has become a tiresome perennial -- the crisis in office space for embassies.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 8 -- The United States Ambassador, William M. Rountree, today denied allegations here that the United States was supporting southern Sudanese rebels either directly or through Cuban exiles sent to the Congo by Washington.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants, winning their sixth straight as Warren Spahn snapped a personal nine-game losing streak, climbed to within one game of the National League lead today by defeating St. Louis, 6-4.
POINT MUGU, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A porpoise named Tuffy is being trained to work with divers in a Navy experiment in underwater living, which will get under way next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -With a push on for adjournment by mid-September, Congress is expected to hand President Johnson two more big legislative victories this week.
Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo said yesterday that his engineers had prepared a new program to cut water use.

Your recent editorial on "That Bridge Over the Sound" will appeal to those who have declared open season on Robert Moses, but it should disappoint those of us who regard the proposed bridge as an absolute necessity.

The Board of Elections has called a special meeting for tomorrow to consider implementing the new Federal Voting Rights Acts that permits any person having completed six years of schooling under the United States flag to qualify as a voter without taking a literacy test.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -More than 350 peace demonstrators were peeled from the streets in front of the Capitol and taken to jail today in one of the largest mass arrests in recent Washington history.

A Brooklyn minstrel who was acquitted on Thursday on a disorderly conduct charge for playing a mandolin in Washington Square Park faces the possibility that he may be convicted on the same charge when he comes to trial Sept. 9.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- "Pass, please" said a bored police guard behind a desk at the diplomatic entrance of the mammoth State Department Building today.

Twenty-one steamship lines will send 38 ships on 218 cruises during the heavy seven-month cruise season beginning in October, according to the 11th annual cruise forecast by Travel Weekly, a trade publication of the industry.
MOUNTAIN LYN LOWRY, N.C., Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, dedicated a giant cross "to the glory of God" atop this 6,280-foot fir-crowned peak near Waynesville today.
THE annual two-day meeting of the United States Water Fowl Advisory Committee, made up of two representatives of each of the four flyway councils plus the Government, begins today in Washington.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Six Roman Catholic nuns were found guilty and each fined $25 today for obstructing traffic during a civil rights kneel-in at State and Madison Streets.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Premier Suat Hayri Urguplu of Turkey said tonight that his country's poor relations with the Soviet Union were a thing of the past.
The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company said yesterday that it planned to expand the sheet-glass capacity of its Mt. Zion, Ill., plant by a third.
The Texas Eastern Transmission Company asked the Federal Power Commission yesterday for approval of the construction of a liquefied, natural-gas storage facility near Linden, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A major break in the deadlocked negotiations between the House and Senate over the $3.36 billion foreign aid authorization appeared in the making today.
The president of an Italian-American organization denounced yesterday a book written in part by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democratic candidate for City Council President.
Prices on the London stock market fell slightly yesterday, as volume rose moderately from last week's depressed trading levels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The State Department denied today that the Johnson Administration rejected last fall a proposal by North Vietnam for peace talks aimed at ending the Vietnam war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction, compared with the level last week, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Even if the water shortage becomes critical enough to merit drastic conservation measures, the city has no plans to curtail the flow of water from its millions of taps for even part of the day.

Stock brokers say that one of the most relentless trends in their business is the proliferation of paper forms that must be filled out, no matter whether the stock market is going up or down.

HERMOSA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 9 -- The surf worshipers descended en masse upon Southern California's sprawling beaches this week to stage their annual rites of summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -They are rolling the bills out of Congress these days the way Detroit turns super-sleek, souped-up autos off the assembly line. The way things are going Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield is talking plausibly about getting his troops out of the trenches before Halloween.

Free baggage allowances for air passengers will become fairly standardized next Sunday among the 11 major domestic trunklines. Net income of the SuCrest Corporation soared to an estimated record of about $2.90 a share in the year ended June 30. Frank C. Staples, president, told a special meeting of the company yesterday.

California has scheduled the sale of $105 million of bonds on Sept. 14, Bert Betts, state treasurer, announced yesterday.

Gen. Ibnu Sutowo, State Minister attached to the Minister of Oil Affairs, said today.

The cargo ship Seven Seas, with its dead bodies and its lone, frightened survivor, drifted into real life as a startling reminder of a famous ship in American literature. This was the San Dominick of Herman Melville's story "Benito Cereno." Captain Delano, aboard his Bachelor's Delight in the Chilean harbor of Santa Maria in 1799, saw the strange ship out of control and boarded her.
The New York Yankees will be playing an unfamiliar role tonight when they open a three-game series against the league-leading Minnesota Twins.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- Southern California advanced to the semi-final round of the United States girls tennis team championship by beating the Eastern squad from the New York area, 4 -- 1, today on the grass courts of the Germantown Cricket Club.

MADRID, Aug. 9 -- Spain, which has been enjoying a spectacular economic boom for the last few years, was warned today that rising inflation threatens her ability "to pursue a rational pattern of economic development."

WASHINGTON. Aug. 9 (AP) -- Eight persons have died of a mysterious respiratory virus that has struck 39 patients at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in less than two weeks.

The New York Philharmonic will play in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park at 8:30 tonight. William Steinberg will conduct, and the guest artists will be Ella Lee, soprano; Joanna Simon, mezzo-soprano; Richard Cassilly, tenor; John West, bass, and the Manhattan Chorus.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Total manufacturing and trade inventories rose by $600 million in June, seasonally adjusted, about the same increase as in May, the Commerce Department reported today.
