STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 9 -- A heated quarrel between a father and son over mowing the lawn caused both their deaths yesterday, the police reported today.
Frontier Airlines reported yesterday that it had agreed to buy five 727 jet aircraft from the Boeing Company and had taken an option to buy five more planes of the 103-passenger planes.
A partial victory was won yesterday by a group of mothers who had been blockading busy Ralph Avenue in Brooklyn on and off for four years to protest the lack of traffic lights.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 9 -- A struggling little band loyalists has begun to try to splice the broken cord between the Democratic party in Mississippi and the national organization.

Management officials and labor leaders involved in the dispute that has immobilized the operations of eight of the nation's major steamship lines since June 16, were again called to Washington yesterday by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- In a highly attractive new setting, the 76th Southampton invitation tennis tournament started today at the Meadow Club with an entry headed by Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia and Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I.

Some physicians feel impelled to call for boycotts or nonparticipation in Medicare legislation. SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 9 -- Darwin W. (Win) Heath Jr. of the Noroton Yacht Club led the way through the preliminary series of the 41st Long Island Sound junior sailing championship today. The Seeburg Corporation has named Martin T. Toohey as a regional vice president.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 9 -- Government leaders hailed Singapore's withdrawal from the Federation of Malaysia today as a "victory" for Indonesia's campaign against Malaysia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -The Seaboard Air Line and the Atlantic Coast Line railroads have asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court decision of May 13, which prevented the merger to the two carriers.
NEW MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 9 -- A Negro will become pastor of the all-white First Methodist Church here on Sept. 1.

A Queens chemical executive and his wife were robbed early yesterday of $25,500 in jewelry and money by two men as they were about to enter their parked car after attending a wedding reception in the Sheepsmitted to Kew Gardens General Hospital in Queens with a possible concussion.
The constitutionality of the recently enacted rent strike law was upheld yesterday by a Civil Court judge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the United States economy demanded a fundamental revision of the Federal-state unemployment insurance system.

The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the Police Department continued their investigations yesterday into the Coney Island death of a 20-year-old grocery clerk allegedly caused by a policeman with a billy club.

NEWARK, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A magistrate settled a dispute over ownership of a collie today by letting the dog decide.

OAKDALE, L.I., Aug. 9 -- High winds failed to deter the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's youngest skippers as competition opened today for the Picken Trophy, emblematic of the association's midget sailing championship.
Prices of cocoa futures advanced sharply yesterday.
Secretary McNamara said last night that Vietcong forces in South Vietnam appeared to have withdrawn somewhat in the last 30 days. He added that he did not know why.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Johnson signed today a $280 million health research bill and announced that he would soon form a White House study group to define United States goals in health, education and "happiness."
Cowles Magazines and Broadcasting, Inc., which publishes Look and Family Circle, reported yesterday a 25 per cent increase in its half-year earnings.

The Girls Club of New York will receive the proceeds of the fourth annual Daiquiri Ball, planned for Nov. 9 at the Plaza. Rums of Puerto Rico, an agency of the island's Government, will again be sponsor. Mrs. Robert Bragarnick is general chairman.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Britain is expected to switch its allegiance from a United States developed system of color television to a German system, according to reliable sources.

The song may have ended, but the melody lingered on yesterday for Mayor Wagner as he remained away from his City Hall office one more day after returning to New York from his honeymoon Saturday night.

The Monthly Labor Review, that bible of industrial relations, has reached the half-century mark and thus proved itself the most durable of Government magazines. JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Subandrio, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, strongly indicated yesterday that Indonesia would demand the removal of British military bases from Singapore as a condition for diplomatic recognition of the island state.

ATHENS, Aug. 10 -- The Greek political crisis deepened today in the view of participants and observers as the principal contestants studied a narrowing number of alternatives for gaining the upper hand.

Last week, officials of the New York Philharmonic were a little worried. They were afraid that only a small audience would turn out in Central Park to hear the orchestra play the Beethoven Ninth, under the stars in the Sheep Meadow.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 10 -- The Federation of Malaysia, staggered by the unexpected departure of Singapore, was pitched today into a political struggle that may separate the three remaining states.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- Mrs. Alva Myrdal attempted today to break the deadlock at the disarmament conference. There was speculation that some of her suggestions might serve as starting points for negotiation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (UPI) -Tommy John's four-hit pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 6-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

I was quite interested in your July 21 editorial "The Fate of the Oklawaha," dealing with a subject I have been interested in prior to coming to Congress in 1949 and in my seventeen years in the House. That is the construction of the vital Cross-Florida Barge Canal, which will link the Western oil producing states and the Eastern consuming states by protected inland waterway.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Sid Luft has renewed his custody battle with Judy Garland. The singer was granted sole custody of Lorna, 12 years old, and Joseph, 10, when she won a default divorce from Mr. Luft on May 19.
TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Japan achieved the world's highest economic growth rate last year, despite the onset of a recession, the Government's Economic Planning Agency said in its annual report today.

The Transit Authority asked the Federal Government yesterday for $23,420,000 to buy 200 new subway cars, matching the 200 new cars the city plans to purchase this year.

ATLANTA, Aug. 10 -- The number of Negroes registered to vote was increased by nearly two-thirds in nine Southern counties today as the first Federal registration offices since the Reconstruction era opened their doors.

The London Stock Exchange gained some ground yesterday in quiet trading. The favorable July British trade figures were considered a factor in the rise, but some felt that it would require a few more months of continued improvement in exports to bolster confidence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Johnson signed today a $7.5 billion housing bill and called it "the single most important breakthrough" in the housing field in the last 40 years.

The Federal Reserve Board, voting 6 to 1, gave its approval yesterday to the acquisition of the Grace National Bank of New York by the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York. The dissenting vote was cast by James L. Robertson. Mr. Robertson declared: "I cannot accept the view that simply because Grace has in effect been labeled a limited service bank and Marine Midland a full service bank, there is no significant competition."

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews hit his 25th homer, with one man on, in the fifth inning, breaking a tie and pacing the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 10 -- The Dominican rebels expressed strong opposition today to several points of the Organization of American States' plan for a reconciliation in this divided country.

The Diocese of Brooklyn has awarded contracts for equipment to begin broadcasting this fall over a Diocesan educational television system to nearly 240 Roman Catholic parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens, it was announced yesterday.

IT IS 34 years now since the publication of William Faulkner's "Sanctuary," 36 since "The Sound and the Fury" made its appearance. And still in the pond of American fiction the ripples caused by those huge stones falling continue to expand in ever-widening circles.
ALLONS. Unless my Franglais is in error that means "Let's go," and that is the word the French Government Tourist Office is giving to American hunters.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company reported yesterday a net income of $42,443,713 for the first half of 1965, up from $35,910,675 in the corresponding 1964 period.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- A small group of civil rights demonstrators began a round-the-clock "camp-out" on the steps of City Hall today to support their demands for action against alleged police brutality.

OAKDALE, L.I., Aug. 10 -Peter Tarr of the Babylon Yacht Club needed only one race today to capture the Picken Trophy, emblematic of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing championship.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -Dave Wickersham set down the Kansas City Athletics on four hits and singled in a run tonight to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 3-0 victory.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10 -- Joseph Farano of Yonkers, a 300-pound salesman of electronic apparatus, was indicted by a Westchester County Grand Jury today for second-degree man-slaughter in the death of Harold E. Schmit of Armonk, a marketing executive of the International Business Machines Corporation.
The divorce between Singapore and Malaysia stemmed from a conflict, more political than racial, between two concepts of Malaysia's future and the two men who embodied them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The House passed by voice vote today a $1.7 billion appropriation for military construction around the world after being told that the bill had been spared sharper cutting because "we are in a war which is escalating."

A public offering of $47.8 million of Wichita, Kan., water utility, revenue-refunding bonds, series 1965, was offered publicly yesterday by an underwriting group headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., F.S. Smithers Co, and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., awarded $17 million of first mortgage bonds yesterday to an underwriting group led by the Stone Webster Securities Corporation.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 10 -- The Housing Authority here failed today to pacify its protesting tenants, organized by a "model" Federal antipoverty program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Retail sales in July, the first month affected by the reduction of Federal excise taxes, rose by nearly half a billion dollars from the June level to a record, seasonally adjusted, of $23.8 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

SELMA, Ala., Aug. 10 -- Hundreds of Negroes went to the Federal Building here today to register to vote for the first time in their lives.

City Controller Abraham D. Beame sought yesterday to force his principal political adversary, City Council President Paul R. Screvane, to promise to abide by the results of the Democratic mayoral primary.

Ljiljana Stevovic has put in only three working days with the New York Life Insurance company but that was enough to clear up several misconceptions she had about America.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Juan Marichal pitched a four-hitter today for his 18th victory of the season and Len Gabrielson's two-run single in the eighth inning provided the winning margin as the San Francisco Giants captured their seventh straight by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -The Department of Justice sued today to abolish the poll tax as a prerequisite to voting in Texas, Alabama and Virginia.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Harold A.R. Philby, a British Journalist and a former diplomat who defected to the Soviet Union in 1963, has been ordered dropped as an officer of the Order of the British Empire.
SAIGON, Aug. 10 (AP) -United States planes pressed attacks in both North and South Vietnam today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- New York players were well to the fore in the Life Master Pair Championship that continued here this afternoon in the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- One day not long ago, the Internal Revenue Commissioner, Sheldon S. Cohen, was trying to unsnarl an obscure problem, with the 1,500-page Tax Code and Charles Reagan Simpson in front of him.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Singapore has asked to be allowed to remain in the British Commonwealth the Commonwealth Relations Office said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The United States will give up its long fight to get the Soviet Union to contribute to peacekeeping operations of the United Nations, according to reliable official sources here.
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Wizard of Oz, the defending national champion in the division, captured the small pony hunter title tonight at the Sussex County Horse Show with 16 points.

Northeast Airlines, Inc., which last month obtained a new lease on life when the Storer Broadcasting Company acquired an 87 per cent stock interest in the carrier, announced yesterday it was ordering $100 million of new jet airliners.

No baseball team can afford to give up half a dozen unearned runs and expect anything other than defeat. That is what the New York Yankees did last night in Yankee Stadium, where they bowed to league-leading Minnesota, 7-3.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 10 -- An attempt by the Board of Supervisors in Nassau County to assess the reaction of residents to a proposal that would change the make-up of the board is turning up scores of letters, telegrams and scribblings that have little to do with the poll.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Representative Henry S. Reuss, whose son had a brush with the Mississippi police last week growing out of his civil rights activities, proposed in the House today a program of rehabilitation for that state under Federal auspices.

The defending champion, Dukla of Prague, and this year's regular-season winner, Polonia Bytom of Poland, end the International Soccer League season tonight at Downing Stadium Randalls Island, with the second and final game of their series for the American Challenge Cup.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) (AP) -- Five of the 19 members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee denounced the consular treaty with Moscow today as a vehicle for Communist espionage and subversion and called for its rejection.

The appointment of Jesse C. Bogue as assistant managing editor in the news department was announced yesterday by United Press International. Mr. Bogue, 53 years old, will supervise development projects and special services to subscribers. He has served since 1961 as financial editor of the large wire service.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell declared yesterday that it would be "unwise" for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to make his proposed visit to Harlem unless he was invited by the community's "broad united leadership."

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- General Motors was acquitted today of responsibility for the performance of a 1960 rear-engine Corvair involved three years ago in an accident that killed two persons.
WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 10 -- Richard M. Nixon called today for a further step-up in air and sea attacks on North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Deep disagreements among leading financial nations on how to reform the international monetary system were disclosed today in the publication of 10nation technical study of proposals to increase monetary reserves.

In another part of the procession was the Latin version of "Let's Go Mets," the "Eamus Metropoli" sign first seen at the Polo Grounds two years ago and now classic.

A 61-year-old owner of an East Side grocery-delicatessen, whose rifle has foiled 15 holdup men in 20 years, killed one robber and critically wounded another with one shot last night as they fled from his store.
PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 10 -- The Fastnet race, the fourth, last and most important of the races that count in the Admiral's Cup competition, was developing into something of a mystery today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate unanimously approved a $1 billion military pay rise bill today as its armed forces expert warned that Vietnam held "inherent dangers" greater than the Korean conflict.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs scored four runs in the fourth inning tonight and downed the Cincinnati Reds, 7-2, behind the six-hit pitching of Larry Jackson.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- Sixty-two opposition Deputies resigned en masse from the National Assembly today. They were protesting the ramming of the bill for ratification of the Japanese-South Korean treaty of amity through a special parliamentary committee last night.
A damp underground vault has been uncovered at Fort Jay on Governors Island. The subterranean chamber echoes with a faint and lonely, but most welcome, sound: plip, plip, plip.
Officials of the Bronx Zoo have decided to put police dogs on patrol duty after dark to guard the zoo against vandals.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Long dry spells during critical periods of growth in the Soviet Union's hinterlands apparently have dulled the outlook for a good harvest of spring wheat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Johnson will sign tomorrow a bill establishing a memorial to Herbert Hoover. The bill authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to purchase 200 acres of land in West Branch, Iowa, where the nation's 31st President was born.
Richard S. Aldrich, Republican Councilman at Large from Manhattan, withdrew yesterday as a candidate for re-election.

DURBAN, South Africa, Aug. 11 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Vemvoerd's Nationalist party followers have come to English-speaking Natal in a festive mood, sounding patriotic themes and singing praises for the solidarity of the white people in South Africa.
" Because we compound [interest] daily -- every day -- you earn 4.97 per cent when our current annual rate of 4.85 per cent is maintained for a year."

Carlos Carrero, 32-year-old beautician of 2 Washington Square Village, died yesterday in Wyckoff Heights. He was accidentally shot Tuesday by Patrolman Gustave F. Wiegmann when the policeman tried to release the hammer of his cocked revolver as the two men sat together in a Brooklyn restaurant.
Many Government bond issues fell to their lowest price levels so far in 1965 as the slide that started July 27 and was interrupted briefly Tuesday set in again yesterday.

WESTPORT, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The Essex County Fair opens next week. Recent rains have eased the drought for the farmers. People in the village concede guardedly that things are a mite better than they were a couple of years ago.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 11 -- The United States Solicitor General-designate Thurgood Marshall, said today at the United Nations crime congress that increasing international crime demanded highly organized international forms of protection.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- The New York Mets lost their 10th straight game -- for the third time this season -- when the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated them, 1-0, tonight on an unearned run in the seventh inning.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox scored four runs off Stu Miller on six successive hits, two of them bunts, in the seventh inning tonight on the way to an 8-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

The wives and children of 139 Staten Island ferryboat officers who are demanding wages back to May 4, threatened yesterday to begin a sit-in at the Manhattan terminal of the ferry service at the Battery if they do not get their money tomorrow.
HOUSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ray Culp scattered eight hits and Alex Johnson drove in two runs tonight, leading the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Bernard Abel, president and editor of a weekly newspaper here crusading against relief abuses, was tried in village court today on a charge of feloniously assaulting with a pistol a family that had called on him to demand an end of the crusade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative in the United Nations, said today that the United States had not yet fixed its position concerning member nations that were in arrears.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 11 -- Indian forces battled an armed pro-Pakistani force within two miles of terror-stricken Srinagar for seven hours before dawn today. Military and civilian officials reported that the Indian troops, assisted by Indian reserve policemen, had inflicted heavy casualties on the force, which was described as a group of infiltrators from Pakistan.

The National Association of Supervisors of State Banks has decided to issue for publication its study of the nation's state banking system, which has been three years in the making, "as soon as possible."

Washington's plan to announce a more flexible position on peacekeeping assessments may prove a lifesaver for the United Nations. Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg in his maiden speech Monday to the 33-nation committee on the U.N. financial crisis will apparently be in a position to help put the General Assembly back into business despite the controversy over Moscow's arrears.

LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 11 -- It's Arnie's Army against the field. As the 47th Professional Golfers Association championship begins here tomorrow, Arnold Palmer is the sentimental choice. But the realists including Ligonier's and Latrobe's top candidate, concede the role of favorite to Big Jack Nicklaus.

The Soviet Union's new wheat purchases from Canada and Argentina snapped wheat traders in Chicago to attention yesterday. They soon bombarded the pit with orders to buy futures, leading to one of the most active days of 1965.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The submarine Medregal and The Rodos, a merchant ship of Lebanese registry, collided in the South China Sea near Hainan Island July 13, the Pentagon said yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Sale Company, a 56-year-old British merchant bank, announced tonight that it was going into liquidation.

Recognizing a Northeast drought emergency that knows no state lines and is dramatically symptomatic of a nationwide problem, President Johnson yesterday pledged the Federal Government's resources to a program for alleviating the water shortage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Elmer Brown, the president of the International Typographical Union, said today that attrition was not the answer to the problem of job cuts by automation in the newspaper industry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission today opposing the proposed merger of the Union Pacific and Rock Island railroads.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ships and aircraft searched the stormy Atlantic 350 miles north of Bermuda today for Navy Capt. Robert R. Carter, lost overboard from the flagship of a destroyer squadron he commanded.

WASHINGTOR, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged today House approval of a Sennate-passed bill to exempt bank mergers from the Federal antitrust laws after a 30-day waiting period.
AUGSBURG, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Americans won eight of 10 events for an imposing 63-42 lead over West Germany tonight at the halfway mark of their two-day track and field meet.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Aug. 11 -- La Banque Continentale, a private branch of the Franklin National Bank that will offer the attentions of a French butler and maid along with other Old-World services, will open soon on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue at 60th Street.
TORONTO, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union has made its second giant purchase of Canadian wheat and flour in less than two years.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 11 -- Britain sought guarantees today that the status of her military bases in Singapore would remain unimpaired despite the separation of the island state Monday from the Federation of Malaysia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Strong opposition to a proposed order by the Department of Interior for the construction of fishing trawlers in Poland was voiced today by Edwin M. Hood, the president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 -- Water pollution, a bugbear to many other parts of the country, is impairing even the fabled beauties of Niagara Falls.
The American Stock Exchange moved into high gear yesterday for the first time this week as most stocks made advances in very active trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- News item: President Johnson announces that he will form a White House study group to define United States goals it health, education and "happiness."
Dominick Dominick, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of Richard S. Parker as a vice president.
BUFFALO, Aug. 11 -- New York will join with Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania in formulating a program to clean up the severe pollution of Lake Erie.

Crews from the Consolidated Edison Company will start this morning to lay pipes beneath The Narrows in New York Harbor to carry the country's largest electrical cables from Brooklyn to Staten Island. The extension is designed to provide a power reserve for future growth on the island.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Six years ago Arthur Lucas picked up a surgeon's scalpel, put on a pair of low-powered binocular microscopes and began to scrape away, for an hour or two daily, at a 500-year-old painting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois introduced in the Senate today a new constitutional amendment on legislative reapportionment with the declaration: "The fight has just begun."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Civil Service Commission sent more examiners to eight Southern counties today to help handle the heavy registration of Negro voters.
Mrs. Katherine B. Beirne of Richmond, in New York for the World's Fair, was walking through an upper floor of Macy's at Herald Square the other day with her grandson.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Virginia F. Lewis, a top Negro in the Chicago school system, was appointed today as assistant superintendent of city schools in charge of integration.
" AN In-Depth Study of Consumer Attitudes Toward Beds and Bedrooms" is how Social Research, Inc., explains what it has been doing for Sealy, Inc., the mattress maker.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 11 -- The new Robert Joffrey Ballet made its debut at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival last night, and the dance world is a cheerier place today because of it. About a year and a half ago, the old Joffrey Ballet ceased to exist because of disagreements between Mr. Joffrey and the Rebekah Harkness Foundation, which had supported the company for two years.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday plans to build a 1,000-ton-a-day ammonia plant at Hopewell, Va., to replace an older and less productive installation there.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron's second home run of the game drove in three runs tonight in the fifth inning and gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-2 victory over the slumping St. Louis Cardinals.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Aug. 11 (AP) -- One of the greatest collections of Japanese art treasures ever to leave Japan was put aboard the liner President Lincoln here today for exhibition in the United States and Canada.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 11 -The New York Jets' concern over losing Joe Namath, their rookie quarterback, to the military draft diminished today when it was learned that Namath was unlikely to be called for a physical examination until several weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A promise of additional Federal assistance in the water crisis facing New York City and the Northeast emerged today from an emergency conference called by President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- White House and State Department press officers said today they had "no evidence" that Henry Cabot Lodge had told Senators the United States would keep its forces in South Vietnam even if the Saigon Government requested their withdrawal.
DUBLIN, Ga., Aug. 11 -- The police here said tonight they had arrested about 50 civil rights workers during picketing at a service station.
The record maritime strike went into its 57th day yesterday as Federal officials increased their pressure on unions and management to find solutions.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union emerged today as the principal buyer of Argentina's wheat crop with the purchase of another 1.1 million metric tons (40.4 million bushels), reportedly at world market prices. The deal is believed to involve about $54 million.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- David C. Acheson, the chief Federal prosecutor in the nation's capital since 1961, was named today as special assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.

A new pattern of development aimed at preventing the New York metropolitan area from being strangled by its own growth was proposed yesterday by a consulting expert of the Tristate Transportation Committee.

An estimated total of $600 million has been made available for Latin-American real estate investment as a result of a provision in the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965, which was signed into law by President Johnson on Tuesday.

A Columbia Broadcasting System public affairs program has received permission from the Soviet Union to film a documentary at Moscow University. Isaac Kleinerman, producer of "The 20th Century," said yesterday that filming would begin early in October.
