The trustees of St. John's University will be advised to recognize their board by a committee they named last spring to recommend far-reaching changes in the university's structure.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 11 -- Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, relaxed today requirements that representatives of the poor be included in the direction of federally subsidized legal aid programs.

Stunned but happy, officers of the New York Philharmonic were congratulating each other, their musicians, the city fathers and the people of New York for the success of their concert in Central Park's Sheep Meadow on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William Cody Kelly, who was recently ousted as an assistant to Ray C. Bliss, the Republican National Chairman, is getting his $3,000 back. The Republican party doesn't want it, at least "at this time."
Members of Local 10 of the independent American Communications Association voted approval yesterday of terms for settling a week-long labor dispute with R.C.A. Communications, Inc.

The news that British exports soared to a record last month should dispel rumors that sterling will be devalued. British producers, helped in part by the Labor Government's measures to spur exports, are demonstrating an ability to compete in world markets. If they can continue to improve their position and if Labor's moves to curb imports are successful, the pound will be in a position to recover from the suspicions that now surround it.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 11 (AP) -- A scientist reported today development of a "really promising" new drug treatment for gout, a worldwide malady with 500,000 sufferers in the United States alone.

YONKERS, Aug. 11 -- Despite the presence of a 1-9 favorite in the event, the $122,236.25 Yonkers Futurity Trot, the initial leg in the triple crown of trotting series, is expected to attract about 30,000 fans to Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Small Business Administration, in a major change of policy, announced today that henceforth it would allow commercial banks taking over its loans to charge the borrower the prevailing bank rate of interest instead of the lower S.B.A. rate.

Mario Biaggi, a much-decorated former policeman and newly appointed campaign aide to Abraham D. Beame, has been dismissed from his $13,355-a-year state job, Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo announced yesterday.
The General Aniline and Film Corporation, a cash-rich company in the Wall Street spotlight, is rapidly putting its money to work in an expansion program.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Don Wert's single drove in the winning run in the 10th inning as the Detroit Tigers completed a sweep by beating the Kansas City A's, 5-4, in the second game of a double-header tonight.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 11 -- A Federal district judge ordered the Oklahoma City Board of Education yesterday to speed desegregation by pupil transfers, school pairings and a more balanced distribution of Negro teachers.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 11 -- On a littered, weed-grown waterfront site in this city, a little west of Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City will deliver to the state of New Jersey at noon on Tuesday the title to 155.8 acres of city land.

A band played, people danced and children stuffed themselves on free cake and fruit drinks yesterday at the opening of two gaily decorated plazas separating market buildings under the New York Central tracks in East Harlem.
City legislation to protect open land areas from "premature development" was urged yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The huge Canadian wheat sale to the Soviet Union may well require a resumption of Russian sales of gold in the West, in the view of financial officials here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The controversy over the location of the $65 million Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has bubbled to the surface again.

THE professionals would have called the show strictly amateur, but not even the most sophisticated could have faulted the clothes previewed yesterday at Design Research. Marimekko dresses from Finland are still in fashion's major league after a run of 14 years.

The city's Board of Elections, after a few days of unexplained delay, agreed yesterday to comply with the new Federal voting law that permits Puerto Ricans to vote even if they cannot read or write English.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Sheriff Jim Clark of Dallas County, Ala., may have been "nauseated" by the sight of hundreds of Negroes registering to vote in Selma, but he ain't seen nothing yet. If only one day's activity by Federal registrars in the South had that effect on the Sheriff, he is going to be a desperately sick man before long -- say, by November 1966.

A whole town -- farmers, plumbers, merchants, teachers, doctors and tourists -- has saved the Lake Luzerne (N.Y.) Playhouse, 187 miles from Broadway. The Adirondacks village has a population of 6,000 in the summer, dwindling to 2,000 in the winter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate voted today to give the cities a voice in the Cabinet by creating a Department of Housing and Urban Development.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., showed a slight dip in second-quarter earnings, but fared better than in the first quarter in relation to 1964 results.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 11 -- David Ben-Gurion was only partly successful tonight in his first attempt to rally popular support for his bid to re-enter politics.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 11 -- In this week's agreement separating Singapore from the Federation of Malaysia, it was stipulated that the two states would cooperate in economic matters to their mutual advantage.
A $25 million offering of Beaunit Corporation convertible debentures is expected to be offered today carrying a 4 1/4 per cent interest coupon and priced at 100.
The London stock market improved yesterday, influenced in part by the recovery of sterling in further consideration of the July trade figures. Trading was light.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Hubert H. Humphrey, and all the Vice Presidents who come after him, may find a proper home at last because of two moves in the Senate today.
New city restrictions on the use of air-conditioners were announced yesterday as a water conservation method that will be felt by many New Yorkers where they live or work.
The Canadian dollar advanced yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Pentagon's plan to merge the organized units of the Army Reserve into the Army National Guard was rejected today by a House Armed Services subcommittee.

PHYLLIS DILLER, a comediene with martini-colored hair that looks like a well-used broom, and hazel eyes that change color as fast as you can say "contacts," sums it all up with: "I'm not nuts about looking like this."

HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Independence, the plane used by Harry S. Truman when he was President, left here today for Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio, where it will be placed in the permanent Air Force museum.
Representative William F. Ryan said yesterday that rent control in the city was "on the rocks" and that two of his rivals for the Democratic mayoral nomination had helped put it there."
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Dave Kelley of Ridgefield, Conn., won all four events in the green working hunter division of the Sussex County Horse Show today.

" A City Destroying Itself: An Angry View of New York" by Richard J. Whalen, will be published by Morrow on Sept. 15. In it Mr. Whalen declares that, "New York City has become a colossal failure in human arrangements."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- John G. Lorenz was named today to serve as Deputy Librarian of Congress. Mr. Lorenz is now director of the Division of Library Services and Educational Facilities in the Office of Education.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- President Johnson told travel industry executives today that he hoped "before the year is out -- when Congress gets out of here -- I can do some traveling too."

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 11 -- The English yacht, Quiver IV, appeared to be the winner among the Admiral's Cup competitors in the Fastnet race tonight when she was placed ahead of Figaro IV on corrected time.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Laurence F. Moore of Burlington, N.J., won the Dewar Course metallic-sight match yesterday in the national rifle and pistol competition. He fired a 400-23.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 11 -- About 800 acres of shabby frame houses and small factories in this city's southwest section were designated today for renewal.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 11 -- Leftist groups have been waging an ideological struggle among themselves for power in the Dominican Republic.

Commissioner Henry Barnes will not be convinced that his scheme for midtown garages is wrong until New York is strangled. But that's too big a price to pay just to convince Mr. Barnes. [Editorial July 22.]

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y Aug. 11 -- Quick Pitch managed to fight off a stretch run by Flag to win the $29,750 Bernard Baruch Handicap today. Competing in a field of 10 on the turf course of 11/16 miles, Quick Pitch scored by a nose under a ride by Jimmy Combest.

Last night's Prospect Park concert by the New York Philharmonic was supposed to start at 8:30. But at 8:30 a busy, perspiring, fast-moving crew was still assembling the shell, before an entranced and kibitzing audience of some 20,000.

WARSAW, Aug. 11 -- Ambassador John Moors Cabot has protested to the Polish Foreign Ministry against an alleged attempt by Polish security policemen to recruit an American exchange student here into their service.

55-Year-Old Leader in Field of Women's Education Has Wide Influence. Miss Margaret Clapp, one of the nation's leading exponents of women's education, has resigned as president of Wellesley College, effective next July 1.

A decline of 502,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week's end, total supplies were 193,111,000 barrels, compared with 193,613,000 a week earlier and 190,034,000 year ago.
The appointment of Allan D. Emil as chairman of the 1965-66 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York was announced yesterday by Irving Mitchell Felt, federation president.
Nonfarm employment in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area has reached a record high, but the rate of job growth here is only a third that of the nation as a whole.
Federal narcotics agents jailed four persons last night after a scuffle outside a Greenwich Village meeting called to support the "abolition of jails."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. warned civil rights workers today not to rest on their laurels. He said the movement should insure that at least a million new Negro voters go to the polls next Election Day.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Early in 1960 Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez, then the monarch of tennis, said in Los Angeles:
MIAMI, Aug. 11 -- Roberto Ramirez was charged with five counts of murder and one count of piracy today in the death of five crew members of the small freighter, the Seven Seas, late Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today the nominations of Abe Fortas as a Supreme Court Justice; John W. Gardner as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and Thurgood Marshall as Solicitor General.
The Seagram-Distillers Company is making the most of that "water-saving" fountain display in two of the Fifth Avenue windows of Tiffany Co.
Robert Mackey, 30-year-old assistant to the president of the Belgian Village at the World's Fair, was arrested yesterday on a charge of felonious assault on a Pinkerton patrolman at the fair.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The American Medical Association told member physicians today that, acting individually, they could lawfully refuse to accept a patient who received benefits under the Federal medicare program.

NEW DELHI,. Aug. 11 -- The Indian Government reported casualty figures today for the fighting in Kashmir in the last week. The death toll of infiltrators was put at 2 officers, 79 enlisted men and 3 paramilitary guerrillas.
Polonia Bytom of Poland played 90 minutes of zestful and soul-satisfying soccer last night and achieved the object of its perfection -- the International Soccer League's American Challenge Cup.

TOKYO, Aug. 11 -- The president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange said today that the outlook for the market, despite, several days of losses this week through profit taking, had become "very rosy" as a result of positive measures being taken by the Government to counter the business recession.

The increasing evidence of our determination in South Vietnam has, predictably, aroused increasing protests from those who believe we had no business there in the first place and that the soundest course is to get out as fast as we gracefully can.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Juan Pizarro blanked Washington on one hit -- a single by Woodie Held in the fifth inning -- for his first victory in two months and second of the year as the Chicago White Sox whipped the Senators 7-0 for a split of their double-header tonight.

The Harkness Ballet, which was formed last year by the Rebekah Harkness Foundation, will make its first tour in the United States this fall. The six-week tour of some 30 cities in 13 states will begin at Arizona State College in Tempe on Oct. 4 and end in Princeton, N.J., on Nov. 13.
A group of students from France complained yesterday that they had been snubbed on a visit to the White House and given only "a regular tour."
The directors of Litton Industries voted yesterday to split its common stock two-for-one and also pay a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend.

DENNEHOTSO, Ariz., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Five Navajo Indians, ranging in age from 12 to 24, raped a 19-year-old antipoverty worker today in a remote reservation village, the Federal Bureau of the Investigation reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Roman Catholic bishops now have permission from Rome to allow celebration of the nuptial mass at the marriage of a Catholic to a non-Catholic, the National Catholic Welfare Conference said today.
" PLEASE do not call me pro-Western," Indonesia's Defense Minister, Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, told an American who called on him in 1963 in the airy parlor of his Jakarta home.
Pierre Salinger has been named to head an international movie theater project that will engage in the construction and operation of film showcases around the world.

It may not be known as the Republic Aviation Corporation, but the prospects are that the sprawling aircraft-building installation at Farmingdale, L.I., will continue to be a major industrial operation -- and perhaps be expanded.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- It's that time of the year when Max Hirsch has his birthday celebrations. That's right, celebrations. Going royalty one better in the custom of plural observances of natal days, the ancient and honorable horse trainer is having his third birthday party of the year sometime during the current meeting here.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- Gov. George Romney called today for an investigation into allegations that a state judge, two state legislators and three other officials had tried to keep a star prosecution witness from testifying in a gambling trial.
The Celanese Corporation of America is planning to spread its paint business around the globe through the proposed acquisition of the second-largest manufacturer of paints in Britain.
Price advances were announced yesterday in heavy industry and chemicals.

WARSAW, Aug. 11 -- Marian Bucholc is a member of the newly rich in a Communist country. He wears a handsome tweed jacket and gray flannel slacks, owns two cars, sends his family to the seashore for vacation, takes vacations in the West himself, and pays more in taxes than the average Polish worker earns.

The AMK Corporation, formerly the American Seal-Kap Corporation, announced yesterday plans to offer stockholders the right to subscribe for one additional share at $10.25 a share for each five shares held at the close of business yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- An armored relief column joined forces shortly before midnight last night with the Vietnamese paratroopers who have been defending the Special Forces camp at Ducco against determined Communist attack.
ATHENS, Aug. 11 -- George Papandreou asked tonight for an audience with King Constantine, reportedly to offer a compromise solution to the four-week political crisis.
Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

PARKSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Three men and a woman were burned to death and 10 persons were injured today when an early morning fire raged through the Prospect Inn, a Catskill Mountain resort hotel catering to elderly guests.
The sound of taps drifted over Governors Island yesterday for Capt. Christopher J. O'Sullivan who was killed in action in Vietnam May 30.

" SPRING TIDES," writes Samuel Eliot Morison, "are not the tides of spring as many landsmen suppose. They are the very high and very low tides which occur twice a month, with the new and the full moon, when solar and lunar magnetism pull together to make the circumterrestrial tide wave higher than at other times.
NEWPORT. R.I., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The Navy discontinued today its search for Capt. Robert R. Carter, 47-year-old destroyer squadron commander missing at sea.

The Standard Products Company -- facing a take-over bid by the American Steel and Pump Corporation and attempting to counteract it with a tender offer of its own -- challenged yesterday the jurisdiction of a New York court in a stockholder suit filed here.
A conveyor belt system that will bring baggage to travelers and end wild scrambles for luggage will be installed by next spring at the International Arrival Building at Kennedy International Airport.
The United Federation of Teachers has rejected a proposal that mediators be appoint to help resolve the impasse in the union's contract negotiations with the Board of Education.

Councilman Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday that he was "extremely concerned" that the rank and file of the Reform Democratic movement "are being driven into the waiting arms" of Representative John V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor.

Two organizations of undertakers, representing about 15,000 of the nation's 24,000 funeral establishments with licensed personnel disclosed yesterday draft codes of ethics that require families to be told in advance exactly how much a funeral will cost.
The city's new restrictions on the use of air-conditioning equipment went into effect yesterday, but they will not be enforced until Tuesday.
ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- George Papandreou, in a sharply worded statement to King Constantine, said tonight he was still determined to regain the leadership of the Greek Government on his own terms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Johnson added his comment today to the controversy over whether Henry Cabot Lodge told Senators that the United States would keep its forces in South Vietnam even if a government there requested their withdrawal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- A record farm output for 1965 shows the failure of the Administration's crop control program. Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said today in a telegram to President Johnson.
Milt Jackson, a charter member of the Modern Jazz Quartet, brought a group of his own to the Museum of Modern Art last night for the ninth event in this season's "Jazz in the Garden" series.
The appointment of Leon Climenko as Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Labor was announced yesterday by Industrial Commissioner M.P. Catherwood.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Campaigns are being planned here to oppose the Labor Government's new policy of restrictions on immigration from countries of the British Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Maritime Commission denied today that it had violated an agreement by making public information on ocean freight rates between the United States and Great Britain.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Frank Chapot rode San Lucas, a smooth-stepping 8-year-old chestnut gelding, to victory in the open jumper bonus point class tonight at the Sussex County horse show, barely beating out his wife.
TICONDEROGA, N.Y. -- There is the art of a museum about the sprawling white house as it its here in stately and almost jealous possession of its treasures.
The "Don't Block Crossing" safety campaign has cut violations by motorists by 41 per cent. the Police and Traffic Departments announced yesterday.
NIKOS KAZANTZAKIS, who died in 1957, was generally considered the greatest Greek writer of this century; by some he was considered a genius.

The United States is the odd man out in the huge wheat purchases being made by the Soviet Union. Canada and Argentina have received windfalls largely because United States wheat is too costly as a result of the Government's discriminatory requirement that 50 per cent of wheat exports to Soviet-bloc countries must be shipped in American vessels.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 12 -- The Santa Fe Opera gave Dmitri Shostakovich's first opera, "The Nose," in its handsome open air theater here last night. It was the work's first production in the United States and only the fourth in its history.

The threat of the maritime strike on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts spreading to the West Coast this Sunday was temporarily averted yesterday. The Seafarers International Union announced the indefinite extension of a 60-day strike moratorium it granted last June that would have otherwise ended on Sunday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The four countries of the Lower Mekong River basin signed today in Vientiane, Laos, the first power-exchange convention of the area's development program.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Dr. Eugene D. Genovese, the Rutgers University professor under attack for having said he would welcome a Communist victory by the Vietcong in South Vietnam, said here today that he was expelled from the American Communist party in 1950.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A long struggle to raise the limits of an airline's liability to a passenger killed or injured on an international flight appeared today to be nearing a showdown.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- Soviet city planners announced the opening of an architectural competition today to solicit comprehensive plans to give downtown Moscow a face lifting.
The constitutionality of the new Federal voting rights law will receive its first legal test Tuesday in State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Administration is now fighting hard on two fronts. It is trying to beat off the military attacks of the Vietcong in Vietnam, and at the same time it is trying to beat down the political and intellectual attacks on its Vietnam policy at home.

A suspect said by the police to have staged six holdups in three and a half hours before dawn yesterday was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court on charges of assault and robbery, grand larceny and violation of the Sullivan Law on carrying weapons.
The increase in West Germany's bank rate yesterday nipped in the bud a modest recovery in United States Government bond prices.

FALMOUTH, England, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two Royal Air Force planes scoured the Atlantic 200 miles off the Cornish coast for seven hours today without finding a trace of a lone American trying to sail his 13 1/2-foot boat from Massachusetts to England.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 -- India charged today that infiltrators now fighting in Indian-held Kashmir belonged to a special Pakistani army unit known as "Gibraltar Forces."
Selling in the final half hour of trading reduced the number of advances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday although the list still managed to finish stronger in active trading.

Mario Biaggi of the Bronx, a man versatile in politics as well as profession, has been dismissed from his $13,335 job in the Rockefeller administration because he wanted to remain on payroll while acting as operations director in Abraham D. Beame's campaign for Mayor. Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo's version is that he offered his assistant a leave of absence without pay but that Mr. Biaggi demanded to go on paid vacation instead.

MILO BAUGHMAN'S daughter thinks that most of the furniture around today is dull and uninteresting. This is what father kept in mind when he designed the new low-slung sofas and chairs that go on display today at Macy's.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 12, (UPI) -- Ken Boyer, who had struck out and reached base on a passed ball, raced home in the 13th inning on Mike Shannon's single to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today and end a five-game losing streak.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- Dr. John P. Gallaher, an American neurosurgeon, flew home today leaving behind a wave of gratitude -- and a substantial new amount of goodwill for the United States -- for his life-saving operation on an Argentine actress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Congress completed action today on a military pay rise bill that went far beyond the Administration request early this year. The increases may take effect Sept.1.
For traders in commodities, a good crop report can make pessimistic reading. A case in point came yesterday in world sugar futures, which lost ground in an active session.

DURBAN, South Africa, Aug. 12 -- South Africa's restrictive racial codes tend to keep persons whose identity cards say something other than "white" from making their way in the select professions. But ff Radha Singh had never faced any restrictions, she would not now be Durban's only practicing woman lawyer.

AREA A -- Bottom fishing along the New Jersey coast is reported excellent with bass and blackfish in good supply. The big schools of tinker and Boston mackerel remain in the area and catches are good.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The British Government is trying to find a new approach to the problem of Aden.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Johnson paid tribute to Herbert Hoover in a ceremony at the White House today, describing him as "an uncommon man and an uncommon American."

Behind two modest storefronts in the southeast Bronx a new breed of community project is developing -- one that a client calls "utopia, a place where anybody in this neighborhood can go with any kind of problem at all, and get some help . . . at last."

Your recent commendable series of editorials treated with an apparent inexcusable state of affairs produced by the strike of certain segments of maritime labor. It seems incredible that so relatively small a part of American labor may with seeming impunity wreak so much harm and at once both frustrate and negate the implementation of a form of Government policy designedly intended to protect and promote a broad public interest.

Screen rights to Romain Gary's autobiographical novel "Promise at Dawn" have been acquired from 20th Century-Fox by Arthur Cohn, the Swiss producer, for an English-language film to be made abroad. Vittorio De Sica is to direct from a scenario by Cesare Zavattini.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts will attempt man's longest space flight next week -- eight days, the equivalent of a round trip to the moon.

The suggestion of Mayor Wagner, also made in the July 22 letter of G. Whittlesey, that New York City tap the Great Lakes for water, deserves an answer, if for no other reason than its demonstration of the strange thinking often associated with water problems.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- Fierce rioting again gripped the Negro section of south Los Angeles tonight. Officials called it the worst racial incident in the city's history.
A traffic violator was wounded last night after he repeatedly bit a patrolman during a scuffle in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, according to the police.
HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Ed Roebuck of the Philadelphia Phils went in to quell a ninth- inning Houston Astro uprising tonight and preserve a 7-3 victory for Chris Short.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Patti Caretto of Commerce, Calif., a 14-year-old junior high school student, bettered her own world record in the 1,500-meter free-style today at the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor swimming and diving championships.

Philanthropic foundations have performed a crucial task in alerting the nation's educational and social service institutions to the need for change and experimentation. The schools, colleges and universities, faced with the combination of unprecedented demands for mass education and the drive toward full equality by disadvantaged minorities, were in particular need of subsidies for daring.

STICK with Joseph Papp and his New York Shakespeare Festival and you are bound eventually to achieve the enviable distinction of having seen all the plays that Shakespeare ever wrote. This has been a remarkable semester of progress toward that Nirvana in Central Park's Delacorte Theater.

RUDI GERNREICH, who won fame for topless bathing suits and transparent underclothes, is about to start on no-nonsense nightgowns and pajamas. While some of them will be what he calls "very, very short," they will all cover the top of the body in almost Puritanical fashion; some will have long sleeves, some will trail on the ground.
" Orville, it will never get off the ground."
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 -- A move to nationalize the Chilean copper industry was made today by the Liberal party, a right-wing group.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Vernon Law of the Pittsburgh Pirates stopped the San Francisco Giants, 5-2, on seven hits in the second game of a double-header here today.

LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 12t -- Arnold Palmer stood by while a section of a wooden bridge was demolished at the Laurel Valley Golf Club and thereby received a two-stroke penalty as the Professional Golfers' Association championship opened today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that Philadelphia and New York were on a "collision course" in the Delaware River water emergency.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 12 -- The leader of the main party in the Government coalition warned the Sudan's neighbor today that if they did not curb the political activities of Sudanese rebels in their territories they would invite intervention in their affairs.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 12 -- Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania said tonight there was not room in the Republican party for the radical right wing.

" TENANTS and landlords are two groups in this city you can never please," a friend warned Mrs. Hortense Wittstein Gabel two years ago when she accepted the position of the city's Rent and Rehabilitation Administrator.
MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The canopy from an Air Force T-33 jet trainer plummeted 26,000 feet into the backyard of a suburban home today.
The report of the New York State Electric and Gas Company disclosed yesterday a net income of $5,675,974, or 71 cents a share, for the June quarter this year on revenues of $32,973,501.
The television career of a 6 1/2-year-old boy was ended yesterday -- at least until he becomes 7 -- when a State Supreme Court Justice upheld Mayor Wagner's objection to the boy's performing.

The original manuscript of the Christmas carol "Stille Nacht," one of the most famous songs of the last century and a half, arrived here yesterday at Kennedy International Airport. The manuscript, together with the guitar used by Franz Xavier Gruber to compose the melody, is insured for $1 million, a spokesman for the Austrian Mission to the United Nations said.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 12 -- Britain took the honors, retaining the Admiral's Cup here today, but the United States took the glory when a little yacht called Rabbit, designed and owned by Dick Carter, who sails under the flag of the Boston Yacht Club, came in the over-all winner of the Fastnet race.

YONKERS, Aug. 12 -- Noble Victory, the darling of nearly all harness racing fans, if not of all IBM computers, easily captured the $122,236.25 Yonkers Futurity Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The chalk-bettors among the 25,180 on hand for the first leg of the triple crown of trotting, plunging with justifiable confidence, accounted for a world record mutuel handle for place wagering.
BUFFALO, Aug. 12 -- The five Lake Erie basin states reached an agreement with Federal officials today on a program to halt the lake's severe pollution, possibly within four years.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 12 -- Syrian and Israeli tank and artillery forces clashed for two hours today at the Jordan River north of the Sea of Galilee.
Paul L. McCulloch has been named a vice president of the Pettibone Mulliken Corporation.
The German mark, benefiting from the bank-rate change announced by the Bundesbank in Frankfurt, showed gains in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Office of Economic Opportunity said today it was ready to finance a second front in the war on poverty.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- John Orsino's two-run pinch single capped a four-run Baltimore rally in the seventh inning today and sparked the Orioles to a 5-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

A Brooklyn grand jury handed up a detailed report yesterday to substantiate its findings that a rookie white policeman who shot and killed a Negro ex-convict in Brooklyn on July 15 had acted in self-defense.

As almost any railroad traveler knows the nations railroads have sharply curtailed in recent years their passenger train services. The railroads have eliminated hundreds of trains from the timetables and reduced the miles of track operated in passenger service by more than 50 per cent since the end of World War II.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 12 -- The Government of Singapore indicated today that it would impose limitations on Britain's use of its military bases on the island.

Speaking of gin, and more people along Madison Avenue are these days, it's getting to the point where a bartender will be able to tell which agency an adman works for by the brand of gin he orders in his martinis.

Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba denied yesterday that he had said he saw a "propagandistic victory" in the State Department's refusal to allow Bobby Fischer, United States chess champion, to go to Havana for a tournament.

How the mighty have fallen. The league-leading Minnesota Twins held the defending-champion New York Yankees in such little regard last night that they pitched a former clubhouse boy in the deciding game of the three-game series.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A smashing 10,000-meter victory by the Olympic champion, Billy Mills, and the fastest 1,600-meter relay of the year helped the United States track and field team score a 142-91 victory over West Germany tonight.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that the proposed Hudson Valley Expressway would not be an objectionable "gasoline alley," but would enhance the valley's scenic beauty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Military operations by both sides in the Battle of Ducco near the Cambodian border illustrate significant changes in the war in Vietnam -- particularly the broadened combat role of American forces.
The Procter Gamble Company had its most successful year in its 128-year history in the fiscal period ended June 30. Sales exceeded the $2 billion mark for the first time, it disclosed yesterday.

" The Bloody Battle for Suribachi," which Crowell will issue on Sept. 10, is Richard Wheeler's recreation of his own marine platoons fighting on Iwo Jima. These were the men who planted the American flag on the peak on Feb. 23, 1945.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- The glory that was Jerry Cromwell's changed to the ashes of bitter defeat today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Drawing away from his opposition midway in the contest, Natty Bumppo registered a 10-length victory today over Wise Ship in the $11,600 Saratoga National Hurdle. Natty Bumppo set a course record, covering the 2 1-16 miles in 13:41 4-5.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Intercity truck tonnage and rail carloadings in the latest week ended Aug. 7 were considerably above the corresponding week of 1961.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Gov. William W. Scranton's speech to the American Bar Association in Miami Beach tonight was the first step in a carefully planned campaign to isolate radical right-wing influence in the Republican party and to reopen a meaningful debate between the party's re sponsible progressives and conservatives.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate restored today more than half the cut made by the Appropriations Committee in funds for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 12 -- A group of Seoul University students demanded today dissolution of the National Assembly in the wake of mass resignations by opposition legislators.

LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 12 -- There was a general in the ranks of Arnie's Army today. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, an enthusiastic golfer, was among the early arrivals as 12,142 spectators followed play in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association championship.
St. Francis College in Brooklyn has fitted the last piece into a mosaic of parcels, completing a building site for its $3.5 million science building. Demolition will start within two weeks.
The Alabama Power Company, a subsidiary of the Southern Company, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday two large issues of securities to be sold at competitive bidding.

THE jokes accumulate, along with the defeats. Crowds keep pouring into Shea Stadium, and Casey Stengel's face and words enliven sports pages and television screens. Unsolicited interpretation of the Mets as a cultural phenomenon is still on the increase. No one can deny that baseball, these last four years, has been more fun because of the Mets.
Cardinal Spellman predicted in Toronto last night that additional declarations from Ecumenical Council Vatican II would he promulgated to "fulfill and implement" the council's Decree on Ecumenism.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 12 -- Republican legislators chartered today a nationwide program to build G.O.P. muscle in state governments.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 -- The Soviet Union's purchase of 187 million bushels of Canadian wheat and flour without any apparent price concession was interpreted by grain dealers today as a favorable development for world-grain prices.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- Laurels for one of the biggest civilian trans-Atlantic airlifts in aviation history were offered tonight to El Al Israel Airline by the order of Ahepa, a Greek American organization holding its annual convention here this week.
GENEVA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- India accused the United States and the Soviet Union today of trying to persuade the rest of the world to renounce nuclear weapons while increasing their own atomic arsenals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The House of Representatives passed tonight the Administration's measure authorizing a $3.3 billion program to revive the economies of depressed areas throughout the nation. The vote was 246 to 138.
LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 12 -- After fog delayed the start of the Professional Golfers Association championship for two hours, Tommy Aaron took a one-stroke lead today with a 66.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The Rev. James Bevel, Alabama project director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, told the group's convention here today that President Johnson had signed the "civil rights move ment out of existence" when he signed the voting rights bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
Raymond International, Inc., announced yesterday the election of William Denny and Henry F. LeMieux as vice presidents.
The city gave landlords of rent-controlled apartments permission yesterday to raise rents if they install closed-circuit television systems to protect their tenants.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 12 -- In a surprise move, the city's Board of Education ruled today that the suspended principal of Hillhouse High School is facing discharge only as a principal, not as a teacher.
The stock market once again outperformed the popular averages yesterday, with electronics and other growth issues over-shadowing the blue-chip stocks.

The labor-powered steamroller that rushed the Administration's bill to nullify state "right-to-work" laws through the House with no amendments has slowed down in the Senate just enough to allow special protection for workers with religious scruples against forced union membership. A Senate Labor subcommittee voted unanimously yesterday to exempt conscientious objectors from having to join unions as a condition of holding their jobs, provided they paid the equivalent of union dues to charity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Senate Labor subcommittee approved today by 7 to 1 the Administration bill to repeal section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Law that allows states to ban the union shop.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Social Security Administration will open 71 new branch offices and 21 temporary service centers, Commissioner Robert M. Ball announced today.
Business borrowing at New York City banks rose $70 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
BONN, Aug. 12 -- The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, raised its discount rate today from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent, effective tomorrow.

President Johnson has performed a useful service by personally scotching the report that the United States would keep its forces in South Vietnam even if the Saigon Government requested their withdrawal.

Superiors of Francis J. Farrell, the Federal narcotics agent under investigation by a Brooklyn grand jury for an alleged attempt to shake down a Mafia figure, will support his denial of any wrongdoing, it was reported yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Adm. U.S. Grant Sharp Jr., commander in chief of the United States' Pacific forces, confirming that a Navy jet had been downed by a North Vietnamese missile, said today that missile sites would be destroyed "when we locate them."

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Don Demeter drove in seven runs with a single, triple and grand-slam homer today to lead the Detroit Tigers to an 11-1 victory over the last-place Kansas City Athletics and a sweep of the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Johnson Administration withdrew today its objections to a major part of at bill proposing a $110 million-a-year increase in benefit payments to 700,000 retired Government personnel and their dependents.
The Jazzmobile visited 129th Street last night, and once the novelty of having 20 big-time musicians playing in the shadow of the tenements wore off, everyone relaxed and had a good time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The United States Information Agency is filming the life of President Johnson in a movie called "Texas Story," Senate debate disclosed today.
New cars continued to sell at a record rate in early August.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., raised its net income to $14,674,000, or $3 a share, in the first six months of this year, from $11,067,000, or $2.28 a share, in the same period last year.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 -- A Government spokesman said today there had been no change in Japan's policy on trade with Communist China, despite widespread speculation that Tokyo was easing its stand on providing funds to help deferred-payment sales.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Linus Pauling said today eight of the ten Nobel Peace prize winners had signed an appeal to world leaders "to take immediate action to achieve a ceasefire and a negotiated settlement" of the war in Vietnam.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- The Central Synagogue of Moscow has donated a 200-year-old silver breastplate for adorning the Holy Scroll to the museum of the International Synagogue at New York's Kennedy Airport.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the Justice Department today to send Federal voting examiners to Jones County, Miss.
Dan River Mills, Inc., the diversified textile company, has made a multimillion-dollar cash offer to purchase the Clifton Manufacturing Company of Spartanburg County, S.C., a textile fabric maker.

MIAMI, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- One of the two survivors of murder aboard the Seven Seas, a small freighter, testified today he had seen a fellow crewman, Roberto Ramirez, fire two of the shots that killed the captain and four others.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 -- Phan Dinh Thinh, a shopkeeper in Saigon, has hidden $500 he saved during the last year. He will use the money to try to get his family out of South Vietnam if the Americans leave.
Prices on the London stock market advanced again yesterday in moderately active trading. Institutional buyers were active for the second day.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 -- A United States Navy jet fighter-bomber was shot down today by a ground-to-air missile about 50 miles south-southwest of Hanoi, mili tary sources reported. The craft was the second downed by a missile in the area.

CHARLES J. KLEIBACKER starts his day at 7:30 A.M. in one of his box-shaped rooms at the Park Royal Hotel. There he snips, stitches and drapes the timeless dresses that have led Norman Norell to rank him as one of a dozen American designers "with their own creative looks."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Thomas Trantino, under death sentence for killing two policemen in a Lodi nightclub, has been granted a second stay of execution to give his lawyer time to file an appeal with the United States Supreme Court.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson saw 5-year-old children today who, six weeks ago, did not know what a toy was, or what you did with a spoon or the meaning of the word corner, or that you had to peel a banana before you could eat it.
Classic films from the Museum of Modern Art archives will be made available to educational station WNDT for showing over Channel 13, beginning in October.
Three industrial relations authorities have agreed to serve as the public members on a panel that will study the city government's collective bargaining procedures.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- The Boston Redevelopment Authority and the Boston Terminal Company have reached agreement on the sale of the South Station railroad terminal for $6.9 million.
Net income of the companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group in the first half of this year totaled 107,885,000 ($302,078,000), it was reported yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 12 -- Malaysia will celebrate her second anniversary at the end of this month without Singapore as a member of the federation but with many of the same racial and economic problems she has always had.

The leader of a local union that says it represents the city's 600 lifeguards warned yesterday that the guards would strike tomorrow if Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris and Mayor Wagner did not respond to their demands.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 12 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today he was planning to appeal directly to President Ho Chi Mirth of North Vietnam, to President Johnson, to the Vietcong and to the Saigon Government to halt the war in Southeast Asia.
ANCHORAGE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two Russians who drifted in a walrus-skin boat from Siberia to Alaska have asked for asylum, the commander of the 17th Coast Guard District said today.
The executive committee of the New York County Republican organization yesterday unanimously endorsed Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, a Democrat, for election as Manhattan Borough President.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 -- The United States military command, stung by premature announcements of American troop movements, announced today that any future violation of security rules would be punished by canceling the military accreditation of the offending journalist.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 13 -- Hayato Ikeda, Premier of Japan from 1960 to 1964, died at 12:25 P.M. today in a hospital here. He was 65 years old.

Please permit me to question the statement in your July 29 editorial "This Is Really War": "It is fruitless at this stage to argue over errors of past policy . . ." If you mean there should be no public washing of dirty linen while our men are dying, then I agree.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Automobile production in the United States eased to 87,747 units this week as production of 1965 models went into its final days and 1966 models began to trickle out.
A zoo in Erie, Pa., contained two small gorillas last night, proving, said a representative of the Sperry Hutchinson Company, "that there's nothing you can't buy with green stamps."

ATHENS -- One disagreeable consequence of the nasty Greek crisis is its effect on NATO. The alliance's eastern flank had already been weakened by conflict over Cyprus between Greece and Turkey. But now, while a Turkish Premier is visiting Russia for the first time since 1931 and seeking to improve bilateral relations, Greece's body politic has ripped itself apart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Retail sales in the week ended Aug. 7 declined 4 per cent from the previous week, but were 6 per cent above the level of the corresponding week last year, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson formally submitted to Congress today a $140 million supplemental appropriation request to accelerate development of a supersonic transport plane during the next 18 months.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 12 -- Delegates at an international conference on birth control last night heard a former President of this Roman Catholic country accuse the church, the Government and himself of failure to cope with Latin America's runaway birth rate.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace said today he would file suits in Federal court to stop or limit racial demonstrations in Alabama and to challenge the new Federal voting rights law.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged community participation in the nation's antipoverty program last night at a street rally on the Upper West Side.
Loehmann's, a 35-year-old retail chain that sells high fashion and other apparel at discount prices, will take its biggest step next week toward shifting from a one-man to team management.
An Orthodox rabbi has entered the fight for a State Senate seat in the Bronx with the backing of the county's Democratic leader, Charles A. Buckley.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The House Education Land Labor Committee approved today the extension of minimum wage coverage to millions of new workers, including farm workers.

The directors of the Xerox Corporation voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend to 17 1/2 cents a common share from the 12 1/2 cents paid in past quarters. The new dividend is payable on Oct. 1 to stockholders of record of Sept. 3.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. David Johnstone scored an alternate-shot 43, 36 -- 79 today and won the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's husband-wife championship at the 5,861-yard, par-74 Montclair Golf Club.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Four demonstrators were hurt today when 300 singing, chanting protestors against the war in Vietnam tried to halt a troop train and board it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Lew Mathe and Robert Hamman of California took the lead in the Life Master Pair Championship this afternoon. With one session remaining to be played their total was 436 points. Leonard Harmon of New York and Ivar Stak-gold of Chicago were in second position with 429 1/2.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An official Soviet source described this year's Russian wheat crop today as poor.

The Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Company achieve new highs in premiums earned and the net gain from operations in the first six months of this year, E.F. Averyt, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The Treasury Department today held to its earlier decision to downgrade the Detroit Collector of Customs office to a district office. Senator Patrick V. McNamara said he and his Michigan Democratic colleagues, Senator Philip A. Hart, thought the decision showed "extremely poor judgment."

A Federal Government complaint of antitrust violation against the United States Aircraft Insurance Group is "without foundation in fact," the president of an underwriting concern that manages the group of aircraft insurers said yesterday.
BRASILIA, Aug. 12 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco sent to Congress today a detailed $3.5 billion federal spending plan for next yea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Rudy Bukich rifled three touchdown passes and an alert Chicago defense made two key interceptions in the fourth quarter tonight as the Bears edged the Washington Redskins, 31-30, in a National Football League exhibition game before a sellout crowd of 45,142.

Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon granted a postponement yesterday until Nov. 1 for the Justice Department to present a "plan of relief" in the antitrust suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. The Justice Department was supposed to have submitted a plan by Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Some of the 53 victims of the Titan 2 missile silo disaster at Searcy, Ark., may have died because an escape ladder was blocked when two men were jammed together in a desperate effort to pass simultaneously through a narrow opening.

In your editorial of Aug. 5 "Conflict in the Sudan" you failed to pinpoint the real causes of the conflict in that country. This is known to have been contrived by well-organized and financed Christian missionaries.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. E.C.K. Finch of the home club who won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship last week, was the low-gross victor today in the association's one-day tournament at the Country Club of New Canaan.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12 -- Experimental evidence supporting a new concept about the inheritance of behavior was reported here today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- On the surface at least, the late summer and the early fall are peaceful seasons in Britain. School is out, Whitehall slumbers, and everyone heads for 'Majorca, Portugal or the Scilly Isles.
With the second Beatles invasion about to begin on Sunday, musicologists and laymen have again expressed an almost unanimous astonishment over the way Beatlemania has taken hold.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative, had his first conference with the Russian delegation today on the dispute over the Soviet right to vote in the General Assembly while refusing to pay assessments for peace-keeping operations.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 12 (AP) -- United Nations truce supervisors succeeded in ending the tank and artillery clash at the Syrian-Israeli border today in their second attempt.

A 10-alarm fire roared out of control for more than four hours in a heavily industrialized area of Brooklyn yesterday, devastating several blocks and causing damage estimated at more than $5 million.

CRAWLEY, England -- It is 9 A.M. on a Saturday in the gleaming new shopping center at Crawley, a town of 65,000 persons halfway between London and Brighton. Operation Price Comparison is about to begin.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Steve Worcester from the American Yacht Club completed the junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound open regatta season today by gaining his fourth Lightning Class victory in five starts.

Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said yesterday that the United States "should do away" with all restrictions that limit the expansion of trade in commodities and consumer products with the Soviet-bloc nations.

" It's a beautiful day out here -- just beautiful," Roger C. Walcott said ebulliently at 10 A.M. yesterday as the stock market was opening in Wall Street where brokers longed for the weekend to begin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The chairman of the House Banking Committee criticized as special-interest legislation today a bill that would let six banks get out from under antitrust suits brought due to mergers.

Theodore C. Sorensen, President Kennedy's closest aide and adviser, said yesterday that one of the principal fears of the late President was that he was being isolated from the realities of the world by a vast bureaucracy.
Herman Frederick Marks, the former chief executioner of the Casto revolution in Cuba, broke his right leg early yesterday when he and his binoculars fell out of a tree.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 13 -- Those countries seeking economic advances through increased population were urged rather to concentrate on effective birth control programs.
New-car sales in early August were up 7.4 per cent from the volume a year earlier. The sales total for the Aug. 1-10 period was 185,816 units, up from 173,076 a year earlier.

THE scene is Harlem. To Claude Brown's sharecropper parents, it had sounded like "the promised land." And so they had migrated from the Depression South to New York. Only the promised land turned out to be a slum ghetto, "a dirty, stinky, uncared-for closet-size section of a great city."
The city's 600 lifeguards have been offered a wage increase of $2 a day, a union official said last night.

Interfaith activity involving Protestants, Roman Catholics, Orthodox Christians, and Jews has increased throughout the world in the last few months. The ecumenical spirit has broken through centuries-old barriers of suspicion and stand-offishness with such intensity that scarcely a week goes by that some new development is not announced.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Three gunmen, one of whom doffed his hat before announcing his intent, today robbed an office of the United Savings and Loan Association here of $5,000 in cash and $10,000 in travelers checks.

HOUSTON, Aug. 13 -- The New York Mets, who had lost 10 straight games outdoors, lost one indoors tonight when the Houston Astros defeated them, 3 -- 2, on an unearned run in the bottom of the ninth inning.

The decision of the Seafarers International Union to keep its members at work pending further negotiations has prevented a drastic worsening of the two-month strike of ships' officers that has tied up a major part of the Atlantic and Gulf merchant fleet. WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts, who will begin an eight-day space flight next week, will be secluded for 11 days after they land, the space agency said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Thoroughbred horse racing is becoming a fillies' game, as indicated by the high prices brought by female horses at the current yearling sales. In view of this trend, the Alabama Stakes tomorrow takes on more than ordinary significance.
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 13 -- San Lucas, the only United States Equestrian Team mount in the competition, won the Puissance (high jump) open jumper class tonight at the Sussex County horse show.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 -- The American Motors Corporation announced today the appointment of William V. Luneburg as vice president for automotive manufacturing.

A threatened sit-in at the Staten Island ferry terminal was averted by the city yesterday when the Department of Marine and Aviation paid $25,000 in disputed wages to 109 officers who had been on strike. The month-long strike ended June 8.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 13 -- President Johnson directed Secretary of State Dean Rusk today to inform the International Committee of the Red Cross that the United States was abiding by the "humanitarian principles" of the 1949 Geneva conventions and that it expected "other parties" in the Vietnamese war to do the same.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- William F. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for Mayor of New York City, was denied permission yesterday to visit Edgar Smith, a convicted murderer, in the State Prison death row.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 -- Five States Navy fighter-bombers were shot down over North Vietnam yesterday by conventional antiaircraft fire. A small United States Air Force observation plane was lost in South Vietnam.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Most West Berliners quietly went ahead with their own affairs today, paying little attention to the fourth anniversary of the erection of the wall that separates them from East Berlin.

Terry.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The 91st National rowing championships got off to a desultory start today as 13 qualifying heats were held in six events.

The election of Lynn G. Walck as a vice president of Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton, Inc., was announced yesterday by Perry A. White, president of the manufacturer of heavy construction equipment.

SEARCY, Ark., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Air Force today evacuated some workers from the Titan 2 missile installation where 53 civilians died Monday in a fire and explosion. It said that "abnormal vapors" had been detected. More than three hours later the system returned to normal.

The Beatles, those four engaging Englishmen, whose rock 'n' roll singing and long hair have stirred strong emotions in youngsters, proved yesterday that their mere presence in town can create more commotion along the Avenue of the Americas than the months of subway construction.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 13 -- Rioting broke out in the industrial city of Medellin last night as the police tried to stop the Rev. Camilo Torres Restrepo from speaking in the city's main square.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- New York pairs won first and second places in the Life Master Pair Championship this afternoon. The winners by the slender margin of one and a half match points were Sam Stayman and Victor Mitchell with 795 points.
Government bond dealers, with few orders from customers to bother them, continued yesterday to show concern that interest rates were headed higher.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 13 -- President Johnson asked Con gress today for $1,311,000 for planning and construction of reservoirs to provide additional water storage in the drought-stricken Northeast.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 13 -- A record-breaking 35, 34-69 by Graig Harmon of Wykagyl and Mrs. Thomas Hory of Winged Foot today won the Women's Tri-County Golf Association s mixed foursome championship at Tamarack Country Club.
The London gold price fell sharply yesterday in anticipation of gold sales by the Soviet Union to finance wheat purchases from the West.
LA CORUNA, Spain, Saturday, Aug. 14 -- The Government approved yesterday a bill that would abolish press censorship in Spain for the first time since the end of the Civil War 26 years ago.

New York Supreme Court Justice Edward T. McCaffrey reserved decision yesterday on a motion to enjoin the Standard Products Company, a Cleveland weather stripping producer, from acquiring a large block of its own stock.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that it would be able to supply other producers with limited quantities of its new 15-inch color-television picture tube in the first quarter of 1966.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- Marilynn Smith shot a one-under-par 71 today to take the first-round lead in the $12,500 St. Louis women's open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.8 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Aug. 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 13 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri warned Pakistan today that further "aggression" in Kashmir could lead to war.

Wallace Groves, president of Grand Bahama Port Authority, Ltd., and Louis A. Chesler, a large stockholder in Grand Bahama Development Company, Ltd., announced jointly yesterday that Mr. Chesler had severed his ties with the development group.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Aug. 14 -- The Navy announced today that it had extended for four months the enlistments of all regular Navy and Marine Corps personnel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell assailed a New York assistant district attorney today for examining his personal financial records on file with the Sergeant at Arms of the House.
DETROIT Aug. 13 (AP) -- Dick McAuliffe's two-run homer and clutch pitching by Denny McLain carried the Detroit Tigers to a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

With so much Federal aid money being waved in the direction of states and cities, for so many purposes, it would have been strange indeed if New York had not got around to asking for substantial help to relieve one of its biggest financial headaches -- its subway system. The Transit Authority has applied to Washington for $23 million to buy 200 cars, thus making its first bid for Federal help on capital improvement needs.
Some 20,000 Americans under the scrutiny of about 800 medical scientists are involved in current efforts to test the medical usefulness of the compound dimethyl sulfoxide.
MORE than 50,000 women will climb on or off the streamlined jets at Kennedy Airport this week -- coming or going, or possibly unsure which, on the overseas travel routes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- John A. Jenkins, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and today that the United States must not allow fear of Communist China to interfere with its military action in Vietnam or its over-all foreign policy.

In a sense, the New York Yankees reached a point of equilibrium by defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 3-1, at Yankee Stadium last night. They are now exactly halfway between the top and bottom of the American League -- 17 games behind Minnesota, the same margin ahead of the Athletics.

The reactivation of eight more Victory ships from the nation's defense reserve fleet was announced yesterday by the Maritime Administration. The agency said the ships were being withdrawn at the request of the Military Sea Transportation Service, the Defense Departments transportation agency.
The stock market scored a major advance yesterday, with prices moving up strongly along a broad front.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 13 -- United States military advisers are aiding Laotian guerrilla groups in raids against North Vietnamese supply trails in eastern Laos.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam has said that, prior to any peace talks, the United States must give "tangible proof of its acceptance" of Hanoi's demands of last April.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -Spokesmen for the automobile manufacturers defended today the quality of tires supplied with new cars. They said the tires were as safe as technology could make them.

More than 2,500 women began gathering here yesterday for the opening tomorrow of the four-day, 51st annual convention of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Rabbi Schulem Rubin said last night that he would ask his congregation to ratify his decision to seek the Democratic nomination in the 36th Senatorial District.
After this summer's attack of eye-twitching dresses based on the moving paterns of Optical art, the fashion world is racing down another part of the gallery of modern art.

The Great Northern Railway expects revenues this year to exceed those of 1964, but earnings may dip, John M. Budd, president, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency announced today that contracts totalling $146 million had been awarded to four manufacturers to continue developing a supersonic jet airliner.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 13 -- Australia and New Zealand reached agreement in Canberra today on plans for limited free trade between the two countries starting Jan. 1, 1966.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- United States B-52 bombers carried out a saturation raid today on Vietcong strongholds only 17 miles from North Vietnam, a United States military spokesman said.
The National Funeral Directors Morticians Association will ask to be associated with two other undertakers' groups in newly drafted codes of ethics.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 13 -- An attempt will be made tomorrow to form a statewide biracial Young Democrats organization that would support the national Democratic party.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 13 -- The brutal guerrilla war in the rain-drenched tropical bush country of the southern Sudan has reached its most ominous stage in 10 years. The rebels are better armed and more active than ever and the Government is determined to try to crush them by force.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, whose management is seeking to broaden the system's earnings power through ventures outside transportation, announced yesterday it had reached an agreement with the Macco Corporation to acquire control of the Macco Realty Company, a leading Southern California real estate development concern.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Gene Oliver slammed a pair of two-run homers and Eddie Mathews also slugged one with a man on base to lead the surging Milwaukee Braves to an 8-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The United States is withdrawing its embassy staff from the former French Congo, now the Congo Republic, in response to what it calls "serious mistreatment" of American officials there over the last nine months.

A painting contractor, who had been indicted for perjury in connection with a grand jury inquiry into the alleged rigging of bids on painting contracts of the City Housing Authority, was seized at Kennedy International last night by detectives as he stepped off a plane from Spain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Pentagon disclosed today that the commander of the First Cavalry Division had refused to accept the "austere" accommodations aboard the aircraft carrier Kula Gulf for his helicopter pilots and crew chiefs on the way to Vietnam.

Your esteemed paper reported on Aug. 5 a delay in the calling by the city of the first of its community conventions for "grass-roots leadership in neighborhood campaigns against poverty." The delay is a good thing.

Freight revenues of 87 water carriers subject to Interstate Commerce Commission jurisdiction were $48 million during the first quarter of 1965, according to Transport Economics, a monthly report published by the I.C.C.'s Bureau of Economics.
GENEVA, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The Western powers were reported today to have reached agreement on a draft treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to nations that do not now possess them.

The re-election of Mrs. Constance Baker Motley as Borough President of Manhattan has been brought closer to certainty by the unanimous endorsement given her by the executive committee of the New York County Republican organization. A Democrat, Mrs. Motley already has the Liberal party endorsement and is in a primary contest for the Democratic nomination against Earl Brown.

LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 13 -- Tommy Aaron increased his lead in the Professional Golfers' Association championship to two strokes today, while Arnold Palmer was again subjected to a two-stroke penalty because of a rule infraction.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 13 -- A Richmond surgeon today became the first Negro in Virginia's history wo win a Democratic party nomination to the state House of Delegates.
GAY HEAD, Mass., Aug. 13 -- The conservation-minded residents of Martha's Vineyard have suffered a setback in their flight against a road to be built through a dunes area on the island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A Federal Court stayed today a Federal Communications Commission order that American Telephone and Telegraph Company end its package deal known as Telpak.
Mayor Wagner declined yesterday to intervene at this time in the contract dispute between the United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education.
The city administration was accused yesterday of "fumbling, bumbling ineptitude" in its labor relations.
Stocks on the London market closed the week's trading on a generally firm note.
The Dow Chemical Company, as part of its increasing business activity outside the United States, has established a bank in Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Seven antidelinquency programs in New York City have been given $1,021,950 by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
A New York specialty-store exectutive, discussing the timing of her fall merchandising program with a visitor this week, made a telling point when she said. "Fall starts creeping in in July."

Two of New York's leading supermarket chains, Waldbaum, Inc., and Daitch-Shopwell, announced yesterday that they would discontinue use of trading stamps at the end of August. Both chains, whose combined units total 161 supermarkets, have been issuing King Korn stamps, supplied by the King Korn Stamp Company, Chicago, for about three years.
Water officials have caught the Parks Department illegally using city water to sprinkle the greens at city golf courses and have ordered the practice stopped immediately.

The gloominess of the options the United States faces in Vietnam makes it important that the country's policymakers keep open the fullest opportunities for two-way communication between them and the American people. President Johnson has been alert in recent weeks to the necessity for informing both Congress and the country of the motivations and limitations of American involvement.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The commander of the California National Guard said tonight his troops sent into riot duty would use "whatever force is necessary to do the job but we hope to avoid hurting anyone."
BONN, Aug. 13 -- When the International Chemical Fair opens in Moscow next month, West Germany's booming chemical industry will have the largest and probably the most impressive exhibit.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Strong relief pitching by Bob Tiefenauer and two errors by the Minnesota Twins helped the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over the American League leaders tonight.
The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway broke off merger negotiations yesterday that had been under way since last November.

FROM running a decorator's shop in Greenwich Village to weaving fabrics and designing clothes may not sound like a logical progression, but for Lisa Mann it has seemed the most natural sequence in the world.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox broke a tie with a run in the seventh inning on a passed ball by J.C. Martin, Chicago catcher, and beat the White Sox, 3-2, tonight behind the relief pitching of Bob Duliba.

The rain the New York Philharmonic had been dreading all week fell in Queens last night, causing what Carlos Moseley, the Philharmonic's manager, described as "an unprecedented presentation" of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

How a family repeatedly turned personal trials into triumphs is the subject of "On Thin Ice," by Henry Jelinek Jr. and Ann Pinchot. The Jelinek Family, of which Henry is the youngest, suffered as a result of Nazi persecutions hi Czechoslovakia and, later, Communist occupation.

MASSENA, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The huge cargoes involved in the new Russian purchase of 187 million bushels of wheat from Canada have already started to move down the St. Lawrence Seaway, and the volume of business ahead contributes new support to the growing enthusiasm about the waterway's future.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair and Norman Landau of Alpine won the Garden State Women's Golf Association mixed-invitation tournament today.
Soybeans, the nation's most actively traded commodity, once again captured speculators' attention yesterday, taking the spotlight away from wheat.

ATHENS, Aug. 13 -- Behind-the-scenes negotiations for a compromise candidate to settle the month-old Greek political crisis continued tonight. The leading contender at this point is Elias Tsirimokos, the former Interior Minister from the powerful Center Union party.
A liberal Roman Catholic magazine, Ramparts, has taken an editorial stand against the motion picture censorship policies of the National Legion of Decency.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 -- Should Phan Dinh Thinh's 18-year-old daughter become the mistress of an American soldier? Mr. Thinh, a shopkeeper in Saigon, has pondered the question and decided that she probably should.

A soft-spoken 56-year-old Episcopal priest bowed to the wishes of his vestry yesterday and departed from the Queens rectory he had lived in for 12 years. He left behind, at least for the moment, a neighborhood controversy over his clinic for narcotics addicts.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 13 -- Though they failed to win the Admiral's Cup, the Australians certainly have brought to European offshore racing the same delightfully refreshing approach that Gretel's men did to Newport in 1962 during the America's Cup races.
The Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., announced yesterday that its opening night performance would be given on Saturday, July 9, 1966, by the New York City Ballet.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13 -- The National Assembly today approved a Government plan to send a 15,000-man combat division to the aid of South Vietnam. The vote was 101 to 1, with 2 abstentions.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The police sought two white men today in the bombings last night of a Negro motel and hotel where civil rights workers were staying.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A rifle without a hammer or firing pin that shoots a bullet with no cartridge case or primer was demonstrated here today.

DARWIN, Australia -- Separated from the populous southeast and southwest corners of Australia by 2,000 miles of sun-baked, empty, almost waterless plains and mountains, Darwin is beginning to live down its traditional image as a remote tropical backwater with a dismal past and no future.
The Colonial Corporation of America, an apparel maker, reported yesterday that profits in the second quarter and first half declined from 1964 levels, although sales increased.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Naval Academy will use its athletic recruiting techniques and organization to attract top academic students from high schools, Rear Adm. Draper L. Kauffman, the academy superintendent, announced today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Four years of controversy over this city's handling of welfare cases ended today when the Orange County Board of Supervisors approved a resolution to merge the city and county welfare departments.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 -- Canada's business boom is being marred this year by the most serious outbreak of strikes since 1959. The trend could continue, in light of the increased militancy of the labor movement, observers here believe.
ROME, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Three landowners sought court action today to force the Soviet Ambassador in Rome to demolish two staff residence buildings on embassy property.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Paul H. Nitze explained today why he believed United States Marines sometimes must burn huts in villages fortified by the Vietcong.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Prospects for the Egyptian cotton crop this year are generally good due in large part to success in combating inroads of the cotton worm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Presidents of the United States have been signing bills with ceremonial pomp and circumstance since the early days of the republic. SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 14 -- South Korea's National Assembly, acting in the absence of 62 Opposition members, ratified today the controversial treaty restoring full diplomatic relations between South Korea and Japan for the first time since 1910.
