Dave Marr shot a one-under-par 70 yesterday to tie Tommy Aaron for first place in the Professional Golfers Association tournament in Ligonier, Pa. Each has 209 for 54 holes. Gardner Dickinson shot a 69 for 210 and Jack Nicklaus and Bill Casper shared fourth place at 211.

Only occasionally is a job posted. At times, when the striking unions clear one of the immobilized ships for requisitioned military duty in the emergency sea-lift to Vietnam, a whole crew joyfully hurries off to sign the articles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The United States campaign to get the Soviet Union and 11 other nations to pay for United Nations peacekeeping operations is expected to end next week. Barring a last-minute change of plans, the United States will indicate to a 33-nation U.N. committee that it no longer intends to make a fight to keep those nations in arrears from voting at the next session of the General Assembly this fall.
Three men were arrested early yesterday as they attempted to steal an impounded car parked in front of the High Bridge station house in the Bronx, the police said.

KISSIMMEE, Fla. -- This cowtown in central Florida has long been noted for its colorful rodeo every July 4. It is now gaining considerable fame for another annual event, one in a field far removed from cowboys and horses.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The third in a series of orbiting solar observatories will be launched Aug. 24 to investigate the sun and how it affects conditions on earth, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14 -- Two African former convicts who gave The Rand Daily Mail sworn statements about the use of electric shock tortures in a South African jail have been rearrested in the last week, the newspaper reported today.

ZURICH, Switzerland -- Those Americans who come to Zurich are often surprised by the many contrasts that this Swiss metropolis presents. Bustling Bahnhofstrasse, a shady avenue that runs from the station to the Lake of Zurich, is a reminder of the city's modern elegance.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Capt. Lones A. Wigger of the Army marksmanship training unit at Fort Benning, Ga., and M. Sgt. William E. Krilling of the same unit shared top honors yesterday as the small-bore phase of the national rifle and pistol matches were completed.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Domestic airlines and travel agents -- who are fighting for more commissions on air travel sales -- presented their views today to a subcommittee of the House Select Committee on Small Business.

GREAT KILLS, S.I., Aug. 14 -- Elias A. Kalil took first place today in the Richmond County Yacht Club's 12th annual predicted log contest for the Captain Billop Trophy. His boat, the Irene K VI, covered the 41-mile course around Staten Island at 9.8 knots with 1.1331 per cent error.

ELLIOT MARTIN may not have overt or covert intentions of letting into a race with David Merrick or any other producer for quantity production honors his season. But he could be a strong finisher if present plans materialize.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Faced with the growing demands of the war in Vietnam, the Navy has resorted to relatively brief compulsory extensions of service for regular Navy and Marine Corps personnel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Republicans have shifted to the "guns or butter" issue in their creeping barrage against President Johnson's conduct of the war in Vietnam. WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Last month, according to Government figures just published, there were 6.5 million young men and women 19 years old or less at work in the American economy, a larger total than ever before and nearly a million more than in July a year ago.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Alan Simpson, Britain's middle-distance ace, defeated Josef Odlozil of Czechoslovakia and Jim Grelie of Portland, Ore., in a mile race today with a spectacular final quarter to finish in a time of 4 minutes 4.1 seconds.

HENRY WATSON FOWLER was born at Tunbridge Wells, England, in 1858 and was educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford. The 164-year-old Brooklyn Navy Yard launched its last ship yesterday amid the blare of martial music, the boom of cannon and the fluttering of flags. St. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- The shareholders of Pet Milk Company approved today an increase in common stock from three million to eight million shares, to effect a two-for-one common stock split.

NARA, Japan, Aug. 7 -- Two enemies, dogs and automobiles, are sharply reducing the tame herd of sacred deer that have charmed countless visitors to Nara, the shrine city that was Japan's capital 1,200 years ago.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Impressive came through with a stakes-winning performance for his owner, Ogden Phipps, in the $35,300 Saratoga Special today. With the competent Braulio Baeza guiding him, the son of Court Martial took the $35,300 test for 2-year-olds by 1 1/2 lengths over Samuel Lefrak's Flame Tree.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- Relative calm descended on the riot-torn Negro district in southwestern Los Angeles today, and the immense work of recovering from five days of destruction began on many fronts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Treasury hill rate declined at today's auction after some strength in recent weeks, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
An expensive off-stage production cost the Lincoln Center Music Theater $35,000 over the weekend, the approximate cash sum that was stolen from a walk-in vault at the New York State Theater.

MIAMI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said tonight that he would fly to Los Angeles tomorrow to meet with Negro and white leaders and help create "a community of love" in the violence-racked city.
Prices on the London stock exchange rose slightly yesterday in fairly active trading. Confidence in Britain's economic prospects and the improved outlook for the pound were factors in the rise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Senate Republicans charged politics and mismanagement today to buttress proposals for a cut in antipoverty funds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- James E. Day, president of the Midwest Stock Exchange, announced today that the exchange's centralized electronic bookkeeping system has been extended to the New York City and California areas.

The Rev. W.L. Damian Pitcaithly, who last week was pressured to move himself and his clinic for narcotics addicts out of the rectory of St. George's Episcopal Church, now has a new place for the center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Last June, in one of the great Presidential speeches of our time, Lyndon Johnson told the Howard University graduating class that their hard work and good fortune had only made them a minority within a minority.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- Shorty is a fast-talking, middle-aged Negro who acts out his sentences with wide, vivid gestures. He wants everyone to know that he has worked at the same job for 18 years and that he is a conscientious taxpayer.
Two men who hold the United States publishing and distribution rights for the Beatles' souvenir programs were arrested yesterday on bookmaking charges.
BONN, Aug. 16 -- Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo met with ranking West German officials today and emerged from the meetings with promises of $2.5 million more in economic aid to his nation.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Aug. 16 -- Ketchikan, which calls itself the salmon-canning capital of the world, has four main lures for tourists: hunting, fishing, camping and totem pole watching. The deer season is open and neighboring waters abound in trout (wrapped in foil with butter, salt and pepper and cooked directly on the coals at the camp site), salmon, halibut and cod.

The police cordoned off a four-block area and firemen stood poised with hoses for three hours yesterday in the heavily populated Fordham section of the Bronx while a bomb-demolition squad dismantled a dynamite charge hooked to the rear wheels of an auto owned by a gambling figure.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 -- A high-level United States mission that recently visited Brazil has caused surprise and some uneasiness in several South American capitals.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 16 -- The ten day-old Board of Education hearing for Robert T. LeVine, suspended principal of Hillhouse High School, ended here this evening on a contradictory note.
DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- United States auto makers' production of 1965 models will end this Friday when the final 1965 Chevrolets and Mustangs roll off the assembly line.
The city withdrew a contract offer yesterday from a union that says it represents 600 lifeguards. But the union refused to accept the rejection.

The world's first nuclear-powered ship, the 9,380 dead-weight ton Savannah, will be converted from a demonstration model to a commercial one this Friday, the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.

BONN, Aug. 16 -- A few dozen spectators watched silently from the terrace of the Bonn-Cologne airport restaurant today when Asher Ben-Nathan arrived to take up his duties as the first Israeli Ambassador to West Germany.
Dr. Augustus B. Kinzel, a research metallurgist, was elected yesterday as a director of the Sprague Electric Company of North Adams. Mass.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 16 -- When the starting gate opened, nine chunky horses that can work as well as race went barrelling down the stretch like a bunch of kids heading for home on the last day of school.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- General Brewing Company, a co-defendant with the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company in the Government's antitrust fight against Schlitz, joined forces with the Government as trial of the case opened in Federal Court today.

STORRS, Conn., Aug. 16 -- A 10-point long-range conservation program to help solve the serious water shortage in the Northeast was proposed today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

President Johnson's call for an end of the two-month shipping strike puts his full prestige behind the only kind of settlement that will have any genuine significance for the nation -- one that creates the framework for an integrated arbitration machinery embracing all maritime unions and all the associations of ship operators.

FALMOUTH, England, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Robert Manry turned up alive and well today off the British coast in his tiny sailboat Tinkerbelle. He blew a kiss to his wife, downed a pint of milk and continued on the last part of his 3,200-mile solo voyage across the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Some United States officials here said today that the decision to avoid a showdown on United Nations assessments would decidedly weaken the world organization.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 16 -- The historic Hunt House on the Cross County Parkway right of way in Mount Vernon was saved from wreckers today. The house had been threatened by the East Hudson Parkway Authority's widening and straightening of the highway.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Twenty - two of Chile's 25 provinces were declared disaster areas today following violent storms that have killed 96 persons and left more than 70,000 homeless. The Government also announced that a big, new Pacific storm was headed for Chile.
A white pyramid in the Wall Street skyline is serving as a symbol for the massive face-lifting taking place in the financial district.

Under pressure from the United States Senate the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association have agreed to another moratorium in the war they have been carrying on intermittently for more than a quarter-century. Gen. Douglas MacArthur, at the request of President Kennedy, worked out the last truce between them; but, unfortunately, it did not survive the 1964 Olympics.

The Convention and Visitors Bureau held a luncheon at the Manhattan Hotel yesterday to kick off the promotion of the Army-Notre Dame and Syracuse-Pittsburgh games scheduled for October at Shea Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The military build-up now under way as a result of the escalation of the war in Vietnam produced its first tangible impact on the civilian economy today.
President Johnson called yesterday for a quick end to a maritime strike that has entered its third month.
The stock market continued its advance yesterday -- the fourth successive session of general price increases -- although profit taking in the final hour shaved the gains of some major groups.

Theodore Dreiser, who was the subject of a huge, scholarly biography by W.A. Swanberg this spring, is discussed in another scheduled for Sept. 1. It is "Theodore Dreiser, A New Dimension," by Marguerite Tjader, which will be published by Silvermine Publishers and distributed by Taplinger.
NEWPORT R.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- John Riding arrived here today in a 12-foot sloop after a leisurely solo trans-Atlantic cruise that began in July, 1964.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- A municipal judge insisted today that persons arrested in connection with rioting here had a right to bail. He refused at the opening day of arraignment to grant the prosecutor's request that they be held without bail to accommodate the police.
Many merchants were slow to comply yesterday with the controversial new regulation requiring that price tags be placed on almost all retail items.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The three major railroads serving New York City stood firm today behind their position that a merged Pennsylvania-New York Central system should not be required to continue the New Haven Railroad's passenger service.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Work training programs for 1670 dropouts from the New York City school system will be financed under a $236,802 Federal antipoverty grant announced today.
THE pleasure derived from watching a heavy trout rise up like a submarine to engulf a floating fly is at least as sweet as sneaking a meal of pasta and clam sauce while on a diet.

Buster Mathis was introduced to New York boxing society yesterday by a six-man syndicate of sponsors that hopes to make him the next world heavyweight champion. Almost everyone -- Buster included -- thought the venture might succeed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Industrial production continued to rise strongly in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Before President Kennedy made his fateful trip to Texas, he remarked: "If they are going to get me, they will get me even in church."
TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- Civil aviation negotiations being held here by the United States and Japan are expected to be recessed at the end of this week with a new agreement still unattained.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Air Force Systems Command at Andrews Air Force Base, Camp Springs, Md., announced today the appointment of Maj. Gen. Robert H. Warren as Chief of Staff.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A 10 per cent increase in earnings for the second quarter was reported today by the Federal National Mortgage Association, (Fanny May).

SINCE their marriage last year, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Duchin have been nagging painters, prodding carpenters, wheedling plumbers, haranguing electricians and learning to loathe the men who installed the marble.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 16 -- A battalion of Singapore's infantry regiment is scheduled to leave for northern Borneo within the next two days to take its place in the defensive line facing the Indonesians, informed sources here said today.

TORONTO, Aug. 16 -- Inflation, rather than the United States dollar, appeared to be the chief concern of the Bank of Canada today as the government announced terms of a $450 million federal refunding.
Four posters, each based on a forthcoming event at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, have been commissioned from four prominent American artists.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- For a few moments tonight the great Soviet ballerina Maya Plisetskaya, who has joined the Bolshoi Ballet appearing at the Royal Festival Hall, held the audience enthralled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The membership of the National Association of Securities Dealers has approved a group of of changes in the rules and bylaws of the organization aimed at implementing the changes in the securities laws enacted last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The House voted today to use up to $750,000 of Treasury money to finance Government registration of claims by Americans against Cuba.
A tender offer to purchase the 705,794 shares of Whitin Machine Works at $30 a share in cash was made yesterday by the Marblehead Corporation of this city.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- With calm prevailing for the third night, more than 800 National Guardsmen who had been alerted for antiriot duty were released here today.

A $2.1 million contract awarded to the New York Telephone Company by the city last January without competitive bidding was ruled legal yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson. The contract is part of a proposed $100 million electronic traffic-control system.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Foreign Office has told the Soviet Embassy in London that the Bolshoi Ballet cannot be permitted to give a farewell performance Sept. 13 in aid of the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that state income tax collections would be $50 million higher than Governor Rockefeller's estimate, indicating "the sales tax could have been avoided."

The American Can Company announced yesterday the development of a tin-free can for beer and other beverages.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Pentagon made public today, for the first time, an aerial reconnaissance photograph of a North Vietnamese surface-to-air missile site.

The man who is trying to frustrate a third comeback attempt by Carmine DeSapio has decided not to run with Representative William F. Ryan in the Sept. 14 primary.
Two obstacles loomed yesterday to the city's project for piecing together more than 1,200 acres of land for a continuous four and one-half mile beach at Breezy Point, Queens.
Prices of shipping containers, folding cartons, fiber cans, plastic packages and cans are rising.

Jerome Robbins, director and choreographer of "Fiddler on the Roof," is expected to perform those duties for "Come Back! Go Away! I Love You!," three short musicals tied into a triple bill by the same theme.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Johnny Longden won the 6,000th race of his brilliant riding career today with a three-quarter-length victory aboard the favorite, Prince Scorpion, at Exhibition Park.
Mayor Wagner and his bride of three weeks have chosen a six-room suite overlooking the East River at 82d Street as their new home.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Police and fire units were manned at full strength today to guard against further outbreaks of Negro rioting here.

Commissioner Newbold Morris said yesterday that the Department of Parks was still using city water on the greens at eight city golf courses but "we're not spraying them the way we were."

For many generations men have wondered what the other side of the moon -- the face always turned away from earth -- looked like. The extraordinarily detailed pictures released by the Soviet Union yesterday give the best answer to that puzzle yet available. They represent a historic extension of human knowledge -- an engineering accomplishment, perhaps intermediate in difficulty between the Rangers' photography of the visible moon and Mariner 4's camera work near Mars.
HONG KONG, Aug. 16 -- A faint but perceptible coolness has developed in Communist China's relations with North Korea.

The price of gold on the London bullion market continued to decline sharply yesterday amid expectation that the Soviet Union would make big gold sales to finance extensive wheat purchases from the West.
David L. Yunich and Walter H. Bruning, the heads of two of New York's leading merchandising organizations, added banking trusteeships yesterday to their activities.
Enthusiasm for the ecumenical movement for Christian unity dominated the conversations of 2,500 teen-agers gathered here to discuss Roman Catholic life and leadership.

There are times when constructive policies are advocated for erroneous reasons. Your July 22 editorial "Fighting Narcotic Addiction" is an example of such advocacy. While your support of humane treatment with methadone is welcome, several facts need clarification.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 16 -- This is a typical American place by the sea where typical Americans come to do typical summer things. There is a typical American vacationing group in the house across the street. They party until 4 A.M., then send a car out for pizza and when the car gets back it sits in the street and honks that the pizza has arrived.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The quarter-final matches of the Spingold Knockout Championship here this afternoon began favorably for the New York teams, three of which established commanding leads at the halfway stage.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- Can modern masters of sculpture stand the challenge of having their works viewed against the background of ancient masterpieces that set the standards of classical perfection and beauty?

YONKERS, Aug. 16 -- Six standardbreds will go to the post and there will be win, place and show wagering on Thursday night's $100,000 Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway. Customs collections in the Port of New York last month totaled $62,822,166 up $2,850,545 over the total for July, 1964, according to Joseph P. Kelly, Collector of Customs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States, in the face of certain opposition from the Soviet Union and some quiet differences with Britain, will propose tomorrow a treaty to prevent the spread of atomic weapons.

ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Three senior scientists from the Los Alamo, N.M., Scientific Laboratory, were killed during a mountain climbing expedition at South Maroon Peak, west of here, yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- Japan set an export goal of $8.53 billion today for the 1965 fiscal year. The figure represents an increase of 18.7 per cent over the $7.19 billion recorded on a customs clearance basis for the 1964 fiscal year, which ended last April 1.

The largest merger in the apparel industry in many years -- that proposed by the Puritan Fashions Corporation and the Colonial Corporation of America -- probably wilt trigger a new merger wave among garment makers.
ROME, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Churning westward through the Erie Canal, the tugboat Mary Moran approached a low bridge near here. Her captain touched a switch and the pilot house descended like an elevator.

A YOUNG Frenchman who studied upholstery and slipcover making for four years at the Ecole Boule in Paris is now turning out folding screens to order in a little shop at 1548 First Avenue (near 80th Street).

The New York Board of Rabbis announced yesterday that it had no objections to the recently announced candidacy of Rabbi Shulem Rubin. who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the State Senate from the 39th District in the Bronx.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Police here disclosed today the theft of $100,000 in jewelry from the house guests of Gene Markey, a former film producer, and his wife, the owner of Calumet Stables.
Steel production in the United States fell 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 16 (AP) -- An Army private on a hunger strike protesting his assignment to Vietnam was ordered today to face a court bartial at nearby Fort Benning when he refused orders to eat.

The September world sugar contract, in which trading stops today, and the October contract made new life-of-contract lows yesterday -- 1.68 and 1.81 cents a pound respectively. The previous lows were 1.77 and 1.90.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, a leading food processors and distributor, reported reported yesterday its 10th consecutive year of record sales and earnings in the annual period ended June 30.

THERE was a frantic rustle through a lot of closets around town last night as fashionable women tried to decide what to wear for their impromptu roles in an underground movie. In the end, shyness won over the desire to star at The Scene, a discotheque in a cozy cellar at 301 West 46th Street.

Friends of the Hampton Day School, an independent, co-educational institution to be built in East Hampton, L.I., will visit the studios of artists on Long Island Aug. 28.

CENTERPORT, L.I. Aug. 17 -- Steve Nightingale of Noroton Yacht Club took a 4-point lead in the first three races of the final series today in the Long Island Sound Midget Class sailing championship. The event is being conducted by the Centerport Yacht Club committee on the Sound, off Eaton's Neck.
The election of Richard E. Bennett as a vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced yesterday by Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 17 -- Mississippians voted overwhelmingly today in favor of a state constitutional amendment wiping out traditional state barriers against Negro voter registration. The result was viewed as a major advance for forces of moderation in the state.

Mayor Wagner yesterday made his long-expected endorsement of Paul R. Screvane to succeed him and, as equally expected, backed the Screvane running mates, Daniel P. Moynihan for City Council President and Orin Lehman for Controller. While he had complimentary things to say about other Democratic candidates for Mayor, he reserved for Mr. Screvane this superlative: "I have never known an abler executive and administrator."

The Missouri Pacific Railroad is opposed not only to a proposed merger of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad into the Union Pacific Railroad but also to a counter merger bid offered the Rock Island by the Chicago North Western Railway.

HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Vernon Law scored his 14th victory tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed the Houston Astros, 8-6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A comprehensive plan to end the present hodgepodge of state taxes levied on businesses that operate across state lines was recommended to Congress today by a special subcommittee created four years ago to study the problem.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector). Aug. 17 -- The main streets of Jerusalem were littered tonight with yellow squares of paper bearing the Star of David and the word "Jude." The printed emblems had been distributed by Israelis to protest the formal ceremony scheduled for Thursday when Dr. Rolf Pauls will present his credentials as West Germany's first Ambassador in Israel.

Shouts like these filled the three-story trading room of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange at 79 Pine Street from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. yesterday. Thirty members stood around the sugar "pit," buying and selling sugar futures for customers, or themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Fifth-seeded Patsy Rippy, an Oklahoman who used a two-handed backhand grip, reached the fourth round in the 48th annual United States girls' grass-court tennis championship today by defeating Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., 6-3, 6-4, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Arvada, Colo., a suburb north-west of Denver with a population that has doubled in the last five years, sold $5.44 million of water refunding and improvement bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate managed by John Nuveen Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The House Education and Labor Committee rejected by an 18-to-12 vote today the Administration's proposal to require double-time payment for overtime in an effort to spread employment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States' announcement that it would no longer feel bound to pay for United Nations activities to which it objected was, in the view of officials here, the best way to accept a defeat over the Soviet refusal to pay assessments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation asked industry today to submit proposals for an advanced spacecraft to be used in a worldwide commercial communications system.
Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., announced yesterday that it had borrowed $25 million from a group of institutional investors in the United States to finance new projects outside Britain.

Isaac Stern, the violinist, did some last minute shopping yesterday before leaving today for Israel. He bought one of the world's great violins, the 225-year-old Guarnerius once owned by the Belgian virtuoso, Eugene Ysaye.

CRESTLINE, Calif., Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Investigators said today an Orange County couple and their two children apparently were riddled with .22-caliber bullets for no apparent reason in the bedroom of their mountain cabin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Juan Pizarro scattered seven hits and clouted a two-run homer in the finale as the Chicago White Sox ran their winning streak to five by sweeping a double-header from the Washington Senators tonight, 7-2 and 5-1.

The British pound was steady in dull trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation was $2.7908, unchanged from the previous day.

" The Meaning of Europe," a new work of political and historical comment by Denis de Rougemont, will be published by Stein Day on Sept. 1. The American Safety Razor Company has put its Personna stainless steel blade on the back of a turtle for an upcoming ad campaign and labeled it "The blade that finishes last."
MARION, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Britain, defeating the United States for the third time, clinched the international 14-foot dinghy class matches off the Beverly Yacht Club today.

Van Cliburn and the Long Island Philharmonic will repeat the program they are offering Saturday night at the Long Island Festival in Brookville in an extra concert at 8:30 P.M. Sunday. The Saturday event has been sold out since June.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of steel, announced yesterday a doubling of capital spending plans -- to $1.8 billion over the next three years -- and a far-reaching capital reorganization.

The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday a net income of $78,075,000, equal to $1.73 a share, for the 12 months ended July 31. This compares with $72,671,000, or $1.61 a share, for the preceding 12-month period.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 -- Does the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee face a rebellion from its prospective Canadian subsidiary, John Labatt, Ltd.?
The protracted decline in Government bond prices continued yesterday, raising yields for some long-term Treasury issues to their highest levels since the spring of 1960.
BARCELONA, Aug. 17 -- Spain's tennis players took a 2-0 lead and virtually wrapped up the Davis Cup interzone final against the United States today.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington, stolen four years ago from the National Gallery and recovered last May, was on view today -- in Bow Street Magistrates Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation announced today that it is preparing to sell $20 million worth of mortgages it has acquired over the years in the process of reorganizing and merging failing savings and loan associations.
HOUSTON, Aug. 17 -- The important question of how much detail on earth's surface a man can see from an orbiting spacecraft may get a thorough scientific testing during the flight of Gemini 5.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17, Ambassador Lincoln Gordon, of the United States said today that since the military overthrow of President Joao Gou-for Progress had made more than $1 billion available to Brazil.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The semi-final matches in the Spingold knockout championship here this afternoon produced two hard-fought battles. In a match of wild swings with many slam deals, the defending champions, Eric Murray, Sammy Kehela, Bruce Elliott and Percy Sheardown, all of Toronto, led by one international match point at the halfway stage.
The city's 741 warning sirens will be tested today at 11 A.M., Robert E. Condon, civil defense director, said yesterday. The public will not participate.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., led the advance of top-seeded players today in the Essex County Club's invitation tennis tournament.
The Marine Midland Trust Company is expected to complete its acquisition of the Grace National Bank today despite the fact that a lawsuit to prevent the merger is still unsettled.
Following are sketches of some of the passengers aboard the United Air Lines jet that crashed Monday night in Lake Michigan:

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- A 10-year old Negro boy fired a shotgun blast today into a schoolyard on the South Side, injuring two white nuns, a Negro volunteer worker and seven Negro children. No one was seriously hurt.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Randy Matson, Bob Schul and Dick Roth headed United States track and swimming teams named today for the World University Games. The 10-day, competition will start Friday in Budapest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Administration picked up needed votes for the farm bill today by officially giving up its fight for the so-called "bread tax."
Following is a list of the passengers and crew members on board the United Air Lines jet that crashed Monday night in Lake Michigan:
The stock market, buoyed by mounting wave of optimism in the investment community over the short-term prospects for equity prices, rose again yesterday.

A group of 14 Episcopal clergymen, all from Arizona, have petitioned the Episcopal House of Bishops to ask the Right Rev. James A. Pike. Bishop of the Diocese of California, either to make a "public repudiation" of his theological teachings or stand trial for heresy and face the possibility of losing his position.

Aaron Copland, who has been associated with the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood since its founding in 1940, is retiring from the two positions he has held there. He has been head of the center's department of composition since 1940 and chairman of the faculty since 1957.

FISHING tournaments really prove nothing, except that a particular person or team won by catching a larger fish or more fish than the rest of the contestants. And sometimes a tourney doesn't even yield a victor.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Lew Krausse, making his first major league appearance of the season, limited the Cleveland Indians to two hits over six innings tonight and gained credit for the Kansas City Athletics' 3-2 victory over the Indians. He got fine relief help from Don Mossi.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Ian Crookenden of New Zealand, the victor over Fred Stolle last week at Southampton, was beaten in the third round of the Hall of Fame invitation grass tennis tournament at the Newport Casino today.
A plan to train large numbers of new teachers as specialists in the problems of children in slum schools has been developed by the Coordinating Council on Education for the Disadvantaged.

SAIGON, Aug. 17 -- In this phase of the Vietnamese war the most significant fact is not that big powers are being so bold but that both sides are being extremely cautious in the face of severe provocation. The commanding officer of the American forces, Gen. W.C. Westmoreland, is not rushing into battle with the Vietcong or yearning to take over the main burden of the defense from the South Vietnamese Army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The consular treaty with the Soviet Union will not be called up for Senate action this session despite the fact that it has been favorably reported by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Los Angeles County authorities estimate that the county now has 6.8 million residents and that 8.5 to 9 per cent are Negroes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- An ambitious Federal program to encourage utilities to put their electric transmission lines under ground was proposed today by Representative Richard L. Ottinger.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Problems with the Gemini 5 spacecraft power system tonight threatened to postpone the eight-day flight of Lieut. Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. and Lieut. Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr.
Two more major paper producers announced yesterday they would raise container prices a minimum of 3 per cent as of Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Tom Farrell, the St. John's track star, caught between the rival powers ruling United States amateur athletics, told a Congressional inquiry today he might be barred from college meets next fall and winter.
Directors of several corporations brought cheer to their stockholders yesterday by voting increased quarterly dividends.

PARIS, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Indonesia withdrew today from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, less than eight months after she left the United Nations in protest at the seating of Malaysia in the Security Council.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 -- About 33,000 demonstrators yelled support for former Premier George Papandreou, leader of the Center Union party, and cursed the royal family in the streets of Athens tonight while King Constantine resumed efforts to form a new government.
Profits of $2,550,628, equal to 36 cents a share, for the first fiscal quarter were reported yesterday to stockholders of Food Fair Stores, Inc., at their annual meeting in Philadelphia.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- A pair of breakdowns in the fourth event marred an otherwise perfect day of sailing today for the six skippers competing in the area semi-finals of the men's national sailing championship.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Last May's wage agreement in the general printing industry and the provincial and suburban newspaper industry may result in an increase "out of keeping" with Government policy on prices and incomes, the National Board for Prices and Incomes declared today.

SYOSSET, L.I., Aug. 17 -- A group of irate Syosset residents has called on the Oyster Bay Town Board to ascertain whether the rabbi of the East Nassau Hebrew Congregation is running a "bar mitzvah factory" and kosher catering business disrupting the tranquility of the community.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17 -- A 22-year-old former prison warder was given a three-year prison sentence today for having sworn falsely that he had seen electric-shock tortures applied in a South African prison.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board began an investigation today to determine why a jet airliner with 30 persons aboard crashed into Lake Michigan last night just short of its destination.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower demurred gently today at President Johnson's frequent suggestion that United States military
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- A general restoration of law and order in the city's riot area was signaled today when Gov. Edmund G. Brown ended the curfew in effect since Saturday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Albert Pierce of Upper Nyack, N.Y., won the East Coast championship of the 5-0-5 Class today after placing third and second in the final two races of the five-event series held on Long Island Sound off Larchmont Yacht Club.

FALMOUTH, England, Aug. 17 -- Robert Manry, stepping gingerly and smiling broadly, came ashore in Falmouth today to a hero's welcome after 78 days alone in the Atlantic. "I've never had such a reception in my life," the Cleveland newspaperman told the scarlet-robed Mayor of Falmouth, and he immediately bent down and kissed the cold concrete of the Customs House quay.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -- Results of the elections for student directorates in Brazil's universities reflected a strong protest today against Government limitations on student political activities.

The United States Pony Clubs, Inc., an organization that obviously believes it is best to start at the grass roots, welcomed 36 boys and girls from 16 to 21 years old yesterday to its International Exchange, which will run until Sept. 8.
A "shocking" increase in the reported number of neglacted, abused and battered children in Queens was disclosed yesterday by the county Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
The Harlem widow to whom Representative Adam Clayton Powell owes about $34,000 sent her lawyer into State Supreme Court yesterday to ask for $500,000 more.
The domestic airlines' passenger traffic last month increased 20.8 per cent over July, 1964, the Air Transport Association of America reported yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Hubert Julian, the so-called "black eagle of Harlem," announced today he was giving up his residence in the United States. He said the action of rioting Negroes in Los Angeles led to his decision.

The Southern California Edison Company awarded yesterday $75 million of convertible debentures to an investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- Quota restrictions on imports of foreign automobiles to Japan will be ended Oct. 1, Takeo Miki, Minister of International Trade and Industry, announced today.
Drastic revisions of city fiscal policies to cut waste and increase revenues were advocated yesterday by three aspirants for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The United States began assessing the impact of its new United Nations financial policy today, confident that it was well liked by foreign powers but less certain about its reception in Congress.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 -- The ground war in South Vietnam today went into its fourth day of lull but the air war against North Vietnam and Vietcong-controlled areas in the south continued unabated.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Wilt Chamberlain, the 7-foot 1-inch, 290-pound perennial National Basketball Association scoring leader, signed a three-year contract today with the Philadelphia 76ers at an annual salary estimated at $110,000.
May I avail myself of space in your columns to express my official and personal appreciation of the service rendered to the Borough of Manhattan by Just Lunning, who died Aug. 11.

Three new plays have been scheduled for Off Broadway presentation. "The Trigon," by James Broom Lynne, will open Oct. 2 at Stage 73, 321 East 73d Street. Arthur Cantor will produce and direct the play, described as "a perverse comedy."

BERGDORF GOODMAN is going to invade Chicago. The 64-year-old specialty store, whose customers include Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Barbara Streisand, has been negotiating to open a store in file 100-story building being constructed for the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company on North Michigan Avenue, between Delaware and Chestnut Streets, in Chicago.
CHESTER, N.S., Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Four treasure hunters were trapped in a 25-foot shaft and died today on Oak Island, which is reputed to be the hiding place for about $30 million in gold.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 17 -- Johnny Longden, the 58-year-old jockey, is evidently unwilling to quit while he's ahead -- at the wire.

WHEN temperatures and tempers soar, and the humidity wrings tears from stone statues, there's no cooking like no cooking. Yet the palate is soon appalled if salad days stretch on into a wilted lettuce infinity, and the sweet tooth begins to ache for a homemade dessert, be it ever so fattening.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Viscount Head, the British High Commissioner for Malaysia, returned to his post today after high-level consultations on the divorce between Singapore and Malaysia.
The Times (Aug. 1) contains a news item entitled "Inflation Curbs Urged in Soviet." The headline gives a distinctly erroneous impression of the content of the article.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the draft treaty on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons to additional nations, submitted by the United States to the disarmament conference here today:
A renegade colony of Portuguese men-of-war continued to plague Rockaway Beach yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17 (AP) -- A trustee was appointed today in the bankruptcy of Henry S. (Hank) Bloomgarden, one-time $21,000 prize winner on the TV quiz show "Twenty-One."

A second shareholder filed suit yesterday to prevent Standard Products Company's management from holding a special meeting on Sept. 3 at which shareholders would be asked to authorize the company's purchase of 100,000 to 300,000 of its shares at the book value of $17.25 a share.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17 Federal Treasurer Harold Holt jolted Australians tonight by presenting a budget that provides for heavily increased exppenditures, particularly for defense.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The 71st Monmouth County Horse Show, the state's oldest, will be held from Thursday through Sunday at Wolf Hill Farm here. The major beneficiary is Riverview Hospital in Red Bank.

Squads of inspectors went out yesterday to enforce the city's new restrictions on air-conditioning units. They ran into some unusual problems, including an East Side office building in which the lights fail when the air-conditioning goes off.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A draft treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons was presented by the United States in Geneva today, and President Johnson described it as an "important step forward."
Trading on the London Stock Exchange produced only small price changes yesterday as an initial upturn failed to continue throughout the day. There was a predominance of minus signs at the close.

Joseph A. Loftus in the July 30 Times states as a well-known truth something which is just not true. He writes: "In 1953, under stimulus of Korean War demands, the jobless rate fell to 2.6 per cent for five months. Economic conditions then generated tremendous upward pressure on prices and wage rates."

Did you know that if you cut the gold brocade curtain of the Metropolitan Opera House (two parts, each 30 feet wide and 48 feet high) into 3 inch by 5 inch pieces you would have about 27,000 pieces of curtain?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said today that 475 persons had already accepted invitations to attend the White House conference on equal employment opportunity Thursday and Friday.
Mrs. Esther Peterson spent a full and busy day in New York on Monday and made her first tour of an advertising agency.

Two cargo airlines, each seeking to obtain the route that Slick Airways plans to abandon, have entered an unusual aircraft exchange agreement to better equip themselves for getting authorization to serve the route, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- The Rev. Casper Glenn, a Negro Presbyterian minister, took of his clerical garb today, put on a drab sports shirt and slacks and walked out of his church into a street still littered from rioting.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The "big" horse on today's card was a filly, the Claiborne Farm's Moccasin. This Kentucky-bred full sister of Ridan streaked the 5 1/2 furlongs in 1:04 under 119 pounds while beating her nearest rival, Indian Sunlight, by eight lengths.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Three white men were arrested last night in connection with racial unrest in San Diego's Negro communities.
Vice President Humphrey appealed here last night for a worldwide effort to conquer cancer, a project he said was as important as putting a man on the moon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- U Thant made another series of intensive efforts today to prevent more serious fighting between Indian and Pakistani forces in strategic areas of Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, called today for a cut in economic and military aid to Europe in an effort to end the deficit in United States foreign payments.

A LARGE, easy-going man with twinkling blue eyes and a mane of silver hair, Dr. Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd has been the uncompromising chief architect of South Africa's policy or rigid racial segregation, a program known as apartheid.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 -- Argentina is, perhaps, the only Latin American country other than Mexico where the Alliance for Progress has had a marginal effect on economic development and where political attitudes are generally cool to the United States-sponsored development aid program.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 17 -- Despite vigorous efforts in the last five or six years to restore Bangkok's reputatiion in the northeast as a strong, beneficent ruler, there is still enough discontent in the 15 northeastern provinces to make that area especially vulnerable to subversion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles and Sargent Shriver, head of the Federal antipoverty program, exchanged bitter criticisms tonight in a dispute over responsibility for the riots that broke out in Los Angeles last week.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17 -- The retrospective concert of music by Aaron Copland, presented tonight as part of the Festival of Contemporary American Music, turned out to be, in a way, a memorial to the leading American composer. For at the concert Erich Leinsdorf came on stage and announced that Mr. Copland would no longer head the faculty and composition department of the Berkshire Music Center.
Many leading performers are expected to return to Broadway next season. With them will be an array of newcomers who will be elevated into major roles.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Twenty-three persons were arrested tonight after a rally in sympathy with the Negroes of riot-torn Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed formally today on a foreign aid authorization of $3.36 billion for the current fiscal year.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 17 -- This city, where urban renewal has registered some of its more impressive achievements, took another step toward beautification today. Mayor Richard D. Lee announced plans for an $8 million skyscraper as headquarters for the Knights of Columbus, the Roman Catholic fraternal order founded here in 1882.

Revlon, Inc., is planning to add the U.S. Vitamin and Pharmaceutical Corporation to its long list of diversified operations that range from drugs and hair preparations to shoe polish and women's apparel. The acquisition would involve nearly $55 million of stock.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 17 -- The Indian Government's policy toward Pakistan came under renewed attack in Parliament today.

Prices of copper fluctuated widely yesterday in what one broker called a "rather mixed-up market." Four of the eight contracts made new life-of-contract highs yesterday but all four dropped enough to close below the previous day's final prices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The Administration asked Congress today to extend the Sugar Act to 1971. It recommended giving domestic and Latin American producers a larger share of the United States market and dropping a proposed sugar import fee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- The California Public Utilities Commission rejected today a plan to put asterisks in telephone books to mark the manes of subscribers who did not want to receive solicitations by phone.
Most prices stayed within a narrow range in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 -- A former United States soldier who refused to return home after being held prisoner by Communist China during the Korean war arrived here today expressing a desire to "live a peaceful, ordinary life" in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The airlines operating across the North Atlantic studied today a Civil Aeronautics Board suggestion that they cut economy fares by about 10 pet cent.

The latest readings on the current state of business activity and the future cost of the war in Vietnam are contributing to a new wave of confidence among stock market investors in Wall Street and economists in Washington.
Gregory Cruz, 23-year-old clerk who was shot and arrested by a city detective last Sept. 9 filed a $2 million damage suit yesterday in Federal court against the city.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Fifty-one community leaders met for two hours with Mayor Richard J. Daley today to try to form a program to prevent a recurrence of two days of rioting in a West Side Negro district last week.
YONKERS, Aug. 17 -- Queen's Mohican, given the benefit of a ground-saving drive by Del Insko, won the feature invitation one-mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Government reported today the first quarterly surplus in United States transactions with the rest of the world since 1957.
The city of Mobile, Ala., is making a determined bid to fall heir to the Spanish Pavilion at the World's Fair.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Jim Lefebvre's third straight single scored the tie-breaking run in the seventh inning tonight and the Los Angeles Dodgers pulled away to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies that maintained their half-game National League lead over the Milwaukee Braves.
David C. Cates, manager of the bank stock department at Salomon Brothers Hutzler, has a story that he sometimes tells security analysts' groups in order to characterize bank stocks.
Nine more films have been selected for showing at the third New York Film Festival, which starts on Sept. 7 at Philharmonic Hall. Twelve movies have already been announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A Senate committee wrestled today with the problem of balancing freedom of the press and defendant's right to a fair trial without damaging either of these constitutional guarantees.

President Johnson's decision to endorse a common market for Latin America as the Alliance for Progress enters its fifth year is a constructive effort to improve hemispheric relations. So is his pledge to seek new ways to bolster world prices for the basic commodities Latin Americans depend on for a large part of their foreign earnings.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Although the New York Jets have 54 musclemen in training camp here, the smoke screen of a cleverly designed promotional campaign has obscured all but three, the bountifully advertised quarterbacks. Perhaps that's as it should be, though. In the modern scheme no pro team gets very far without an outstanding passer.

Tokyo, Aug. 17 -- Tokyo's newly elected Metropolitan Assembly today began what appears certain to be a turbulent four-year term by electing a Socialist as speaker. This was the first time a Socialist had filled the job.

An abstract painting by Stuart Davis is about to emerge from the relative obscurity of a WNYC television studio and go on exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The work, done in 1939 as a relief project, is now valued at $60,000 to $100,000.
Charles (Ruby) Stein is a dapper Broadway figure known to authorities as the "most notorious loan shark in the metropolitan area" and a man who owes the Government $276,000 in income taxes.
THE Bench Warmers of the Mets proved yesterday that the men of the team have a consistently sharper eye off the field than on it.

EVERYWHERE there are brave people who endure the blows of fate and the miseries of life with steadfast courage. But it takes more than this kind of quiet bravery to defy tyranny and to risk death or imprisonment when both could be avoided by merely keeping one's mouth shut.
Customer's net debit balances, which show the borrowings of individual investors on margin, registered a substantial decline of $252 million during July.

CAPE KENNEDY, Aug. 17 -- A gigantic "crawler-transporter" that is to move the Saturn 5 moon rocket from an assembly building to its launching pad here has been crippled by the repeated failure of roller bearings.
The French import called "Life Upside Down," which began a commercial run yesterday at the Little Carnegie, was presented here last year at the New York Film Festival under the title "Inside Out."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Johnson gave a ringing assurance to Latin America today that the United States would support to the fullest the goals of economic and social development laid out by the Alliance for Progress.
Settlement of the 63-day strike of marine engineers was announced yesterday by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Chase Manhattan Overseas Banking Corporation, will open an office in Melbourne, Australia, in September.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche called today for the elimination of "every black ghetto in this land" as the only way of preventing a recurrence of the kind of racial violence that racked a Los Angeles area.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd last night ridiculed the idea that he had been trying to provoke clashes with the United States to win votes in South Africa.

LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Dr. James Z. Appel, president of the American Medical Association, predicted today that "quite a few" doctors throughout the country would refuse to participate in the medicare program.
NEWARK, Aug. 17 -- Anthony DeAngelis, the key figure in the $150 million vegetable-oil swindle, was sentenced today to 20 years in jail.
PARIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- President de Gaulle received a two-hour report today from Andre Malraux, Minister of Cultural Affairs, on his recent talks with Communist Chinese and Indian leaders.

DETROIT, Aug 17 (AP) -- Willie Horton drove in four runs with two homers tonight to pace the Detroit Tigers to a 7-4 victory over the league-leading Minnesota Twins. The triumph sent the Tigers into sole possession of second place in the American League.
The $4 million purchase of a 1,928-acre tract in Yaphank, L.I., formerly owned by Webb Knapp, Inc., has been completed by Mid-Island Estates, a development concern headed by Bernard Krinsky.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- Clearing their decks for the four-game series against the Los Angeles Dodgers later this week and for the increasing pennant-race pressure that series will mark, the San Francisco Giants today reactivated Orlando Cepeda, rested Willie Mays, announced that Warren Spahn was their starting pitcher for the Dodger series and polished off the New York Mets, 3-2, for the second day in a row.

A crowd officially estimated at 73,500, the largest ever to attend a New York Philharmonic program, filled the Sheep Meadow in Central Park last night to hear the free concert. In the opinion of some Philharmonic officials, it was the largest audience ever to attend a symphony concert anywhere.
Settlement of the 63-day strike of marine engineers was announced yesterday by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 19 -- United States marines have trapped about 2,000 Vietcong guerrillas with their backs to the sea and killed "hundreds" of them in the first major battle involving American troops in Vietnam, a military spokesman reported yesterday.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that its previously proposed offer to exchange some of its common shares for a new preferred issue will be made to shareholders on Sept. 7. The offer will expire Sept. 30.
Three prisoners overpowered a Department of Corrections guard and escaped from a detention cell yesterday in the county courthouse in St. George, S.I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for early floor action on legislation substantially altering the nation's immigration laws.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- State Health Commissioner Hollis S. Ingraham said today that 34 communities and 29 industries faced hearings soon on charges that they were major water polluters.

" New York City has become a colossal failure in human arrangements," writes Richard J. Whalen in "A City Destroying Itself," which William Morrow will publish September 15. Mr. Whalen is also the author of "The Founding Father: The Story of Joseph P. Kennedy."
Thirty-one public housing authorities sold $132,025,000 of bonds yesterday in the third sale of such securities under the auspices of the Public Housing Administration this year.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A test case on whether suburban school boards may agree to educate pupils from racially imbalanced city schools was brought before the State Education Commissioner today.

Sylvester Muldowny and Milton J. McNicholas have been elected directors of the Andrea Radio Corporation. Mr. Muldowny is chairman of the executive committee of the Wilson Bros. Corporation. Mr. McNicholas is manager of Government and industrial sales for Andrea Radio.
PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The French Government said today that the recent talks between Chinese Communist leaders and Andre Malraux, French Minister of State, were of "very great significance."

President Johnson's intervention has ended the most complicated phase of the nine-week shipping strike -- the walkout of marine engineers. But the ship lines and the unions representing masters, mates and radio officers are still wrangling over contract terms. Even though the negotiators have failed to meet the President's settlement timetable, there seems little doubt that the United States and the other prides of the merchant marine will soon be back on the high seas.

An officer of the American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it was doubtful that the network would continue to televise major-league baseball next season. This season the viewing audience has been smaller than was hoped, and A.B.C. and the baseball clubs have had disagreements on how the games were to be covered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled today that it was a clear violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to designate a racial qualification in help-wanted advertisements.

A giant balloon capable of lifting 10-ton loads out of inaccessible logging areas will be delivered next month to the Bohemia Lumber Company, Cottage Grove, Ore., Goodyear Aerospace Corporation, the manufacturer, announced yesterday.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. Aug. 18 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, criticized Negro civil rights leaders tonight, saying they had not provided leadership in Northern cities.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 18 -- The old Turkish battle cruiser Yavuz, which played a key role in the entry of Turkey on Germany's side in World War I, has been put up for sale as scrap to the highest bidder.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- Edward G. Lansdale, once a much sung operative of the Central Intelligence Agency and now a retired Air Force major general, will bring with him eight to 10 aides when he comes here to serve as a special assistant to Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge, official United States sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach designated today five additional counties in Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana for Federal examiners under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Pete Ward and John Romano combined for seven runs batted in tonight as the Chicago White Sox won their sixth in a row beating the Washington Senators, 8-2.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- The Government proposed today that the Transamerica Corporation, one of the world's largest holding companies, be ordered to set up a new statewide banking system if the $3.75 billion merger of two large California banks is declared illegal.
ESOPUS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The last in a century-long line of "wickies" abandoned today the Victorian lighthouse that rises up in the middle of the Hudson River at Esopus, south of Kingston.
ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- King Constantine, in a last-ditch effort to break Greece's five-week political deadlock, tonight asked Elias Tsirimokos, a 58-year-old Socialist, to form a Government.

Plans for a second residence for the elderly, a $4 million, 16-story apartment house in Flushing, Queens, have been announced by the Flushing YMYWHA and United Help, an agency that assists Jewish victims of Nazi persecution.
Three steel companies were fined a total of $100,000 yesterday on price-fixing charges after they changed their pleas from not guilty to no contest.

Contracts have been drawn for "Man of La Mancha" to open late in October at the ANTA Washington Square Theater, 40 West Fourth Street, the former home of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company. The musical is based on "Don Quixote" as well as incidents in the life of its author, Cervantes.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus and Arnie Palmer were among the 154 golfers who tested Pleasant Valley's fairways and greens today in a final tune-up for the opening round tomorrow of the $200,000 Carling world golf tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Eric R. Murray's Canadian team made a powerful bid to retain its Spingold Knockout Team title here this afternoon. At the half-way stage in the 72-board final match his squad led Edgar Kaplan's team by 62 points.
TOKYO, Aug. 18 -- In a guarded communique, Japan and Nationalist China pledged today to "maintain and develop" close relations.
Two 100-foot U-shaped objects were towed from Hoboken to Brooklyn yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown announced tonight the allocation of $1.770,000 in Federal funds to aid the 45-square-mile site of Negro rioting here, as National Guard troops began leaving the area.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- United States military advisers to South Vietnamese troop units have been ordered to refuse to accompany them on operations likely to lead to ambushes and to refuse the use of United States - controlled resources such as helicopters in such operations.

Fines against landlords for building violations have been steadily declining to a point where the court is no longer considered by city officials and civic groups as an effective tool in the fight against slums.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- John Huarte, battling Joe Namath for the quarterback job of the New York Jets, practiced place-kicking today as the team prepared for the exhibition contest against the Buffalo Bills at Rutgers Stadium on Saturday.

Robert Moses has informed the executive committee of the World's Fair Corporation that the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority will rehabilitate a portion of Flushing Meadow Park when the fair closes. Mr. Moses is president of the fair and chairman of the authority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Melvin M. Belli, a former attorney for Jack L. Ruby, indicated his opposition to the bill today in a letter that was read into the record.
ATLANTIC CITY. Aug. 18 (UPI) -- A convention of 1,000 Negro Masons has deplored the Los Angeles riots because they "hurt the American Negro in ibis civil rights fight."
The diagram above illustrates the motion of the (]eminl 5 space craft relative to the Rendezvous Evaluation Pod during the ejection, separation and rendezvous maneuver.

The F.W. Woolworth Company, which operates the country's largest chain of variety stores, announced yesterday that it would open a store chain in Spain and also import Spanish-made goods for sale in its stores in the United States, Canada and elsewhere.
The Sunshine Mining Company announced yesterday what it described as "two major discoveries" of silver at its mine in Kellogg, Idaho.
The stock market went up in the morning, down in the afternoon and ended just about where it began yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Juan Marichal, whose next assignment will be a head-to-head battle with Sandy Koufax on Sunday, worked at the opposite end of the scale of difficulty today. He hurled a three-hitter against the New York Mets and gave the San Francisco Giants a 5-0 victory, which completed a three-game sweep of the New Yorkers.
A decline of 2,784,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
The price of gold dropped another cent to $35.12 1/4 an ounce on London's bullish market yesterday.

The Maritime Administration has decided to subsidize an American Export Lines Isbrandtsen containership service to Europe for a six-year trial period, Nicholas Johnson, administrator of the agency, announced yesterday.

For two days 150 water inspectors made several thousand inspections here to test compliance with the city's new restrictions on the use of air-conditioners. At 2:10 P.M. yesterday, one of the inspectors finally got tough.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The Chrysler Corporation introduced today a moderately restyled line of 1966 Dodge cars and stressed the safety features.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today he had had reports that confidence men representing themselves to be Medicare representatives of the Social Security Administration were swindling elderly persons in the Dallas and Buffalo areas.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 18 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, the Prime Minister of Malaysia, is scheduled to make an emergency trip to Sabah and Sarawak tomorrow in an effort to head off growing dissatisfaction in those two states over their position in the Malaysian federation.

ALBERTSON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- A grant of $225,000 was announced today by the Irene Heinz Given and John LaPorte Given Foundation to meet the costs of specially designed equipment and furnishings for the newly constructed Human Resources School here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Civil rights leaders said today that Mayor Richard J. Daley's "refusal" to explore their suggestions for removing causes underlying Negro rioting had left the situation as "explosive" as ever.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Roger Taylor and Mark Cox of Britain found themselves in jeopardy today, but won their fourth-round matches in the lawn tennis Hall of Fame invitation tournament at the Newport Casino.
THE well springs of teen-age enthusiasm run deep and Abraham Straus knows how to tap them.
Negro building trades workers voted last night to picket an undisclosed construction site next Wednesday morning in a mass demonstration against job discrimination.
A table-model microwave oven that operates on regular ll0-volt household circuits was introduced and demonstrated here yesterday by the Atherton Division of Litton Industries, Cleveland.
SEATTLE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A decision on the back-to-work movement by more than 6,000 nonstriking Metal Trades Union members at Seattle shipyards has been postponed by their leaders until Friday.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Gov. John A. Volpe signed today a bill making racial imbalance illegal in Massachusetts public schools.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Sargent Shriver said today that the missing ingredient in Los Angeles's antipoverty operations was the participation of the poor.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The 25th anniversary of an international defense pact that began here as a hasty scrawl on a white tablecloth was observed today by Canadian and United States officials at a colorful ceremony on a bank of the St. Lawrence River.

LA BAULE, France, Aug. 18 -- Twenty-seven youngsters of eleven nationalities shoveled, scooped, shaped and scrutinized mounds of sand in Brittany today on one of France's best beaches. They were participants in the eighth annual Contest of Sand Sculpture.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -The omnibus farm bill survived bruising attacks from both Democrats and Republicans today as the House edged toward a final vote probably late tomorrow.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The Black Rock Yacht Club crew, captained by Ralph Sperry Jr., won the Area B semi-final series of the North American junior sailing championship today as the two-day, four-race series, sailed in Lightning Class sloops, ended with two races on Long Island Sound off Black Rock Yacht Club.
BONN, Aug. 18 -- The West German Government rejected today an East German proposal to extend the Berlin pass agreement until Jan. 31, 1966.

No state has fought a more stubborn rear-guard battle against equal rights than Mississippi. Even murder has gone unpunished in the violence of its resistance to granting the Negro the equality of opportunity the Constitution supposedly made his birthright. Most disturbing of all, the few who raised voices of reason against bigotry and hoodlumism often found themselves reviled or ostracized.

The Southern Company reported yesterday a net income of $63,889,442, equal to $2.70 a share, for the 12 months ended July 31. This compares with $59,521,495, or $2.51 a share, in the preceding 12-month period.
The Harsco Corporation, a Harrisburg, Pa., metals refiner, announced yesterday the election of J.G. Underwood as an executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York and chairman of the powerful House Judiciary Committee and its antitrust subcommittee, announced today his unalterable opposition to proposals to grant a partial immunity from the antitrust laws to stock exchanges.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- President Johnson today signed legislation authorizing development of Ellis Island as part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.
Directors of the Alan Wood Steel Company have approved arrangements to borrow $30 million from institutional investors to pay for capital spending.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The building of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will begin about Dec. 1 on the planned Potomac River site, despite a recent outcry that it belongs in the heart of Washington.

WADING RIVER, L.I., Aug. 18 -- The sign at the sprawling roadside orchard reads "Pick Your Own Peaches." It attracts passing motorists who harvest their own tree-ripened fruit at $2.50 for a 16-quart basket. A half-mile away at a roadside stand the same amount of fruit would cost $3.75.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Jack Kralick and Gary Bell scattered 11 hits to give the Cleveland Indians a 4-1 victory over Kansas City in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Athletics had taken the opener, 4-2.

Questions about our means in Vietnam persist in many minds. Is there any qualitative difference between Hitler's blitzkrieg over the Netherlands and our bombing, strafing, defoliation, scorching, spilling jellied gasoline, hunting in helicopters to kill Asians like rabbits in North Vietnam?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- To hear people tell it, people are ruining everything. "They've ruined it," people said of Paris one year after they went there and discovered it full of people.
THE new member of the City Planning Commission was visibly excited and moved as she spoke of her appointment yesterday.

South Africa's white minority Government is using all of its substantial powers to discredit the recent detailed disclosures of appalling practices in the country's prisons. Typically, it is trying to persecute and prosecute those responsible for the disclosures instead of ordering a judicial inquiry to determine actual prison conditions.
WALTER LIPPMANN told Howard K. Smith in June 1961 that President Kennedy was "not moving in a new direction -- but changing the direction in which he's going to move."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- There is "a time to be born and a time to die," Ecclesiastes tells us; "a time to weep and a time to laugh . . . a time to get and a time to lose." So it is in life and so it surely is in politics -- which, after all, is only a desperate effort to cope with life.

A Young. Young Sophisticate will own a real fur coat, bell-bottom trousers and a Mondrian-inspired smock, aggressing to Gimbels, which opened a second-floor children's boutique with a fashion show yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The White House reported today that consumers had received the benefit of about three-fourths of the $1.75 billion excise tax reduction enacted two months ago.
Two prominent civil rights leaders pointed an accusing finger yesterday at Los Angeles Police Chief William H. Parker in separate assessments of the causes and effects of the West Coast riots.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 18 -- A scheduled conference of the Indian and Pakistani Foreign Ministers has been canceled because of what the Indian Government described as "a sharp and serious deterioration" of relations between their countries.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., has again run into a situation in which a new account assignment is in the same area as an old account.

SARATOGA SPRINGS N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Lady Dulcinea made her way out of the pack in the stretch to win the $25,400 Adirondack for 2-year-old fillies today. The daughter of Nantallah had the margin of a neck over Leonard P. Sasso's Lovely Gypsy in carrying the colors of Jacques Wimpfheimer to the victory.

A Brooklyn grand jury will begin Monday an investigation of a patrolman's role in the death of a 20-year-old Negro grocery clerk -- the jury's third investigation of a killing involving the police in the last four weeks.
" United States Steel is tired of being the whipping boy of Wall Street," a brokerage firm officer declared yesterday. "This latest move is an announcement to the world that Big Steel isn't dead."

The new Soviet pictures of the face of the moon invisible from earth have posed a major mystery before the world's astronomers and intensified debate among scientists backing different theories of the moon's origin.
Advances in making clock and cameras more independent of the user were in the spot light yesterday.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 18 -- In a hysterical finish, with the umpire screaming for silence, Jose Luis Arilla and Manuel Santana defeated Clark Graebner and Dennis Ralston, 4-6, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, 11-9, in three hours of magnificent, thrill-stabbed tennis on the Real Club's court today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a three-step increase in the minimum wage to $1.75 an hour and added coverage of 7.2 million workers.

The Los Angeles riots beg us to view by contrast the calm of New York City this summer and to reflect on the reasons for this calm -- such antipoverty programs as Job Corps, Neighborhood Youth Corps and countless other programs run by public and private agencies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -President Kennedy and his advisers all believed that the Soviet Union was "almost certain" to retaliate elsewhere when they ordered a blockade of Cuba in the 1962 missile crisis.
Record or near-record earnings were reported by most companies in the oil industry in the first half of this year.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Roger T. Fortin's Thunderbird, a light-displacement fiberglass sloop of the California-40 Class, won in Class A for the second day in a row in the Corinthians and Stamford Yacht Club cruise today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- New York City was relieved today of its obligation to pour 200 million gallons of water into the Delaware River system every day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Federal judiciary urged today legislation to restrict information that prosecutors or defense attorneys should give to newsmen about Federal criminal cases.

A financial wizard who turned a corporation's $4 million annual loss into a $684,000 profit in only three years was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Defense Department of more than $1 million.

President Johnson's announcement of plans to release water from Greenwood Lake in New Jersey to Newark Reservoirs brought expressions of concern yesterday from residents and officials in the lake area.

In its Aug. 13 editorial "Protection for Conscience" commenting on the revision of the Taft-Hartley Act now before the Senate. The Times raised the question whether "such action should not be accompanied by other revisions in labor law more directly keyed to advancing the national welfare."

Approval of the merger of the Kings County Trust Company and the Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn was voted by shareholders of both institutions at special meetings yesterday. The merger plan must still be approved by the New York State Banking Department and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates built up a seven-run lead and held off a ninth-inning uprising by Houston tonight to hand the Astros an 8-7 defeat.

IT'S still too early in the season for grandstand managers to begin calculating which pitchers might attain the sacrosanct plateau of 20-game winners.
