But it is not too early to toy with a much more resplendent idea. Can Sandy Koufax, the most Artful Dodger of all, move into the baseball stratosphere with 30 victories?
TOKYO, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- The positions of Japanese and United States civil aviation negotiators are still far apart, a Japanese spokesman said today.

Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach disclosed yesterday that the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company had reached agreement with the Government on a plan to settle the antitrust suit pending against the bank.
The nation's electric power production rose 12.3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 14 from the level in the 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
FALMOUTH, England, Aug. 18 -- Robert Manry of Cleveland walked the streets of Falmouth today as a national hero after his 78-day voyage from Falmouth, Mass., in a 13 1/2 foot sailboat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler sharply disputed today the view that the improvement in the nation's balance of international payments was hurting other countries and drying up the world's money supply.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Buffalo's plan for ending racial imbalance in the public schools was attacked at a hearing today before Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner.

The battle on the Van Tuong peninsula makes evident the extent to which American troops are now directly engaged in combat in South Vietnam. In these circumstances the question of how the United States got into this land war in Asia takes on political as well as historical interest.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Each concert of the current Festival of American Music at Tanglewood has been arranged to include a Fromm Music Foundation commission. This evening it was "Folia," by Charles Dodge, a work scored for nine players and the assortment of instruments beloved of so much of the avant-garde.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senate Democrats held fast today against fresh Republican assaults on the $1.65 billion antipoverty bill.

Reflecting the record results in the fiscal year ended June 30, directors of the Meredith Publishing Company authorized yesterday the distribution of a 100 per cent stock dividend, and raised the quarterly dividend to 42 1/2 cents from 35 cents a share.

THE man-size sandwich is moving onto the Chock Full O' Nuts menu to meet the demands of hearty male appetites in the Wall Street area. It seems to be setting a trend for the restaurant chain throughout the city.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Kansas City has engaged Barton H. Emmet of the Minnesota Theater Company at Minneapolis to establish a professional repertory troupe and build a theater.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- Pope Paul said today that the Ecumenical Council was seeking to restore "the Christian conscience" to those who have easily absorbed the "new ideas, doubts, negations and utopias" of their time.

Two westerly sections of Jones Beach were shut down yesterday after about 15 bathers reported that they had been stung by Portuguese man-of-war jellyfish, which have been plaguing bathers at The Rockaways since Sunday.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- The $2.20 minimum payoff prescribed by the recently passed LaVerne bill may have spread a certain amount of happiness among some bettors in the harness racing set. However, some of the operators of the eight trotting tracks in New York State have become disenchanted with that part of the pari-mutuel law.

CENTERPORT, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Steve Nightingale of the Noroton Yacht Club had a first and a second place today, in the final races of the series to win the Long Island Sound Midget sailing championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The nation's top amateur athletic organizations were accused today of semi-professionalism and of wearing out athletes through improper administration of international track meets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Maxwell D. Taylor, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, declared today that the "increasing brutality of the terror tactics of the Vietcong" had helped to produce a sharp rise in the flight of refugees into territory controlled by the Government of South Vietnam.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane was given the preferred position on the voting machines yesterday among Democrats running for the mayoral nomination in the Sept. 14 primary.

NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE, England, Aug. 18 -- For the first time in the history of polar exploration, an American vessel has successfully penetrated and traversed the Kara Sea in the Soviet Arctic to gather basic oceanographic information.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., the Fullerton, Calif., food and grocery processor, reported yesterday a 29 per cent increase in earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30 on record sales.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The British Labor Government's austerity program appears to be succeeding and the nation's foreign trade should show a surplus by the end of next year, an economic review said today.

FIVE-MINUTE chess is played with time-control clocks. Either player, at his risk, may take as much time as he wishes on any move. But the player whose clock ticks past the five-minute mark loses, regardless of the position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The White House, seeking to prevent any partisan breach on Vietnam policies, insisted today that there was no difference between President Johnson and former President Dwight D. Eisenhower over the historical basis of the American military commitment in Vietnam.
Fifteen health and hospital experts put forth proposals yesterday to expedite better medical services in the state under provisions of the Folsom Act, which will take effect next Feb. 1.

Representative John V. Lindsay charged yesterday that in the last decade the city government had allowed "our economic base to deteriorate, our business opportunities to evaporate and our jobs to disappear."
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Police Chief John Lyons refused tonight to grant a parade permit for a civil rights protest demonstration Saturday to protest alleged police brutality.
Just how big is the commodity futures business?
After nearly six months of house hunting, a young couple found their "dream house."
The Kaiser Jeep Corporation introduced yesterday a new high-fashion Wagoneer station wagon series. The new models embody the first major changes since the line made its debut three years ago.
India, through one of its more successful manufacturers, announced here yesterday that it was ready to make its first industrial investment in the Western hemisphere.

An Episcopal minister and a Reform rabbi charged yesterday that the owner of a building in Astoria, Queens, refused to rent space to them for a narcotics clinic after he had received threatening telephone calls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara, has told a Senate Committee that Soviet air defense missiles "have shot down several U-2's in the past several years."

WATERFALL, Alaska, Aug. 18 -- A salmon canning factory may not sound romantic and idyllic but, by golly, the Nakat Packing Corporation here may come, in its setting at least, as close as any other on earth. Visitors arrive by a small plane (there's no other logical way to get here that wings its way over hundreds of small, multiform islands, fishing craft and spruce-filled mountains dotted with lakes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- John E. Gardner was sworn in today as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and was asked by President Johnson to chart the course for new Great Society attacks on disease, ignorance, poverty and bigotry.
ROME, Aug. 18 -- Four American citizens jailed in Palermo's Ucciardone Prison at the start of an anti-Mafia drive on Aug. 1 were visited today by the United States Consul, John Ordway.
The election of Plato Malozemoff as a director of the Bankers Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday by William H. Moore, chairman.
The Emery Air Freight Corporation has elected John T. Thompson as a director, it was announced yesterday by John C. Emery, chairman.
Whitey Ford, who has survived more adventures in the Bronx than Charles Buckley, survived another last night, but the rest of the New York Yankees were not so lucky.

HOUSTON, Aug. 18 -- The Gemini 5 space flight, planned to begin tomorrow, will probably tell medical scientists definitely whether man can safely live in space long enough for a round trip to the moon.
HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Dr. Duane Graveline, 34 years old, resigned today as one of the nation's six new scientist-astronauts, the Manned Spacecraft Center announced.

PORT WASHINGTON. L.I., Aug. 18 -- The 33d annual race week of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club began today with a smart turn of wind and 196 starters trying for championships in 21 classes. All hands hoped that each of the remaining four days would produce equally good sailing.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- A supporter of the discredited Lysenko school of biology has warned against an uncritical acceptance of the tenets of classical genetics, long barred from Soviet research.

The Opera Theater of New York presented a staged production of Verdi's "Otello" on the Central Park Mall last night. It was the fourth of eight summer performances in parks given in co-operation with the Department of Parks.
Murray H. Weinkrantz, head of a group of investors who specialize in lower Manhattan commercial buildings, has moved to new offices at 230 Park Avenue. Mr. Weinkrantz was formerly at 22 Reade Street.
The American Stock Exchange showed little strength yesterday and most issues ended mixed in quiet trading.
Mrs. Samuel Spatt of 136 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, long active in community affairs, was named by Mayor Wagner, yesterday as a $15,000-a-year member of the City Planning Commission.
The short-interest position of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange set a record in the month ended Aug. 13 for the second successive month, the exchange announced yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller accepted with bitterness yesterday the admission of 13 upstate counties to membership in the Appalachian Regional Commission.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- The state today for the first time raised the speed limit to more than 50 miles an hour on a major highway containing cross roads.
A youth about 19 years old shot and wounded two other youths yesterday after they had teased him about his long black hair. He fled after the shooting and was being sought by the police.

CAIRO, Aug. 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser met tonight in Alexandria with Yemeni republican leaders, including Ahmed Noman, who was ousted as Premier six weeks ago, to try to work out proposals for a peace compact with Saudi Arabia on Yemen.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 18 -- William Ostermiller, former Hillside Township treasurer, pleaded guilty here today before Union County Judge Chester A. Weidenburner to three accusations charging him with embezzling a total of $53,716 in township and Board of Education funds.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Julia Anthony of Malibu, Calif., turned in another excellent performance in reaching the quarter-final round of the United States girls' grass-court tennis championship today. She scored a 6-4, 6-1 victory over eighth-seeded Cecilia Martinez of San Francisco at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The secretary-treasurer of the International Typographical Union suggested today a "grassroots" campaign among local unions to initiate a policy of higher assessments to replenish the organization's depleted strike fund.

DALLAS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Sheriff's officers jailed the 27-year-old husband of Mrs. Marina Oswald Porter tonight after she said he slapped her in the face and frightened her with a gun. They were married less than three months ago.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- John Marshall of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, Conn., took the lead today for the ninth North American championship of the 5-0-5 Class by winning both races that opened the series off Larchmont Yacht Club.

President Johnson's program of Federal help for the drought-stricken Northeast, prefaced by publicity fanfare and hurried visits by "crisis teams" to several cities, confirms the expected: Neither Washington nor anybody else has any magic formula for instant water.
About 2,500 delegates unanimously adopted a budget of $9,488,000 yesterday for the 1965-66 programs of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 17 -- There is a rumble of serious discontent in the Sudanese Army, which has been bogged down for months in a campaign against increasingly well-armed guerrillas fighting for self-rule in the southern Sudan.

Charles Seligson, the court-appointed trustee for Ira Haupt Co., said yesterday he would not be able to meet the Sept. 15 deadline set for acceptance of the American Express Company's settlement offer to victims of the salad oil swindle.

NAHA, Okinawa, Thursday, Aug. 19 -- Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan said on his arrival here today that the Japanese could not consider the postwar era ended 'until Okinawa's return to its home country."
MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Bluefish fans up and down the Long Island coast are enjoying an excellent and sustained run of the choppers.

Not since Ralph Greenleaf emerged 45 years ago from Monmouth, Ill., to win the world pocket billiard title at 19 years of age has there been a youngster, some say, the equal of 20-year-old Steve Mizerak Jr.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

OLIVE MOORE was having a hard time to decide what to give her husband, Bill, for Christmas eight years ago. "I wanted to make it a real surprise," said Mrs. Moore. "A neighbor of ours in Trenton, Edward Marshall Boehm, the famous sculptor, owned some minia ture schnauzers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach denounced today as "outrageous" proposed legislation that would legalize, retroactively, six bank mergers that the Justice Department believes violate the antitrust laws.

Efforts to resolve the last of the merchant marine's current labor disputes continued in Washington last night after Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz reported to President Johnson that the differences between the industry and the mates' and radiomen's unions were not settled.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- Whenever the doorbell rings these days in the unpretentious suburban home of Fritz Seltmann, his little girl rushes into the basement to hide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- United States Senators are being deluged with thousands of letters from members of Liberty Lobby and other right-wing organizations urging them to vote against the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- When America goes to war, even to hide-and-seek war like this one in Vietnam, it goes big!
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Thursday, Aug. 19 -- The United States will seek an official world record for the longest manned space flight when the Gemini 5 begins its eight-day journey here today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Don Dillard's pinch homer in the ninth inning tonight gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and their sixth triumph in a row.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- An Adlai E. Stevenson Memorial Fund to continue Mr. Stevenson's work for world peace and international cooperation was announced here today. The fund is to be supported by contributions from the public.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Government is seriously considering ending the arrangement that for the last two years has exempted married men without children from the draft.
The threat that New York City would run out of water next winter was ended yesterday, barring unforeseen difficulties, a spokesman for the Department of Water Supply said last night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17. -- When their leaders, their finances and the Vietcong perpermit, the Saigonese still do their best to have a good time in their tense city.
Trading continued quiet on the London stock exchange yesterday and most sections showed losses.
Government-bond prices appeared to stabilize yesterday as most issues closed unchanged from their levels Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson, who had hit into a triple play in the first inning, singled home the winning run in the eighth tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Boston Red Sox, 3-2.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Bret Hanover's winning streak ended here today when he was beaten in the first heat of the Review Futurity for 3-year-old pacers by Adios Vic. The time for the mile was 2:00.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- A high Government official said today that criticism of United States policies in Vietnam by prominent civil rights leaders might lead to dangerous miscalculations by America's enemies.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Leading Chicago churchmen donated $20,000 tonight to build a community leadership organization in a West Side Negro neighborhood torn by rioting last Friday.
The Boston Stock Exchange, which is revamping its rules and procedures, said yesterday that Smith Barney Co., Inc., has purchased a membership for $5,000.

Having put off his retirement date since June 30 for lack of a successor, Herbert R. Mayes can now step down as president and chief executive officer of the McCall Corporation. A successor to the presidency has been found.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 19 -- Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barreras, president of the junta regime, charged today that the Organization of American States was largely to blame for the delay in ending the Dominican civil war.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 19 -- A white Volkswagen pulled up across the street from the building of The Rand Daily Mail this morning and parked in a spot that gave the two men inside an excellent view of the newspaper's front door and the entrance to its garage.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- Julie Anthony of Malibu, Calif., today scored her third successive victory over a seeded player and reached the semi-finals of the United States girls grass-court tennis championship. She defeated fourth-seeded Wendy Overton of Ormond Beach, Fla., 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
The International Harvester Company had record sales in three and nine months ended July 31, but its earnings declined from the levels a year earlier, the farm-equipment maker reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- William E. Simkin, the Government's chief labor mediator, said today he was confident negotiations would avert a steel strike, threatened for Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The proposal to add a 611-acre mainland tract to the Fire Island National Seashore appeared today to be heading for Congressional approval.
A $500,000 campaign for funds to combat "the roots of discrimination and poverty" was announced yesterday by the Urban League of Greater New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 -- Eight American Special Forces soldiers were rescued by helicopter today after the Vietcong overran a mountain town near the Laotian border. But the fate of the South Vietnamese garrison there was not known.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 -- Demands for the resignation of Police Chief William H. Parker were intensified today by church and civil rights leaders, both Negro and white.
Wall Street traders, who yesterday appeared to be looking for a reason to reap some profits after six straight ad-advances, found their excuse in an adverse British economic report.
The election of Roy C. Hackley as a vice president of the Continental Oil Company was announced yesterday by L.F. McCollum, chairman. Mr. Hackley had served as executive assistant to Mr. McCollum.

TO a wayfarer along the sports trail it comes as a continual surprise to discover how steadily the heroes of his youth fade away into the misty past. A new generation of fans takes over with recollections that don't go much beyond Joe DiMaggio in baseball, Slingin' Sammy Baugh in football and Joe Louis in boxing, the same generation that is convinced Arnold Palmer is the inventor of golf.

SUTTON, Mass, Aug. 19 -- A thunderstorm halted the first round of the scheduled $200,000 Carling open golf tourney today. The deluge washed out the 17th tee and prevented resumption of play after the rain abated at the Pleasant Valley Country Club.
A one-year contract in the cotton-garment industry was agreed on yesterday by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and representatives of major shirt and pajama manufacturers.
A report strongly favoring the installation of water meters here is almost ready to be sent to Mayor Wagner. It may be placed on his desk early next week.
ANGOLA, La., Aug. 19 (AP) About 500 convicts lounged on the grass in a fenced compound tonight in a sitdown strike at Louisiana State Prison.
ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- Supporters of former Premier George Papandreou clashed with policemen in downtown Athens tonight. At least 10 persons were injured.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The feasibility of a jetport on eastern Long Island will be discussed here on Sept. 3 by officials of the Federal Aviation Agency and Suffolk County.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight, in the latest week ended Aug. 14, were both ahead of levels in the corresponding 1964 week.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Don Fullmer, using a stinging body attack in close, won a unanimous decision over the world welterweight champion, Emile Griffith, tonight in a 12-round nontitle fight.
ON Dec. 29, 1170, four of King Henry II's household knights forced their way into the Cathedral of Canterbury, terrorized the monks and priests there and killed the Archbishop.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United States aid authorities sent an inquiry to Saigon today on whether South Vietnam is trying to spend American aid for luxury furniture.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- A bus crash in the Catskill Mountains yesterday claimed a second life today, when Susan Fierro, 15, of Liberty N.Y. died of injuries.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 19 -- The last of the five consecutive evening concerts of the Festival of Contemporary American Music took place tonight in the theater-concert hall at Tanglewood. Much the same pattern was observed.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Three boats were locked in a close struggle for the lead today after two races of the Atlantic Class national championship at the Cedar Point Yacht Club.
Changes approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission in the long-pending Flatlands Industrial Park in Brooklyn are expected to lead to a prompt beginning on the project's actual development.
In a game marked by fielding gems, Clete Boyer's 13th home run of the season and Mel Stottlemyre's pitching, the New York Yankees defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 3-1, at the Stadium yesterday.

William F. Buckley Jr., Conservative party candidate for Mayor, caustically criticized yesterday the 10-point program for the economic rejuvenation of the city outlined by Representative John V. Lindsay.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 19 -- The United States finally salvaged one point from this Davis Cup debacle when its top-ranking player, Dennis Ralston, defeated Juan Manuel Couder, a substitute, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, at the Real Club de Tennis today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 -- John A. McCone was appointed chairman today of a committee of influential residents of the Los Angeles area who will investigate the causes of the Negro rioting here and recommend action to prevent its recurrence.

The 4:58 out of Long Island City swayed and clacked and baked under the afternoon sun on its way to Oyster Bay. In the bar car, balloons bobbed festively on the ceiling, fried grasshopper hors d'oeuvres glistened on the counter and a rock 'n' roll combo began to wail, "I can tell, I can feel, You are mine, you are reeeeel."

I was particularly interested in your Aug. 9 editorial dealing with "Project Camelot." As a member of the subcommittee on international organizations and movements of the House Foreign Affairs Committee which held hearings on this project and other social science research programs conducted abroad, I was deeply disturbed by the "Camelot" case, and by certain issues implicit in it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee overruled its Republican members today and approved a $1.2 billion outlay for President Johnson's new program of school aid and medical research.

New Jersey water officials said yesterday that the drought-stricken northern counties would get through the year without running out of water. They strongly indicated that this would have been so even if President Johnson had not declared the section a drought disaster area.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- The Chrysler Corporation unwrapped its 1966 Plymouth here today. The new cars included a restyled line in the intermediate class and an affluent version of its standard-size Fury model.

THE quickest, most convenient and least expensive way to buy readymade clothes and have them look like custom is to go to a good, understanding store -- and then get on affectionate terms with the alteration department, many women have discovered. For these shoppers it means nothing to pay more for alterations than for a dress, suit or coat.
The housing shortage here has eased, but not enough to end rent control.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 19. -- A demonstration against Dr. Rolf Pauls, West Germany's first Ambassador to Israel erupted into violence today during the ceremony for the presentation of his credentials.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Duane E. Watts's Knutsen-35 sloop, Willowind, Roderic M. Scott's Triton, Jeff MacDane, and John Runyon's wooden-hulled Galatea, a Shaw-24, scored close victories today as the six-day cruise of the Corinthian and Stamford Yacht Club closed with a 17.9-nautical-mile downwind race.

The architects of international monetary reform face a formidable task. Just how formidable is apparent from a study of various reform proposals undertaken by 33 experts from the ten leading industrial nations under the chairmanship of Rinaldo Ossola of the Bank of Italy.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has donated "Esso World Theater," eight cultural programs filmed in as many countries, for showing on educational television stations. Esso sponsored the hour-long shows last year on commercial stations in several cities, including New York.
John J. Burns, the new Democratic state chairman said yesterday that future legislative patronage will be cleared by his office.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The contest for district attorney of Nassau County mushroomed today into charges and countercharges involving a deputy sheriff's badge, a former convict, an extortion case and reports of a Federal investigation.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- A foursome from Rockville Links won the Hoffhine Trophy at Westchester Country Club today after shooting a 296 early in the day and watching the rest of the field drop out of contention.

FRANKFURT, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Johann Schobert, 42, youngest of the defendants in the Auschwitch trial, was acquitted today in accordance with proposals by defense and prosecution. The prosecution said he had shared only "minor guilt."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- Roy Emerson of Australia and Roger Taylor of Britain filled the semi-final upper-half brackets in the lawn tennis Hall of Fame invitation tournament today at the Casino.
BUTTE, Mont., Aug 19 (UPI) -- Charles R. Lee, who sought the governorship last year as a third-party candidate, was injured early today when his car was blasted by dynamite.
There were some tense moments yesterday when experts from the Metropolitan Museum of Art began to remove the Stuart Davis painting from its wall in a WNYC television studio in the Municipal Building.

The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York notified the newspaper's management yesterday that it would strike during the week of Sept. 12 "if a satisfactory contract has not been reached before that time."
The New York Giants yesterday completed the reorganization of their executive staff, naming Wellington T. Mara as president of the National Football League team.

Frank Wille, State Superintendent of Banks, has sent out a second set of letters to all national and state commercial banks in New York. This time, he is seeking comments on the proposed holding company being formed by the Bankers Trust Company.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 19 -- The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia is greatly concerned over possible financial failure of the Davis Cup challenge round because of the United States' loss to Spain in their interzone semi-final.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The International Typographical Union called today for more cooperation among the printing trades in negotiating contracts and in prosecuting strikes when they occur.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales in the week ended Aug. 14 amounted to $5.21 billion, a drop of 1 per cent from volume in the previous week, but up 5 per cent over the level of the corresponding 1964 week.
Victor Muscat, president of Defiance Industries, Inc., said yesterday the concern or one of its subsidiaries would "probably" make a tender offer for control of Whitin Machine Works.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, Aug. 19 -- David Warner, who made such a success of "Henry IV" for the Royal Shakespeare Company, played Hamlet in a new production at Stratford-on-Avon tonight.

An Illinois Congressman has entered a plea to the nation's airlines to speed up introduction of a new crash-clue device in the wake of last Monday's jetliner disaster near Chicago, which claimed 30 lives.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 19 -- Heat, electrical problems, lightning and fire combined today to postpone the eight-day Gemini 5 flight at least until Saturday.
Stock brokers and secretaries could scarcely believe what they saw at the corner of Wall and Broad Streets yesterday morning shortly before the New York Stock Exchange opened at 10 A.M.
Stock prices fell sharply on the London exchange yesterday as a run of discouraging news darkened the economic outlook.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 19 -- Seventeen former members of the Nazis' Auschwitz concentration-camp staff listened calmly today while a West German court pronounced them guilty of having participated in murder and torture.
TORONTO, Aug. 19 -- The effect of a default by the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., continued to widen today, as its parent company disclosed that it would pay no quarterly dividend on Sept. 1.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- John Marshall of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, Conn., remained undefeated in the North American championship of the 5-0-5 Class today when he won the third and fourth races of the series being held on Long Island Sound off Larchmont Yacht Club.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Home Office announced today that an independent group headed by a High Court judge would examine the case of Timothy John Evans, who was hanged for a crime he may not have committed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Senate underwrote today a $1.65 billion, one-year extension of the antipoverty campaign. The vote on final passage of the bill was 61 to 29.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 18 -- The refrigerator assembly line began rolling at the General Motors plant this week after seven months of idleness.
ANDREW GOODMAN will give a party or go to one quicker than anyone can say Bergdorf Goodman.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked yesterday by the city and state of New York and by the Port of New York Authority to reopen the record in the Norfolk Western Railway's merger of last year by which it acquired the New York. Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and several other railroads.

One of the "largest peacetime mobilizations" in the history of the nation's merchant fleet is under way behind a Defense Department cloak of secrecy, Representative William S. Mailliard said yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Eighty-eight, a 28-year-old brown gelding from the stables of David Sapkin of Hidden Valley, Calif., proved that you're only as old as you feel as he scored twin victories in the opening session of the four-day Monmouth County Horse Show today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved $1 million today to continue planning the Tocks Island dam and reservoir on the upper Delaware River during the fiscal year that began July 1.
Business loans at banks reporting to the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $80 million in the week ended Wednesday. the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

In early July it was revealed, amid the worsening drought, that the Wagner administration had sent investigators into other cities to examine their experience with water metering as a conservation measure. A staff report to City Administrator John V. Connorton now estimates that installation of meters in 390,000 one-family and two-family houses and 140,000 apartment houses could save the city 150 million gallons of water daily.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House approved a compromise $3.36 billion foreign aid authorization bill today after praising its negotiators for resisting Senate demands for a two-year program at double the amount.
Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday it had exercised its option for 15 Douglas DC-9 twin jet airplanes for 1967 delivery.

For those of us who admired Adlai Stevenson no physical memorial could fully capture the magnanimity of his spirit or the humanity of his vision. At best we can hope to indicate the depth of our admiration for him, and I believe changing First Avenue to Adlai Stevenson Avenue would be an appropriate, if only partial, way for New York City to honor his greatness.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Eight major foreign steamship lines obtained a temporary restraint in Superior Court today against a National Maritime Union official who has been charging them with violations of state law.

Because of certain divergencies of view between The New York Times and Walter Kerr, general manager of the International Edition of The Times, concerning the operation of that edition, Mr. Kerr and The Times have agreed to terminate their relationship.
James A. Farley endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beame for the Democratic mayoral nominationx yesterday and declared that Mayor Wagner was the biggest boss "we've had around here in a long time."

AREA A -- Some blues have been hooked at Acid Waters at night. There is a plentiful supply of mackerel at Brielle, but porgies are scarce there. A wave of green algae has hampered fishing around Long Branch. Some fluke and stripers have been found there, however.

YONKERS, Aug. 19 -- Race Time, as expected by virtually everyone -- and especially by the stockholders at Yonkers Race-way -- was the easy winner of the $100,000 Empire Pace tonight at the hilltop course. The track operators were so certain that Race Time would triumph, they had the horse barred from the wagering.
PEKING, Aug. 16 -- All signs still indicate that China wants to stay out of the war in Vietnam. After a two-week vacation, a returning resident is struck by the lack of any sense of crisis in Peking.

Jimmy Dupree, who has picketed for his punching rights, will meet Johnny Persol Tuesday night in the 10-round main event at Madison Square Garden, a match made with the help of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company warned yesterday that the "welfare wave of the future" is likely to bring increasing pressures to finance Social Security spending from the general revenues of the Treasury.

Genesco Inc., which is firmly planted in both retailing and apparel manufacturing, is interested in adding to its 37 operating divisions through new acquisitions of companies producing children's wear, women's dresses, men's and women's playwear and swimwear.
The price of gold dropped a cent an ounce to $35.11 1/4 on the London bullion market yesterday, following a similar decline the day before.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Canadian defending champions retained their title in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here in a session that ended early this morning.

NAHA, Okinawa, Friday, Aug. 20 -- Okinawan leftists, demanding the immediate return of this American-administered island to Japanese rule, staged a tumultuous five-hour demonstration last night and early today, and barred Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan from his hotel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation asked 24 firms today to offer earth station construction plans for antenna systems in Hawaii and the state of Washington.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Eight fires, several ignited by "Molotov cocktails," flared up overnight in the predominantly Negro districts of East Palo Alto and East Menlo Park, the police reported.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 19 -- The police opened fire on mobs looting grain shops in Kolhapur today.
LOWER BANK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- In a bustling factory on the Mullica River here near Egg Harbor, the piercing whine of the power saw offers a noisy rebuttal to the idea that wood boats are passe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A group of Government officials, labor leaders and personnel officers tackled today what experts on sex discrimination in employment call "the bunny problem."

BONN, Aug. 19 -- Former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer charged today that the new United States proposal to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons would mean in the long run "the surrender of Europe to the Russians."

The executive director of the National Committee For a Sane Nuclear Policy announced yesterday that a peace rally would be held in Washington Oct. 16 to urge President Johnson to seek an early end of the Vietnam war through political negotiations.
DALLAS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Thirteen of 22 white summer instructors were dismissed today by the president of Bishop College, a predominantly Negro school, for what he called "stirring up the students."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 19 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower repudiated today any effort to make a partisan issue of the Johnson Administration's policy in Vietnam or its decision to concede defeat on the United Nations assessments controversy.
Uneasiness over the British economy weakened prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prizes for the dates shown.

The Hospital Review and Planning Council of Southern New York, as quoted in the Aug. 11 Times, stated "that there would be sufficient general hospital beds in the metropolitan area to meet the needs of elderly persons when Medicare went into effect next year."
The legality of the new city regulation requiring a price tag on everything sold here was challenged in State Supreme Court yesterday by a group of art dealers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Government told Americans today that the national economy has been a little different from what we all thought it was, at least statistically, but not only this year and last but all the way back to 1948.

RICHMOND, Aug. 19 -- Top officials of the United States Plywood Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation of Virginia disclosed plans here today for a joint plywood manufacturing venture that will make use of pine-forest resources in Virginia and Maryland.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (Comtelburo) -- The decision today of Ford Motor Company, Ltd., to put 10,000 workers starting next week on a four-day week was blamed on credit restrictions and the inability of dealers to stock up.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- A dispute of theory as well as of practice has crystallized between strategists of the Soviet Union and the United States over the issue contained in the phrase "war of national liberation."

A plan to acquire some of its own shares for redemption and retirement was announced yesterday by the Continental Insurance Company through its chairman, J. Victor Herd. The plan has been approved by the New York State Superintendent of Insurance, he said.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Gov. Harold Hughes called out Iowa National Guard troops tonight in a move against what he said were "rumors of everything from civil demonstrations to riots" to occur at the opening of the State Fair here tomorrow.

A setback to improved Soviet-American relations is the news that the consular treaty with Russia -- negotiated more than a year ago -- will not be called up for Senate action this session for fear it would not be ratified. Such a treaty, has been needed ever since diplomatic relations were established in 1933, if for no other reason than to provide legal protection for citizens of each country traveling in the other.
Marine engineers in Atlantic and Gulf ports overwhelmingly ratified a new contract yesterday in the first break in a 65-day maritime strike by three unions.

HOUSTON, Aug. 19 -- The fuel cell system, which caused two separate periods of uneasiness before contributing to the postponement of the Gemini 5 flight today, is one of the most important technical innovations of the mission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Johnson carried his campaign of national unity to the State Department today.
Michael D. David has been named a vice president of the Cerro Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Robert P. Koenig, president of the nonferrous metals mining concern.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 19 -- Malaysia and newly independent Singapore, weighing their economic need for each other, appeared ready today for close cooperation in trade despite their sudden split last week into two nations.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 19 -- Prince Ismail Nasiruddin Shah, Sultan of the Malayan State of Trengganu, today was chosen the new Yang di-Pertuan Agong, or Paramount Ruler, of Malaysia.
CORNING, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- A graduate center that will enable students within 50 miles of Corning to earn advanced, degrees from four colleges and universities will open here in September.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Aug. 19 -- A racially integrated educational program has been started here to test whether a group of public school students who have not reached the top academically can be developed to their full potential.
The State Department is planning to send overseas three popular American musicals that would be performed in repertory in an experimental mobile theater during the 1966-67 season.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Dick Stranahan, Indian Hills, and Pat Palmieri, Southampton, eliminated the 1961 champs, Gene Borek, Pine Hollow, and Gil Cavanaugh, Meadow Brook, 2 and 1, in the quarter-finals of the Bob Stuhter Memorial golf tournament at the Sands Point Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The report of a major success in Vietnam has underscored a question that has puzzled Washington this summer: Why is the war not going as badly as had been predicted?
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Two unpublished works of Sergei Prokofiev, criticized under Stalin for their "unmelodiousness," will be performed here on the 75th anniversary of the composer's birth next spring.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Vice President Humphrey said today that American Negroes were on the verge of a major economic crisis that could not be averted simply by ending discrimination.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Mrs. Timothea Larr, who as the former Timothea Schneider once included the national Raven Class championship among her sailing laurels, was back at the tiller of one of the slippery planing sloops as a winner today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week competition.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Communist party sharply attacked President Johnson tonight for what it called his introduction of a new and dangerous foreign policy for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The United States in a major tactical decision, announced today that it would go ahead on schedule Sept. 16 with agricultural offers in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations in Geneva, even if the European Common Market is unable to meet the deadline.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Senators received sharply conflicting views today on whether legislation was necessary to assure that the right to a fair trial was not impaired by freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The House Interstate Commerce Committee approved today a three-year, $90-million program to develop high-speed ground transportation that could carry commuters between Washington and Boston at 150 miles an hour.

The Democratic primary fight steadily sinks to lower levels. Recently we chided Paul P. Rao Jr., campaign chairman for Abraham D. Beame, for outrageously misusing a scholarly book of which Daniel P. Moynihan was co-author, in an obvious effort to stir up racial and religious prejudices against the Screvane-Moynihan-Lehman ticket. Now supporters of the Screvane slate have stooped to equally disreputable tactics.

The American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company has elected Richard E. Sansom, a corporate vice president, to its board. It also named Ralph E. Calhoun mining vice president. Mr. Calhoun was formerly manager of mines.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Government released new evidence today that austerity had begun to grip the nation. Uncomfortable reports that unemployment was edging up while production was declining came on the heels of a private economic analysis that Britain would soon face a choice of either continued "quasi-stagnation" of the economy or an inability to repay her massive debts by 1970.

Who remembers the acronym Batson used to shout tot Billy turn into Captain Marvel? Who remembers the "everyday" identities of Superman and Batman, the Flash, the Spirit and Plastic Man? It may all come back in a rush in November, when Dial will publish "The Great Comic Book Heroes."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Officials here are still trying to puzzle out the significance of Andre Malraux's recent conversation with the Chinese Communist leadership.
" Some folks say being a porter is a low-class, dead-end job. But if you do your work and the boss likes you, you never can tell. Anyway, a decent $1.88 an hour is better than welfare."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- President Johnson has directed that the costs of the Vietnam war should not be allowed to become a disguise for hidden military expenses and increased, unnecessary spending, the White House said today.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 19 -- The Indian Government proposed today a sharp increase in import duties on many goods to help meet a $200 million gap in this year's budget.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 19 -- Congolese rebels ambushed a 10-man army patrol about 60 miles from Albertville Tuesday and killed all but one of its members.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, pastor of the Revelation Baptist Church here, was granted a restraining order today that prohibits seven members of his congregation from interfering with services next Sunday.

THE bell has sounded for Seventh Avenue's Mondrian-sweepstakes and few have been left at the starting gate. The burst of early speed put on by manufacturers could rival any stable of thoroughbreds. The concerns that have not entered the race are either thinking in Mondrian terms or awaiting the shipments of Paris originals that will arrive here about the end of the month.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 19 -- "It looked like a Bowery bum. You wondered, if you washed the dirt from its face, whether you would find anything worthwhile left underneath. But it responded magnificently to every touch."
MONCTON, N.B., Aug. 12 -- Twice each day Moncton watches the gigantic Bay of Fundy tides rush up the Petitcodiac River channel, and dreams of power -- tidal power.
ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- A Greek cartoonist took the liberty of making some changes in the royal coat of arms today.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The United States Army sent three helicopters today to drive away an unidentified helicopter believed to be East German, sighted over Checkpoint Charlie, the East-West crossing at the Berlin boundary.
Mayor Wagner yesterday directed Armand D'Angelo to arrange for a team of observers and scientists to fly to California where success has been reported in rainmaking by electrifying the atmosphere.
VANTUONG, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 -- Under a sweltering midday sun, United States Marine Supply Column 21 lumbered to its death yesterday in the morass of a Vietnamese rice paddy.

An English husband and wife were arrested here yesterday morning on forgery and grand larceny charges growing out of a bank robbery in London last month.
The House of Representatives has a duty to unseat five members from Mississippi who were "immorally elected under an illegal system," Representative William F. Ryan declared yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Jim Lonborg batted in two Boston runs with a double and pitched a six-hitter tonight as the Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 11-3.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) --Jim Maloney of the Cincinnati Reds pitched the first major league no-hitter of the season today, beating the Chicago Cubs, 1-0, in 10 innings.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Civil rights leaders met with Gov. John A. Volpe for more than six hours today and then dropped plans for a big weekend demonstration in racially tense Springfield.
SAIGON, Aug. 20 -- The savage battle at Chulai -- the most successful but costly American engagement of the Vietnamese war -- has a very special but limited significance.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) --The St. Louis Cardinals took advantage of four Milwaukee errors to score two unearned runs and defeated the Braves today, 5-4.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 19 -- There were Cadillacs in the cornfields, cold turkey on the table and air-conditioning in the tent as major Republican contributors met today on former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's farm to discuss the financial condition of their party.
Government bonds finally made it yesterday. They closed higher after three weeks of modest declines. However, the general advance could hardly be described as robust.
A private agency to help increase United States exports to African nations on a mutually beneficial basis was announced yesterday by a group of business and educational officials.
Holders of short positions in soybean futures dashed for cover yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. As a result, they rushed buying orders to cancel their positions.

The banking community tried yesterday to analyze the news of the settlement between the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Department of Justice in the pend ing antitrust suit against the bank.
Jimmy Rushing and the rain both arrived about halfway through the Jazz in the Garden concert last night at the Museum of Modern Art.
The National Fuel Gas Company sold $19.5 million of sinking fund debentures yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Goldman, Sachs Co.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- In the sort of extravagantly eventful, interminable struggle that made Giant-Dodger games legendary in New York, the Los Angeles Dodgers today reclaimed the National League lead by defeating the San Francisco Giants, 8-5, in 15 innings.

The 26-story, 1,200-room Henry Hudson Hotel, once the temporary home of the United Nations Security Council, has been sold for more than $4.5 million to an investor who is considering renovation of the building to serwe the hotel trade generated by the Lincoln Center complex.

Charges against the Rt. Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, by 14 priests of his church -- all Arizonians -- are not likely to result in a heresy trial for at least two reasons, church sources said here yesterday.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 20 -- In a fierce two-day battle that ended yesterday, United States marines killed at least 550 Vietcong guerrillas, trapped on a peninsula about 72 miles south of this port town.
TRENTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Edgar H. Smith has been granted a seventh stay of execution in his eight-year series of appeals from a conviction for killing a 15-year-old Ramsey High School girl.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Sandy Valdespino's pinch-single in the eighth inning scored Zoilo Versalles from second base and gave the Minnesota Twins a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the second game and a sweep of a doubleheader today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Dick Stuart's double with the bases loaded in the 12th inning drove in three runs at 12:05 A.M., today and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-3 victory that knocked the Los Angeles Dodgers out of first place in the National League.

A Federal judge yesterday ordered the manufacturer of 454,000 Eisenhower jackets, previously convicted of defrauding the government and misappropriating cloth, to pay $485,629 for the stolen material. Two associates and three corporations also were ruled liable for the reimbursement.
DALLAS, Aug. 19 -- Marina Oswald Porter and her husband of two and a half months, Kenneth Jess Porter, agreed to resume their marriage today after they had talked alone in a judge's private office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House passed the omnibus farm bill tonight after days of bitter debate. The vote was 221 to 172. The bill now goes to the Senate, where it could meet trouble. Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, who was Secretary of Agriculture under President Harry S. Truman, has been highly critical of the measure.
Stock prices on the London exchange continued to move downward yesterday, but declines were narrow in contrast to the sharp drop in the preceding session.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- A West Berlin court suspended a ruling today under which a 9-year-old girl Angelika Kurtz, was to have been taken from the West Berlin home of her father and sent to East Germany to live with her mother in Zittau.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Some of 13 white instructors dismissed by Bishop College left for home today. A half dozen stayed in their campus apartments, however, "to make a point."

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Aug. 20 (AP) -- A traffic accident early today took the life of Matt H. Murphy Jr., 51 years old, a third-generation member of the Ku Klux Klan who attracted attention by his legal defense of a Klansman charged with murdering a white civil rights worker.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Consistently good sailing today moved Dr. Thomas Kantor into first place by 9 points after four races of the Atlantic Class national championship at Cedar Point Yacht Club.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The meeting between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and King Faisal of Saudi Arabia due to take place in Saudi Arabia in the next few days shows that both sides are eager to end the war in Yemen, according to British diplomatic informants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, a Roman Catholic, joined today as a co-sponsor of a bill by Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, to deal with population control.
The Opera Society of Brooklyn and the Brooklyn Academy of Music will present three opera companies at the academy this fall and winter for a total of a dozen performances.
A Federal official said yesterday that the Government was investigating the tangled affairs of a bankrupt jukebox company, which have touched off charges against public officials.

A salesman accused of assaulting a switchboard operator last year was discharged in his own recognizance yesterday after the plaintiff reported she could not go through with the "lurid details" of a second trial.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- Nettled by a line decision, Fred Stolle of Australia lost his composure and the hour-long opening set to Edward (Butch) Newman of San Antonio, Tex., then recovered to win the quarter-final match in the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame invitation tournament at the Casino today.
While some futures markets were quiet yesterday, the grains and soybeans were demonstrating plenty of zest.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Irvin Cross, a defensive halfback for the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, has run afoul of zoning restrictions in suburban Newtown Township, and may not be able to build the $26,000 home he had planned.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Orlando Pena's clutch relief pitching gave Detroit a 3-2 second-game victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight and a sweep of their double-header. Denny McLain pitched a three-hitter as the Tigers won the opener, 2-0.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A group of top Soviet scientists and artists published an open letter to President Johnson today saying they were "shocked to the depth of the soul by the monstrous massacre of the population of the Negro ghetto in Los Angeles."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 20 -- Two major battles in central Vietnam subsided today, and the focus of military action returned to small guerrilla operations in the Mekong Delta, where South Vietnam's population is most heavily concentrated.

The petition filed by Jesse Gray, a militant civil rights leader, for a place on the Sept. 14 primary ballot as a candidate for Mayor was attacked in court yesterday for containing "page after page" of forged names of enrolled Democrats.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- John Marshall, a 23-year- old skipper from Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, Conn., won the ninth annual North American championship of the international 5-0-5 class with a perfect score today as the three- day regatta ended off Larchmont Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senators seeking to untangle the amateur athletic feud got some suggestions today and heard a witness call the Amateur Athletic Union greedy and not interested in a settlement of the dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Administration is searching for ways to emphasize its political commitment to economic and social change in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Johnson denounced the Los Angeles riots today and said that rioters must be exposed and dealt with in the same way as Ku Klux Klansmen in sheets and masks. "A rioter with a Molotov cocktail in his hands is not fighting for civil rights any more than a Klansman with a sheet on his back and a mask on his face," the President said.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Fifteen young women of Westchester and Fairfield Counties will be presented to Francis Cardinal Spellman at the St. Vincent Debutante Ball on Sept. 1 at the Apawamis Club here. A dinner dance on the terrace given by the debutantes' parents will precede the ceremonies in the ballroom.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 20 -- An unusual new repertory theater company devoted to science fiction will move to New York next month after a 44-week run in Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A system was patented this week for the actual docking and sealing together of two orbiting space craft. The equipment is designed to allow men and tools to be moved back and forth between the two vehicles while they are joined.

Oceangoing ship traffic through the Port of New York accounted for 21.9 per cent of the traffic registered in the country's 11 leading ports during the first six months of 1965, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, reported yesterday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 20 -- Tall cranes lift steel girders, earth-movers prepare industrial sites, and the whir of electric drills and other tools echoes through East Tennessee. The activity means new industries or expansion in an area extending from the edge of Virginia to the Georgia border -- nearly 250 miles -- from the North Carolina to Kentucky borders in a width ranging up to more than 100 miles.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The police arrested 650 Communists and other political extremists in a series of raids here last night and today, a police spokesman announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- A Maryland law enforcement officer said today that Congress might be "creating a Frankenstein monster" if it restricted lawyers from giving crime news to newsmen.

LIGHTNING -- in its simplest sense -- is the result of the equalization of static electricity accumulated in thunder clouds and the ground below. WHAT'S out there in the "glitteringly beautiful world above ?" Clifford Hicks answers the question neatly by analyzing "a vertical slice out of the sky" layer by layer, "the sky" in this context actually meaning "space," starting at the surface of the earth and extending upward -- or outward -- to infinity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers wound up back in the first-place seat today in their long-distance game of musical chairs involving the San Francisco Giants and Milwaukee Braves. An 11th-inning home run by Wes Parker, immediately after an unsuccessful squeeze bunt, gave the Dodgers a 6-4 victory over the Giants be fore 42,283 spectators, the largest crowd of the season at Candlestick Park.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Homero Blancas of Houston, golf's leading rookie, shot a 67 today and took a one-stroke lead in the $200,000 Carling open tournament. A member of the professional tour since mid-April, the 27-year-old Blancas posted a 36-hole total of 138.

It took only 20-odd minutes last Monday for the United States to reverse its policy on U.N. financing and to end a year-long dispute which might have wrecked the world organization. MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 21 -- At commencement exercises this week, Middlebury College bestowed honorary degrees upon a German cultural leader and two American educators. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia, the world's two ranking amateurs, reached the final round of the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today and will play for the cup tomorrow at 2 o'clock. Broadway's first premiere of the 1965-66 season will be "Mrs. Dally Has a Lover," starring Arlene Francis and Ralph Meeker. The opening is set for Sept. 22 at the John Golden Theater.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- The scene was Dresden, a few weeks after the Soviet Army had captured the bombed and battered city from the Nazis in May, 1945.
Deere Co., the farm equipment maker, reported over the weekend a decline in earnings for the nine months ended July 31 despite increased sales.

Accused of trying to get a $1,000 reward for $10,000 worth of lost jewelry, three men were held in $15,000 bail each by Judge Walter H. Gladwin in Criminal Court yesterday. They were charged with grand larceny and conspiracy.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Dr. Frankel said today that he would take a leave of absence from Columbia University to serve in his new post. He discussed the President's nomination, which is subject to Senate confirmation, at his rural home here at 317 Phillips Hill Road.
PUEBLO, Colo., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Floods receded today in the aftermath of heavy rains that swelled rivers and streams here.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Hal Keck of Hellertown, Pa., and A.M. Kovaleski of Scranton, Pa., won the second annual 500-mile race for production sports cars here today. Keck and Kovaleski led all but six of the 218 laps over the Glen 2.3-mile course and averaged 93.91 miles an hour in a Cobra Ford.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 22 -- A Van Cliburn show was presented here last night in the green and yellow striped tent of the Long Island Festival on the grounds of C.W. Post College.

A news article in The Times of July 8 outlined the proposal of the Committee to Beautify the City of New York that up to 1 per cent of the total construction costs of all new buildings be allocated for works of art.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Aug. 22 -- The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee is bringing 10 of its most experienced field secretaries to Lowndes County in the aftermath of the shotgun slaying of a white civil rights worker here Friday.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Don Demeter's two-run homer in the second inning today gave the Detroit Tigers a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox in a game called in the sixth inning because of rain.
SPRINGFIELD, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders here called today for a "respect for law [and] mutual concern for the welfare of others."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 22 -- National Guard troops with fixed bayonets solemnly watched a line of civil rights marchers four blocks long move peaceably through this Connecticut River Valley city today.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22 -- At the end of his first game at quarterback for the New York Giants, Bob Timberlake threw a punch and the football at John Baker, a 270-pound defensive end for the Pittsburgh Steelers.
A theologian said yesterday that "thinking laymen" were as essential as he and his colleagues were to contemporary religious thought.

President Johnson's forthright veto of the $1.7 billion military construction bill and his reluctant approval of $1 billion in military pay increases reflect his fear that Congress is overstepping itself. His is a legitimate concern. Mr. Johnson, who has been both generous and frequent in praising Congress for following his lead, is right to criticize it for action that exceeds its authority.
The capital markets this week will be faced with an un-seasonally heavy demand for investment funds.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Seventy United States physicians have volunteered to go to South Vietnam to help lessen the critical shortage of doctors in that nation.
Successful executives with the assistance of a fellowship program offered by Columbia University, are exchanging old careers in business for new careers in fields such as teaching.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 -- The political conduct of the war in Vietnam is a worry to most American officials in Saigon.

The Canadian Hydrographic Service told mariners last week to navigate with caution in the St. Lawrence River Estuary near Father Point next month and in October and to keep a sharp lookout for special buoys and red torpedo-shaped moored floats.

A 10-year-old Hong Kong-based shipping company, World-Wide (Shipping), Ltd., has passed the million-ton mark in vessel ownership, Y.K. Pad, chairman of the company, reported yesterday.

Novelists and instant sociologists may some day substitute the name Third Avenue for Madison Avenue as shorthand for the advertising way of life. In recent years more than 35 advertising concerns have moved to newer buildings on Third Avenue from the industry's traditional Madison Avenue habitat.

SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 22 -- Jack Hood Vaughn, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told the Executive Council of the Organization of Central American States tonight that the United States looked forward to closer relationships with the Central American Defense Council.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet press agency Tass today attributed the Gemini 5's problems to the haste of United States scientists who have been ordered, it said, to "beat the Soviet Union at any price" in sending up the longest-lasting orbital flight.
Two German Roman Catholic leaders agreed yesterday that there had been a generally favorable response in their country to the Vatican Council's emphasis on the importance of the laity.

CALI, Colombia -- A quiet revolution is taking place all over Latin America, one that is not spectacular and not violent, but it will affect every man, woman and child in that rapidly exploding area of the world. For the first time in Latin America a conference, openly and under high auspices, has publicly discussed birth control.

SAN BENEDETTO DEL TRONTO, Italy, Aug. 22 (AP) A Czechoslovak family of four arrived in this small Adriatic fishing port today aboard a tiny rubber boat. They said they had fled their country through Yugoslavia with the help of an American relative.
Buyers two years out of college and one year out of the training squad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians scored three runs in the 10th inning today for an 8-5 victory over the Washington Senators.
In Wall Street, where giant money maneuvers are the order of the day, a few canny members of the investment community have found profits in the "baby bonds."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians scored three runs in the 10th inning today for an 8-5 victory over the Washington Senators.
In Wall Street, where giant money maneuvers are the order of the day, a few canny members of the investment community have found profits in the "baby bonds."

Whenever some drastic military action is taken by American forces against the Communists, for defensive or strategic reasons, there are outcries so swift and thunderous that they now seem entirely predictable.
The superliner United States, flagship of the nation's merchant fleet, was freed yesterday from a maritime strike that enters its 70th day today.
Eighteen shots were exchanged yesterday in a spectacular midtown gun battle in which a suspect was killed by the police and a pedestrian was wounded.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 23 -- There is one thing to be said about dining in the Alaskan capital. The decision-making is not complicated by a proliferation of restaurants. There is the Latchstring of the Baranof, the town's best-known hotel, and Mike's Restaurant, a five-minute drive across the Gastineau Channel in the neighboring town of Douglas.
The Wah Chang Corporation, a large metals concern here, announced a price rise yesterday on tungsten rods, effective at once.

M'KEESPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 -- They know people are coming so they've baked a lot of cakes -- and cookies and gnocchi and pirogi. The International Village that opens here tomorrow consists of dancing and singing but mostly of eating.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- William J. Bowerman, the University of Oregon track coach. charged today that amateur athletes were paid to compete in meets sanctioned by the Amateur Athletic Union.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP) -- While grieving kinsmen prepared to bury a slain companion, a young white priest wounded in a new outbreak of racial violence rallied and was listed in serious condition today.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 23 -- A Chinese Communist team was reported by the Tanzanian Government to be in the border town of Tunduma today to begin a study of the route and construction costs of a rail link from Zambia to the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam.
A melodramatic scene was enacted yesterday over the grim and leaky main sluice gate of the Central Park Reservoir.
Stockholders of Castle Cooke, Inc., Honolulu, were told yesterday by Malcolm MacNaughton, president, that the diversified company was off to a good start in its 1965-66 fiscal year.

ST. PETERSBURG., Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Two records were set, four new champions were crowned and two successfully defended their titles at the National Inboard Speedboat Championships on Lake Maggiore yesterday.
Thurow Electronics, Inc., has announced the election of Donald K. Lau as a vice president. Formerly purchasing agent, Mr. Lau will handle purchasing, engineering and production activities.
Hundreds of families who have moved out of the path of the planned Lower Manhattan Expressway may have to move again to make way for a low-income housing project.
The city's Site Selection board voted 4 to 1 yesterday to use the site of Squadron A. Armory, Park Avenue at 94th Street, only for the construction of Junior High School 29.
Production of steel declined again last week, but the downturn was more pronounced than in the preceding week.
Stop Shop, Inc., a supermarket chain in New England, was reported yesterday as planning to give up trading stamps, which are distributed in 75 of its 140 outlets.

Mobilization for Youth, the Lower East Side antidelinquency project that was severely criticized by city investigators nine months ago, received $1,542,820 and some encouraging words from the city yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 23 -- Judicial authorities today charged 116 persons arrested in the violence here last Friday night with incitement to sedition. About 120 persons were hurt in the outbreak, which followed the swearing in of Elias Tsirimokos as Premier.

Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, John Wesley, Hogarth, and Madame de Pompadour are in the cast of Will and Ariel Durant's "The Age of Voltaire." The volume runs to 900 pages. It is the ninth in the Durants' huge, lavish chronicle, "The Story of Civilization," and, according to plan, the next to the last.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union, eager to penetrate the commercial airline market outside the Communist world, has sold the United Arab Republic seven new passenger planes at what are described as bargain-basement prices.
The British pound made its customary recovery from a pre-weekend decline yesterday in extremely quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Chuck Huckaby, playing with James Fox of Woodmere, scored 33, 29 -- 62 to take first place in the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament today. Huckaby took second place with Leo Fox, also of Woodmere, with 31, 32 -- 63.

GYONGYOSSOLYMOS, Hungary, Aug. 23 -- Among the thousands of acres in the Communist collective farm surrounding this little village are two acres belonging to Frigyes Furdock. These are worked by the peasants on the collective, and he receives 400 liters of wine (105 gallons) as his share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Treasury-bill rate rose significantly at today's auction from the levels of a week ago, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Mayor Wagner appointed a three-member mediation panel yesterday to try to avert the teachers' strike threatened for Sept. 13, the opening day of the new school year.

Water main breaks are an old, old story to New Yorkers. The broken four-foot main in Brooklyn that disrupted subway and phone service was merely the latest in a long series of such mishaps. Over the past decade they have averaged nearly one a day, with a maddening toll of flooded cellars, blocked traffic and general inconvenience. Now the drought has made the leakage something more than a massive irritant; it is a potential disaster.
SEATTLE, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Shipyard workers crossed machinists' union picket lines at Seattle shipyards today and were greeted by jeers and catcalls. No violence was reported.
VILLINGEN, Germany -- Emil Schmeckenbecher's cuckoo clock factory in this Black Forest town is a cheerful place.

Just One Break, Inc., which helps the physically handicapped, will be helped Oct. 7 by the annual preview party for the National Decoration and Design Show, opening the next day at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street.
Many buildings in downtown Brooklyn lost telephone contact with the rest of the world yesterday as crews worked to repair cables flooded early Sunday by a broken four-foot water main.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Johnson now has repulsed Congress at least three times in defense of the doctrine succinctly stated by Andrew Jackson in 1833:

BUDAPEST. Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The United States, with a small delegation of 40 athletes, continued today to dominate the World University Games as the crack American swimming team won its sixth gold medal.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- White persons did not turn out today for what a segregationist organization had billed as a "massive rally" to start a white voter registration drive going.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Marcelino Lopez, backed by the hitting of Jim Piersall, coasted to his 14th victory of the year tonight as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Cleveland Indians, 8-2.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Six horse owners who are also art lovers have agreed to fgive fees earned by their stallions to help raise funds to build the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
The rally of Treasury bond prices late last week proved to be only a momentary sign as the Government market entered its fourth week of continuous declines yesterday.
The president of Grace Line, Inc., today denied a report that the 100-year-old ship line was going out of business.

WEST CALDWELL N.J., Aug. 23 -- Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair won the qualifying medal in the 12th annual Garden State Women's Golf Association match play championship today with a 38, 38-76 at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.
Mayor Wagner angrily demanded a tighter check on leaks in the city's water system at a meeting with his aides yesterday.
The Board of Elections declined yesterday to rule against Jesse Gray's candidacy for the Democratic mayoral, nomination, leaving the case in the hands of the State Supreme Court.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 -- The Arab Socialist Baath party consolidated its power in Syria today with the establishment of a National Council to serve as the country's Legislature.

YONKERS, Aug. 23 -- Since not one of the current crop of 2-year-old trotters is a standout, it was not surprising that 18 colts and five fillies were named today to start in the second edition of the E. Roland Harriman Trot Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 23 -- The Organization of American States started a new round of talks today with the rebels and the civilian-military junta in an effort to break the deadlock on a peace accord.
Barry Goldwater yesterday, said unemployment was one of the reasons for the recent Los Angeles riots.

Thousands of Brooklynites traveled to their Manhattan jobs by strange routes yesterday, bypassing a half-mile stretch of BMT subway tunnel that was flooded after a four-foot water main burst over the weekend.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- After repeated "no comments" and much persuasion by Manager Herman Franks, Juan Marichal finally told his side of the story tonight just before the San Francisco Giants began a four-game series with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Gower Champion, director and choreographer of "Hello, Dolly!," has agreed to stage a farce, at present called "Fun and Games," in which Paul Ford is to be starred.

Directors of Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., are expected to name Francis G. Fabian, Jr. as president and chief executive officer of the company at a meeting on Friday, according to a company statement issued yesterday.

Three weeks before the primary election the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor are just beginning to make their positions known on serious issues. We shall discuss these views, in a series of editorials, taking up first the program of Abraham D. Beame, City Controller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Senate passed today a $4.3 billion public works and reclamation appropriation bill that also carried funds for the Atomic Energy Commission, the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Panama Canal and other major programs.
The small stocky, white haired man walked up to the teller's window at his Brooklyn bank yesterday, and just as he had done so many times before, he handed over a deposit slip.
