JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The Star, South Africa's leading daily newspaper, today accused the Government of having misused its powers in withdrawing the passports of the editor of The Rand Daily Mail and one of that paper's senior reporters.

A secondary offering of 535,449 shares of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) stock was reported oversubscribed within an hour after it was officially announced yesterday. The stock was priced at 75 1/8.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Tony Lema is a golfer who can afford to order champagne and pay for it, even if he were not associated with Moet and Chandon, who supply the wine for Lema's press parties that follow his tournament victories.

NO fans stormed onto the field in an attempt to dismantle the goal posts after the Giants had beaten the Pittsburgh Steelers, 16-7, in the Yale Bowl on Sunday. It was hardly an occasion for wild, unrestrained jubilation. It was more of a moment for somewhat tenuous satisfaction. There may have been a faint flicker of hope far down the road and the New Yorkers may have taken their first step toward it.
TAHOE CITY, Calif. -- Tourists and gamblers outdress the members of San Francisco's affluent old families who maintain summer homes here -- but not by much.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Accidents and technical problems have been delaying the start of the Navy's Sealab 2 experiment to see how long men can live on the floor of the sea, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd charged today that a publication of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, dealing with the Dominican Republic, was "heavily slanted against the Administration.

Mortimer M. Caplin, trustee of Webb Knapp, Inc., filed a motion in the Federal Court here yesterday aimed at increasing the yield to the bankrupt real estate concern in the proposed sale of the Paramount Building.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 -- Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, cautioned teachers today against striking and said that weapon should be used only as a last resort when all other efforts failed.

The question as to what extent foreign operators of cruises from United States ports should be supervised, licensed and possibly bonded will be explored by the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee when it begins hearings this morning on pending bills.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 23 -- The Yankees were denied an apparent victory tonight when their bull pen betrayed them in the ninth inning and the league-leading Minnesota Twins went on to a 4-3 victory on Jerry Kindall's single with one out in the 10th.
In the frenetic world of commodity futures trading, the soybean accounts for more volume than any other commodity. Soybeans have become the glamour crop of American agriculture in a few years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- With the Republican finance picture looking better than it has in months. Ray C. Bliss, the party chairman, is moving this week to improve G.O.P. ties with three groups -- Negroes, intellectuals and young people -- who defected to the Democrats in massive numbers in 1964.
SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Champagne Tony Lema won the Carling open golf tournament today by two strokes after a charging Arnold Palmer faltered on the last three holes.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 23 -- The seventh Maccabiah Games opened today with all the trappings of the Olympics before a crowd of 40,000 including President Zalman Shazar. More than 1,000 athletes will compete in 20 events starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Nobody expected Lucius Mendel Rivers to be a yes man to the Pentagon when he became chairman of the House Armed Services Committee last January. If there was ever any doubt on that score, the volatile South Carolina Democrat has throughly removed it by his words and deeds of the past few months.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Automobile production in the United States was expected to hit its low point of the year this week as practically all General Motors plants were closed because of model changeover, while the American Motors output was hit by labor troubles.
The shakedown case against a Federal narcotics agent and a city policeman has apparently collapsed, reliable sources reported yesterday.
Sales of new cars are continuing to show increases, according to reports issued yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation and the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation.
NEWPORT. R.I., Aug. 23 -- Roy Emerson added today the Newport Casino Cup to the Nassau Bowl among his tennis trophies for the American season.

Brazil's military "revolution" has developed a split personality. It has been able to make considerable progress in the economic and financial fields. The rampant inflation of the Goulart regime was cut down from 85 per cent last year to about 40 per cent this year and it is still being reduced. The political chaos and the tolerance of leftism under President Goulart, which so alarmed high military officers and conservative civilians, have disappeared.
MONTE CRISTO, Italy, Aug. 23 (AP) -- This rocky dot of an island, made famous by the Alexandre Dumas novel, is to be turned into a tourists' haven.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 -- A Unitarian minister known here for his efforts in behalf of racial integration was in serious condition tonight after being wounded by a shotgun blast fired from ambush.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences said today that it was too early to fix a realistic date for man's landing on the moon.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., announced today plans to raise 50 million ($140 million) through bonds sold to investors in Britain to help pay for future expansion and modernization programs.
The First National City Bank is considering the possibility of acquiring the Hilton Credit Corporation's Carte Blanche credit-card business.
HOUSTON, Aug. 23 -- Gemini 5 made a rendezvous today with a rocket that wasn't there.

A bar is to be installed at the Mark Hellinger Theater, 237 West 51st Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. Earlier this month the Palace Theater, the former vaudeville and film house that is being turned into a legitimate theater, announced plans for two bars on the premises.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A spot check of 19 major cities showed all have multimillion-dollar projects aimed at helping disadvantaged children of low-income families. All are ready to go as soon as Federal funds become available, a spokesman for the Office of Education said today.

WILMINGTON, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Members of Local 6700 of the United Steelworkers of America have voted 660 to 60 for a 90-day contract with the Harvey Aluminum Company to end a strike at its plant in nearby Torrance. The walkout began April 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Johnson described as "heartening" today a report that all but about 180 of the nation's 25,000 school districts had expressed willingness to maintain classroom desegregation to receive Federal funds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A chemistry professor told a United States District Court jury today that krebiozen, a drug taken by some cancer patients, is simply creatine monohydrate, a common laboratory substance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Amida fast verbal pepper game with a couple of Republican legislators in the White House Cabinet Room, President Johnson signed today a Congressional resolution establishing Baseball Week.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, Aug. 24 -- A United States Marine Corps transport plane with 71 persons aboard crashed into the bay off Hong Kong today shortly after taking off for South Vietnam.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- Bandits held up a mail truck here yesterday and escaped with 57 sacks of airmail, including 19 from the United States.
A narcotics case against a 28-year-old woman and a friend collapsed yesterday in Federal Court, when Judge Edmund L. Palmieri refused to accept as evidence nearly a half a pound of hashish.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- A shipload of Texas cattle appears to have reached the end of the trail in a tragi-comic finale of a United States effort to break into the French market for beef.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 23 -- While pickets chanted outside, Vice President Humphrey urged college students today to replace "destructive" demonstrations with constructive social action.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Rescuers searched in the Mekong River today for two American civilians, a Thai Army officer and a Laotian officer missing since the crash of a helicopter into the river.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 19 -- The South African Government is keeping 31 tribal Africans in a state of perpetual banishment in some of the loneliest, emptiest corners of this land.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A grant of $1,104,652 to establish a National Educational Television Center at Indiana University was announced today by the Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach confirmed today that the Justice Department was considering a unification of the fragmented Federal correctional system.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Aug. 23 -- More than 2,000 voluntary applications for transfer to Vietnam have been received from members of the United States Army in Europe, a spokesman said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- George D. Widener's Steeple Jill uncorked a dramatic stretch run to win the $28,850 Diana Handicap today. Philip Weissman, a psychoanalyst, attempts in this book to examine what makes actors act, directors direct and playwrights write as they do. The result of his study is a reasoned, sympathetic, pleasingly modest, not overly technical volume that cannot but be of interest to the theater buff.
BRUSSELS -- The Common Market Commission has broken ground in two new areas in its continuing effort to encourage trade among the six member countries.

BONN, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- West Germany and the United States will jointly develop a "jump-jet" fighter and reconnaissance aircraft to be battle-ready in the ninteen-seventies, the Defense Ministry said today.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Jose Greco, paying his fourth visit to Britain, tonight opened a three week London season at the Royal Festival Hall.

ABOARD U.S.S. LAKE CHAMPLAIN AT SEA, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., and Lieut. Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr. carried two $1 bills into space to prove on landing that they are the same spacemen who were launched last week.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Rev. Eugene V. LaPlante, instructor in theology at Assumption College, was appointed today as chaplain for American Roman Catholics in Moscow.
Prices drifted down in slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

John Roseboro appeared with a bandage over his scalp. Manager Walter Alston was ejected before the third inning was over. And Don Drysdale was raked for 11 hits before being removed in the eighth inning.
HOUSTON, Tuesday, Aug. 24 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts worked through a busy day in space yesterday making a rendezvous with an imaginary rocket and shaking down for a long voyage.

DEAL, N.J. -- Changes, some subtle, some abrupt and flamboyant, are nearly everywhere along the 127 miles of New Jersey shore, from Sandy Hook to Cape May. Many are easy to see -- new homes, new stores, crowded beaches and traffic jams, even south of Atlantic City.

The National Football League's experiment in theater television, tried out for the first time last year, will not be continued this year -- not on the same scale, at least. Although club owners had hoped the experiment would lead to a new source of revenue, the results were not financially impressive and the promoters of theater television actually lost money.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 23 -- A 19-year-old youth died last night when he was accidentally buried in a sandhole at nearby Island Beach State Park.
A Criminal Court judge's concern over proper courtroom attire drove several lawyers to haberdasheries yesterday to buy ties for their clients.

PRAGUE, Aug. 19 -- President Johnson's policy of trying to build "bridges" to Eastern Europe while waging war in Vietnam has put United States diplomats here in the awkward posture of a man extending his right arm for a friendly hand-shake and cocking his left arm to ward off hostile bricks and bottles.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 -- Indications of increasing unrest among students in the Hue area were reported today. The unrest was said to be alarming.
When 70,000 people attend a symphonic concert by the New York Philharmonic, as they did recently, that's news -- front page news, in fact.
During the last 10 years, scheduled-airline employment in this country has increased from 109,000 to 190,000, with an annual payroll of more than $1.5 billion.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics halted a five-game losing streak tonight with a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
A wave of speculation rolled over the stock market yesterday as prices generally declined for the third successive trading session.

ONE of the quickest and most profitable ways to make a behind-the-scenes tour of the garment industry is to be a designer, good enough to be taken on by an important manufacturer at anywhere from $10,000 to $25,000 plus a year but not good enough to have a business of one's own -- at least not yet. And New York State apparently will furnish everything but transportation funds.

Harry R. Gonzalez has resigned as president of the General Development Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The resignation from the Florida land concern became effective Friday. A successor has not been selected.
KEENE, N.H., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- An Episcopal priest criticized today the Episcopal Church in Alabama for not holding a memorial service for Mr. Daniels.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The silver quarter began going the way of the Indian head penny today as the Philadelphia Mint stamped the first of the nation's new silverless 25-cent pieces.

COMMON SENSE dictates that a defender who ruffs an opposing winner should do so with a worthless trump rather than with a trump that may win a trick in its own right. More obviously, a defender should not use even an apparently worthless trump to ruff one of declarer's losers.

On Aug. 20 The New York Times and other papers carried a news account of revisions in governmental data which indicate that the economic growth rate during the past year or longer has been somewhat higher than indicated by earlier data.

KENOSHA, Wis., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers struck the Kenosha plant of American Motors Corporation, Wisconsin's largest private employer, at 10 A.M. today. More than 16,000 workers in two cities were made idle as members of Local 72 walked out an hour after all-night negotiations had been suspended.

BAY HEAD, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Steve Moore of the Manhasset Bay (L.I.) Yacht Club beat Jim Crane of the Noroton (Conn.) Y.C. for the top position today as the 27th North American Lightning Class championship qualifying races ended on Barnegat Bay.
The Carrier Corporation observed its golden anniversary with its highest sales and earnings for the third quarter and nine months ended July 31, William Bynum, chairman reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- Tuna tournaments off the Massachusetts coast seem to be hooked to a jinx that is so persistent some local anglers are thinking in terms of an international conspiracy.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes promised today that a proposed $180 million system of express highways cutting across the state from the Delaware River to the Atlantic Ocean "will be built -- and built as promptly as possible."
The Central and South West Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended July 31.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 23 -- Another step toward drafting a treaty to make Latin America a nuclear-free zone was begun here today. A preparatory commission of Latin-American delegates met to consider the findings of working committees organized at the beginning of the year.
Arthur C. Ford, president of the city's Board of Water Supply, said yesterday that a suggested merger of the board with the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity would be fruitless.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- bout 60 members of the Vietnam Day Committee attempted to block a troop train bound for the Oakland Army terminal today, but failed again. The committee has previously made similar attempts in vain.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves lost a six-run lead, but hung on to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 7-6, and climb back into second place in the National League pennant race tonight. They are a half-game out of the lead.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Nassau County voters will decide in November whether to increase the size of the Board of Supervisors for a one-man, one-vote system instead of the present weighted voting arrangement. The board voted today to place on the ballot the recommendations in the majority report of the Charter Revision Commission.
The Washington Manufacturing Company, a privately-owned Nashville, Tenn., concern, has purchased Ely Walker, Inc., St. Louis, from Burlington Industries, Inc., of Greensboro, N.C.

WINSLOW, Ariz., Aug. 22 -- Drawn by 290 horses, the coach pulled out of Albuquerque and headed into Indian country carrying a tenderfoot from back East and two boys. The trail was fast and treacherous, with other coaches galloping along at 75 miles an hour, and an appalling succession of desert perils lay athwart the route.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- A report submitted to Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz sharply criticized the action of Western Air Lines in discharging 123 flight engineers who staged a wildcat strike in 1961.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- The San Francisco Giants dropped to third place in the National League race tonight by losing the opener of a four-game series to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-2.
IS it kind, is it cricket, to take Hemingway's owlish detractors far beyond land's end, as Nelson Algren does in this book, keelhaul their standards, and bury them at sea?

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 23 -- Two archrivals of the Arab world, King Faisal and President Gamal Abdel Nasser, made a predawn journey to Mecca today and then sat down to try to work out a peace formula for Yemen, where they have been fighting a war by proxy for nearly three years.
Three large advertising agencies appointed senior vice presidents yesterday.
Prices closed mixed on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in quiet trading.

GATWICK, England. Aug. 23 (UPI) -- More than 200 Canadian and American tourists who were stranded at Gatwick airport as a result of seizure of aircraft for debt flew home today when the impounding was lifted.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Robert Danforth, the defending champion, sailed his Wayward Too around a pair of rivals on the final leg today and won the opening race for the international 210 Class championship, conducted by the Corinthian Yacht Club.
Net new orders for machine tools -- the machines drills, presses, lathes, grinders and so on -- that make machinery, turned sharply downward in July.

Investors in the stock market have shaken off their fears that the economy may be headed for another 1929, but they have yet to make any firm decision about where the economy -- or the market -- is going.

Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, will sit down today at a chessboard near a window facing a shady tree-lined backyard in Greenwich Village, to play the first of a series of games with 22 opponents gathered together 1,350 miles away in a Havana hotel.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- Almost a million people have visited South Hills Village since it opened here July 28. They have been attracted by the fact that its developers contend it is the largest enclosed shopping center be tween New York and Chicago, with an enclosed mall and a variety of unusual architectural features.

Sixteen artists, from Joan Baez and Duke Ellington to Birgit Nilsson and Claudio Arrau, will be presented in a new recital series, Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall. This will be the first recital series undertaken by Lincoln Center itself without booking by outside managements.
Real estate courses for the layman and the professional will be offered in the fall at New York University's general education division.

Jimmy Dupree, a 30-year-old Bronx light heavyweight noted for picketing Madison Square Garden on fight nights, showed up in the Garden ring last night as a main-bout performer. But the only signs he showed were those of wear and tear.

New car sales continued at a fast pace in mid-August, but there are indications that the gains over the levels a year ago are slackening. It should be noted, however, that last year the new models were introduced generally one to two weeks earlier than schedules call for this year.

" New Soff Puffs, more absorbent than cotton, stronger than tissues, and never a hint of lint," is the advertising line to be taken by Johnson Johnson for its new cosmetic wipe this fall. More than $1 million will be spent to carry the campaign through 1966.

The switch to jets of the regional airlines that link the nation's small communities with major air routes received added impetus yesterday when Southern Airways of Atlanta announced an $11 million jet purchase.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -Brushing aside Republican protests, the House voted $1.2 billion today to finance school aid and several other Great Society programs authorized earlier this year.

MRS. ARTHUR JOHNSON got up at 5 o'clock the other morning, picked 1,000 ears of white and yellow corn, chased two of her five children out to pluck beans and tomatoes from the vines, sent the remaining three into the 450-foot flower bed to gather bunches of asters, zinnias and marigolds, and even organized breakfast for the whole Johnson family.
Highly selective buying of airline and electronic issues dominated stock market activity yesterday.

George Abbott, producer, director playwright, and actor, will he honored by the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers. Mr. Abbott, who is 78 years old, will receive the organization's first annual award of merit at a dinner to be held Nov. 14 in the New York Hilton Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Mark Spitz, a slight schoolboy from Santa Clara, Calif., and a 17-year-old Israeli girl held the spotlight today as the United States team set records in winning four of five swimming championships at the World Maccabiah Games.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 (UPI) -A Roman Catholic priest has resigned as pastor of a church here because his superiors allegedly told him to stay out of community problems.

Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, Manhattan Democrat, yesterday charged Mayor Wagner, City Council President Paul R. Screvane and Controller Abraham D. Beame with "flagrant hypocrisy" on the subject of police review boards.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Cosmo Iacavazzi was graduated from Princeton last June with All-America honors in football and classroom honors in aeronautical engineering. Today, he flunked his first postgraduate test when he was dropped by the New York Jets.
TORONTO, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) --Gunnar Mining, Ltd., will mail an up-to-date financial statement to shareholders in a week or so, the company told the Toronto Stock Exchange today.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The New York Giants dropped four players from their squad today and each cut had its significance in the reconstruction of this rapidly changing team.

DENVER, Aug. 24 (AP) -Lida Fee Matthews of Portsmouth, Ohio, stroked a oneover-par 74, today, matching her round of yesterday, to capture the medal with 148 in the 36-hole qualifying competition for the United States women's amateur golf championship.
The Seamen's Church Institute of New York will benefit on the evening of Oct. 14 from a preview exhibition of Woldemar Neufeld's paintings of the East River from Gracie Square to the Battery.

HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia has reached an understanding with Communist China that will bring increasing pressure to bear on the defenses of the Western powers in Southeast Asia.
Federal mediators kept maritime bargaining teams in almost continuous session in Washington yesterday as the strike against eight shipping lines moved through its 70th day.

The Kayser-Roth Corporation, one of the nation's largest apparel manufacturers achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history for the seventh straight year, Chester H. The forthcoming release of the city's audit of the finances of the New York World's Fair may include a bombshell in the nature of the fair's public relations expenditures.
A computer that can identify a lawbreaker among ordinary motorists in one ninety-second thousandth of a second helped apprehend a Queens housewife on the Grand Central Parkway yesterday.

Francis Keppel, the United States Commissioner of Education, went to the convention of the American Federation of Teachers this week and warned: "This is no time to have strikes." In a thoughtful address he expressed hope that the nation's teachers and school administrators would never let their grievances outweigh the needs of their pupils. He asserted that strikes should be a last resort in communities where public apathy had reduced teachers to desperation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda complained today that the percentage of women in leading positions in Soviet economic and political life was decreasing instead of getting larger.

MONTREAL -- Fashion isn't spinach here. It's a tossed salad of British and Canadian lettuce, French dressing and American seasoning. And, like a salad, its variety is infinite, reaching taste levels comparable to and often surpassing other world capitals. An integral part of Montreal life, fashion is treated with respect, amusement and the firm hand of discipline.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 -- A sizable force searched vainly today for Vietcong guerrillas who shelled the United States air base at Bienhoa during the night, damaging 49 aircraft and wounding a small number of American and Vietnamese airmen.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Jerry Lumpe got three hits, Norm Cash slammed a two-run homer and Denny McLain posted his 12th victory as the Detroit Tigers routed the Kansas City Athletics, 8-2, tonight.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -Frank Howard drove in four runs to pace the Washington Senators to an 8-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox in the finale of a double-header tonight.

As a superspy, Napoleon Solo in "The Man From U.N.C.L.E." has always been victorious, but on Nov 26 he will lose out to James Bond. WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -The Senate completed Congressional action today on the $3.36 billion foreign aid authorization bill and sent it to the White House for President Johnson's signature.
The election of William Q. Harry, Alexander V.R. Halsey and Thomas J. Sweeney as vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was announced yesterday by John M. Meyer Jr., president.

ATHENS, Aug. 24 -- Premier Elias Tsirimokos asked Parliament tonight for a vote of confidence. His statement of policy was calm and free from the bitterness that has marked Greek politics since a struggle began when King Constantine ousted George Papandreou as Premier July 15.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 24 -- Tom Tresh, who has played all three outfield positions this year for the Yankees, also frequently finds time to win ball games with his bat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, added his voice today to the growing chorus of opposition to legislation that would retroactively legalize six bank mergers that have been attacked under the antitrust laws.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- The San Francisco Giants, who have quietly developed a mild batting slump amid all the recent excitement, lost a little more ground in the National League tonight by losing to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-2.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Rev. Eugene V. LaPlante, instructor in theology at Assumption College, was appointed today as chaplain for American Roman Catholics in Moscow.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Charles Pastorino of Ridgewood (Conn.) Country Club, who won the medal yesterday, led the way into the semi-finals by winning two matches today in the 41st annual Westchester County Golf Association junior championship at Bonnie Briar Country Club.

Northwest Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $4,609,703 for July and earnings of $23,252,232 for the first seven months this year. In July of 1964 the carrier cleared $2,491,082, it had a net income of $12,584,951 in the first seven months of last year.

The Robert Joffrey Ballet will give a preview performance on Sept. 8 at the Delacorte Theatre in Central Park to benefit the Foundation for American Dance. Subsequent performances, on Sept. 9, 10, 11 and 12, will be open to the public as part of the New York Shakespeare Festival and will help underwrite production costs of the ballet's premieres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate Finance Committee announced today that it would hold public hearings next week on a suddenly controversial tax-law amendment that could materially affect what company gets a huge pending contract to supply natural gas service to Southern California.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Angels scored five runs off Luis Tiant in the sixth inning tonight and handed the Cleveland Indians a 7-1 defeat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Corporate profits showed a huge increase in the first half of this year, following an almost equally large growth in 1964 above 1963, the Government reported today.

Prof. Aly S. Dadras, a specialist in urban planning and architecture, has been appointed chairman of the architecture department at the New York Institute of Technology. Professor Dadras, head of Dadras International City Planners, is chairman of the house consulting committee of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -Fifty-eight marines lost their lives when a United States Marine Corps aircraft plunged into the sea after take-off from Kai Tak Airport here this morning.
Three more individuals have denied Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that they bought Texas Gulf Sulphur Company stock on inside information of a rich ore strike near Timmins, Ont.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -The school districts that apparently have decided to reject Federal assistance for the coming year generally are in areas that would profit most from the Federal aid appropriation voted today by the House of Representatives.

Prices declined in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 -A social welfare system assertedly preoccupied with red tape rather than with meaningful field work was cited today by officials as a contributing cause of the recent Los Angeles rioting.

Henry Moore, the British sculptor, arrived on schedule at 9:30 A.M. yesterday at Lincoln Center to give a look at two huge crates containing the two huge parts of his huge bronze "Reclining Figure." HOUSTON, Thursday, Aug. 26 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts said yesterday they had taken pictures of Cuba. They called them "just scenic shots."
BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- An American citizen and two Britons have been arrested by East German authorities within the last two weeks and are being held in prison in East Berlin, it was disclosed today.

The Contomporary Music Project for Creativity in Music Education is soliciting applications from young Amercan composers for one-year fellowships as composers-in-residence at selected public school systems in various cities for the school year beginning in September, 1966.

THE third annual New York Avant-Garde Festival got off to a limping start last night at Judson Hall. About 100 persons showed up for a program of Action Music by the Korean composer Nam Jun Paik, and it was a study in instant ennui.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The Indianapolis News has endorsed William F. Buckley, a conservative candidate, for Mayor of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The House of Representatives, by a vote of 318 to 95, passed tonight a new immigration bill designed to do away with the national origins quota system and to put all nations on a relatively equal footing.
IN "New American Story," a resolutely avant-garde anthology, there are some tales more bizarre than what goes on in Ian Fleming's last novel, "The Man With the Golden Gun."

Business has been soaring recently in the Broadway playhouses. Theatrical observers said yesterday that there was an unusual number of full houses for this time of the season -- or for any time of year.

On Aug. 20, 1807, Robert Fulton left New York on the first round-trip by side-wheeler steamer up the Hudson to Albany and back. Three weeks later his North River Steam Boat (so called after the optional name for the Hudson River) entered commercial service, making the run to Albany in a little under 29 hours.
ATLANTA, Aug. 25 -- The American Civil Liberties Union filed suits in Federal Courts against two Alabama counties today asking an end to the alleged exclusion of Negroes from grand and petit juries.
TANCANH, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- The South Vietnamese Government has promised the men of its 42d regiment a promotion of one grade in rank if they can hold this outpost until Nov. 1.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 25 -- Jack Hood Vaughn, Under Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that he sensed after a week of travel in Latin America that the main problem "is definitely in the rural sector."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- The war in Vietnam is so alien to the American experience and such a tangle of conflicting cultures, interests, memories, religions and personal, regional and tribal ambitions that it defies precise definition and is almost beyond comprehension. Even the words normally used to describe a war are misleading here.

Part of the 50-cent toll that a motorist pays at the Lincoln Tunnel could be used to keep the price of tokens at 15 cents at the subway change booths, City Council President Paul R. Screvane suggested yesterday.

A Federal Trade Commission staff proposal that presumably would afford the Consolidated Foods Corporation immunity from antitrust attack on acquisitions made prior to July 1, 1965, was approved yesterday by the concern's directors.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that reinforcements would be abailable at 8 A.M. today for the hard-pressed forces that have been trying to plug the leaks in the city's water system.

A series of regional study conferences to explore the effective use of the daily newspaper in the school curriculum will be held in 11 cities beginning this October, under the sponsorship of the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Administration faces an almost certain filibuster in the Senate against its bill to ban state "right to work" laws.

POMONA, N.J., Aug. 25 -- The Curtiss-Wright X-19, an experimental vertical take-off and landing plane, crashed in flames today on its first extended test flight at the National Aviation Experimental Facilities Center here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 25 -- Prospects for the passage through Congress of the Government's copper "Chileanization" program appeared far more favorable today when it was reported that talks between Government supporters and Radicals in Opposition to the measure reached a satisfactory conclusion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Johnson announced today what he called a "revolutionary" new system of planning the Federal Government's many programs and drawing up its budget.
The metropolitan area was described yesterday as "a veritable dust bowl" because of reduced street flushings caused by the water shortage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Johnson announced today that he had appointed Deputy Attorney General Ramsey Clark as head of a study group to find ways of easing tensions in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee decided today to cut no more than $75 million from the $3.36 billion foreign aid authorization that cleared its final Congressional hurdle yesterday. It was the smallest reduction eve proposed by the foreign operations panel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The influential Asian-African group is near agreement today on a formula that it hopes will meet Soviet and United States views on the financing of peace-keeping operations, delegation sources reported today.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The prosecutors in the Auschwitz death-camp trial said today that eight defendants had got off too lightly, and asked new trials for them.
Representative John V. Lindsay assailed Governor Rockefeller last night at a Queens street rally. The Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor said his fellow-Republican "is wrong on many issues."
RACALMAS, Hungary, Aug. 24 -- The young and husky farmer was working the melon patch on the collective farm here, but he was not a member. He was a sharecropper and he was rich.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- At least 58,000 Negroes have been registered in four Southern states since the Voting Rights Act of 1965 was signed Aug. 6, the White House said today.

Remaco, Inc., a concern that specializes in the repair of rubber products, will move from a warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, to a new building in Jersey. The company has broken ground for a headquarters and distribution center on a 10-acre site in Northvale, N.J.
Representative William F. Ryan said last night enough new men should be added to the police force "so that patrolmen on the beat will be visible in every neighborhood of the city."

GREENSBORO, Ala., Aug. 25 -- An aged Negro was beaten severely and his tongue was cut out last weekend, and a county officer said today he believed it was in retaliation for speaking out against the civil rights movement.
Price changes were announced yesterday on chemicals and paper products.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Diplomats in London think that the North Vietnamese are now more interested than they were in "keeping channels open" and in "maintaining communications" for possible peace moves.
The nation's electric power production rose 15.4 per cent in the week ended Aug. 21, from the level in the 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -Lmperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., announced onight plan to build a u31 million ($86 million) plant at Stevenston, Scotland, for the production of nylon. The plant will be completed In 1967 and employ 1,100 perSONS. The company, the largest British maanufaeturer, said the new project bring, s to u76 million ($212.8 million) capital expenditures sanctioned for additional nylon production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- "On Dec. 23, 1907, our first boy, James, was born, and with what relief and joy I welcomed him, for again I had been worried for fear I would never have a son." So wrote Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in her autobiography, commenting on the birth of her second child, following a daughter, Anna Eleanor.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 25 -- The Minnesota Twins, looking more than ever like the pennant winners their enthusiastic partisans hope they'll be, snuffed out a New York Yankee rally in the ninth inning tonight and posted a 5-4 victory before a crowd of 33,966 in Metropolitan Stadium.
Ample Federal funds are becoming available for meeting the country's "major domestic challenge" -- the revitalizing of its cities -- Daniel P. Moynihan said yesterday.

A fantastic, terrifying -- and yet in the present state of world affairs, a necessary -- measure of arms preparedness was proclaimed by President Johnson in his news conference yesterday. The United States Air Force has been given the go-ahead signal to build military manned, orbiting laboratories.
PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The House of Assembly here. They play a game called said, and little work gets done.
The decline in the ship-repair industry in the Port of New York in recent years may force the Federal Government to send emergency repair work to other ports along the Atlantic Coast.
Several leading American companies were identified last night as major creditors in the default last June of a Canadian finance company.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- A Richmond man held briefly in New York in connection with a possible bomb threat said on returning home tonight that the whole thing was ridiculous, stupid and "getting out of hand."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 -- President Johnson has given across-the-board instructions to all Federal agencies to help in any way possible in rectifying conditions underlying the great Los Angeles race riot, qualified sources indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- An American shipping executive suggested today that foreign-flag cruise ship operators be required to pay a license fee for each passenger they carry out of United States ports.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- With a cautious preface about the risks of premature optimism, President Johnson expressed satisfaction today about recent military developments in South Vietnam.

WILLIE VICENS is the No. 1 man in the dog show world of Ponce, P.R., the largest city on the southern coast of that island discovered by Columbus in 1493. He is the president of the Ponce Kennel Club.

ATHENS, Aug. 25 -- Amid scuffles, insults and occasional punches, the Greek Parliament began tonight its examination of Premier Elias Tsirimokos's policy statement last night asking for a vote of confirmation.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- It was an end-of-the-season "bash." Three hundred young people, many of them high school and college students had paid $2 each for entrance to the huge old frame house on the edge of this resort village.
BUDAPEST, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Randy Matson of Texas A. M. put the shot 66 feel 7 5/8 inches today and won the event in the World University Games as the United States' total of gold medals rose to 11.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 -- India announced today that her troops crossed the Kashmir cease-fire line last night in two places and occupied Pakistani positions.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25 (AP) Tony Perez slammed a pinch three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning as fourth-place Cincinnati tightened the National League pennant race by downing second-place Milwaukee, 7-4, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The ruling powers of United States track and field endorsed today binding and continuing arbitration of their jurisdictional row.

As the United States accelerates its military moves in Vietnam, Government procurement of service apparel is expected to create shortages in America's textile industry, some of which are already becoming evident, according to the chairman of M. Lowenstein Sons.
A half-dozen immaculately clad, beardless artists, none more than 12 years old, gathered in an East Side gallery yesterday to discuss their works, which will be exhibited in Rumania in October.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- Demonstrations of student unrest in the former Imperial Capital of Hue, 400 miles north of Saigon, continued today for the third consecutive day, reports reaching here said.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Memorial services will be held tomorrow in five Alabama counties where a slain Episcopal seminarian worked, officials of the Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity announced today.

Several major industrial companies announced plans yesterday for new plants or additions to existing facilities. In London, Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., announced plans for large nylon plant to be built in Scotland at a cost of $86.8 million.
First of the current contenders to declare for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Representative William F. Ryan has been, from the beginning, the angry man of municipal politics.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 25 -- Industrial pollution was blamed today for the death of tens of thousands of fish and hundreds of big eels that have covered the beaches in West Haven.

Cocoa futures were the standout yesterday in an otherwise dull and generally declining commodity market. After a sharp price drop in the morning, cocoa futures made a sharp rise in the afternoon and closed above their Tuesday levels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Luci Baines Johnson younger daughter of President and Mrs. Johnson, has received !the sacrament of confirmation !in the Roman -- 'atholie Church.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Communist China is reported to have told France that it would consider discussing the Vietnam crisis if it were admitted to full membership in the United Nations Security Council.
Needham, Harper Steers, Inc., has elected Paul E. Belknap as managing director of its New York office and executive vice president of the agency.
Alan McArthur has been appointed vice president of the Kimball Systems division of Litton Industries, Inc. He was formerly vice president of Litton's American Tag division.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Don't be surprised if Congress has to decide what to do about the beach buggy situation. Members of the Massachusetts Beach Buggy Association are up in arms over edicts passed in two Cape Cod communities putting heavy restrictions on the mechanized sand-hoppers.

Stockholders of the Norfolk Western Railway at a special meeting in Roanoke, Va., yesterday approved a plan for the elimination of the carrier's 4 per cent adjustment preferred stock and 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- The Government was defeated in the Senate today over a controversy concerning the import of American planes for an interstate freight service.
The board of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend to 37 1/2 cents a common share from 32 1/2 cents in earlier quarters.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25 -- Alone among the eastern Arab states, Syria condemned the Faisal-Nasser agreement on Yemen.
Prices edged higher in light trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

BRISTOL, England, Aug. 24 -- The Bolshoi dancers currently visiting Britain have now finished their London season and split up into two touring groups, one starting in Bristol, the other, led by Maya Plisetskaya, starting in Dublin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, said today that picketing of him by at least 100 persons outside his hotel here "will be blown out of all proportion in the Communist world."
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored an unearned run in the third inning and, behind Milt Pappas' four-hitter, defeated the Chicago White Sox, 2-1, tonight.

Your Aug. 8 editorial "Grimmer War in Vietnam," accepting as a sad necessity the escalated war in Vietnam which you seriously questioned and seemed to oppose earlier this year, prompts a closer look at your flat claim: "No possibilities exist for an honorable withdrawal from Vietnam."

NEWARK, Aug. 25 -- Walter H. Jones, leader of the powerful Bergen County Republican organization, broke with Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. over the most controversial issue in the campaign for Governor -- whether a Rutgers history profesor should be dismissed for saying publicly that he welcomed a Communist victory in South Vietnam.
An increase of 574,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The major shake-up in the top echelon of the United States mission today restored the name of Roosevelt to prominence in the United Nations and elevated a Negro to a post enabling him to speak for his country in the Security Council.
PORTLAND, Ore. Aug. 25 (AP) -- The American Legion voted today to permit veterans of the cold war to join their organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Aug. 25 -- On the streets near the aging courthouse and in school lunchrooms over a glass of tea, a dozen people here made almost the same observation today: A year ago it wouldn't have seemed possible, and even now it seemed unreal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he had no intention of running for Vice President in 1968, that he expected to try for re-election in 1970, and had no plans to seek the Presidency in 1972.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that he would not "buy peace" with the city's teachers by giving them money that the city needs for vital school improvements.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- At his news conference today, President Johnson wore spectacles with clear plastic rims instead of contact lenses.
The New York Telephone Company is introducing new equipment that will enable totally deaf people to use the telephone.

DENVER, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The defending champion, Barbara McIntire, pressed most of the way, led other favorites through the first and second rounds of the United States women's amateur golf championship today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The major shake-up in the top echelon of the United States mission today restored the name of Roosevelt to prominence in the United Nations and elevated a Negro to a post enabling him to speak for his country in the Security Council.
PORTLAND, Ore. Aug. 25 (AP) -- The American Legion voted today to permit veterans of the cold war to join their organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Aug. 25 -- On the streets near the aging courthouse and in school lunchrooms over a glass of tea, a dozen people here made almost the same observation today: A year ago it wouldn't have seemed possible, and even now it seemed unreal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he had no intention of running for Vice President in 1968, that he expected to try for re-election in 1970, and had no plans to seek the Presidency in 1972.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that he would not "buy peace" with the city's teachers by giving them money that the city needs for vital school improvements.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- At his news conference today, President Johnson wore spectacles with clear plastic rims instead of contact lenses.
The New York Telephone Company is introducing new equipment that will enable totally deaf people to use the telephone.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A stubborn fire aboard the 325-foot refrigerator ship, Arctic Reefer, burned itself out today. The danger of explosion was over, but the ship appeared to be a total loss.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- Moscow's main active churches, a mosque and a synagogue are among the places of interest marked on a new city map that went on sale at newstands today.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 26 -- As Jim Ferrier and Johnny Pott shared the lead at 68 in the opening round of the $100,000 American Golf Classic today, Jack Nicklaus was an 80 shooter.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 26 -- The Minnesota Twins continued to behave like pennant-winners in Metropolitan Stadium today by routing the embattled New York Yankees, 9-2, before a highly partisan crowd of 27,073.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Intercity truck tonnage and rail-freight carloadings in the latest week ended Aug. 21 continued to reflect high industrial activity and were both above levels of the corresponding week of 1964.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Four hundred persons paid $5 a head here yesterday to walk, sigh and exclaim their way through the only African compound on the East Coast that's used as a private home.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 -- On Feb. 9, 1954, during the French Indochina war, a French platoon was almost wiped out and a lieutenant named de Bellefont was killed about six miles northeast of Kontum on Route 5.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A District Court judge found 12 persons guilty today of charges of breach of the peace in a disturbance July 17 that created a furor over alleged police brutality.

Having seen the population problems of Chile during the two years of Peace Corps service there, I can appreciate the significance of the conference held at Colombia's Universidad del Valle, and reported by Herbert L. Matthews on Aug. 22.

ELIAS KALIL hopes somebody else wins the Huguenot Yacht Club's predicted-log contest tomorrow, but he's going to do his best to see that no one else does. "I can't help it," the 66-year-old retired textile executive from Manhasset, L.I., said yesterday in explaining his pre dicament.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes was urged yesterday to have meter maids ticket cars illegally stopped on crosstown express streets and to have the cars towed away.
The grass is green in front of the High Mountain School in North Haledon, and Mayor Alvin G. Blau of that parched North Jersey community is happy to explain why.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Johnson's urgent request to Congress for a new immigration law banning the national origins quota moved an important step toward fulfillment today.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Two hundred conservatives, most of whom supported Barry Goldwater in the 1964 Presidential campaign, will meet here Saturday to organize what they hope will become a major national political party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Republicans demanded today that hearings be ended and a vote taken on a series of bills affecting bank mergers, but Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, blocked action. Mr. Patman is chairman of the House Banking Committee, which has held hearings five days a week for the last two weeks on the measures.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Perry Mason and the cast of "The Defenders" were all but indicted today when a State Supreme Court Justice ordered an educational program aimed at dispelling the idea that such television programs present a true picture of the court.
The Los Angeles riots, costing a quarter billion dollars and 31 dead, are a direct result of a tragic migration of 13,000,000 people off the farms and into overcrowded cities.

DIREDAWA, Ethiopia, Aug. 26 -- Seventy thousand refugees and 250,000 head of cattle have crossed the border from Somalia in the last two weeks, creating an immense administrative problem, Ethiopian authorities said here today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates bombarded San Francisco for 26 hits tonight and defeated the pennant-contending Giants in both ends of a double-header, 8-0 and 6-5. It ran the Pirates' winning streak to six games.

YONKERS. Aug. 26 -- Easy and easier best described the manner in which first Governor Armbro and Bonus Boy captured their respective divisions of the E. Roland Harriman Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday against a proposal to enlarge the power of the City Planning Commission. An hour and a half later, John V. Lindsay arrived to support the plan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Government announced today its intention to publish payments statistics in the future on the so-called Bernstein basis as well as on the present basis.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Ted Davidson went in in relief of the injured Joe Nuxhall in the fourth inning and protected a two-run lead as the Cincinnati Reds defeated Milwaukee, 3-1, tonight and moved into a tie with the Braves for second place in the National League.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Navy's Sealab 2 was lowered 205 feet to the bottom of the ocean today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd virtually made certain today that the fight over reapportionment of state legislatures would be put off until January.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 -- President Johnson moved directly into steel labor negotiations today with telephone calls appealing to top bargainers for a "responsible and decent settlement."
Two leading shipyard concerns in the Port of New York have strongly protested a plan of the Maritime Administration to send Federally owned vessels to other ports for repairs.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The price of gold rose a cent an ounce to $35.1225 on the bullion exchange today.
TORONTO, Aug. 26 -- A dispute about a $5 million short-term note of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation Ltd., has been taken to the Supreme Court of Ontario.
For the first time in a citywide election, rival slates of candidates will not appear in the same columns on voting machines in all boroughs on Primary Day, Sept. 14.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Men between the ages of 19 and 26 who get married from today on will not be exempt from the draft. Their new draft status was established in an Executive order signed yesterday by President Johnson. The action was taken to meet the growing manpower demands of the war in Vietnam.
The Corps of Engineers has been asked to make a study on the removal of debris from the Hudson River, from north of New York Harbor to the Troy dam.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26 (UPI) -- James P. Coleman, recently appointed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, has asked that he be removed from a panel named to hear a suit contesting Mississippi's poll tax.

Stocks edged up slightly in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Of the 765 issues traded, 276 advanced, 263 declined and 226 were unchanged Volume amounted to 1.72 million shares, the same as Wednesday's turnover.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Sandstorm, a palomino gelding owned by a St. Louis disk jockey, won the junior jumper championship today as the C.W. Post College horse show began a four-day run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ester Peterson, President Johnson's Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs, today urged shoppers to keep up pressures on merchants who have not yet passed on the excise tax in the form of lower prices.
HOUSTON, Aug. 26 -- The fuel cell system emerged again today as probably the controlling factor in the length and character of the Gemini 5 space flight.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 -- Indian troops have captured another position on the Pakistani side of the Kashmir ceasefire line, the Government said here today.

We would like to commend The Times for bringing to the attention of the public the unsatisfactory state of New York City's Housing Court. Our com mittee's report of an eighteen-month study of Housing Court recommended last January that penalties should be imposed which are appropriate to the seriousness of the charges and the defendants prior record.

DURING the last two or three years there has been an outpouring of World War I books, and more are on the way. In part, this is due to the usual anniversary celebrations: last year was the fiftieth anniversary of 1914, this year is the fiftieth of 1915, and so on -- we won't be done with it until 1968, and then comes Versailles.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 25 -- The United States and Hungary have stepped back from their position of a year ago when they were on the threshold of exchanging ambassadors and initiating broad cultural and economic ties.
ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Premier Elias Tsirimokos suffered a parliamentary setback tonight that left him scant hope of surviving the vote of confidence expected by tomorrow night.

Stockholders of ACF Industries, Inc., approved an increase yesterday in the authorized common shares to allow for a two-for-one stock split previously proposed. Shortly afterward, management informed them it planned to buy the company's stock in the open market from time to time.

THIS is the time of year that all pro football coaches dread. So do most of the rookies and a few battle-scared, aging veterans. The cutdown dates keep arriving with inexorable finality as the ax chops squad numbers down toward prescribed limits, 40 in the National Football League and 38 in the American.
ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Two headless, life-size statues of women dating from about 100 B.C. were found last week on the Aegean island of Naxos.

SIERRA VISTA, Ariz., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Rev. Thomas L. Hobson said yesterday he had removed his name from a letter accusing the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop at San Francisco, of heresy.
A two-month experiment to increase the technical and professional efficiency of 14 African news executives will begin next Thursday at the American Press Institute of Columbia University.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 26 -- Authorities recovered nine bodies today from the wreckage of a neoprene manufacturing plant following 26 explsions yesterday.

Milton Mollen, the city's former top housing official, called yesterday for a sweeping overhaul of the housing code enforcement program. He proposed a new Department of Housing Maintenance, tripling of the inspection force, and creation of a five-man board empowered to subpoena and fine delinquent landlords.

BONN, Aug. 26 -- Franz Josef Strauss, former West German Defense Minister, warned today that a "new Fuhrer-type" who "would promise and probably also acquire nuclear weapons" might emerge if Germany was subjected to "military discrimination" as it was under the Treaty of Versailles.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Tom Reynolds and Wayne Causey provided the punch and Jim Dickson and John Wyatt the relief pitching as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-3, today.

Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo yesterday suspended his two top Manhattan engineers, accusing them of deliberately hiding leaks from the Central Park reservoir. He said they had apparently diverted the water into a nearby sewer.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- No task is happier than that of saluting a really distinguished debut. Tonight, a young, and brilliant unknown, Indian girl. Yamina Krishnamurta, scored a genuine triumph at London's Commonwealth Institute Theater.

" What's your current opinion on I.B.M.?" Questions such as this kept coming this week to the desk of Robert A. Sullivan, a tall, studious-looking man of 35 whose dark hair is starting to turn gray along the sideburns.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- In a series of unpublicized and indirect approaches to North Vietnam, the United States is now offering to exchange demonstrations of a desire to slow down the war.

DUISBURG, Germany, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia scored a one-length victory over the Ratzeburg crew of Germany today in a preliminary heat of the European rowing championships.
Herbert von Karajan, music director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, has been engaged to direct and conduct a new production of Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung" at the Metropolitan Opera.
The Communications Satellite Corporation has named A. Bruce Matthews as financial vice president, it was announced yesterday by Leo D. Welch, chairman and chief executive officer.
Since Erik Satie was the granddaddy of the avant-garde, it was as fitting as it was surprising that the second program in the Avant-Garde Festival at Judson Hall was devoted to his music last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 --Proposed legislation to control sailings of foreign-flag cruise ships from United States ports was attacked here today by foreign steamship and tourist officials as a potential economic danger to shipping and tourism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Irving M. Pollack has been chosen as the new director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of trading and markets. Formal announcement of the appointment is expected soon.

WHEN R. Conrad Cooper picked up the phone in his 38th-floor executive suite in the Pittsburgh headquarters building of the United States Steel Corporation at 11:30 yesterday morning he talked to one of the most persuasive telephoners in history -- President Johnson.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 26 -- The Singapore Government arrested 20 Communist leaders today and said it had smashed an Indonesian-backed plot to take over this island state.

The Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad and Investors Diversified Services. Inc., reported yesterday that net assets for its common stock stood at $163,100,000, or $13.56 a common share as of Aug. 25.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has joined other enforcement agencies investigating the possibility that a highly complex stock swindle is related to a Canadian finance company's multimillion-dollar default on its notes.

About 200 residents of Manhattan's West Side astonished city officials and each other last night by holding a community antipoverty convention that was quick, quiet and orderly -- enlivened only by a few charges of "railroading" that were greeted with scattered applause.

McKEESPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 -- There is a field in Renzielausen Park where McKeesporters normally work up an appetite playing softball. But for the last three evenings they were flocking there to satisfy their appetites for unusual foods.

THE area of the game in which the expert has the greatest advantage over the average player is neither in bidding nor in dummy-play, but in defense. A well-taught beginner can bid well enough in most situations, except when competitive judgment is required, and most players of some experience are reasonably competent in handling the dummy.

The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York announced yesterday that it would no longer continue contract negotiations at The Times, but would meet under the auspices of the Federal Mediation Service when management was ready to make "concrete counterproposals."
HAMLET, N.C., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A truck driver from Florida was arrested here early today for terrorizing passengers aboard a Miami-to-New York train with a 12-gauge shotgun.

The National Sugar Refining Company, which suffered a loss of almost $5 million last year, is planning to diversify its business for the first time in 65 years through a merger with the privately owned Krim-Ko Corporation.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 26 -- The parents of five young children were arraigned on charges of manslaughter in Nassau County Court today after a sixth child died of malnutrition.

SPETSAIS, Greece -- The current historical moment seems marked by a paradoxical phenomenon. In many democracies there is a tendency to put increasing executive authority in the hands of a single leader. Yet, at the same time, there is a reversed tendency in some Communist states.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 26 -- First love and its often, heartbreaking disappointments are the subjects of "Lasky Jedne Plavovlasky" (Loves of the Blonde), the Czech entry shown tonight on the Venice Film festival's competition program.

The Amazing Mets overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers last night for the third straight time -- and defeated Sandy Koufax for the first time in their history -- before a roaring crowd of 45,950 fans in Shea Stadium that included Mayor and Mrs. Wagner.

President Johnson's announcement that men from 19 to 26 years old who were not married by midnight would be subject to the draft resulted in a flurry of activity last night by young bachelors anxious to beat the deadline.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Bill Morgan of San Francisco State College ran the 10,000 meters in 30:55.8 today slashing two minutes off the Maccabiah mark. Bill Silverberg of Overland Park, Kan, was second in 31:06 for the silver medal.
Pepsico, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of Pepsico International to broaden sales of its convenience and snack foods and soft beverages in foreign markets.
The new Hall of Primates opens today at the American Museum of Natural History.
The election of James H.M Ewart as senior vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company was announced yesterday by Harold H. Helm, chairman.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Less than a month has passed since Arthur J. Goldberg presented his credentials as chief United States representative at the United Nations, but already the mission that he heads is beginning to present a new appearance to the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity said today it had helped place more than 100,000 Negroes and other nonwhites in jobs in the last two years with its Plans for Progress program.
San Antonio, Tex., awarded $15 million of various-purpose bonds yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers.

A family from Laguna Beach, Calif., filed a $6 million suit against Saudi Arabia yesterday charging that the kingdom's militia had sunk its seaplane with gunfire in the Gulf of Aqaba on March 23, 1960.
The British pound eased slightly in inactive trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, the restaurant chain and coffee producer, announced yesterday the election of Herbert Samuel as a vice president.

HOUSTON, Friday, Aug. 27 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts surpassed two Soviet space records yesterday on their sixth day in orbit. But renewed difficulties with the fuel cell power system threatened to end their flight tomorrow.
The First National City Bank's plan to go into the mutual-fund business came a startling news yesterday to most members of the investment and banking community, but, to a few, it came as no surprise.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 -- B-52 bombers of the United States Strategic Air Command today made their 11th raid on the Vietcong in South Vietnam, a United States military spokesman announced.

Gladys Schmitt's seventh book, "Electra," a psychological novel set in Mycenaean Greece around 1100 B.C., will be published by Harcourt, Brace World on Sept. 22. Miss Schmitt writes that her novel is based on the legend of the House of Atreus and "attempts to draw an authentic picture of life as it was when the legend may actually have taken place.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has completed arrangements for the purchase of 20 feature films from Columbia Pictures for $8 million. This may mean that the television network is planning two "nights of movies," the second to start possibly early in 1966.
As in separate dramas on an opening and closing night, two scenes were enacted on Broadway yesterday that evoked youthful nervousness and a veteran's nostalgia.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 26 -- The junta regime announced today that it was "stimulating" wide participation from all over the country in a rally to be held here Sunday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Former Senator Barry Goldwater's Free Society Association said today that the two major parties offered voters no "real political choice."
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 -- There will be an international battle in the Little League World Series championship on Saturday when Connecticut faces Canada.

The formation of RoyWest Banking Corporation, Ltd., to make mortgage and development loans in the Bahamas and British Caribbean countries was announced yesterday by its seven principal corporate shareholders.
BUDAPEST, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United States overwhelmed the Soviet Union, 81-38, in their basketball meeting today before a strongly pro-American crowd at the World University Games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Johnson cautioned today that racial violence, corresponding to that in Los Angeles, could break out in the nation's capital and other cities unless immediate steps were taken to open the gates of economic opportunity to Negro populations.
Sales and earnings of Genesco, Inc., in the fiscal year ended July 31 were the highest in its 41-year-history, according to the report going to 30,000 shareholders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Johnson is expected to reverse soon a policy that half the American commercial wheat sales to countries in the Soviet bloc must be shipped in United States vessels.

Samuel Trepner has resigned as vice president and general merchandise manager of J.W. Mays, Inc., department store chain based in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Max L. Shulman, president and chairman.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- United States authorities said today that East Germany was holding three American citizens, one serving an eight-year prison sentence and the others awaiting trial.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board has inaugurated a program of annual awards for excellence in design and construction of buildings in the borough.

DENVER, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Barbara Mclntire, the defending champion, lost, but a three-time winner, Mrs. Anne Quast Welts, triumphed, along with Polly Riley and Connie June Day, in the quarter-finals of the United States women's amateur golf championship today.

The W.T. Grant Company realized a 68.6 per cent gain in earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended July 31 on a sales gain of 8.8 per cent, the variety chain of 1,087 stores reported yesterday. For the six months, the earnings rose 87.6 per cent as sales climbed 9.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A $650 million higher education bill including the nation's first Federal scholarship program won House approval tonight. The vote was 367 to 22. The bill now goes to the Senate, where action is expected next week.

SAIGON -- All the available information here indicates that both sides are planning for a long war. Van Johnson and George Voskovec are set for starring roles in "Mating Dance" and "The World of Ray Bradbury," respectively. The former will open Oct. 27 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. "The World" is due Oct. 5 at Off Broadway's Orpheum Theater.
The stock market showed yesterday its first genuine signs of strength in a week as the blue-chip issues joined defense and glamour stocks in a broad upward sweep.

The Fourteen Hotel on 60th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, home of the Copacabana nightclub, has been sold to a real estate investor by the concern that has owned the property for the last 15 years. The sale was for more than $1 million in cash over mortgages.

Paul R. Screvane, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Mayor, yesterday accused the Republican-Liberal candidate, John V. Lindsay, of "supporting Republican efforts to sabotage President Johnson's antipoverty program."
An Episcopal minister and a Reform rabbi announced yesterday that they had rented new quarters in Astoria, Queens, for their much-harassed narcotics clinic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Government literally stopped the census clock to proclaim that the United States became a nation of 195 million people today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Tonight at Groovy's you can have "Bitter Rice" with your cheeseburger rare.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Postal authorities, with a sigh of relief, announced today recovery of 50 stamps with a major printing error.
Memorial tribute was paid yesterday to Adlai E. Stevenson at the World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A confidential report submitted to President Johnson last spring by a committee on civil rights has become one of the most widely discussed and quoted papers in Washington.

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Couples trying to beat President Johnson's midnight draft deadline by getting married are in such a hurry, said a justice of the peace here, that "they don't even have rings."
James Boyd, president of the Copper Range Company, has been elected a director of the New Jersey Zinc Company. He succeeds Gordon H. Chambers, who has resigned.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Mrs. Ogden Phipps's The Sport was the best of a three-ply entry trained by D.M. (Mike) Smithwick in the $22,050 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today. In this case, being the best of the group was the same as being the best in the race.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Britain issued a Foreign Office white paper today in which she drew attention to her persistent efforts since last February to promote a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Malin Burnham of San Diego won the third race of the International Star Class world championship sailing regatta yesterday to take a one-point lead in the over-all standings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A Pentagon weekly summary of casualties in the war in Vietnam showed today that the number of combat deaths since Jan. 1 rose during the week to 618. During the week 57 United States servicemen -- the largest weekly toll -were killed, and 73 were seriously wounded, bringing the total of wounded to 3,097.

AREA A -- Bluefish are reported running well from the Klondike Banks to Shrewsbury rocks and off Manasquan and Sea Girt beaches. Quite a few sea bass and stripers have been caught near the jetties and beaches at Long Branch.
Treasury bonds resumed their four-week-old downward price trend yesterday after Wednesday's one-day respite.

The House of Representatives has acted emphatically to eliminate immigration quotas based on national origin. It reflected a salutary transformation of the Congressional climate since the passage in 1952 of the McCarran-Walter Act, with its grossly discriminatory provisions.
