Jesse Gray, the Harlem rentstrike leader who had sought the Democratic nomination for Mayor, withdrew as a candidate yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- A union of Russian machine workers agreed today to send a small representative delegation of tourists to the United States next spring in reply to an American exchange party now concluding a two-week stay in Moscow.

ALBANY, Aug. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller tartly rejected today a request of Democratic leaders for a special legislative session on reapportionment, reminding them that a joint committee was supposed to be working on a plan.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Dick Green's run-producing single off Whitey Ford in the ninth inning tonight gave the Kansas City Athletics a 1-0 victory over the New York Yankees.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Art Ellis of Weekapang, R.I., sailed to victory in Gardiners Bay today in the Bradford McPherson Memorial Series for the Comet Class junior championship.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Charlie Johnson capped a last-ditch, 80-yard drive with a 15-yard touchdown pass to Sonny Randle in the final two seconds tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 17-17 tie with the San Francisco 49ers in a National Football League exhibition.

CANNES, France, Aug. 27 -Jean-Louis Tixier-Vignancour, the flamboyant right-wing lawyer who is the only French politician actively challenging President de Gaulle for the Presidential election, is winding up a month-long, country-wide barnstorming tour on the beaches of the Riviera.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 27 -- Led by a pair of high school sophomores whose average weight is 113 pounds, American swimmers outclassed athletes from the rest of the world in the swimming competition at the seventh Maccabiah Games.

Plans have been made by Joseph Cates for a musical adaptation of "Caesar and Cleopatra," by George Bernard Shaw, whose "Pygmalion" emerged as "My Fair Lady," one of the most successful hits ever. Mr. Cates expects to bring the show to Broadway during the 1966-67 season.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 27 -- A general-alarm fire destroyed a $300,000 pier here tonight. Six firemen were overcome by smoke, and Fire Chief Patrick Carmody was injured when a stream of water from a fire boat knocked him down.

The "me too" gambit, so firmly embedded in maritime labor relations, is one of the chief reasons why the merchant marine strike of seagoing personnel went through its 73d day yesterday without a settlement.
Under a broiling sun and before hundreds of onlookers, 1,361 men, women and children were baptized yesterday in a mass immersion of Jehovah's Witnesses at Orchard Beach, the Bronx.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 26 -- The new Sao Paulo Philharmonic, the first privately financed symphony orchestra in Latin America, is off to an exciting start with an assist from Howard Mitchell, director of the Washington National Symphony.

Real Madrid of Spain and Independiente of Buenos Aires played to a 1-1 tie last night in an international soccer match but only after as bizarre a finish to a sporting event as New Yorkers have seen in many a year.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- The Soviet leadership welcomed President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic to Moscow today for five days of talks that may lay the basis for a new peace initiative on Vietnam.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27 (UPI) -Art Hanes, a former mayor of Birmingham and a seregationist, agreed today to represent three Ku Klux Klansmen accused of murdering Mrs. Viola Liuzzo, a civil rights worker from Detroit.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 27 -- An important part of the summer came to a close today for 160 potential Darwins and Thoreaus whose ages range from 5 to 13.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -Two Democrats on the Senate Agriculture Committee have moved to amend the omnibus farm bill to abolish shipping restrictions that have prevented wheat sales to countries of the Soviet bloc.
General Motors' common stock briefly touched par -- the Wall Street term for 100 -- yesterday and closed at 99 1/2, up 1/4 for the session.

ALBANY, Aug. 27 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, warned the State Board of Regents today that criticisms of deficiencies in primary education can be expected to shift soon to the college and university levels.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 27 -- Tension rose today as the military-civilian junta continued to delay action on peace and the rebels charged a conspiracy to wreck a reconciliation.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A professor at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, lost for three days in the thick woods of the Catskill Mountain foothills, turned up today at Ellenville, a small village about three and a half miles from the point at which he had entered the woods.

AWAN SHARIF, Pakistan, Aug. 26 -- Clouds laden with the rain that this small Punjab village needs for its maize and wheat were just overhead today, but many farmers here were busy packing and getting ready to move out.
The Judson Memorial Church warned yesterday that it would no longer allow exhibitors in the Washington Square Outdoor Art Show to adorn its spiked iron fence and yellow brick walls with their works.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Industrial peace returned to the British Motor Corporation today with settlement of a strike atone of its components factories that put 20,000 other men out of work.

It is most unfortunate that certain political factions have taken this time of water crisis to attack Mayor Wagner and his administration as well as Arthur C. Ford, President of the Board of Water Supply, and his staff for even suggesting that they failed to provide adequate means of water supply for the needs of New York City.
I was very much interested in your Aug. 10 editorial "The Liquidity Riddle."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The United States, the Soviet Union and France were said to have accepted today the main points of a formula to end the big-power dispute over the financing of United Nations peace-keeping operations.

American nuns are throwing themselves into civil rights and antipoverty struggles as a direct result of a major effort in the last decade to raise their educational standards, according to Sister Bertrande Meyers, president of Marillac College, Normandy, Mo.

Some interesting lessons on what is wrong with the way in which New York City transacts its affairs can be drawn from the fate of Item 312 on the Board of Estimate's calendar for last Thursday. This was a zoning amendment that would have given the City Planning Commission discretionary control over the future location of municipal garages in or under public parks.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 27 -- Saboteurs, whose sporadic raids into Israel have come mainly from bases in Jordan, struck last night from Lebanon.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana -- On Sept. 6, there will be a modern version of a gold rush here.
HOUSTON, Aug. 27 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts are providing a valuable weather eye for forecasters on earth and may even help forecast weather conditions for their own Atlantic landing area.

An important element of comedy, the psychologist advises, is the superiority the audience feels as it watches the comic. Thus, we have the pathetic clown in his tattered clothes; the poor slob who slips on a banana peel or gets a pie in the face; the stuttering funnyman who, try as he might, cannot get the right words out.

Several civic and political groups and three outraged candidates for Mayor joined yesterday in demanding that the Board of Estimate reconsider its rejection of a proposal to enlarge the power of the City Planning Commission.
OTTAWA, Aug. 27 -- The proposal in the United States Senate to restrict immigration from the Western Hemisphere received a mixed reaction here today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Dear Chance, aided by Jim Fregosi's two-run homer, four double plays and Bob Lee's tight relief hurling, won his 11th game of the year tonight as the Los Angeles Angels beat Detroit, 3-2.
Northeast Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday net income of $140.000 for July, in contrast to a net loss of $67,000 for the month last year.
CAIRO, Aug. 27 -- Authoritative United Arab Republic sources denied today that President Nasser had taken any formal proposal for peace in Vietnam with him to Moscow.
The British pound registered the customary weekend hedging dip yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
Thirty-three firemen were treated for smoke inhalation at a five-alarm fire that spread quickly through a 65-year-old loft building at 39 West 23d Street last evening.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation shut down its appliance manufacturing plant here today because of "production problems," including damage to some products.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it was planning to reduce the amount of vitamin D that may be added to food products.
Plans for construction of new plants were announced yesterday by Crown Zellerbach Canada, Ltd., the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the United Gas Pipe Line Company.
LA CRESCENTA, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Massed firemen kept a brush fire away from a group of hillside homes today, then fought to halt it as it burned across precipitous mountain slopes above.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Frank Adamucci, co-owner of the Rickshaw Inn, was shot and killed tonight in phone booth at the restaurant, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Last month's reduction in excise taxes, most of which was passed on to consumers, slowed but did not stop the recent trend toward higher consumer prices.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27 -- Government authorities conceded today that the multimillion-dollar default by the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation probably had soiled Canada's financial image in the United States. But they expressed confidence that the incident would not affect the flow of direct investment across the border.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- A 26-year-old artist, one of six persons arrested on charges of possessing narcotics early Wednesday at a wild party for 300 young people here, was sentenced to 180 day's in jail today on a charge of disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -Inventories of steel in the hands of manufacturers that use steel rose to 16.3 million tons at the end of July, compared with a normal level of 9.5 million tons a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Saturday, Aug. 28 -- Mayor Thomas G. Dunn attacked local leaders of the Congress of Racial Equality early yesterday, accusing them of distorting facts and stirring up tensions in the Negro community of this cramped old city of 110,000.

THE fall schedule of Walking Tours of New York neighborhoods sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York will begin Sunday, Sept. 12. The first tour will be the Chelsea area from the Chelsea Hotel to Old St. Peter's Church via the General Theological Seminary.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27 -The Long Island chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality announced today that it had reached agreement with the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage on ending alleged job discrimination at the company.

Every time resuscitation seems hopeless for the novel, an old novelty revives it. In "New American Story," just published by the Grove Press, ten authors give fiction another chance to go on. The stories by Burroughs, Kerouac, Creeley, Selby and others are to be read for their linguistic rather than their semantic potential.

The largest crowd to see a single baseball game in Shea Stadium -- 56,167 persons -- turned out last night to watch the return of Warren Spahn, a melodrama in several acts that the San Francisco Giants won from the New York Mets, 9-2, with five resounding home runs.
The threat of long and expensive legal actions by established liquor dealers is scaring away many persons who might seek retail licenses, the chairman of the State Liquor Authority said yesterday.

TALL and gangling Bobby Fischer used to cry when he lost a chess game. Now he freely admits that he is the greatest chess player in the world; and a lot of experts agree even though he has not won the world's championship.
NEW BERN, N.C., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Many schools in North Carolina's coastal counties, an area of heavy Negro population, were integrated today in a quiet but tense atmosphere.

The General Battery and Ceramic Corporation has sold the voting-machine business of its subsidiary, the Shoup Voting Machine Corporation, to the Warden Corporation of Philadelphia for more than $8 million.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Four hundred maintenance men voted today to end a two-week wildcat walkout that had kept nearly 20,000 British Motor Corporation workers idle at plants in England and Wales.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 27 -- Stern steps by President Chung Hee Park's Government brought a lull today in massive student demonstrations that have bloodied the dusty streets of Seoul during the last week.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The chairman of a theater ticket agency today criticized the Government for spending too much public money on "sensational experiments" and not enough on the conventional British theater.
The curtain on the first legitimate theater production to be staged aboard a trans-Atlantic liner is scheduled to go up this weekend in the 664-seat theater of the French Line flagship France.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today to provide mail subsidy for two helicopter airlines to carry them through the rest of 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- An examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that 11 supplemental airlines be given permanent authority to continue operating charter air services.
PLYMOUTH, N.C., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Civil rights leaders agreed today to halt demonstrations here over voter registration, at least until after a conference with Gov. Dan Moore.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Dennis Bennett posted his first complete game victory of the season tonight, pitching the Boston Red Sox to a 6-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a doubleheader. Chicago won the opener, 3-2.

AN attractive young woman in Southampton is not permitted to lie in the sun long enough to get a good tan. Her husband won't let her. She is Evelyn Welker Jiras. Her husband is John Jiras, a 36-year-old make-up man at C.B.S. who, at one time or other in his career, has put eye-liner and lipstick on everybody from Elizabeth Taylor to Ilka Chase.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- All Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge did was to say something in public about hoping the South Vietnamese would carry out a "true revolution." But many people thought he was urging a new coup d'etat.

Both sides will be looking hard for quarterback development as the New York Giants and Jets play preseason games today. The Giants meet the Philadelphia Eagles at Palmer Stadium, Princeton, N.J., this afternoon and the Jets take on the Boston Patriots at Norfolk, Va., tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The conservative youth organization, Young Americans for Freedom, opened its fifth anniversary convention tonight with confidence in the eventual triumph of its right-wing philosophy apparently unmarred by the 1964 election.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Jean Pierre Roggo, a 23-year-old Geneva, Switzerland, skipper retained the International Moth Class world championship today. He sailed Dunand Moth to five victories in six races to win the Carling Bowl Trophy. Roggo, just out of the Swiss army, finished the five-day International Moth Association regatta at the Corinthian Yacht Club with 3 3/4 points.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 28 -- Giant B-52 bombers of the United States Strategic Air Command raided the Communist jungle stronghold of War Zone D, north of Saigon, late yesterday for a second straight day.

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- A justice of the peace told today how he had married 67 draft-age men -- sometimes at the rate of one every three minutes, or about as long as it takes to boil an egg -- between late yesterday afternoon and midnight last night.
WINNIPEG, Aug. 25 -- W.C. McNamara is the sort of man who, just by flying to Ottawa for the day, can shake the grain market with rumors of an impending wheat sale to Red China.
The Bank of America announced yesterday plans for installing new computer equipment to replace its present depositaccount system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The index of primary market prices was unchanged at 102.8 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Aug. 24, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- A fisherman returning from Canada told the police today that five women had pulled him from his car at an east side intersection, slashed him on his face and legs and took $83.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 -- The American Federation of Teachers ended its week-long annual convention here today after adopting a hotly debated resolution supporting the foreign policy of President Johnson.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, Vietnamese chief of state, yesterday rejected the possibility of a coalition government with the Vietcong guerrillas.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Closer economic cooperation within the sterling area is being discussed here as a means for creating a stronger pound and an improved world-payments position. The area covers one-quarter of the world's land surface, one-quarter of the world's population and carries out one-quarter of the world's trade.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Britain's National Theater company will play for three weeks in Moscow and one week in West Berlin next month when it embarks on its first foreign tour.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- The crippled Los Angeles Dodgers clung to first place in the National League tonight by outslugging the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-8 before 26,740 at Connie Mack Stadium.

William Friedman, a stockbroker, died yesterday of a fractured skull suffered after he and two friends tried to quiet a noisy group in a barroom in Yonkers Wednesday night. He was 64 years old and lived at 1180 Midland Avenue, Bronxville.
The Welch Scientific Company, a Chicago manufacturer of laboratory equipment for schools, announced yesterday the election of Richard E. Welch Jr. as chairman and chief executive officer.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Ace of Diamonds, an aged chestnut gelding, won two of the five classes and scored in the other three to capture the first-division junior working hunter championship today at the C.W. Post College horse show.
Traders in grain futures reacted bullishly yesterday to reports that President Johnson is planning to ease restrictions on wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, has made new approaches on Vietnam to the 14 Governments that have participated in international conferences on Indochina.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week on a moderate upbeat yesterday as most stocks advanced on good volume.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Gov. George C. Wallace filed a complaint in United States District Court here today, asking for a permanent injunction to stop civil rights demonstrations in Greene County.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 -- The status of steel labor negotiations was described in bleak terms tonight by William E. Simkin, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

City antipoverty officials said yesterday that unless they were successful in getting more money from Washington, about 6,600 young people, most of them unskilled high school dropouts, would lose their first jobs by the end of October.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 -- A South Vietnamese force supported by American paratroopers tried today to open National Highway 14 north of here. The Government convoy did not get through, but three Roman Catholic nuns in a Land-Rover decorated with a cross did.

GREENSBORO, Ala., Aug. 27 (UPI) -- An 87-year-old Negro farmer whose tongue was cut out as an apparent warning to those who speak out against racial demonstrations died today without naming his attackers.

Carmine Lombardozzi, the racketeer and Cosa Nostra figure, and five companions were arrested yesterday evening after a melee with the police in a Brooklyn restaurant.

MADISON, Wis., Aug 27 -- Restrictions proposed by the Federal Food and Drug Administration on the addition of vitamin D to food products drew a sharp response here today from a spokesman for a university foundation that has been marketing vitamin D for 40 years.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- Ken Boyer's two-out double in the 14th inning tonight drove in Lou Brock and gave St. Louis a 6-5 victory over Cincinnati.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A state welfare official says that Alabama's refusal to sign a nondiscrimination pledge is "no defiance" but merely a way to get the issue tested in court.
ROQUEBRUNE CAP-MARTIN, France, Aug. 27 -- Le Corbusier, the architect, died of a heart attack today while swimming off this Riviera resort. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- President Johnson signed two bills today to help veterans with service-connected disabilities. "America owes these new laws to the men who have been injured and wounded in her service," he said.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Baltusrol won the Jersey Professional Golfers Association title today with a 72-hole total of 278. This was 10 strokes under par for the Echo Lake Country Club course.
The election of Frank T. Bartlett and Col. William J. Marquette, U.S. Army, retired, as vice presidents of the Waterman Steamship Corporation, was announced yesterday by Edward P. Walsh, president.
NATCHEZ, Miss Aug. 27 -- George Metcalfe, a civil rights leader, was seriously injured today when a bomb destroyed his automobile.
DENVER, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Anne Quast Welts got a par on the first extra hole to beat Polly Riley today in the semi-finals of the women's national amateur golf championship.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- A guide at a United States architectural exhibition touring the Soviet Union was accused today by Izvestia, the Government newspaper, of having been a German intelligence agent operating against the Russians in World War II.

LENOX, Mass. -- The beavers are gnawing and building along the Yokun Brook here, and they do not care who watches them do it. In fact, like just about everything else at the Pleasant Valley Wildlife Sanctuary, the beavers symbolize congenial, informal hospitality.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- Vague but unmistakable storm warnings are up for Soviet writers and the younger generation of readers.

MADRID, Aug. 28 -- West Germany has begun pension payments to disabled veterans and families of slain members of the Spanish Blue Division, which fought with the Nazis on the Russian front in World War II.

THE scene was Grand Central Station's main concourse one recent rush hour: in a roped-off section near a train gate, a Hollywood crew, including an intense young director with an electric megaphone, a poker-faced cameraman and assorted grips and technicians were busily filming repeated takes of a well-dressed young man being lovingly greeted by a well-dressed (for a time) young blonde who, after the afternoon wore on, suddenly stripped down to a spectacularly brief bikini.

NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The owner of the best of 752 dogs entered in the Newton Kennel Club show in Memory Park next Saturday will receive the trophy from Gov. Richard Hughes. The show, the 22d to be held by the club, will benefit the youth of the community, with the proceeds going to the Newton Recreation Fund and the Sparta Boy and Girl Scouts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Interior Department proposed today that a national lakeshore be established in the Apostle Islands region of Wisconsin, near the western end of Lake Superior.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Mohawk Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board this week for a new route between Islip, L.I., and Detroit, by way of New Haven-Bridgeport, Conn., and Albany, Utica-Rome, Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo, N.Y.

About eight years ago a small trade magazine serving the men's wear field, called Apparel Arts, changed its format and became a consumer magazine designed for men with a more than passing interest in their clothes.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The Caracas police announced today they had smashed a Communist-led plot "of great proportion" to overthrow the Government of President Raul Leoni and to sabotage major installations in the country.
HOUSTON, Sunday, Aug. 29 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts prepared to land shortly before 9 A.M. Eastern daylight time today after a record-breaking, eight-day flight in space.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 28 -- Peasants and other groups from the interior started converging on the capital today for an "anti-Communist concentration" tomorrow morning.

KYOTO, Japan, Aug. 9 -- With a series of fine planes, Sotoji Nakamura's expert Japanese carpenters produce boards so smooth that they feel like panes of glass. Mr. Nakamura disdains sandpaper, which is one of the reasons why his art is in demand by patrons from Pocantico Hills, N.Y., to Paris.

A building contractor who regularly makes campaign contributions to both the Republican and Democratic parties, "to keep away the evil spirits," will contribute as well to the major contenders in the Democratic primary here.

GREAT BARRINGTON is a year-round resort on the Housatonic in the Berkshires. William Cullen Bryant practiced law there and was the town clerk. Today the little community will be bustling with dogs -- 737 to be exact, the entry at the 23d annual fixture of the Great Barring ton Kennel Club.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 28 -- Twenty years after the explosion of the first atomic bomb, which was built here, this quiet community has been transformed from a "forbidden city" to a tourist attraction.
ATLANTA, Aug. 28 -- Southern school officials were preparing this weekend for the largest wave of public school desegregation in the South's history.

HUE, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- An estimated 3,000 persons gathered in a park in downtown Hue this morning amid a sea of banners ad posters denouncing Maj. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, chief of state as chairman of South Vietnam's ruling directory. The posters called General Thieu a "dictator."

Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, last week told the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers, in Los Angeles, that he is opposed to teachers' strikes. "They must be the point of last resort," he said.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 -- Consider the blooming baseball pitcher. In a field sometimes full of weeds, he is a carefully cultivated orchid. His development may take years (vide Sandy Koufax). Yet he can fade almost overnight, like Ken McBride and Jack Sanford.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 28 -- Consecutive homers by Rocky Colavito and Fred Whitfield tied the score and then Chuck Hinton's ninth inning sacrifice fly drove in the winning run today in Cleveland's 6-5 victory over Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- "The rubber-stamp 89th Congress," intoned The Richmond News-Leader recently, "once more has demonstrated its spineless acceptance of the proposition that what Lyndon wants, Lyndon gets."

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 28 -- Mike Taliaferro the forgotten quarterback of the New York Jets, let the world -- and the Boston Patriots -- know tonight that he was still around. His second-half heroics led the Jets to a 17-0 victory over the Patriots in an American Football League preseason game.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Two tracking stations sponsored by the Smithsonian Astro-physical Observatory have obtained photographs of the Gemini 5 space vehicle and a section of a rocket that boosted it into orbit.

A ROAR of applause greeted the final Olympic torchbearer as he entered the stadium, jogged around the track and up 163 steps to stand silhouetted against a clear October sky. There were tears in the eyes of old men as he stepped forward to light the flame opening the Olympic Games of Tokyo.

Twenty-five of the nation's finest speed and endurance swimmers will begin a one-mile ocean race at Smith Point, Suffolk County's Park, at Shirley, L.I., for the Walter T. Shirley Memorial Trophy next Sunday.

Louis Calder Jr. of New York City, Armonk, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I., president, treasurer and a director of the Perkins-Goodwin Company, Inc., of New York, an international pulp and paper organization, died of a heart attack Friday on the golf course at Laval sur le Lac, Que. His age was 46.

IN the Caribbean the universal cat-and-mouse fable features Nangato the Cat befooling Perez the Mouse by feigning sleep. The moral is still the same -- that shrewdness prevails over strength. Familiar folktales in a Spanish guise tell how pretty Pepita wins a prince, about the sticky siesta of honey-stealing amigo Fox, or how Senor Rabbit harnesses Senor Tiger as a horse.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The present and future well-being of millions of children in Asia will be the key objective when representatives of 20 nations and territories gather in Bangkok, Thailand, next month for the first Asian conference on children and youth in national planning and development.
Stores are replenishing their supplies of back-to-school apparel and merchandise, according to reports from resident lying offices. Reports on various departments follow:
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Billy Williams drove in three runs with a home run and a single today as the Chicago Cubs beat Milwaukee, 3-1, and extended the Braves' losing streak to five games.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- South Africa, already ahead, 1 -- 0, in the series, was in a strong position today at the end of the third day of the third and final cricket test against England at The Oval here.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 28 -- A Kentucky law requiring junkyard owners to screen junked cars from public view is being obeyed by 75 per cent of the state's 758 junk dealers.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. -- One of the most picturesque of the villages of the Pueblo Indians occupies the flat, 40-acre mesa of Acoma, about 60 miles southwest of here. The mesa rises 350 feet above the plain, and to reach the village means a hard climb up a tortuous stone trail.

SOME seasons ago Maureen Howard wrote a beautifully orchestrated little tour de force about an errant professor entitled "Not A Word About Nightingales." Her second novel, also about a fugitive from life, is in a different key, and it lacks the tidy proportions of her first.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Tom Rolfe, a 3-to-10 favorite, had to hustle hard the final sixteenth of a mile to beat Royal Gunner by a neck today in the $107,500 Arlington Classic at Arlington Park.

CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 28 -- The race for A and B Class production cars shapes up as the one of greatest interest on tomorrow's 10-race Sports Car Club of America national championship program here. AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- Al Geiberger, chilled despite two sweaters, scored a 69 today to gain a five-stroke lead in the $100,000 American Golf Classic. The one-under-par third round brought the slim, 27-year-old Californian a 54-hole total of 208 over the Firestone Country Club course.

THE American story, from George Washington to Lyndon Baines Johnson, is told with considerable verve and variety in James Munves's survey. Here are the struggle for independence, the creation of a new government, westward expansion, regional differences, Civil War, social and economic changes, Depression and world wars -- all described and related the one to another in a smooth and knowledgeable narrative.
CAIRO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Cairo suburb of Kerdassa was placed under martial law today after violent clashes between the military police and followers of the outlawed extremist Moslem Brotherhood.

ALAN SILLITOE has now written four novels, of which only the first, "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning," had genuine literary merit. That book was a peculiar mixture of vaguely leftist complaints against, and rather joyous description of, the unpleasantness of English working-class life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The course of relations between President and Congress, like that of true love, never has run smooth. AS soon as the lilies in the fields south of Portland, Ore., flower, they lose their heads. With nonchalant abandon, workers go through the acres with sharp knives in hand and cut off the blossoms. The long strike of sea-going engineers against the subsidized segment of the merchant marine on the East and Gulf Coasts has finally been settled. RICHMOND, Aug. 28 -- The Virginia General Assembly will meet in special session Tuesday to reapportion the state's 10 Congressional districts.

ALGIERS, Aug. 28 -- Official Algerian sources confirmed today that Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika met Wednesday with Communist China's Ambassador Tseng Tao; the Vietcong representative here, Huyng Van Tam, and the North Vietnamese charge d'affaires.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia reached the final round of the United States doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club today with Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., and Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico.

THE Olympic record for acrimony and international ill-will was unquestionably established at Shepherds Bush in London during the 1908 games, a monument of such bitterness that historians still refer to the games as "the Battle of Shepherds Bush." It probably would have remained undisturbed in the dusty archives if a sweet little man named Johnny Hayes had not died last week.
ANNISTON, Ala., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Sheriff Roy Snead said today that a white man had been charged with murder in the shotgun slaying of a Negro father of seven children.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 29 -- Henry Laskau of Mineola, L.I., who is 49 years old, came out of retirement to win the 3,000-meter walk at the Maccabiah Games today.
HOUSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- "It was funny," Jane Conrad said, "watching my husband go by looking like a star."
Mayor and Mrs. Robert Wagner struck deep in the heart of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon for a day of politicking, but few seemed to care about politics.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Ernie Banks and Ron Santo each slugged two homers and drove in four runs today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 10-2 victory over Milwaukee. It was the Braves' sixth straight defeat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The thin facade of alliance and mutual forbearance has been torn off the relationship between the United States and Pakistan, setting the stage for a major readjustment or a bitter and costly quarrel.
BUDAPEST, Aug. 29 (AP) -- United States trackmen were shut out today as Hungary won the battle for gold medals in the fourth World University Games.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Australis, a high-stepping 6-year-old bay mare who has two national championships to her credit, captured the open jumper title today at the concluding session of the C.W. Post horse show.

" Loop the Loop on the Moebius Strip," a script dedicated to Michael H. Schwerner, James E. Chaney and Andrew Goodman, the three civil-rights workers who were murdered in June, 1964, in Philadelphia, Miss., will be produced at an Off Broadway house in mid-October.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Edmund Dubin Jr. and John Puskar of the Rockaway River Country Club defeated Rudy Ozol and Dr. Joseph Giacona of Suburban, 3 and 1, today to win the New Jersey four-ball match play tournament at the Navesink Country Club.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 29 -- The Deacons for Defense ant Justice, an armed Negro defense league, moved openly into Mississippi today in response to an increase in white terrorism during the last week.

SAINT CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Salvage crews are attempting to raise the United States tug Vegco, which sank in lock No. 4 of the Welland Canal yesterday after a collision with the Swedish freighter Eva Jeanett.

YONKERS, Aug. 29 -- The $100,000 New Zealand pacer, Cardigan Bay, with Harold Dancer Jr. at the reins, has been installed the 5-2 early favorite to win the $25,000 Hal Dale Free-For-All Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
DUISBURG, Germany, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Ratzburg Rowing Club crew gained a convincing victory over the Olympic champion Vesper eight today in the final of the European rowing championships.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 29 -- In a successful race against time, impeded by a labor dispute and red tape, the United States entry of paintings and sculpture for Sao Paulo's eighth Biennial was delivered today to the Museum of Modern Art here.

William C. Freund, chief economist of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, believes that 1966 will reverse the pattern of 1965, with the economy accelerating its pace as next year unfolds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Danny Cater's run-scoring single in the seventh inning of the second game snapped a tie and helped the Chicago White Sox to complete a sweep of a doubleheader with Boston today by 3-2 scores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Lawrence Francis O'Brien was once described as "the Jim Farley of the Kennedy Administration." But it was a description without appropriate portfolio. Today, President Johnson amended that to "the Jim Farley of the Johnson Administration" and provided the portfolio to go with it: the job of Postmaster General.

Damage to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company's neoprene plant at Louisville, Ky., is much less extensive than first feared and repairs already are under way, the company announced over the weekend.

MIAMI, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- A tropical storm north of Puerto Rico became the second hurricane of the season today, lashing the Leeward and Virgin Islands with heavy rain and moving into the open Atlantic.

The Joy Manufacturing Company announced over the weekend that it would seek shareholder approval at a special meeting Oct. 20 of the authorization of a new class of preferred stock and a broadening of the corporate purposes.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Aug. 29 -- Some of the musicians of the Marlboro Festival discovered here today that their "republic of equals" in Vermont contains features of kibbutz life.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United States won the gold medal in basketball at the Maccabiah Games today, scored additional first places, but suffered an embarassment in the pole vault, long considered its domain.
A light calendar of new bond offerings in both the corporate and municipal markets this week will enable dealers to prepare for the heavy fall season that begins after the Labor Day weekend.
THE death of David Bruce in Los Angeles last Thursday recalls the period some 30 years ago when, as David Burnstine, he was among the highest-ranked New York experts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The International Monetary Fund shied away in its annual report today from any conclusions as to how best to improve the world monetary system.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 2 -- The Johnson Administration's optimistic assessment of the march of the Alliance for Progress was challenged today by Chile's leading newspaper.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. James A Farrell Jr.'s smooth fox terrier, Ch. Forecast Ebony Box of Foxden, walked off with best-in-show honors at the Great Barrington Kennel Club's show tonight.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The world's monetary problems, in the eyes of European officials, are the pound now and reform later, not the other way around.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 29 -- India said today her troops had beaten back a major Pakistani attack across the Kashmir cease-fire line and had killed at least 25 Pakistani soldiers.
Formation of a worldwide alumni council for International House, 500 Riverside Drive, was announced yesterday by John J. McCloy, chairman of the board of trustees.
NEWARK, Aug. 29 -- New Jersey will lift its ban on press coverage of Juvenile Court proceedings, beginning Sept. 13.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 29 -- Al Geiberger, whose lack of stamina keeps him from competing more often in tournaments, won the $100,000 American Golf Classic today. The slim, 27-year-old Californian's 72-hole aggregate of 280 gave him a four-stroke margin over Arnold Palmer.

Commonwealth Associates, Inc., a new company engaging in real estate brokerage, consulting and property development, has been established with offices in New York and San Juan, P.R.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Monday, Aug. 30 -- Dominican rebels in downtown Santo Domingo exchanged fire last night with inter-American forces separating the rebels from junta-controlled territory.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 -- Steel labor negotiations broke off tonight. President Johnson's mediators said collective bargaining could not solve the dispute and prepared to give him their analysis of the crisis tomorrow at breakfast.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Steve Hargan, a rookie, thwarted a succession of Minnesota scoring bids in the first six innings today as he pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over the American League-leading Twins.

THE fashion message from Paris is a medley of flared or feathered coats, sequined shifts, high-climbing collars and mid-knee hemlines. Its youth quotient is high, ranging from Dior's dirndl skirt suits and big schoolgirl bows to Saint Laurent's baby dresses with smocked fullness and kindergarten sashes. But the instant news is Saint Laurent's Mondrian-inspired dresses.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The National Guard has withdrawn the last 250 troops standing by to guard against recurrence of the Los Angeles riots.

KARACHI, Aug. 29 -- Abdul Hamid Khan, president of Pakistani-controlled Azad (Free) Kashmir, warned India today to evacuate the three posts she occupied on the Pakistani side of the cease-fire line in recent days. He also called on the Indians to pull out of Kashmir "before it is too late."

Britain's decision to limit immigration from Commonwealth countries to 8,500 a year is based on racial discrimination and could have "serious repercussions'' among colored members of the grouping, a Jamaican Cabinet minister said here last week.

MADRID, Aug. 29 -- A leading Spanish poet was reported today to have resigned his teaching post at the University of Barcelona in support of five professors recently dismissed or suspended by the Government for allegedly taking part in political activity.

In the heart of the financial district on lower Broadway about a dozen independent businessmen are looking forward to the start of the school year Sept. 13 in the hopes of improving their net earnings for the last quarter.
