A 95-page second edition of the New York City Housing Statistics Handbook has been published by the Mayor's Housing Executive Committee.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- The Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth and dissident members of his congregation agreed today to try to settle their dispute over church funds without going to court.
The American Sugar Company made its first move yesterday toward diversifying its operations.

Recently a physicist took 4,400 gallons of mineral oil 10,492 feet down into a South African gold mine to hunt a strange atomic particle that had never been detected in its natural state. Now he has reported success.

The International Monetary Fund has added its voice to those calling for international monetary reform. Its annual report observes that while there is no need for immediate action, it would be prudent to reach an "international consensus" on plans for strengthening and improving the present system so that both industrialized and developing nations can continue to increase internal growth and external trade.
Directors of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation voted yesterday in Chicago to increase the quarterly dividend to 30 cents a common share from 25 cents in earlier quarters.

Governor Rockefeller's rejection of Democratic pleas that he call a special session of the New York State Legislature to permit the creation of a bipartisan advisory commission on legislative redistricting is disappointing, though hardly surprising. The Governor, who has shown great consistency in being wrong on this issue, vetoed a similar bill at the end of the regular legislative session.

The 16-foot ketch Venus rocked gently at anchor in Sheepshead Bay yesterday while her 26-year-old skipper recalled the highlights of a 16,000-mile voyage that started in England 14 months ago and ended here Sunday.

The Government filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to collect $635,000 in taxes from two brothers, who allegedly had a secret bank account with $750,000 from undeclared income earned during World War II.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Auto junkyards must be hidden behind an eight-foot fence and the operators must be licensed under a new state law effective Wednesday. Local governments are given power to enforce the law.

MANY have tried to understand Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, his character as well as his twisted words, and few have succeeded entirely. Yet, some keys to such understanding have always been readily available.
Speed horses found the going slow and tiring, but there were no signs of fatigue among the horseplayers yesterday as thoroughbred racing returned to Aqueduct.

In the four months of conflict between rebel and junta forces in the Dominican Republic, 2,500 persons have lost their lives, the economy of the country has been badly disrupted and anti-Americanism has grown.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Nine days ago, Paul Savidge became a married man. Tomorrow, he will say goodby to his wife and report to the Princeton football team. Ten days later, he will see his wife again.

The leasehold on the 21-story Fawcett Building at 67 West 44th Street, northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas, has been sold by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to the 44th Sixth Corporation, headed by Gerard Oestrelcher, realyt investor.
TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Japanese veterans or the Burma-Thailand railway, built with forced labor in World War II, have brought out a book challenging the description of atrocities on the project.

The London Stock Exchange and other financial institutions were closed yesterday in observance of the "August Bank Holiday." Markets on the Continent might well have been on holiday too in view of the light trading and moderate price changes that occurred.

THE late P. Hal Sims had a psychological recipe when he needed to guess the location of a vital queen. He would sit and think until one of the defenders broke the tension by making a remark, by lighting a cigarette or by ordering a drink.

Casey Stengel has been part of New York baseball longer than most fans can remember. He played on Brooklyn's first pennant-winning team in 1916. His home runs helped win World Series games for the old Giants in 1923. As a manager, he guided the Dodgers, the Yankees and the Mets. And, as he would say, if you don't believe it, "you could look it up."
The last-minute effort to reinstate proportional representation here got a push from Mayor Wagner yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 -- Federal Judge Frank J. Battisti denied today a motion for a preliminary injunction to block a Standard Products Company special meeting scheduled for Sept. 3.
Your Aug. 6 editorial regarding nonparticipation of physicians in Medicare needs a few facts to refute its implications.
A sharp price drop in National Video was the standout feature in a generally irregular market yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Quietly and doggedly all summer long Congress has been undergoing what the psychiatrists call group therapy. It has been trying, by talking things out, to get at the root of some of its quirks, bad habits and infirmities of age.
The British pound made its customary Monday pick-up yesterday in continued inactive dealings on foreign exchange markets here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The 35-member African group decided today against backing Foreign Minister Alex Quaison-Sackey of Ghana for re-election as President of the General Assembly.

GLENDALE, Calif., Aug. 30 -- A specially commissioned painting called "The Resurrection" was unveiled at Forest Lawn Memorial Park the other day amid elaborate ceremonial trappings. Brian Sullivan and the Roger Wagner Chorale were on hand to sing for the 1,500 guests.

A Federal-state dispute was set off in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday over the Federal Government's assertion that a Veterans Administration mortgage had to be paid off before local real-estate tax liens could be satisfied in a foreclosure sale.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United States lost $80 million of gold in July, the smallest monthly loss this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The eight-day postponement of the steel strike, won through the intercession of President Johnson, provides needed time for a restoration of economic perspective in this crucial labor-management conflict.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 30 -- The Elizabeth branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today called for a boycott of the open enrollment plan recently drafted by the Board of Education to end racial imbalance in the city's public schools.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that certain top officials of VTR, Inc. -- now a tire and soft-drink franchise business -- had misappropriated company funds over the last seven years to finance personal ventures.
HOUSTON, Aug. 30 -- Preparations for the next two Gemini flights moved ahead today as the Gemini 5 astronauts began 11 days of intensive reporting on their eight-day journey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Leaders of the Republican party argued behind closed doors today about "splinter groups," civil rights and the balance-of-payments problem. After six hours of private talk, they decided to say nothing publicly about any of them.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 -- It's getting downright embarrassing for directors of tuna tournaments off the New England coast. The seventh annual Cape Ann competition has ended with anglers on 44 boats batting zero again.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Robert Doyle of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., and Edward Butler of the Mission Bay Yacht Club of San Diego, Calif., were the most effective young helmsmen in today's sailing for the North American junior championship and its prize, the coveted Sears Cup.

To the Editor: Under the heading "Bishops Oppose Birth Curb Bill," which bill proposes setting up Federal offices to coordinate both research and the dissemination of birth control information, we read in The Times of Aug. 25 that William B. Ball, speaking for the bishops, condemned the bill on several grounds.

MIAMI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A team of weather scientists left Miami today to take a close look at the hurricane named Betsy and decide whether to seed the storm with silver idodide in an attempt to calm it.
Plans for expansion were announced yesterday by several concerns in varying fields.

Mary McCarthy, James Agee, Vladimir Nabokov, James Baldwin and Ayn Rand will be added starters in the fourth edition of "The Oxford Companion to American Literature." The editor, James D. Hart, has written new entries on 223 authors.
Wellington Associates has acquired an option to buy a half interest in the land under the Plaza Hotel, on Central Park South near Fifth Avenue.

DURANGO, Colo., Aug. 30 -- Is anybody else here old enough to remember Ken Maynard? Thirty years ago, or maybe longer, he was a low-budget John Wayne and in every movie he had this scene about the sarsaparilla.
TRENTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes was minus a popular political weapon today -- the handshake.

MIAMI, Aug. 30 -- Cuba's elementary schools will be linked to military units, children will participate increasingly in agriculture, and scholastic achievements will be de-emphasized under the new Cuban educational program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the formation of an executive committee of leading experts to plan a White House conference on health this autumn.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation reported yesterday that its profits in the three and six months ended July 3 rose sharply from 1964 levels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Administration's three-year old guidelines for noninflationary behavior on the part of labor and management will face their gravest challenge yet in the current steel negotiations -- and in the view of many informed persons here may not survive.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 30 -- The 17th annual Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion will be held here Sept. 10 at the Wee Burn Country Club. The event, at which 41 young women will be presented, will benefit the Stamford Hospital and St. Joseph's Hospital, both in Stamford, and Norwalk Hospital.
New York City experienced the coldest Aug. 30 in recorded weather history yesterday as the temperature dropped to a November-like 50 degrees at 6:50 A.M.

The appointment of John F. Burditt and Henry A. Correa as executive vice presidents of ACF Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday by William T. Taylor, chairman of the manufacturer of railroad cars and automotive and aerospace equipment.
The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company announced yesterday in Chicago that it will postpone by 30 days the closing on its acquisition of the Simplicity Manufacturing Company.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic is finding the Soviet leaders receptive to his initial efforts toward putting together a new Vietnam peace initiative, an authoritative Egyptian source said today.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball will meet President de Gaulle tomorrow to discuss Vietnam and other questions.
TORONTO, Aug. 30 -- The chant of an auctioneer sounded the physical finish today for the Racan Photo-Copy Corporation, Ltd., one of the most mysterious companies ever promoted here.

As recent news stories have disclosed, Canada is reaping bumper foreign sales from its 1965-66 wheat crop. The Dominion recently sold 214 million bushels to the Soviet Union at a price of $450 million.

ATLANTA, Aug. 30 -- Thousands of Negro children quietly entered once-white schools in the South today as racial desegregation moved for the first time into many small cities and rural areas. Some educators said it was the biggest day of integration in the South's history.
The city will continue its employment program for 4,000 disadvantaged youths until Dec. 31. It was originally scheduled to end tomorrow.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 30 -- Eighteen Indonesian soldiers were killed or wounded yesterday when a Malaysian security patrol surprised a party of raiders near the border between Indonesian Borneo and Sarawak, according to the Malaysian Defense Ministry.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 30 -- India said today that her troops had captured at least nine important Pakistani positions in a major offensive into the part of Kashmir held by Pakistan.
A YOUNG graphics designer in San Diego, Calif., has discovered a new use for cardboard -- a children's chair that sells for $2.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska -- Anchorage is a place of squares and angles and cubes that looks as if it had been designed by an architect in love with building blocks. Buildings are low and rectilinear and some of them, from a plane's eye view, look like dominoes set on end.
" When in the name of heaven are we going to give the people at the seat of the nation a chance to participate in the democratic process?"

MUSIC al fresco is an old and honored institution all over the world. Only in recent years, though, has the activity been taken seriously as a cultural phenomenon. Historically, outdoor music meant light music; and as often as not, band music.
Commissioner Maurice J. O'Rourke of the Board of Elections said yesterdy that the six-week summer voter registration drive that ended Saturday was "a major disappointment to me."
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- The weather could have been worse, which would have made the test better, but under sunny skies today Roosevelt Raceway unveiled its all-weather track.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler began a two-week series of financial talks in Europe today amid signs that the United States and its most outspoken adversary were moving closer together on fundamental issues of world monetary reform.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation has made a time study of British life.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- A poem by Boris Pasternak, written during the height of the harsh campaign against him in 1958, was published here today for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked a Spokane, Wash., broker's registration today, accusing Russell L. Irish of persuading his customers to change their mutual fund holdings frequently so he could collect more commissions.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug 30 -- The first 30 minutes of talk with Bill Elias, Navy's new football coach, lacked something. There had not been a mention of that four-letter word -- Army.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it had set aside 90 minutes on Sunday, Sept. 19, five days after the Democratic primary, for a television debate among the three major candidates for Mayor.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, still adding entertainment specials to its television schedule for next season, has booked Gene Kelly to star on an hour-long musical variety show on Feb. 14 at 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Chairman William McChesney Martin Jr. of the Federal Reserve Board told a Congressional committee today that an improved international monetary system must continue to rely upon the dollar as reserve currency.

ATLANTA, Aug. 30 -- The Municipal Theater of Atlanta ended its summer season in the 6,000-seat Chastain Amphitheater on Saturday night with a performance of Bizet's "Carmen," starring Beverly Wolff, Richard Tucker and Frank Guarerra.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Jack Cullen, a rookie right-hander, thwarted two rallies by the Los Angeles Angels tonight as he pitched the New York Yankees to a 4-2 victory in the opener of a four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Johnson ordered drastic economies in nondefense spending today. Government agencies were instructed to reduce their spending plans for the next fiscal year by nearly $9 billion.
There is one aspect of the Aug. 19 decision of the German court in Frankfurt in the Auschwitz death camp case which should not be overlooked.

A torah hidden in a German cemetery during the Hitler era, two silver breastplates from the collection of the Central Synagogue of Moscow, and a 200-year-old shofar, or ram's horn used by the so-called "black Jews" of Cochin, India, are among the items already donated to the International Synagogue, now under construction at Kennedy International Airport.

KAINANTU, New Guinea, Aug. 28, -- Dr. Richard Hornabrook, the man who knows more about kuru than anyone else, said here today that the prospects were "fairly good" that the cause of the mystery disease that afflicts a small pocket of primitive people in the New Guinea highlands near here would be found.

BONN, Aug. 30 -- A spokesman for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that, while Bonn wants to improve relations with the Soviet Union, it believes West Germany would weaken its position by submitting specific proposals for a peace settlement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The reassignment of Ambassador John Moors Cabot will be determined after he returns from Poland.
A shift in downtown traffic patterns, as an alternative to the projected Lower Manhattan Expressway, was proposed yesterday by Representative William F. Ryan.
A five-alarm fire raged through a textile manufacturing complex in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn for three-and-a-half hours last night before it was brought under control at 9:45 o'clock.
Yesterday morning, when it seemed the steel negotiations had reached an impasse, stock prices began to fall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board told the airlines today there no longer was any justification for charging higher fares on jet planes than on older piston engine craft.

Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, New York State's first Congresswoman, left an estate of more than $1 million in personal property and $100,000 in real estate, according to her will, admitted to probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Kipchonge Keino of Kenya won a mile race at White City Stadium today in 3 minutes 54.2 seconds -- the fastest mile ever run in Britain.
Four men emerged yesterday as the likeliest candidates to succeed Casey Stengel, minutes after the announcement by the patriarch of the New York Mets that he was stepping down.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Royal Mint is trying to discourage bulk purchases of coins, made on the off chance of finding something valuable.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The British Empire is running out of candidates for independence. After having helped a score of territories with about 700 million inhabitants set up as independent countries, the British are discovering that many of their remaining 34 dependencies, with a population of 10 million either cannot afford or do not want independence.
" MUST I shoot a simple soldier boy who deserts," Abraham Lincoln asked, "while I must not touch a hair of a wily agitator who induces him to desert?"

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The casualty list of young Kennedys stood at three today, with the disclosure that Joseph, 12 years old, son of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, suffered chest injuries in a boating accident yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Johnson announced tonight an eight-day postponement of tomorrow night's steel strike deadline.

The British bank holiday, the end of a maritime tie-up in East Coast and Gulf ports, the possibility of a steel strike in the United States and the weather were some of the main factors affecting the prices of commodity futures yesterday.

The Dominion of Trinidad and Tobago has enjoyed political stability in its three years of independence, but as it celebrates the anniversary today its leaders still scan around for more investment funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Johnson, who has been emphasizing the need for national unity, sought today the advice of two Republican leaders -- former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and former Senator Barry Goldwater.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United States, reversing a previous policy, is setting up a full-scale program to assist the 400,000 refugees made homeless by the Vietnam fighting.
SAAS-FEE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Aug. 31 -- A massive avalanche roared down from a glacier yesterday, burying workers and machines at a hydroelectric construction project near here.
FAIR HOPE, Ala., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A former champion, Mrs. Timothea Larr of Oyster Bay, L.I., gained a 1-point lead today in the first three races of the North American women's championship regatta.

New York's parks are finishing a record concert season that has drawn more than a million persons to free, live music in the great outdoors from the rural precincts of Staten Island in the northern marches of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A small-town banker opposed canceling antitrust suits in six bank mergers today, telling a House banking subcommittee that the institutions "want the rules of the game changed in their behalf."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 30 -- Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barreras and his military-civilian junta resigned tonight, making way for a provisional government sponsored by the Organization of American States.
The authority to hospitalize mentally ill persons will pass tomorrow from judges to doctors when a major reform of the state's mental hygiene law goes into effect.

The Conservative party yesterday opened headquarters for the mayoralty campaign of its candidate. William F. Buckley Jr., on the 10th floor of a 16-story office building at 25 West 45th Street, between 5th Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.
Activity in all three sectors of the bond market came close to a standstill yesterday as dealers and investors anxiously awaited word of developments in the steel industry's labor negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- President Johnson's proposal to create a Cabinet-level department to attack the mounting problems facing cities moved today to the brink of final Congressional approval.
Seamen and shipowners who have lost millions of dollars in the record maritime strike will start trying to recoup some of their losses today.
MOSS POINT, Miss., Aug. 30 -- An Arizona medical student charged with illegal possession of drugs was released in $2,500 bond today after spending three days in jail.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 -- A two-engine Navy plane carrying Eugene Fubini, former Assistant Secretary of Defense, two senior military officers and James Reston, an associate editor of The New York Times, crash-landed near the Danang Air Base today but there were no serious injuries.
North American Aviation, Inc., has announced the election of Lawrence P. Greene as a vice president in charge of the Washington, D.C., office.
A number of price changes were announced yesterday in various industrial fields.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The year's major gathering of sociologists opened here tonight with a tribute to Karl Marx, sociologist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A petition to force House action on a District of Columbia home rule bill picked up a half-dozen more signatures today, and Speaker John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, said if he were not a leader he would sign it.
New rules calling for uniform warning signs and traffic safety devices at street construction sites were announced yesterday by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The resignation of General Imbert and his junta was received with cautious optimism by State Department officials tonight.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Sandy Valdespino's two-out single in the 11th inning drove in the run that gave the Minnesota Twins a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United States, led by a distance runner, Bill Morgan of San Francisco, continued to dominate the men's track events in the Maccabiah Games today.

Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, was a pawn ahead and was expected to defeat his opponent, Alberic O'Kelly of Belgium, when play was adjourned last night in the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament.

The executive council of the Textile Workers Union of America called yesterday for a Congressional investigation into what it said was a "continuing conspiracy" by Southern textile manufacturers to prevent unionization of their employes.
Production of steel in the nation's mills moved up slightly -- 2,000 tons -- from output in the week before.
How good a manager was Casey Stengel? A genius? A fraud? He has been called both. Upon retirement, he deserves an attempt at objective evaluation.

Mrs. Josta Granier, who was dropped as a probationary meter maid because she was overweight, returned to the city yesterday after a 14-day weight-reducing program in Florida. She was down to 174 pounds, 16 pounds lighter than when she was forced to resign.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 30 -- Israeli Government officials and religious leaders have dismissed a rabbi's assertion that he received overtures to become Chief Rabbi of the Soviet Union.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 31 -- Three United States aircraft have been lost in raids ove rNorth Vietnam in five days, an American military spokesman said yesterday.
There were wall-to-wall people yesterday as Alexander's opened its $20 million East Side department store.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The incorporation of Halifax Developments, Ltd., to undertake a 17-acre urban renewal project in downtown Halifax was announced today by J.C. MacKeen, president of the company.

On Aug. 30, 1915, a sandy haired, 15-year-old boy from West Orange, N.J. rode the Lackawanna Railroad to Hoboken, took a ferry across to lower Manhattan and began working for the Bankers Trust Company at 16 Wall Street as a page boy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 -- A high-level Brazilian mission left today for Moscow to negotiate a new trade and economic cooperation agreement with the Soviet Union. The mission was headed by Minister of Planning Roberto Campos, architect of Brazil's economic recovery program.

Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel announced his retirement as manager of the New York Mets yesterday, ending a 56-year career as a professional baseball player, coach and manager. However, he will remain with the Mets in an executive capacity for two more years.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Hanoi radio broadcast a report today on two United States Air Force pilots captured recently and said both had made their flights into North Vietnam from bases in Thailand. Radiophotos of the fliers were also sent out.

In an apartment on the West Side of Manhattan about seven years ago, after a few drinks, two relatively modest Texans began to write a book that would, if nothing else, advance the theory that the world's population was divided not so much by geography or ideology, but rather by an intangible barrier that separated people who were "In" from people who were "Out."

The city's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control said yesterday that if his department did not receive more money in the fight for cleaner air, it would be "waging a battle with both our hands tied behind us."

A strategist for one of the leading Democratic contenders for Mayor sat the other day in his midtown office with his sleeves rolled up, his tie pulled down and talked on the telephone with one of his field workers. His half of the conversation went this way:
The city's two oldest arts clubs, the 94-year-old Salmagundi and the 67-year-old National Arts, are considering merger as a solution to financial pressures.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 -- Two new air strikes in South Vietnam by United States B-52 bombers were announced today and informants here said that attacks by the strategic bombers would soon be carried out at the rate of about one a day for an indefinite period.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Tonight London paid a debt of honor and paid it in full. As the cheers mounted at Covent Garden for the New York City Ballet, and George Balanchine took first one, then another curtain call, it was not difficult to guess his thoughts.

YONKERS, Aug. 30 -- Cardigan Bay, the classy 9-year-old, again displayed his superiority by winning the $25,000 free-for-all Hal Dale Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Driven by Harold Dancer Jr., Cardigan Bay paced the mile-and-a-quarter in 2:34 2/5, before 23,630 fans.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 30 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva's economic program faced a serious setback today as mounting opposition in the Senate threatened to block the copper bill.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation began calling back the 3,000 production workers today who were indefinitely furloughed last Friday after the company charged that appliances were being "deliberately damaged."
ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- The state plans to put pressure on communities and industries along the Hudson and Mohawk Rivers to comply with water pollution regulations.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 -- President Frei said in an interview published today that the "new left" in Latin America had left behind the Communist parties as a force for revolutionary change.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices declined 1 per cent between mid-July and mid-August.
TRENTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Harry Rosen, who was dismissed as public relations director for the Newark Police Department after he was found guilty of moonlighting, was ordered reinstated today.
" I pray for rain," said a city water engineer, "net just to get water, but also to get these politicians off my back. None of this political grandstanding will add a drop of water."
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Weeb Ewbank, the New York Jets' coach, said today that Mike Taliaferro would be his No. 1 quarterback in a scrimmage session tomorrow.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. 30 (UPI) -- The two astronauts of Gemini 5, feeling "great" after their record-setting space voyage, returned today to the site of their launching for the eight-day flight.
DENISON, Tex., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Denison school board changed signals today and voted to name its school community auditorium after former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Larry O'Brien is a man in the finest traditions of our many former Postmasters General. He knows nothing whatever about delivering the mail, but he is an absolutely professional politician who has shown two Presidents that he knows how to deliver the goods -- both on Election Day and when the roll is called up yonder on The Hill.

AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Half a dozen young white men armed with rocks and bricks charged into a crowd of 25 civil rights demonstrators tonight as they marched toward the Sumter County Courthouse.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 29 -- The young writers of Rumania are pushing for new freedoms of expression. They face only flagging opposition from the old guard of orthodox Communist functionaries in the field of letters.

Edward T. McCormick, who resigned under fire as president of the American tock Exchange in 1961, is returning to Wall Street as president of the fledgling and still minuscule National Stock Exchange, it was learned yesterday.

The fourth annual Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival in Central Park began at the Delacorte Theater last night. The week-long festival is presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival and was produced by William Ritman.
Maria Alexandrovna Burdova nervously fingered her black trench coat and paced anxiously at Kennedy International airport yesterday as she waited for "the horse I love."

Buffalo, a city of about 500,000 population, and in recent years off the beaten path for touring plays, is expanding the size of its Studio Arena Theater by moving it from a residential area into the heart of the business section, which is undergoing extensive redevelopment.

Opening dates and theaters for two Broadway attractions and two scheduled for off Broadway have been announced. The Broadway arrivals are "The Royal Hunt of the Sun" on Oct. 26 at the ANTA Theatre and "The Porcelain Year" on Nov. 17 at the Longacre Theatre.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 30 -- Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew declared today that he would never turn to the United States if Britain withdrew her military presence from Singapore.

CASEY STENGEL hobbled into the conference room, leaning on a crooked black cane that might have been borrowed from a Scotsman. He was as chipper as ever, almost too chipper for a man about to announce that he was retiring at the end of the season as manager of the New York Mets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- F. Clifton White, the chief organizer of the campaign to get former Senator Barry Goldwater the 1964. Republican nomination, has gone into business.

BRANDS HATCH, England, Aug. 30 (AP) -- John Surtees of England streaked away from the field in his Lola Chevrolet in both heats today for an impressive victory in the Guards' Trophy international sports car race.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Eight men who figured prominently in a corruption scandal that brought about the dissolution of the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly in June were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from six months to two and a half years.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia took the United States doubles championship today, and Mrs. Carole Graebner and Nancy Richey wrested the women's title from Billie Jean Moffitt and Mrs. Karen Susman.
George Meany has asked that Harold J. Pryor be removed as a vice president of the New York City Central Labor Council and the Long Island Federation of Labor.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The State University in Albany, beset by a strike that delayed construction of a dormitory complex, will house about 300 students in three motels here.
Golfers began their qualifying rounds yesterday for the United States Amateur tournament and not one broke par.
For three years, the Berlitz ads have been shaming readers with pictures of young children and a slogan that asks why the reader can't speak a foreign language if the child can.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- A new dictionary attempts to capture the English language of the mid-20th century by listing colloquialisms such as "with it," Americanisms such as "hooey" and "hornswoggle" and most of the four-letter words appearing in the unexpurgated "Lady Chatterley's Lover."

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The United States spacecraft Mariner 4 is relaying photographs of black space to check the accuracy of pictures it took of Mars July 14, a spokesman at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said today.
Prices opened firm yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and then drifted lower in the late afternoon in moderate trading.

SAAS-FEE, Switzerland, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Alpine pilots failed today to pry loose with dynamite a giant glacier hanging over a dam site where 102 men and a woman were buried in an avalanche yesterday. Swis troops prepared to use mortars to blast blocks of ice that pose a threat to rescue teams.
The 75-year-old owner of a rare coin shop in downtown Brooklyn was robbed yesterday afternoon of coins that he valued at $50,000.
THE Thompson race course in the northeast corner of Connecticut will conduct its 15th annual Sports Car Club of America national championship point races on Sunday and Monday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ed Mathews's No. 30 capped a three-homer barrage that gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-3 victory, over the Cincinnati Reds in the rain-plagued opener of a double-header tonight.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- East German relay teams set two world swimming records today in a meet at Leipzig, according to a report by the official press agency, ADN.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) Sam McDowell pitched a one-hitter as the Cleveland Indians trounced the Kansas City Athletics, 8-1, in the opener of a double-header tonight. then Kansas City scored 3-2 victory on Ed Charles's run-scoring single in the 11th inning.

The week's only major corporate bond offering, the $36.5 million Georgia Power Company 1 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, were won yesterday by a syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Manufacturers' total inventories rose $700 million in July, the biggest monthly increase this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

The sale of the Webb Knapp interests in the $55 million L'Enfant Plaza Development in southwest Washington a group of New York and Washington financiers was announced yesterday by Mortimer M. Caplin, the court-appointed trustee for the bankfupt real estate concern, and Elwood R. Quesada, head of the investment group.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Brooks Robinson hit a homer in each game and drove in two runs in each tonight as he led the Baltimore Orioles to a sweep of the two games against the Chicago White Sex, 4-0 and 7-2.

The formal Soviet reply to the new Western proposals on nuclear nonproliferation not only rejects the American draft treaty but implies a refusal to negotiate at all on this paramount issue at this time.

Dance Theater Workshop will present "Mondays at Nine," a series of eight evenings of modern dance, at the 74th Street Theater beginning Nov. 1. The performances will be sponsored jointly by the Workshop and Norman Keen, director of the theater.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell announced today that investigators would be quickly assigned to "problem areas" of the drive against poverty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- United States officials said today that they had still not turned up any information to substantiate or to explain Soviet charges against a guide at a touring United States architectural exhibit.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 31 -- As Indian troops were reported to be continuing their push through Pakistani-held Kashmir today, fears were growing here that the fighting could expand into a major conflict between the two nations involved.

In 1947 India and Pakistan fought a war over Kashmir that was finally halted along the present cease-fire line. Now, in 1965, India and Pakistan are once again fighting a minor but potentially very dangerous war over the same state of Kashmir.
On the seesaw of commodity futures trading yesterday, sugar was way down and copper way up.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- President de Gaulle and Under Secretary of State George W. Ball discussed Vietnam and the future of the Atlantic alliance today in a meeting that lasted nearly an hour and a half.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has been "terribly far behind" in its antisubmarine warfare capability but is making a major effort to catch up in the face of the threat to the Russian homeland posed by United States Polaris missile submarines, an American Navy expert said today.
CANAAN, N.H., Aug. 31 -- The. bear hunting season opens in New Hampshire and Vermont tomorrow. Ready to go at sunrise is Alvin Partridge, one of New Hampshire's most experienced bear-hunting guides.

MATTITUCK, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Bob Seidelman of Cherry Hill, N.J., opened defense of the Comet Class national championships today by scoring victories in both races. Two events are scheduled for tomorrow and for Thursday.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) -- One of the 10 divers in the Navy's Sealab 2 re-enlisted today under pressure -- 100 pounds a square inch.

A GROUP of designers has abandoned the high fashion world to bring moderately priced, ready-to-wear clothes that sense of exuberance and originality sometimes found wanting at the top. The result is clothes as contemporary as the newest variation of the Frug -- and not planned to last much longer.

A view of Mark Twain's family life and a picture of a period from the viewpoint of that family is given in "Susy and Mark Twain," which Harper Row will publish on Sept. 22. Arranged and edited by Edith Colgate Salsbury, the work is based on hundreds of letters, manuscripts, journals and a biography of Mark Twain written by his daughter, Susy, when she was 13 years old.

While astronauts are trying to find out whether man can survive in outer space and aquanauts are trying to learn whether he can survive under water, perhaps a still more pertinent question is: Can man survive here on good old terra firma!
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The House approved by a 280-113 vote today legislation backing up the agreement with Canada providing for duty-free trade in automobiles and original-equipment parts.
In your Aug. 25 editorial you observe that City Council President Paul R. Screvane is late in advancing his program as candidate for Mayor of New York City.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- South Africa won the three-match cricket test series against England when the third test at The Oval ended in a draw today.
KHABARVOSK, U.S.S.R. Aug. 30 -- Flight 27 of the Soviet Union's Government-operated airline, Aeroflot, leaves Domodedovo, Moscow's newest airport at 1:05 A.M.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The police here accused three teen-agers today of stealing hand grenades and antiriot bombs from a nearby Army camp and using the explosives against Negroes. No one was seriously hurt in the attacks.
The fire that flames so brightly in the Mets when they hobnob with the National League's elite has a way of flickering out when the New Yorkers return to their own lowly set.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday that Joseph B. Kennedy will be formally elected executive vice president at its board meeting on Sept. 21.

THE philosophy of history, writes Morton White, is "a discipline with a checkered past, a respectable present and, I hope, a brighter future." Perhaps this book will help pave the way to that brighter future -- but rich and interesting as it is, it is also evidence that the millennium has not yet arrived.
ABOARD U.S.S. INDEPENDENCE, off Vietnam, Aug. 30 -- The American naval bombardment of North Vietnam now goes on 24 hours a day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Johnson has failed, on the first go-round, to persuade enough House members to sign a discharge petition to force a vote on the District of Columbia home rule bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Representative James Roosevelt, Democrat of California, to a United Nations post.
The General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation were found liable in Federal court yesterday for damages totaling $16,873,203 in a price-fixing conspiracy.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company will use six full-color magazine ads to promote its fiber glass division, featuring artwork creating the impression that it was done with a needle and thread instead of paint and a brush.

SAIGON, Aug. 31 -- The politics of this part of the world make the polities of Texas seem innocent and even virtuous, and this may be one reason why President Johnson is having so much trouble negotiating a compromise in the Vietnamese war.
The president of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation reported yesterday in Neenah, Wis., that profits in the first fiscal quarter fell from the 1964 level, although sales increased.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- In the face of widely supported leftist efforts to limit the use of United States bases in Japan and Okinawa in support of the American effort in Vietnam, the Japanese Government today significantly liberalized its definition of American rights in this area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tony Horton smashed a three-run homer in the 10th inning to give the Boston Red Sex an 8-5 triumph over the Washington Senators and a sweep of their double-header tonight.
The New York State Dormitory University awarded both of its new issues yesterday -- a total of $21,030,000 of revenue bonds -- to a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., and Halsey, Stuart Co.

Norman Carol will succeed Anshel Brusilow as concertmaster of the Philadelphia Orchestra on Aug. 1, 1966. M. Brusilow, who announced his resignation last year to devote full time to conducting the Philadelphia Chamber Orchestra, will continue in his post during the 1965-66 season.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 -- United States authorities have announced that effective today all American and foreign military and civilian personnel serving in Vietnam will be paid in United States military scrip instead of American dollars.
MARINETTE, Wis., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The body of a St. Louis shipping executive, object of a hunt in the stormy waters of Green Bay, was found today on the shore about five miles south of Marinette.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The nuclear ship Savannah steamed into New York Harbor and docked at Pier B here this morning on the first stage of a new career.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 (AP) -The Soviet Union rejected today a United States- proposed treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Gen. Bernard A. Schriever who directed the development of intercontinental ballistic missiles, today was named to head the Manned Orbiting Laboratory program.

Despite overwhelming support by candidates for both parties and no organized opposition, snail-like progress is being made in the effort to let the voters decide this November whether to restore proportional representation in electing future City Councils. Fewer than one-fifth of the necessary 50,000 signatures have been obtained by its proponents, and the petitions must be filed with the City Clerk Friday if the question is to be put to the voters.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- The Vietcong representative in Moscow yielded tonight to growing diplomatic agitation and took his place at the end of a Kremlin ambassadorial line.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Steel union and management negotiators pressed contract talks today under the watchful eye of President Johnson.
I am a survivor of a long hearing at the Board of Estimate in December 1963, at which the Home Builders of Staten Island vigorously fought the application of the City Map to their borough.
New York City's antipoverty officials asked yesterday that pressure be brought on Congress to avoid a 56 per cent cut in the size of the Neighborhood Youth Corps program here.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 31 -- Organization of American States mediators and the Dominican rebel leadership signed tonight a formal accord for a provisional government of the Dominican Republic.
More than 100,000 shoppers and potential shoppers jammed the new Alexander's on the East Side of Manhattan on Monday -- and advertising played no small part in getting them there.
Following are excerpts from Controller Abraham D. Beame's interim report on the New York World's Fair fiscal policies and practices and the text of the reply of Robert Moses, fair president:
ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Atlanta Times, an afternoon conservative newspaper, ceased publication today after 14 months because of financial difficulty.

The House Banking and Currency Committee is wrestling over a Senate-approved bill that owes its origins to the messy state of banking regulation. In an attempt to clear things up, the proposed legislation would exempt banks from antitrust prosecution for mergers made to date and would limit their exposure to antitrust laws on future mergers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The immigration bill was sidetracked in the Senate Judiciary Committee today by a legislative maneuver by Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Republican leader, who was seeking to gain priority for his constitutional amendment on legislative reapportionment.
BOSTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Joseph P. Kennedy, 76 years old, the father of the late President, entered New England Baptist Hospital today after developing "congestion" in the throat and chest area.

The State Education Department, which like the Legislature has been geared to the interests of rural, upstate New York, is shifting its focus to the educational problems of the big cities, Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. has disclosed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 -- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that South Vietnam was "not ready now" to begin negotiations to end the Vietnam war unless there were firm guarantees that Communist troops from North Vietnam would be withdrawn and that American troops would stay in the country until Saigon asked them to leave.

The Long Island Fair's piano-playing marathon at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., which began at noon last Wednesday with five contestants, has narrowed to a close race between Mrs. Dorothy C. Myers, a 45-year-old Bayville housewife, and Eskew Reeder, a 26-year-old New York jazz pianist.
Saran Schroeder picked six winners at Aqueduct yesterday, including the $119.60 daily double, but he didn't have a dime on any of them.
What started as a rush of business developed into a junior-size run on a King Korn stamp-redemption center at Second Avenue and 64th Street around midday yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Harveys of Bristol, Ltd., the 169-year-old maker of Bristol Cream sherry and other wines, has successfully beaten off a takeover attempt by the newer and bigger wine concern of Showerings, Vine Products and Whiteways, Ltd.

I have just seen the letter of Omar Azouni in your International Edition [Times Aug. 13], Mr. Azouni blames the Christian missionaries for the trouble now raging in the Southern Sudan; they taught the Southern Sudanese to fear and hate the Muslim Northern Sudanese.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Yielding to a Presidential veto, the House Armed Services Committee relinquished today its demand that Congress be given broad power to stop the closure or reduction of military installations.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 31 -- A woman was killed and more than 400 persons were evacuated from the President Hotel on the boardwalk here today after a fire broke out in the boiler room of the 40-year-old building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Those who married in haste last week to escape the draft may find themselves repenting in leisure -- and in the Army.
Several key executives will play a role in the proposed merger of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Norfolk Western Railway.
BONN, Aug. 31 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that he would visit President Johnson after the West German election Sept. 19 to "clear up any uncertainties" in Washington about West Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- The San Francisco Giants missed a chance to gain on the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers, who were rained out tonight, when they split a double-header with the Philadelphia Phillies before a standing-room crowd of 33,060.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 31 -- A team from Long Island won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual Golf Illustrated Trophy event today by defeating New Jersey and Westchester in a Nassau-scoring three-ball event at the Nassau Country Club.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 -- The young man is married, with one child, and he thinks endlessly of the future. In particular he thinks of the year 1970, because that is the year, if his luck holds, that he will be able to move from in-laws' apartment to a cooperative apartment of his own.

Harold N. Leitman, president and chairman of VTR, Inc., said yesterday that his company's management had been defamed by "misleading press releases" circulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., said yesterday that apathy of the groups that will benefit most from proportional representation "will probably result in failure to get P.R. on the ballot this fall."
The stock market yesterday finished down for the day but up for the month -- the busiest month of trading since April.
Union jurisdiction over 600 lifeguards at the city's beaches was awarded yesterday to Local 149 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Workers.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 31 -- The Common Market Commission reported today some tangible progress toward freer trade in Western Europe.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 31 -- Data of the eight-day Gemini 5 flight have shown no medical barriers to a planned 14-day mission in space, the astronauts chief physician said here today.

The European Investment Bank, an independent operation of the European Economic Community or Common Market, announced here yesterday that it had registered a $20 million public offering of dollar bonds.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Aug. 31 -- Four Negro children were admitted today to a formerly allwhite public school system of Lowndes County, an area of aggressive segregationist feeling where two white civil rights workers have been slain in the last six months.
CAIRO, Aug. 31--An African-Asian-Latin American solidarity conference is being planned, despite fears that the Soviet-Chinese ideological dispute may hamper the success of such an undertaking.

With the threatened teachers strike less than two weeks away, officials of the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers reopened contract negotiations yesterday under the auspices of city mediators.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31 -- The growing conflict between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and the Baathist party regime in Syria is threatening to wreck the top-level Arab conference scheduled to open in two weeks in Casablanca, Morocco.

WHEN Dr. James B. Conant issued a stinging critique early this year of the nation's state education authorities for their defense of the status quo, Dr. James Edward Allen Jr. may have looked like a traitor to some of his colleagues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- The President of the American Medical Association publicly made a peace bid today to the American Hospital Association in a "contentious quarrel" ever an aspect of the new medical care legislation.
The plan of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio Railroads to forge a giant system with five other major Eastern roads follows the merger route long familiar to the railroads of this nation.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 31 -- The Rand Supreme Court ruled today that the South African police should not conduct any further searches of the offices of The Rand Daily Mail under an old search warrant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The House gave speedy approval today to a proposal from the University of Texas to build a library for the papers of President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The operator of the cruises last year whose cancellation prompted the introduction of four bills designed to impose controls on such sailings told the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee today that one of the proposed measures was aimed in the wrong direction.
W.R. Grace Co. transportation and chemical concern, won a preliminary injunction yesterday against Clyde C. Hargadine, Universal Chemicals, Inc., and the Intercontinental Chemical Corporation.
Mayor Wagner authorized yesterday the installation of the first element of the city's long-planned $100 million traffic system controlled by computers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Johnson was assured today that there would be an 11th department in his Cabinet -- the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday was listless and trendless in light trading, following Monday's August bank holiday.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 31 -- Malaysia, which celebrated her second birthday today, faces her third year with new problems added to the old ones.
A manager of a Greenwich Village coffeehouse was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $325 yesterday for operating illegally and allowing unsanitary conditions in his kitchen.

CASEY STENGEL crossed paths with thousands of baseball, players. Each had his own view of Stengel, his own experiences and impressions. When Casey announced his retirement on Monday, laudatory statements poured forth from all sections of the country, from rivals and politicians, former players and friends.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 -- Dean Chance takes all the fun out of baseball for the New York Yankees. The Los Angeles Angels' right-hander beat them tonight for the seventh straight time and shut them out for the fourth time in the last two years.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The United States added to its large collection of gold medals today as the seventh Maccabiah Games ended.

The serious allegations of financial mismanagement leveled against the New York World's Fair Corporation in the city's audit of its accounts are not adequately answered by Robert Moses' refusal to "dignify the Beame political comments" by extended reply. New York City will expect a better answer, if the fair management has one.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Who is entitled to a higher education? How much independence of administration and policy can a university have when it is receiving substantial support from the government? How can higher educational institutions contribute best to the economic and cultural development of their countries?
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser declared today that he would work with others toward "more radical action" to halt aggression in Vietnam.
Technical problems have delayed for a week or two the fluoridation of New York City's water.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 31 -- President Johnson expressed gratification today at the progress being made toward racial integration of public schools in Southern and border states.

ATLANTA, Aug. 31 -- Public school desegregation continued to spread peacefully through the South today, moving for the first time into Lowndes County, Ala., a racial battleground, and scores of other Southern school districts.
Southern Negroes, aided by professional actors, will improvise dramatizations of their experiences in the civil rights struggle on stage during the travels of the Free Southern Theater.
An anonymous gift of $1 million to the Columbia gymnasium building fund, the third of that amount thus far, was announced yesterday by the university.
The Diamond International Corporation said yesterday it would increase prices by 3 to 4 per cent by Sept. 30 on products representing 70 per cent of its total sales.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco moved today to heal the breach between Brazil's university students and the Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Johnson announced today that the Head Start program to provide preschool training for poor children had been so successful that it would be made a permanent part of the American educational system.
BURAS, La., Aug. 31 -- A state court issued a temporary restraining order today, halting voter registration by Federal examiners in Plaquemines Parish (county).

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Consumers could face an increase on gas and electricity bills of more than 125 million a year and an increase in telephone and telegraph bills of unknown proportions if a technical tax measure now before Congress is enacted, the heads of two Government agencies told Congress today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The United States deposited a formal ratification today to complete a United Nations Charter amendment enlarging the Security Council and the Economic and Social Council.

EAST NORWICH, L.I. Aug. 31 -- With a keen putting touch, Jimmy Grant, the New England titleholder, led the Mettropolitan district qualifiers for the United States Amateur golf championship today. Grant's 146 total that won the medal by a stroke consisted of a morning 75 over the nearby Meadow Brook course and a par 71 at the Pine Hollow Country Club in the afternoon.

Political leaders in certain countries may rail at the United States, but not all their citizens agree with them. Hundreds in Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America are seeking pen friends among Americans. Among them are highly educated young men and women in their 20's, the future leaders of their nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Republican National Committee aides disclosed today that former Senator Barry Goldwater would speak at a fundraising tribute to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower in October.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Tonight at Covent Garden, the New York City Ballet presented the second program of its London season.
FAIRHOPE. Ala., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Timothea Larr of Oyster Bay, L.I., won two of the three races in the North American women's championship sailing regatta today and extended her lead.

The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company announced yesterday in Chicago that its profits in the fiscal year ended June 30 fell to $2,765,138, equal to $1.76 a share, from $3,282,299, or $2.05 a share, in fiscal 1964.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday that he thought it would give Negroes a "tremendous spiritual lift" if President Johnson would tour Northern Negro ghettos.

Sylvania Electric Products Inc., has completed its initial fuel core for power reactors as part of a $1.4 million Atomic Energy Commission contract. The device will be used in the Navy reactor at McMurdo Sound, Antartica.
BATESVILLE, Miss., Aug. 31 (AP) -- William Corr was elected today as the first Republican State Senator in modern Mississippi history.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 31 -- The Venice Film Festival continued today with an afternoon showing of "And a Man Came," about the life of Pope John XXIII, and an evening presentation of the Japanese "Akahige" (Red Beard).
Five hundred independent retail fish dealers, battling against the price wholesalers are charging for fresh-water fish, had to admit yesterday that they were beaten.
A Polish version of "My Fair Lady" is to be presented Sept. 11 in Warsaw's Komedia Theater.

Real estate promoters will have to give up "blank check" solicitation of investments as of this morning, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday. Under a new state law that becomes effective today promoters may no longer offer securities for sale when they have no specific real estate venture in mind.

ASPEN, Colo. -- This lively little ski-and-culture spot nestled between a pair of mountains 200 miles west of Denver hasn't seen such a stir since Mrs. John F. Kennedy came here to try the slopes last winter.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 31 -- Following is an unofficial translation from the Spanish of the Dominican Reconciliation Act signed today.

NCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 31 -- The J.C. Penny Company will open a new, 170,000-square-foot, "tremorproof' store here tomorrow, 522 days after last year's earthquake, which practically destroyed the original, five-story building.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Robert Doyle, the boy who took the 44-year-old Sears Cup symbolic of the North American junior sailing championship to Marblehead's Corinthian Yacht Club a year ago, was well on his way to taking it back there today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate Labor and Education Committee approved unanimously today a higher education bill intended to help colleges meet expanding enrollments.
ATHENS, Aug. 31 -- A change in public and diplomatic attitudes toward King Constantine has become apparent since last Sunday, when Parliament defeated Premier Elias Tsirimokos in a confidence vote.
ATHENS, Aug. 31 -- Below the floodlit Parthenon last night 39 American soloists from the Marlboro Music Festival, led by Rudolf Serkin, gave a memorable performance.
An auditing team from the office of City Controller Abraham D. Beame charged the World's Fair yesterday with fiscal mismanagement on a broad scale.
PLYMOUTH, N.C., Wednesday, Sept. 1 -- One white man was wounded by pistol fire and another cut with a knife late last night in this racially tense coastal city of 5,000 people.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate entered the controversy over police-obtained confessions today by approving a bill to permit the District of Columbia police to interrogate suspects for three hours before bringing them before a magistrate.

Government securities dealers reported increased trading activity and a firming of prices here and there yesterday on the Treasury bond list, but there was little indication that the five-week-old slide in prices might have reversed course.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- French and American financial officials agreed today to continue talks on international monetary reform among the major powers.

Helen Hayes came to town for the day yesterday from Tarzana, Calif., where she has been fluttering while her daughter-in-law awaits the imminent birth of her second child, to attend a party in her honor.
The Central Park reservoir leaks like "an antiquated sieve" and ought to be abolished, City Council President Paul R. Screvane said yesterday.
The King Korn Stamp Company's new catalogue of merchandise that can be obtained for its trading stamps has just come out, bigger and better than in past years.
One of the biggest and most sweeping railroad mergers in the nation's history was proposed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Persons over 65 on the Social Security benefit rolls will begin receiving tomorrow kits containing information on the two new health insurance programs authorized by Congress in 1965.
MIAMI, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Weather scientists today ordered the bombardment of the season's second hurricane with silver iodide crystals in the first massive attempt to tame a powerful storm.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- Robert R. Douglass, a 33-year-old former Binghamton lawyer, was appointed today as counsel to the Governor, thus becoming one of Mr. Rockefeller's top advisers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 -- B-52 bombers of the Strategic Air Command twice pounded Communist bases in South Vietnam today. It was the first time the giant jet warplanes had struck two Vietnamese targets in a single day.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Elizabeth Arden has ordered 56 outfits -- coats, suits and dresses for daytime, cocktail and evening -- from the couture house of Antonio del Castillo for her custom salon in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Johnson installed Leonard H. Marks today as head of the United States Information Agency with instructions to spread the truth, not propaganda.

Henry Moore, the British sculptor, will discuss his life and works on a one-hour television program 10 P.M. on Oct. 5 over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Many of Mr. Moore's sculptures in museums and galleries here and abroad will be shown.

A tea will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza next Wednesday to honor the debutantes who will be presented at the Gotham Debutante Ball on Nov. 25, Thanksgiving night. Among the tea's hostesses will be Mrs. William F. Cogswell, chairman of the ball, which benefits the New York Foundling Hospital.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- John Paske, Colgate's 1965 football captain, is one of the top defensive players in the East. But he may not be the best defensive player on his team. He and others made the Red Raiders the No. 2 team in the nation last year in giving points to opponents.
Robert Manry, who roughed it alone across the Atlantic for 78 days in a 13 1/2-foot sailboat, returned in luxury in 5 1/2, days aboard the 1,081-foot Queen Mary.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 31 -- The Congolese security police published today a list of 20 "undesirable" foreigners who will no longer be allowed in the Congo.
