DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 -- If there were to be betting -- which there won't be -- on the Hambletonian tomorrow at the local Fair Grounds, Noble Victory would rate a 1-to-5 favorite. However, since wagering at fair grounds courses in this state is illegal any "line" on the 40th edition of harness racing's showcase event must be mythical.
BLOOMINGTON. Minn., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bill Freehan's two-out home run in the ninth inning with a man on gave the Detroit Tigers a 7-6 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

Edward T. McCormick moved back into the securities business yesterday after a hiatus of almost four years with a bristling defense of his tenure as president of the American Stock Exchange and a promise of big things to come.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday in Los Angeles the acquisition of the Summers Fertilizer Company for 91,725 capital shares worth about $2.2 million.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 31 -- There was no mistaking the sharp bite in the New England air today. It had the tang of autumn and football. But there was some hesitation in the voice of John McLaughry as he discussed the prospects of his 1965 Brown University football squad.
DENIS DE ROUGEMONT asks Europe to pull up its socks and press on to new grandeur. His fervor has a positively Gaullist ring.

Ralf Brent, president of Radio New York Worldwide, said yesterday that the United States Government was not involved in the broadcasts. He said the bills, totaling $2,362.50 a month, are paid by Dr. Maloire's organization.
The city promised yesterday to allocate $5 million to Haryou-Act, the antipoverty and anti-delinquency project in Harlem.

All eyes in the bond market shifted to the railroad issues yesterday following the news that the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Norfolk Western Railway had decided to merge and extended consolidation bids to five smaller Eastern lines.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Even when showgirls with bare bosoms and shapely legs swarm across the stage of the huge Moulin Rouge nightclub, the American male tourist looks slightly solemn as he inspects it all. He takes small sips from the one glass of champagne included in the price of his tour of Paris nightclubs.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A new stainless steel blade was introduced here today by the Gillette Safety Razor Company. which called it a great advance on all previous blades. British or American.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 1 -- Pakistani and Indian armed forces clashed on the ground and in the air today as the fighting in Kashmir intensified.

The Dow Corning Corporation announced price reductions yesterday of 18 to 20 per cent, effective at once, on its Silastic sealant sold in quantity. The material is used as a caulking and gasketing compound in the automotive, marine, appliance and other industries.
The first phase of a new system to speed traffic through the Lincoln Tunnel by pinpointing trouble spots more quickly with closed-circuit television goes into operation today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic flew here today on his way home from a visit to the Soviet Union. He will confer with President Tito, mainly on the Vietnam situation, during the next few days.
The Port of New York Authority announced the appointments yesterday of John L. Gifford and Hendryk S. Weeks to new posts in the bistate agency's port promotion organization.

Consummation of the proposed merger of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio Railways, coupled with the proposed absorption of five smaller railroads, will call for a series of complex corporate rearrangements and exchanges of stock, if the vast consolidation plan ultimately clears the variety of obstacles it now. faces.
The stock market continued to drift aimlessly yesterday, and since there was no noticeable breeze from any quarter, stock prices finished pretty much where they had started.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -Senator Mike Mansfield summarized today what he understood to be the United States conditions for a peaceful settlement in Vietnam. The White House acknowledged that his Senate speech reflected official policy.

BOBBY FISCHER, the 22-year-old United States champion, was in sharpest fettle as Black in a Sicilian Defense, when he defeated Heinz Lehmann of West Germany in the first round of the Capablanca Memorial Tournament in Cuba.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 1 -- A gas station attendant's assumption that all foreign cars have their gasoline tanks in front backfired considerably last night.

Two city water engineers were officially cleared yesterday of any attempt to hide leaks in the century-old Central Park reservoir, now being compared with an earthen sieve. Commissioner Armand D'Angelo wrathfully suspended them seven days before.

I wish I could ignore your cruel and defamatory editorial of Aug. 31. I would do so if it were not The New York Times, widely read, widely respected and so often terribly unjust. Your paper is accepted around the world as a "newspaper of record."

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which expected that some lawyers would not like "Trials of O'Brien," a new comedy drama show starring Peter Falk, already has received complaints from members of the American Bar Association.

The Mets broke the spell the Astros inexplicably cast over them by winning the first game of yesterday's double-header at Shea Stadium, 4-1, but they fell right back into their trance and frittered away the second game, 8-5.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- Soviet scientists said today they had obtained "detailed pictures" of the results of a United States atomic explosion on July 9, 1962.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange marked time yesterday as prices ended irregularly lower in quiet trading
Copper made news in commodity futures trading yesterday, with speculators buying as prices advanced.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The triumphant progress of the New York City Ballet at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, continues.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 1 -- In a translucent sunset worthy of El Greco. Spain's latest idol of the bull ring. Manuel Benitez, thrust forward his sword and killed his second bull of the afternoon yesterday in the Toledo ring.
PLYMOUTH, N.C., Sept. 1 -- County and city officials formed a biracial committee today to work for racial harmony in the aftermath of a clash in which one white man was shot and another stabbed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Marine Corps announced today that it was cutting recruit training from 12 weeks to eight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Joseph John Sisco as Assistant Secretary of State for international organization affairs.

DENNISON, Tex., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, born the son of a railroad man in this North Texas city almost 75 years ago, returned today to speak of "disgraceful riots" and moral deterioration in the United States.
The British pound maintained its recent steadiness yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 1 -- Lawyers will begin sparring Friday at a pretrial conference here on the Federal suit to declare the Texas poll tax invalid as a requirement for voting.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 1 -- If the New Haven Railroad discontinues commuter service in southwestern Connecticut, about 35 per cent of the persons who use the line, or about 4,000 families, might move out of the region.

Representative William F. Ryan, Democratic aspirant for Mayor, called yesterday for sweeping changes in police interrogation methods, including closed-circuit televising of the questioning of suspects.

National Week, a fall promotion designed to interest more people in buying new homes, will be observed from Sept. 12, to through Sept. 19. The annual event is sponsored by the National Association of Home Builders.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The New York Jets will have a last chance to get set for the American Football League's regular season when they take on the Buffalo Bills tomorrow night at Buffalo's Memorial Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Herve Alphand was noted for a rather aloof manner and was not considered especially close to either President Johnson or President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Senate gave swift approval today to President Johnson's choice of Lawrence F. O'Brien as new Postmaster General.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -President Johnson announced today that Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who resigned recently as Ambassador to South Vietnam, would become a special Presidential consultant on diplomatic and military affairs.
HIGHLAND, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- A shortage of pickers threatens disaster for a $20 million crop of Hudson River Valley apples here in Ulster County.

The Servomation Corporation announced yesterday that it attained record sales and earnings in fiscal 1965, extending to almost a decade the number of consecutive years in which operations reached new highs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A bill to repeal a section of the Taft-Hartley Act that allows states to ban union shop agreements cleared the Senate Labor Committee today. The vote was 12 to 3.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane yesterday proposed Times Square as the site for a memorial to the 6 million Jews slain by the Nazis.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 -- Fox, a 7-year-old pacer who had failed to win in his previous 11 starts this year, responded to a woman's touch and led at every post to win the second race at Yonkers Raceway tonight with Maria Alexandrovna Burdova in the sulky.
Devernon Legrande, a tall self-styled clergyman who, the police say, has a harem in his Brooklyn "church," was arrested yesterday on a variety of charges.

IN 1874, the Queens County Agricultural Society, in an effort to encourage gun dogs in the Long Island area, decided, to hold a show and on Oct. 8, the first formal bench dog show in the United States took place at Mineola, L.I.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Massey-Ferguson, Inc., the nation's third largest farm equipment manufacturer, announced today it would move its North American implement production plant to Des Moines from Brantford, Ont.
Plans for the production of 21-inch rectangular color-television tubes, the first in the industry, were announced yesterday by two producers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The Federal Government will administer a test Sept. 28 to nearly one million children and 5,000 schools all over the country in an attempt to provide a definitive answer to two old questions -- how much and in what ways do minority group children suffer from poor schooling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Willie Kirkland's seventh-inning single drove in Ken McMullen with the tie-breaking run tonight and helped the Washington Senators gain an 8-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 -- United States and Vietnamese planes flew more strikes against North Vietnam during August than in any previous month, an American military spokesman announced today.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The kicking game, so often taken for granted by football fans, was a nightmare of mistakes for Cornell last year. It must improve this year before Cornell improves.

Newspapers serving New York and suburban areas will soon carry the cartoon characters of Whitney J. Darrow Jr., who draws for The New Yorker, in an advertising campaign for the First National City Bank.
The 78-day-old strike by officers on more than 100 American passenger and cargo ships was termed ended by observers last night as members of two unions voted on new four-year contracts.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British Government is deeply concerned about the fighting in Kashmir but does not believe it can usefully attempt any mediation role at this time.
While steel labor negotiations continue in a crucial stage, a controversy is brewing in industrial circles over whether steel prices have been quietly raised.
Wayne C. Marks, who retired in 1962 as president of the General Foods Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Penn Fruit Company, a large supermarket chain.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Jim Maloney shut out the Milwaukee Braves on five hits tonight as the Cincinnati Reds swept a double-header, 7-6 and 2-0, and moved into first place in the National League.

Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the nation's leading trainer, used three different jockeys on the four horses he saddled yesterday at Aqueduct. As usual, he got the best results from the rider he says "understands" him best.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- President Nasser joined his Soviet hosts in an appeal today for an immediate end to the bombing of North Vietnam, but otherwise kept silent about ways of moving toward a Vietnam settlement.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The center drawer of a desk used in the White House by 10 Presidents was autographed today by former President Harry S. Truman.
For the United States as a whole water is going to remain plentiful past the year 2000, Abel Wolman, one of New York's new water advisers, believes.
The proposed merger of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio railroads produced divergent trends in the stocks of the carriers on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court told the State Legislature today that if it did not reapportion both the Senate and Assembly by Dec. 9 the court would put its own reapportionment plan into effect in time for the primary elections of 1966.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Southerly winds of 35 miles an hour lashed Long Island Sound today and led to the postponement of the Sears Cup competition for the North American junior sailing championship.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Tanned, smiling and somewhat awed by his reception, Robert Manry paraded into Cleveland today surrounded by banners and thousands of well-wishers.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 1 -- When Jim Schwendlend left the banks of the Ouachita River in Arkansas four years ago, his chief lament was that he was deserting some of the best bass fishing west of the Mississippi.

Protestants and Other Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, an organization noted for its frequent and bitter criticism of the Roman Catholic hierarchy, appears to agree with the Catholic bishops on the implications of a decision on birth control handed down by the Supreme Court last June.
HONG KONG Sept. 1 -- Communist China announced today that it stood "firmly opposed to United Nations intervention in the Vietnam question" and would change its stand under no circumstances.

Representative John V. Lindsay said yesterday that the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers should begin their contract negotiations before the board submitted its budget request to the Mayor.
Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, who was sworn in as Superintendent of Schools yesterday, pledged that he would "negotiate constantly" to make certain that the schools open next Monday.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 -- The Government announced tonight that a large Pakistani Army force, supported by tanks supplied by the United States, crossed the international frontier into Indian-held Kashmir today.

The Coast Guard expects to write the final chapter today in the voyage of John J. Pflieger of 142 East 71st Street and his 26-foot sailboat, the Stella Maris, and mark his case closed with the notation, "Arrived Bermuda.''

TORONTO, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police was reported today to be making an investigation that could lead to the extradition from New York of Hal Banks, former Canadian leader of the independent Seafarers International Union.
Your Aug. 23 column on the birth control conference in Colombia seemed to me to be indicative of the American attitude that birth control is a problem for everyone but Americans.
ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 1 -- A "remarkably unspoiled" 100-acre tract of land on Great South Bay was given to the National Audubon Society today as a sanctuary for wildlife and natural plants.

The "artistry" of retailing, often debated by observers, can become more effective and can be better regulated through the application of science and mathematics, leading retailers were told yesterday by a team of management consultants.
SOME of the shortest, skinniest and snappiest clothes in the city can be seen at the Foreign Exchange Shop that opens at Stern Brothers today.
A family's living standard and financial stability may be dictated more by the way it spends its money than by the size of its income.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced plans today for stepping up enforcement of the law against racial discrimination in more than 19,000 hospital and other health facilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- At the conclusion of his remarks at the opening Senate Democratic caucus last Jan. 4, Majority Leader Mike Mansfield dealt with the delicate question of what members owed to the President and to their own conscience in the field of foreign policy.
The license of a Brooklyn real estate salesman was revoked by the state yesterday on the ground that he practiced "racism" brokers" against Jewish and Italian brokers

The entire railroad map in the East would be drastically changed by the proposed merger of the Chesapeake Ohio and the Norfolk Western Railroads. Once there were many railroads, big and small, serving the area. Now the relative handful still in operation provide inadequate service and, with a few notable exceptions, are ailing financially. The proposed merger would reduce the number to two giant complexes almost equal in financial strength and earning power.
James B. Somerall was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Pepsi-Cola Company, a division of Pepsico, Inc.
It is just as difficult to predict trading volume in the stock market as to forecast the direction of prices, but some Wall Street brokers see signs of a possible upswing in activity.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Walter H. Page, head of its International Banking division, as an executive vice president.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -- Brazil diplomatially sidestepped today a Portuguese proposal that the two countries join forces to defend Portugal's African territories against "liberation" movements.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The Gemini 5 astronauts will see their wives and children tomorrow for the first time since their eight-day orbital flight that ended on Sunday.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Britain has refused entry visas to a group of Vietcong political leaders, the Home Office said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -The steel industry increased its contract offer to the United Steelworkers of America today in an effort to break the deadlock that has stalled negotiations since late last week.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 1 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, Malaysia's Prime Minister, said today that he had no knowledge of Prime Minister Lee's allegations about an espionage case involving the United States.

BRIDGE columnists offer their readers a regular diet of slam contracts, but it is part-score hands that win and lose matches. Variations in the play are far more likely in part-scores than in slams, because the lead changes hands more often and there is more opportunity for significant decisions.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 1 -- Ten Negro students desegregated the public and Roman Catholic schools of Bogalusa today with a minimum of commotion.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 1 -- Washington's denial of Singapore's charge against the C.I.A. aroused Prime Minister Lee to anger today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- The new president of the American Hospital Association warned today of the possibility of a "major break" between hospitals and the medical profession.

Maria Bueno of Brazil, the defending women's titleholder, will appear in the opening stadium match in the United States amateur tennis championships starting tomorrow at Forest Hills, Queens.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Wilson was believed to have discussed new plans to remodel Britain's economy and halt inflation at a Cabinet meeting here today.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 -- Serious rioting broke out today in the city of Poona, 120 miles south of the port of Bombay on India's west coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The House approved by 340 to 47 today a four-year, $787.5 million program of aid for medical and nursing education.
An increase of 946,000 barrels in gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Anthony Greenwood, the Colonial Secretary, sent a message tonight to the British High Commissioner in Aden saying he was "deeply shocked by this disgraceful crime committed against one of South Arabia's most respected and devoted friends."

It is still business-as-usual at the coffeehouse at 120 Macdougal Street, despite the jailing of its former manager for operating illegally, a State Supreme Court injunction ordering it to stop and repeated Summonses.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1 -- The Cleveland Browns came out the best. They gave up merely a nebulous future draft choice and a reserve linebacker, Mike Lucci, who had already fallen behind a rookie, Dale Lindsey.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31 -- In the unpredictable world of college football, coaches take delight in uncovering stalwarts who excel in defensive play.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today that the major financial powers could conceivably come to some kind of agreement on international monetary reform by the end of next year.
The fuel cells used in last week's Gemini 5 flight are being developed for commercial use, the General Electric Company announced yesterday

TORONTO, Sept. 1 -- Accepted accounting procedures may be revised here following the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, the Toronto finance company that was put into receivership June 17.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Tony Oliva, returning to the starting line-up after a week's absence, hit two doubles and a single tonight as the American League-leading Minnesota Twins defeated the Detroit Tigers, 5-2.

Bobby Fischer sealed his 47th move in a favorable position last night and is expected to win his sixth-round game against Robert Wade of England when the competition continues today at 10 a.m. Yesterday's contest was adjourned at 10:45 P.M. after five hours of playing time.
The American Medical Association has opened a nationwide attack on venereal disease in view of an alarming rise that has reached "epidemic proportions" in some large cities.
ADEN, Sept. 1 -- Sir Arthur Charles, British Speaker of the Aden State Legislative Council, was assassinated tonight by two gunmen outside a tennis club here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The airlines slashed a number of international cargo rates today, some of them by as much as 65 per cent.

The Elgin National Watch Company announced yesterday the formation of a five-man committee to select a new president to replace P.J. Casella, whose resignation was announced on Tuesday and becomes effective Oct. 1.
The Rev. Leo P. McLaughlin, president of St. Peter's College, Jersey City, has been appointed president of Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Declaring that city dwellers hunger for refreshment in nature, President Johnson signed today a bill authorizing the creation of a 72,000-acre national recreation area on the upper Delaware River.
THE Army-Navy surplus store between Seventh and Eighth Avenues on 42d Street was doing a big fashion business yesterday.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Federal prison officials here are prepared for 5,000 or more visitors for the fourth annual exhibition and state of art by inmates Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -President Johnson voiced both relief and apprehension today in greeting the agreement reached yesterday to end the Dominican civil war.

JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley scored 41, 45-86 today to win the third annual Women's Cross-County Golf Association senior championship and the trophy named for her late husband, Reinert M. Torgerson.
HONG KONG, Sept. 1 -- Lee Kuan Yew, Prime Minister of Singapore, this week joined the array of Southeast Asian leaders, once good friends of the United States, who now are bitter critics.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 1 -- The National Student Association said today that the student sit-ins last December at the University of California at Berkeley were "legitimate and responsible."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A Senate subcommittee, nearing the end of hearings on Government wiretap activities, has turned up evidence of large-scale wiretapping by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But it has no plans to investigate the F.B.I.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Two Massachusetts men -- one a State Representative -- chose not to contest charges against them today and gained their freedom by paying fines.

CAMBRIDGE., Md., Sept. 1 -- Charges were heard here Monday and yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board alleging discrimination in hiring at Cambridge port both by Local 1911 of the International Longshoremen's Association and by the management of the port, The Cargo Handlers, Inc.
District Attorney Frank O'Connor of Queens said yesterday that he was assigning a three-man team to determine if there had been any criminal culpability in the management of the World's Fair.

ATHENS, Sept. 1 -- King Constantine gathered 10 former Premiers and a party leader at his palace tonight and appealed to them "to rise to the height of the occasion and give the country, as quickly as possible, the government it is waiting for."
The nation's electric power production rose 8.7 per cent in the week ended Aug. 28, from the level in the 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
A concrete contractor agreed to hire 40 Negroes yesterday after being picketed for five hours by unemployed workmen demanding equal job opportunities in the building trades.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A Federal conference to seek ways to correct the pollution of the Hudson River was called today by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, John W. Gardner.

Shortly before the Republican Coordinating Committee met in Washington this week, Representative Melvin Laird of Wisconsin expressed dissatisfaction with its performance. He said the blue-ribbon group of party leaders was "always bogged doom in arguing over sentences and paragraphs in some paper," rather than shaping strategy for the 1966 election battle against the Democrats.
Macy's Theater Club will give its members, who pay a fee of $5 for the privilege of buying tickets in preferred locations at box-office prices or less, a surprise bonus each month.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- The United States and Japan, in their annual review of joint security problems, expressed substantial agreement today that the war in Vietnam was "turning for the better."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- President Johnson's request for Congressional action on a bill to create 44 new Federal judgeships ran into a slowdown in the House Judiciary Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The English language is suffering from a word shortage. This is because society changes so rapidly nowadays that word makers cannot produce new words fast enough to keep up with all the new things that are happening.
Harry E. Nickelson, executive vice president of the A.C. Nielsen Company, has been elected a director of the company.

Gusty winds whipped across the metropolitan area yesterday, damaging scores of boats in Long Island Sound, knocking out electric power lines in several communities and driving swimmers from the water at several beaches.
Los Angeles hopes that New York City's water restrictions will help it lure some water-using industries to the West Coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A United States guide expelled from the Soviet Union this week on charges he was a Nazi spy against the Russians during World War II said today that the accusations were "totally false."
ATLANTA, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has decided to make Chicago a major target of a "nonviolent" school integration campaign, it was disclosed today.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 1 -- Two candidates for county offices in Westchester charged tonight that $60,000 worth of topsoil had been secretly removed from Westchester park property in Yonkers and that when county officials discovered it they secretly settled for only $1,613.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Premier of North Vietnam, Pham Van Dong, has derided United States peace offers and warned anew that the Communists were prepared to fight a 20-year war in Vietnam.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kennedy, the 76-year-old patriarch of the Kennedy family, was treated in New England Baptist Hospital today for a skin rash. He was reported resting comfortably.
LOS ANGLES, Sept. 1 -- Playing perhaps their sloppiest game of the year, the New York Yankees battled into extra innings with the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- The French Government announced today the appointment of Herve Alphand, the Ambassador to Washington, to the position of Secretary General of the Foreign Ministry. This is the second most influential post after that of Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Another Love, the only stakes winner among eight 2-year-old fillies, scored a front-running victory in the $17,700 Mermaid Stakes today at the Atlantic City track. She finished four lengths in front of Morsey Stable's Ill Wind.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Robert Moses told the Board of Education here today that it had made erroneous assumptions in a resolution opposing the bridge he wants to build across Long Island Sound from Rye.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Bill Bryan and Wayne Causey hit home runs tonight to lift the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to increase taxes of persons covered by the Railroad Retirement Act to the same level as those under Social Security.
RAHWAY, N. J., Sept. 1 -- Three youths were killed and eight injured, one critically, tonight when a Public Service bus and two cars collided on Route 1.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 1 -- President-designate Garcia-Godoy said today that his provisional Government would ask the Organization of American States to redefine the role of the Inter-American Peace Force and stress Dominican sovereignty.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Bill Virdon raced home as Maury Wills fumbled Manny Mota's grounder in the eighth inning tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and a sweep of their double-header.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, rushed appeals to Indian and Pakistani leaders today for immediate measures to end the "immi nent" threat of war in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Consumer installment credit outstanding rose by $666 million in July, up substantially from the June increase but well below the record advance made in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Sixty-five civil rights demonstrators marched tonight for the third successive night outside the North Side apartment of the school superintendent, Dr. Benjamin Willis. Nine persons were hurt and 13 arrested during a demonstration there last night.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 1 -- The jury of Sao Paulo's eighth Biennial today named Victor Vassarely of France and Alberto Burri of Italy co-winners of its international gold medal for painting.

MIAMI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The second hurricane of the season, suddenly a mighty tempest, whipped its peak winds up to 100 miles an hour late tonight and bore down on the Bahamas Islands.

British Government bonds scored impressive gains yesterday in an otherwise lackluster day on the London Stock Exchange.

A woman bird watcher, three boys at play and a patrolman on a motor scooter joined forces in Central Park yesterday afternoon to catch a man accused of stealing a purse and a $200 wig from a parked automobile.

In a surprise move, J. Myer Schine signed an agreement yesterday to sell his real estate, hotel, theater and broadcasting holdings, valued at more than $150 million, to Realty Equities Corporation, a publicly held investment concern.

BARROW, Alaska -- This northernmost town of America is a curious place to visit but it has visitors galore.

The Actors Studio Theater will take a sabbatical for the 1965-66 season, it was reported yesterday by a spokesman for the beleaguered organization. However, Cheryl Crawford, executive producer, said:

The Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, in an unusual municipal bond-market maneuver, immediately terminated its 37-member underwriting syndicate yesterday after having been awarded $25 million of North Carolina public-school facilities bonds.

FAIRHOPE, Ala., Sept. 1 (AP) -- A New Yorker came back strong in the eighth and final race and won her second North American women's sailing championship today.
The election of W. Robert Harris as a corporate vice president of the F.W. Woolworth Company was announced yesterday by Robert C. Kirkwood, chairman.

A high official of the New York City Housing Authority was accused yesterday of having taken about $400,000 in bribes in eight years in a conspiracy to rig bids on painting contracts.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The pound has been looking slightly better recently in the foreign-exchange market.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz outlined a program of orderly progress for Mexico today in the first formal report of his administration.

BONN, Sept. 1 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said today that it would be "a long time" before he again associated himself with the proposed multi-nation nuclear force or any similar United States project for a cooperative nuclear force under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept 1 (UPI) -- A Pacific hurricane posed a threat to the Sealab 2 project, but aquanauts went ahead with installation of the first underwater weather station to gauge conditions man must endure in exploring the world's oceans.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Frank Wiegand and Egen Henninger set world swimming records today, the East German press agency, A.D.N., reported.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -President Johnson was peering over the steel negotiators' shoulders today, just to remind them of the importance of their deliberations. Mr. Johnson also made a hopeful statement about the new Provisional Government in the Dominican Republic and presumably he had his eye on Kashmir, Singapore and Indonesia.

Bobby Fischer, the chess champion of the United States, is a strange, moody and temperamental young man. He also may be a genius, and is certainly the only American player who might be able to wrest chess supremacy from the Russians. In his short (100 pages) biography, Frank Brady makes an honest attempt to come to grips with his complex subject.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 -- The Caterpillar Tractor Company plans to build a factory in Southern Belgium at a reported cost of $80 million to $86 million.

Preliminary results of the final poll taken for City Council President Paul R. Screvane before the Sept. 14 Democratic mayoral primary were reported yesterday to show him holding about half the Democratic vote.

YOU love a parade? Then you probably also love ice shows. Everyone in this town does, or so it seems. No matter which of these extravaganzas makes its way into Madison Square Garden, the crowds pour in.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- President Johnson today nominated Prof. Marvin E. Frankel of the Columbia University Law School to fill a long-standing vacancy on the Federal District Court.

All three sectors of the bond market acted yesterday as through it was the day before the long Labor Day holiday weekend. Business ground almost to a standstill and there were few significant price changes.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 2 -- Some Western Senators are preparing to challenge a requirement that at least 50 per cent of the wheat sales to the Soviet bloc must be carried by American ships on the ground that the provision violates treaty obligations with more than 30 countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Bob Chance, at bat for the first time since he returned from the minors, delivered a two-run pinch single in the seventh inning that gave the Washington Senators a 5-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a foreign aid money bill that was cut only $75 million below the authorized total -- the smallest cut in the program's 18-year history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Intercity truck tonnage registered a gain for the week ended Aug. 28 over the corresponding week of 1964, but freight carloadings declined 0.7 per cent for the same period.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson visited former President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman at the Truman Library today and then left for Abilene, Kan., to visit the Eisenhower Library.
The New York City Housing Authority is reorganizing itself as a result of the investigation into alleged rigging of painting contracts.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito doubled home the tie-breaking run in the seventh inning and Fred Whitfield followed with a two-run single, as the Cleveland Indians beat the Kansas City Athletics, 10-6, today.

FOR nearly 50 years Dr. Abel Wolman has been supplying advice to corporations, cities, counties, states, nations and groups of nations that awakened one morning to find that they were just about out of water or that what they had was too dirty to drink.

The Smithwick brothers combination of Pat the rider and Mike the trainer collaborated on the victory in the 47th running of the Harbor Hill Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday. The most important part of the collaboration, of course, was the horse, Mrs. Ogden Phipps's Mako.
Robert W. Sarnoff will become president of the Radio Corporation of America under an executive realignment to be submitted today to the board of directors of the huge electronics concern.
SAIGON, Sept. 2 -- The American diplomats and soldiers seem to be working very well together in Vietnam under unusual circumstances.
John V. Lindsay appealed to the Federal Government yesterday to prevent the planned cutback in the size of the Neighborhood Youth Corps program in New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Juan Marichal was greeted with substantial booing today as he pitched -- and lost -- his first game since being suspended 10 days ago and the San Francisco Giants split a wild double-header with the Philadelphia Phillies.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Robert Doyle of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., established himself as the best teen-age racing helmsman in the land for the second year in a row today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
TWO specialists in the lady-like school of dressing have presented their custom collections for the fall.
Are banging and clatter that accompanied the carpenters' onslaught at De Pinna last spring forecast the expansion of the Women's Gift Showcase.

' Days of Shame," by SenatorI iCharles E. Potter, is a behind-I :the-scenes account of the Army-l [cCarthy hearings of 1954.: The author was a RepublicanI member of the seven-man corn-! mittee that investigated the l Army's charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Roy M. Cohn.

Mayor Wagner announced late yesterday that the city "would move as rapidly as possible to put into effect" a house-to-house hunt for water leaks and a program for measuring water used by the city itself and major charitable and apartment properties.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has been hospitalized for more than a month, The Baltimore Sun said tonight.
The five mutual funds sponsored and managed by Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis continue to set records as the world's largest investment company group.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 1 -- Having suffered from a year-long rebellion, the Congo is now suffering from what is likely to be a year-long election.

New car sales in the current model changeover period, are apparently stabilized and showing no sharp up-or-down pattern. This was disclosed by preliminary sales figures issued yesterday by major auto producers.

MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Behind the New York City faucet is an empire six times as large as the city itself, a realm that ranges from scenic grandeur to underground settings fit for horror movies.

One of the most bizarre and highly publicized gem thefts in history was carried out the night of Oct. 29, 1964, when a team of acrobatic thieves broke into the American Museum of Natural History and stole 24 gems valued at $410,000.
Negotiations were resumed yesterday between The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 346 Broadway.

BONN, Sept. 2 -- Former Grand Adm. Karl Doenitz, who succeeded Hitler as Chancellor of Nazi Germany in the closing days of World War II, may have to stand trial because of his role in the conviction and execution of a German naval officer.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2 -- A pink marquee decorated to resemble a marble-columned ballroom was the setting this evening for the Junior League of Greenwich Debutante Ball. The event took place in the garden of Mr. and Mrs. Eward Livingston Hicks 3d whose daughter, Miss Elizabeth Stuyvesant Hicks, was one of the 15 young women from this area presented.
Congratulations and thanks for your excellent Aug. 28 editorial "Wrong on Every Count."
The largest work force of longshoremen employed in the port in the last six months tackled backlog cargo yesterday as the long-immobilized freighters began moving to sea.

The executive director of the Illinois Pavilion at the World's Fair acknowledged yesterday that the Fair Corporation had paid a quarter of a million dollars to Walt Disney to help the state mount the Lincoln exhibit in its pavilion.
The five-member Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority -- the prospective purchaser of the Long Island Rail Road -- took a seven-hour ride yesterday on its future property.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Barnes Wallis, a British aircraft designer, proposed today that Britain should build small supersonic aircraft capable of operating from short runways and huge submarine merchantmen capable of operating beneath the polar ice.

HANAU, Germany, Sept. 2 -- The Singer Company, the maker of sewing machines, is going into the mail order business in Europe -- but not, as rumored, through the acquisition of a West German mail order company.
Evidence has been found that a few thousand years ago the earth briefly had a small moon of almost pure iron that disintegrated and fell as an awesome succession of fireball showers.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- On Saturday, the Rutgers football team will end the first week of training with a scrimmage. By the final whistle Coach John Bateman hopes to have a quarterback.
Copper futures achieved new life-of-contract highs yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Ernie Banks hit the 400th homer of his career today as the Chicago Cubs beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-3, in the season's last meeting between the teams.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 2 -- The leading mining town of Broken Hill, which since Zambia attained independence last October has had the first all-African council, is to have a street named to commemorate the country's freedom fighters.
The New York State Labor Relations Board, in an unusual decision made public yesterday, has struck a blow against the so-called "sweetheart" contracts between employers and unions.
A man distributing handbills for the Socialist Labor party was acquitted of a littering charge yesterday in Criminal Court.
Efforts to hold a referendum on proportional representation this year have been abandoned.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2 AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that Sheriff James G. Clark of Dallas County had violated his orders last January by leading racial demonstrators on a forced four-mile march. He fined Sheriff Clark $1,500.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The chairman of a House subcommittee angrily denounced the Justice Department today for not acting against a mail order advertisement that brought thousands of complaints charging obscenity.
While their negotiators met with officials of the Board of Education, members of the United Federation of Teachers started a campaign yesterday to rally public support for their contract demands.
The last of the old steamboat piers on the Upper West Side, at 129th Street, is being torn down as a hazard to shipping.

UKARUMPA, New Guinea, Aug. 30 -- For the Summer Institute of Linguistics, Australian New Guinea, with an estimated total of 700 unwritten languages, is the biggest challenge this worldwide language study organization has yet faced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- A modest increase in the enrollment at the 84 four-year schools of medicine in the country was proposed today by an educator to help meet growing health education requirements.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that sales and earnings in the three-month and nine-month periods ended July 31 were the highest in history.
MIAMI, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The second hurricane of the season whipped into an intense and dangerous storm today that is likely to worry residents of the Eastern seaboard for another week.

It is startling to learn that inspectors of the Federal Wage-Hour Division have turned up more than $5 million dollars in illegally low wage payments to workers in the metropolitan area in the last year. The New York-New Jersey region ranks among the highest in the nation in labor standards and in percentage of union organization; yet victimization of Negroes, Puerto Ricans and other underpaid workers apparently remains widespread.
Devernon LeGrande, self-appointed pastor of a "church" in Brooklyn, was held in $75,000 bail yesterday by Criminal Court Judge John J. Ryan on charges of kidnapping and felonious assault.
Following is the text of the preliminary findings of a panel of four water supply experts submitted yesterday to Mayor Wagner:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A bill that would lead to strict enforcement of uniform health and safety standards for all mines was passed today by the House.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday against "the use of anonymous recorded telephone messages for abusive and extremist attacks and libels on individuals and institutions."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A spurt of activity by the White House today brought the District of Columbia home rule rule bill to the door of the House of Representatives but failed to force it across the threshold.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Jim Lefebvre drove in four runs with three hits tonight to pace the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- Communist China declared today that its support of revolutionary wars in underdeveloped countries was a strategy directed at the eventual encirclement of the United States and Western Europe.
HOUSTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., and Lieut. Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr., came home today from their 3.3-million mile trip in space and were met by their wives and children.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, one of the five roads that the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio railways propose to acquire in their sweeping merger plans, objected yesterday to the exchange terms the two big systems would offer Erie-Lackawanna security holders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The House passed today the Administration's bill for high-speed rail transit research by a vote of 317 to 24.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A unanimous Congressional committee laid down today a series of recommended guidelines for world monetary reform.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Bonds possibly worth more than $2 million stolen from a bank here last spring have been recovered by the police as the result of a telephone tip.
Business is building up in New York City Mayor Wagner declared yesterday. He said that the business community here retained its confidence in the city as a competitive market place.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The cause of the over-age worker was considerably advanced in Congress today by some pretty airline stewardesses who face dismissal because they are nearing 32.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 104.6 on Wednesday from 104.7 on Tuesday.
The American Steel and Pump Corporation said yesterday that it was "temporarily withdrawing" its offer to buy 400,000 shares of the Standard Products Company at $15 a share.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Connecticut Circuit Court's Appellate Division ruled unanimously today that Keyhole, a tabloid published in California, was not obscene.
The case of the Singapore bribe attempt raises serious questions about the Central Intelligence Agency and its role in American foreign policy.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The Treasury reported today a decline of 24 million ($67.2 million) in Britain's reserves of gold and convertible currency during August. They now stand at 923 million ($2,584,400,000).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The White House said today that the number of United States servicemen volunteering for duty in Vietnam "has increased dramatically" since April and now averages more than 100 a day.

TRENTON, Sept. 2 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes today proposed an eight-state Northeastern regional transportation committee to work with the Federal Government on developing a high-speed rail line between Washington and Boston.

The apple growers of the Hudson Valley, who were desperate because of a shortage of harvest hands, received special permission yesterday to import 250 workers from the British West Indies to help gather their crop.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 2 -- A nine-month paralysis in Colombia's Government has ended.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Don Wert drove in four runs tonight with a single and home run while Joe Sparma and Orlando Pena overcame four Detroit errors and pitched the Tigers to a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- United States exports rose in July while imports fell, the Commerce Department reported today.

The nation's largest movie-theater trade organizations, the Theater Owners of America and the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors, agreed to merge yesterday at an executive meeting at the Americana Hotel.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- Two United States cultural exchange projects are being subjected to what United States officials today called "intensified harassment" from Soviet authorities.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves toppled Cincinnati out of first place tonight, beating the Reds, 4-3, in 11 innings.

Five leading New York banks disclosed yesterday that they would join the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in tapping the short-term money market through the use of unsecured, non-negotiable promissory notes.
John J. Pflieger arrived safely in Bermuda yesterday aboard his 26-foot sailing vessel, the Stella Maris.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 2 -- The National Student Association urged the Administration today to cease "immediately" all bombing and other offensive military action in Vietnam.

The ban on discrimination in employment on the basis of sex has not been treated by The Times in the seriousness it merits. The Times's stories ranged from the comic -- "The Bunny Problem" in the Aug. 20 news article -- to the tragic in its Aug. 21 editorial.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Three gunmen stole into the 25-room summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phipps Sr. early today, gave the 84-year-old Mr. Phipps an "awful" beating and fled with $40,000 in jewelry and $700 in cash.
QUINHON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 (Delayed by censor clearance) (UPI) -- The Quinhon Officers Club had never seen anything like it. Every bar stool was occupied by a woman.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The Celanese Corporation of America announced today it had offered to purchase British Paints Holdings, Ltd., for 17 million ($47.6 million).

TOKYO, Sept. 2 -- The Japan Art Festival, to be held in New York from next March 21 to April 23, will be designed and arranged by Kenzo Tange, Japan's best-known architect, organizers of the festival have announced here.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Sept. 2 -- Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. sent 650 National Guard troops armed with rifles and bayonets to Natchez today to smother a threat of racial violence. Negro leaders immediately dropped plans for a street demonstration and, with difficulty, persuaded 500 angry Negroes not to hold a protest march.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 -- The difference a couple of old pros can make was illustrated afresh today as Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford revived the New York Yankees with an easy 8-1 victory over the newly rechristened California Angels. Only 5,198 persons were on hand.

Business loans declined last week for the first time in five weeks at New York City banks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline amounted to $49 million, and compared with an increase of $154 million in the week a year ago.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The New York City Ballet revealed itself to London tonight at Covent Garden in the unfamiliar role of a guardian of tradition. The tradition was that of the Diaghilev Ballet, and the combination of "Prodigal Son" and "Apollo," two of the Diaghilev company's last ballets, gave a surprising insight into ballet history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Senate passed a $4.7 billion higher education bill today providing Federal scholarships for needy students and various other programs to improve and expand college education. The vote was 79 to 3.
HAWORTH, N.J., Sept 2 -- Bonnie Brown of Metropolis won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifth annual Maureen Orcutt junior championship today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk called in the Ambassadors of India and Pakistan late last night and told them that the United States was deeply concerned about the mounting war in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Sept. 3 -- President Johnson, apparently driving for a basic steel contract agreement before Labor Day, told industry and union negotiators yesterday that he saw no reason that they could not compose their differences "right away."

The 100-carat DeLong star ruby, stolen from the American Museum of Natural History last October, was recovered near Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday after months of secret negotiations, a fast exchange of a $25,000 ransom and a search of a parkway telephone booth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The job picture improved in August for Negroes, teen-agers, blue-collar workers and those who had been unemployed for a long time.

James W. Austin, president of Northeast Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that he has exercised an option to buy 50,000 shares of Northeast stock. He said of the 50,000 shares, an option of 35,000 shares was given to him under the company's 1964 employe stock option plan at $4.12 1/2 cents a share.
The stock market turned in its strongest performance in two months yesterday, with almost all major groups participating in a broad advance.
A $6 million account dropped on Madison Avenue yesterday and was picked up by two agencies -- McCann-Erickson, Inc., and Compton Advertising, Inc.
Sparked by the electronics group, the American Stock Exchange made its best showing of the week in active trading yesterday.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Gov. Robert E. McNair asked the Federal Government today to get its Domestic Peace Corps workers out of South Carolina.

Kashmir has suddenly and frighteningly become the most explosive spot in the world. India and Pakistan, for all practical purposes, are at war; the whole South Asian complex of nations will be affected; the icy blast of the cold war is blowing on India's northeastern flank from Communist China. Add the possibility of communal strife between Moslems and Hindus in both countries and the extent of the peril becomes only too clear.
Commissioner of Parks Newbold Morris rejected yesterday as "silly" a proposal that areas of lower Manhattan parks be segregated for women and children.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a farm bill drastically different from the version passed by the House. The Senate bill contains provisions vigorously opposed by the Administration.
