A dispute over an alleged raid on a railway carmen's union by Harold J. Pryor, an official of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, has been settled, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States said today that it planned to recognize the provisional government of Dr. Garcia-Godoy when it is installed tomorrow.

CASTINE, Me., Sept. 2 -- The American merchant marine is having trouble holding young officers in lifelong careers at sea. Forty per cent of all merchant marine graduates quit the sea after two years of service, a symposium here was told.

ONE of the best things about the Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park is that it offers a kind of survey of the varieties of stage dancing available to New Yorkers during the winter season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales increased 3 per cent to $5.37 billion in the week ended Aug. 28 and were 8 per cent above the corresponding 1964 week.

RICHMOND, Sept. 2 -- The General Electric Company announced here today plans to begin production in February of a million small-screen portable television sets, an amount to exceed the expected imports from Japan.

Casey Stengel made his farewell to the troops at Shea Stadium yesterday morning. Like most affairs involving baseball's 75-year-old elder statesman, the ceremonies were long on picture-taking, short on sentimentality, complicated, bizarre and amusing.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2 -- Nineteen Latin-American nations have discovered how hard it is to set an example to the rest of the world in matters of nuclear disarmament.

Work is to begin at once on the first phase of a four-part expansion program that will sharply increase supplies of electric power in several parts of Appalachia. The entire project will cost close to $370 million.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Sept. 2 -- A five-member court of the powerful Mapai party decided today, in a ruling laced with Biblical quotations, that David Ben-Gurion and his colleagues were no longer members.
The Hercules Powder Company said yesterday it had cut prices on three grades of its Pamak oil products, effective as of Aug. 30.

TOKYO, Sept. 2 -- Busy with the endless building and rebuilding that changes the face of Tokyo from year to year, the 15 million daytime inhabitants of Japan's capital came today to the 20th anniversary of their country's surrender aboard the battleship U.S.S. Missouri without apparent notice of this significant date in their national history.
ATHENS, Friday, Sept. 3 -- The Crown Council convoked by King Constantine to suggest a way out of the seven-week-old Government crisis broke up early today in complete deadlock.

MATTITUCK, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Bob Seidelman of Cherry Hill, N.J., who sails under the burgee of the Cooper River Yacht Club, won his second straight Comet Class national sailing championship, defeating a clubmate, John MacCausland, in the final standings of the five-race series.

How did a $75 million deal to buy the coast-to-coast holdings of J. Myer Schine do a complete reversal in the space of six weeks? The aloof, 73-year-old man who built a sizable fortune in real estate, theaters and broadcasting properties over a period of nearly half a century, contracted to sell out practically all his holdings in a single package this week.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's Knickerbocker Championships will begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel. The schedule is as follows: today, Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs, 2:30 P.M.; Mixed Pairs, 8:30 P.M.; Saturday, Open Pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; Sunday, Master Pairs (in three flights) 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; Monday, Open Teams, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; Novice Pairs, 7 P.M.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Bo Wininger, a part-time player on the professional golf circuit, recovered from a miserable beginning and shot a three-under-par 69 today for the first-round lead in the $65,000 Oklahoma City open.
The letter of John I. Shields, asking for a ban on motorcycles in New York City, contains reasoning both illogical and highly imaginative.
The subway advertising industry will use print media in an attempt to sell prospective advertisers on the advantages of advertising in the New York subway system.
Trustees of the New Haven Railroad succeeded in July in cutting the bankrupt carrier's net loss by $337,171 but the line still ended the month with a large deficit.

YONKERS, Sept. 2 -- Speedy Rodney, a standardbred so lazy when he was a 2-year-old that he was turned out and did no racing that season, has developed into the "hottest" trotter in the country. This 4-year-old son of the late Rodney moved to the top of the free-for-all division tonight at Yonkers Raceway when he sped to a track record of 2:32 2/5 in winning the $50,000 Gotham Trot at 1 1/4 miles.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The death of the Speaker of the House of Commons today raised new political hazards for the already strained Labor Government. Its majority could be cut to a single seat.
A penalty of two days' loss of pay was recommended yesterday for Staten Island ferry officers who were on strike from May 4 to June 9 this year, and who were rehired by the city.

The American Medical Association's decision to mount a national drive against venereal diseases is a necessary response to a fast-worsening situation. Public Health Service statistics show that newly reported cases of both syphilis and gonorrhea have been rising for almost a decade. The magnitude of the problem is suggested by the estimate that over a million Americans are infected with venereal disease each year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- President Johnson today approved $29 million in Federal projects for Los Angeles.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Cornelius Shields Jr. on Larchmont, N.Y., captured the Mallory Cup sailing championship on Lake Pontchartrain today.
The British pound continued to show strength yesterday in a moderate volume of transactions on foreign exchange markets here.

THE tyranny of the calendar, which once decreed that no woman outside the Deep South should step forth on the day after Labor Day in a summer dress, is loosening its hold on fashion. Wardrobes are becoming increasingly versatile as women follow the lead of men, who have enthusi astically adopted the suit for all seasons.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 2 -- The Organization of American States team here voiced confidence today that the nations of the Western Hemisphere and many other countries would recognize the Dominican provisional government soon after its installation tomorrow.
THAT bombed-out and abandoned promontory that ought to be the assured place of Ford Madox Ford in the landscape of letters looks as if it might now be reclaimed.

City Council President Paul R. Screvane yesterday challenged Controller Abraham D Beame, his chief rival for the Democratic mayoral nomination to debate him on television and a Beame spokesman replied, "We'd love to."

BERLLN, Sept. 2 -- The East German-West German negotiations on wall-crossing passes for West Berliners reached an impasse today and Western officials expect the talks to be shelved until after the West German elections Sept. 19.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Willard Deason as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ATLANTA, Sept. 2 -- Gov. Carl E. Sanders of Georgia has told close friends that, after months of pondering, he has decided to run next year for the United States Senate seat held by Richard B. Russell. A source close enough to the 40-year-old Governor to speak for him said:
After saying good-by to Casey Stengel, the man who created them, the New York Mets showed yesterday that their style remains unaltered by losing to the Houston Astros, 4-3, at Shea Stadium.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 2 -- In a long-awaited challenge to organized labor in Kenya, President Jomo Kenyatta has disbanded both the country's trade-union federations.
Alcoa Residences, Inc., a subsidiary of Alcoa Properties, has named Charles J. Urstadt a vice president.

Dennis Ralston, Fred Stolie of Australia, Maria Bueno of Brazil, Rafael Osuna of Mexico, Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy and Frank Froehling 3d are among the players who will appear on today's opening program of the United States amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Floyd Robinson, who started the game-winning rally in the ninth inning of the opener, hit a homer and drove in three runs in the second game tonight as he sparked the Chicago White Sox to 5-3 and 9-3 victories over the Baltimore Orioles.

WHEN the idea was first proposed by Art Modell of the Cleveland Browns, other owners in the National Football League were apprehensive. It isn't clear just why they reacted that way. Perhaps they weren't quite sure of the man because he was a relatively new member of their lodge and the standpat old-timers weren't quite certain how to assess one so dynamic, imaginative and daring.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 2 -- While whirling Plexi-glass drums continued to yield the names of more ticket-holders, the names of 11 horses were dropped into the entry box here today for the $281,720 New Hampshire Sweepstakes Classic.
Borislav Ivkov, Yugoslav grand master, defeated Alberic O'Kelly of Belgium, last night to take the lead in the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament in Havana.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A broad, four-month survey of the esthetic recreational and commercial assets of the Hudson River Valley will be undertaken by the Federal Government.
PLYMOUTH, N.C., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Civil rights leaders called off a march to the courthouse today, but scheduled one for tomorrow morning.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- Isaac Heymann came home early yesterday afternoon from the department store where he works as a manager, accompanied by three men.
BUFFALO, Sept. 2 -- The New York Jets had a dismal rehearsal for the forthcoming season tonight as they lost their fifth and final exhibition game to the Buffalo Bills, 31-10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A bill to abolish the stealing of pets was rousingly defended and hotly denounced today at a crowded Congressional hearing.
Joseph E. Seagram and Sons, Inc., the large distiller, announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph W. Christian as vice chairman of its Plan for Progress Committee.

TORONTO, Sept. 2 -- Note-holders of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., a finance company that went into receivership on June 17, received today the details of two rival offers to purchase assets of the insolvent company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 -- A force of several South Vietnamese Army battalions killed 22 Vietcong guerrillas today in an engagement in Quangngai Province, 320 miles northeast of Saigon, an American military spokesman announced.
In your Aug. 30 editorial "Dead End in Greece" you say that "Ex-Premier Papandreou started a fire when King Constantine as good as dismissed him. . . ."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- United States officials are placing a restrained interpretation on the angry revival by Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of an old case of bribery involving the Central Intelligence Agency.

Nonprofit residential professional theater in the United States is at a "testing" point that will determine whether it can survive without subsidy, a Ford Foundation official who has helped the movement grow, said yesterday.

The Dic Concrete Corporation will absorb 40 workers designated by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People without discharging any men already on the payroll, a company official informed the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 -- Jet planes battled over Kashmir today, taking India and Pakistan another step toward full-scale war.

Area A -- Bluefish, averaging from 2 to 4 pounds, were running yesterday in quantity from the Klondike to Shrewsbury Rocks and were responding to trolling as well as chumming. Sea bass were being taken closer to shore.
Government bonds continued their strong advance on the London Stock Exchange yesterday while share prices closed firm.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 2 -- The Pakistani Government declared tonight that troops of Pakistan's well-trained and well-equipped 'army, acting in, support of irregulars of the Azad (Free) Kashmir movement, were still pressing forward across the 17-year-old "cease-fire" line in the Chamb sector.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The United States will be fighting a rear-guard action to prevent the seating of Communist China by the 20th General Assembly.

Champion Papers, Inc., has announced the appointment of George W. Scrimshaw as president of Champion Paper Corporation, S.A., and tim Champion Paper Export Corporation, foreign marketing organizations.
NEW CANAAN, Conn. -- For the last seven years, Derry Noyes has had her own private place in the world -- just below the lowest cloud, just above the level of most adult restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Republican party rewrote its civil rights platform today with a pledge to combat discrimination wherever it appears and a warning that mob action can undermine the drive for equal rights.

Longchamps, Inc., the restaurant chain, has taken one of the prime commercial locations in the 29-story office buildings being erected as part of the new Madison Square Garden Center above Pennsylvania Station.

The national grass court tennis championships got off to the best start in years at Forest Hills yesterday. There was a record advance sale of $82,000, a substantial opening-day turnout of 7,500 in idyllic weather and entertaining competition on the stadium, grandstand and field courts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- State Department officials said today that Jack Paar has asked for and been granted a passport validated for travel to Communist China.
YONKERS, Sept. 3 -- Two men accused of participating in a barroom fight here in which William Friedman, a New York stockbroker, was killed surrendered to the police today.

Customs personnel at Kennedy International Airport and at passenger ship piers were bracing themselves yesterday for a heavy influx of international travelers over the Labor Day weekend and the two days after the holiday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The 31st Stamford Yacht Club Vineyard Race, which started off the Cow's early tonight, had more starters than any of its predecessors.

BONN, Sept. 3 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler has run into less than complete support for his monetary course in West Germany and Italy, not to men tion France. All of them have agreed to Mr. Fowler's stated objective -- further top-level discussions about international monetary reform.

James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, stated yesterday that his office would continue to follow a liberal and flexible policy in the regulation of the nation's nearly 8,000 Federally-chartered commercial banks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board, by a vote of 5-2, approved the merger today of the Wayne State Bank of Wayne, N.J., into the New Jersey Bank and Trust Company of Clifton.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- "Well, I guess art requires sacrifices," a young Russian girl said with a sigh as she joined a block-long queue snaking around the Push-kin Museum.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Last Dec. 30, Capt. W.M. Wade was called a hero for landing a Convair 340 safely with 41 passengers aboard after both engines failed.
BONN, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Twenty years after the end of World War II, the average West German is beginning to earn as much as some Americans, official statistics showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 3 -A Connecticut company received a patent this week for an instrument that can tell a rocket flash from a sunset. This distinction is im portant in automatic tracking of missiles, which may be outlined against a bright sky or a confu sing cloud pattern.
TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- Japan is studying ways to reverse a damaging outflow of funds and, at the same time stimulate depressed business.

PINK curlers bob up in department stores, brown ones are seen bent over the frozen food bins in the supermarket. Secretaries who have overslept tuck their curlers under scarves and dash for the subway, while teen-agers, walking with the dates they hope to impress later, wear theirs unabashedly on the street.
NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- A special committee of the City Council today criticized the administration and organization of Newark's antipoverty program by an independent agency.
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens called yesterday for more police cars instead of policemen to combat crime in the city.
THIS is a fable about a man who wanted to get very rich, very quickly, and was willing to let the whole country contribute democratically to his aggrandizement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Senate Public Roads subcommittee approved unanimously today a sharply revised version of President Johnson's highway beautification bill.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 -- Britain's Walker Cup team of amateur golfers gained a surprising 8-to-3 lead over the United States as the biennial series opened today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -Leaning over a White House privet hedge, a jubilant President Johnson observed this evening that the person who was "really happy" over the steel contract settlement was "Lady Bird."
TORONTO, Sept. 3 -- The biggest wheat crop in Canadian history was forecast today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Many other crop records were also predicted.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The Soviet Union has begun massive sales of gold in Europe to finance huge imports of grain for the second time in three years, according to Swiss financial sources in Zurich.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- John Wyatt, a relief pitcher, stopped an eighth-inning rally by the California Angels tonight to help the Kansas City Athletics gain a 4-1 victory in the first game of a double-header.
A Brooklyn antipoverty agency yesterday accused a rival agency of sending hecklers to disrupt a meeting that ended in a brick-throwing brawl.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- Jim Hickman, who usually has more success against left-handers than right-handers, was afforded three times at bat against the left-handed Ray Sadecki tonight and wound up establishing a record when he became the first member of the Mets to hit three homers in one game.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The spirit of competition breeds conformity rather than excellence, a group of industrial psychologists declared here today.

YONKERS, Sept. 3 -- Somewhat incongruously, to be sure, Russians will be rooting for Yankees Sunday. The parties of the first part will be members of the Soviet Union harness racing delegation here for the international trotting series at Yonkers Raceway.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Pete Rose of Cincinnati slammed a double and a triple, in a seven-run eighth-inning rally tonight as the Reds defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 16-7. Rose got two other hits in the game.

BUFFALO, Sept. 3 -- The crossroad has now been passed. The management of the New York Jets today made the decision that the team is in the football business, not show business. Mike Taliaferro will be the Jets' starting quarterback when the American Football League season opens on Sept. 12, Coach Weeb Ewbank announced.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 3 -- India asserted today that she had halted the Pakistani attack in Kashmir on the west bank off the Manawarwali River, five miles inside Indian-held territory.
Only two of the four series put out by American Motors Corporation will retain the name Rambler for the 1966 models, Thomas A. Coupe, vice president of automotive sales, said yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 3 -- Official Pakistani sources reported tonight that their air force's F-86 Saber jets had shot down an Indian jet fighter plane and damaged two near the front lines in Jammu and Kashmir State.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Minnesota Vikings overwhelmed the Dallas Cowboys tonight with the passing of Fran Tarkenton and a bristling defensive charge as they ran away with a 57-17 National Football League exhibition victory.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Bo Wininger retained his one-stroke lead in the $65,000 Oklahoma City open today with a 36-hole total of 139.

MANILA, Sept. 3 -- Indonesia protested today the presence in this country of a so-called Papuan freedom fighter, Nicolass Jouwe of West Irian, the former Netherlands New Guinea. Jakarta asked the Philippines Government to deport him.

Mao Tse-tung's nightmare blueprint for the world's future has been expounded in detail in Marshal Lin Piao's lengthy article, presently the center of Peking's propaganda trumpeting. Essentially, it is a claim that Mao is now the undisputed leader of the world revolution, a revolution to be carried out by transplanting on a global scale the guerrilla war tactics that triumphed in China.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Oscar Bakke, Eastern region director for the Federal Aviation Agency, said today that Suffolk County could provide a site for a fourth major commercial jetport needed in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler welcomed in a special statement today the British actions aimed at checking upward movement of wages and prices.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A tornado skipped across the northeastern section of Wichita tonight, damaging dozens of homes and destroying others.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Tony Oliva slapped three singles, driving in four runs, and Don Mincher hit a two-run homer tonight as Minnesota scored a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox. The triumph widened the Twins' American League lead to 7 1/2 games over the White Sox.

The Collins Radio Company announced yesterday a net income of $4,549,662, equal to $2.04 a share, for the fiscal year ended July 30. This is a sharp increase over profits of $2,404,635, or 1.08 a share, in the preceding fiscal year.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 3 -- Although little was known of Luchino Visconti's "Vaghe Stelle dell'Orsa" before its premiere this evening, the betting that it would win the Venice Film Festival's Gold Lion of St. Mark has run high.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 3 -- Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew met with a United States official today for the first time since making his charges of improper Central Intelligence Agency activities in Singapore. Mr. Lee met with James D. Bell, United States Ambassador to Malaysia, in what appeared to be an icy, inconclusive encounter.
Identical triplets, estimated by medical authorities to occur once in a million births, were born yesterday in Queens.

RICHARD CAMP's antique shop on Second Avenue is fresh out of elephants. The shortage results from home decorators' demands for objects once associated with Theodore Roosevelt. In addition to parts of elephants, collectors are after stuffed birds, mounted mooseheads, peacock feathers and antlers.
The British pound was steady yesterday on foreign exchange markets here and transactions were moderate with the approach of the Labor Day weekend.
Bears on Wall Street may spend the weekend licking their wounds after the stock market's surprisingly strong performance yesterday.
NEW LONDON, N.H., Sept. 3 -- Heavy consumption of alcoholic beverages has been linked to the development of cancer of the mouth and throat in a study conducted at three New York hospitals.
ATHENS, Sept. 3 -- The florists of Queen Sophia Boulevard breathed a sigh of relief Sunday morning after Greece's Parliament had voted down Premier Elias Tsirimokos.
Scores of thousands of persons left the city for beaches and resorts yesterday, cheered by the prospect of fine weather for the three-day Labor Day weekend.

THE SPRINGS, L.I., Sept. 3 -- There are husking bees, quilting bees and spelling bees, but rarely has anyone seen the likes of the pie making bee that is going on in a barge house in this bayside village near East Hampton.
A Queens assistant district attorney began a study of the disputed fiscal records of the World's Fair yesterday in an attempt to find "any possibility of a criminal act."
After two years of withholding Federal funds from the Port of New York Authority in a dispute over airports for private aviation, the Federal Aviation Agency has resumed the annual grants.
James R. Hayward, president of the McCord Corporation since April 30, resigned yesterday. He will be succeeded by Coleman F. Hogan, chairman of the automotive parts manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A group of 30 Negroes from Baker County, Ga., said today that they were so afraid of Sheriff L. Warren Johnson they did not want to return to the county without protection.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles tonight capitalized on the wildness of a Cleveland rookie, Steve Hargan, for four first-inning runs and defeated the Indians, 5-3.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 3 -- At Boston College there are more giant-sized football players than in all the other schools in the Boston area combined. So Coach Jim Miller must be doing something right.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Tonight Covent Garden saw one of the only two ballets not by George Balanchine to be given during the present London season.
The Consumers Power Company, Jackson, Mich., announced yesterday the election of E. Newton Cutler Jr. as a director.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- The South Vietnamese Government announced a series of decrees today in a move toward tightening its grip on the country by setting up military zones.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Security Council members held talks all day today with one another and with United Nations officials on a possible emergency weekend Council meeting to try to keep the clash between India and Pakistan in Kashmir from turning into a full-scale war.
The Housing Authority began yesterday an apartment-by-apartment inspection of the 139,049 apartments in its 138 projects to find and repair water leaks.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 3 -- Hector Garcia-Godoy assumed power today as provisional President of the Dominican Republic in a simple, subdued ceremony that was followed by a new burst of violence.

A police alarm went out yesterday for any information about three women who, Brooklyn District Attorney Aaron E. Koota said, are missing from the "Parish harem" of Devernon LeGrande, self-appointed pastor of a "church" in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area. LeGrande, 41 years old, was arrested Wednesday.
In this period of international tensions, changes can come fast over a long weekend. With that in mind, many commodity futures traders tended to even out their positions yesterday.
The Chicopee division of A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., producer of sporting goods and toys, announced yesterday the appointment of George B. Estes as manufacturing vice president.

The Government's short-term borrowing costs edged upward yesterday as the six-month Treasury bill rate rose above 4 per cent.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Sept. 3 -The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. sent a top aide to Natchez today to gauge the possibility of a full-scale civil rights movement here.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 3 -- A performance by an American paratroop acrobatic team and a visit by United States naval units at the annual American Day celebration here has been canceled by the Finnish Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today there was a sound basis for significant cuts in economy class fares on transAtlantic airlines.

Ten thousand Chinese fortune cookies popped this week from the ovens of the Key Key oriental cake company of 56 Elizabeth Street. Each bore a bit of paper with an Occidental appeal: "Vote the Beame Team."

Will Herberg, Graduate Professor of Philosophy and Culture at Drew University, Madison, N.J., warned Roman Catholics yesterday to beware of the pitfalls of "modernization" to satisfy demands that the church be "up to date."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The United States mission expressed confidence today that the outcome of the latest attempt to bring Communist China into the United Nations would be "the same as in the past."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- A sharp difference of opinion has developed between the United States and some of its allies over the political consequences in Asia of the war in Vietnam.

Edwin D. Etherington began reading his mail at 9 A.M. yesterday in his paneled, 10th-floor office at the American Stock Exchange.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- United States District Judge Frank Ellis dissolved today a temporary restraining order issued by a state court Tuesday that blocked Federal voting examiners in Plaquemines Parish (county).

NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- The first citywide school construction and rehabilitation program, to cost about $40 million, was approved last night by the Board of Education.

PEKING, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from an article by the Chinese Communist Defense Minister, Marshal Lin Piao, published in all major Chinese newspapers today and made available in English by Hsinhua, the official press agency:

" The Case for Going to the Moon," by Neil P. Ruzic, presents his arguments for his belief that the United States will reach and explore the moon first. He contends that the benefits gained by getting there before the Soviet Union would not be political or military but economic and scientific.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- A 71-year-old Russian pensioner came into Moscow from his country home a few weeks ago to have a medical examination, a look at his circulatory system. When he left the hospital the doctors told relatives his health was all right for a man his age.

There are varying reports on the success of (or at least the adherence to) the ZIP code system. Seemingly, big business is using it faithfully and increasingly; smaller business is trying pretty hard; householders tend to be lax in the matter.

In reference to your Aug. 22 editorial "Cleaning Up Lake Erie," Lake Erie is more than "an interstate body of water," it is international. Approximately 45 per cent of the shoreline and one-third of the lake's area is in Canada.

STORRS, Conn., Sept. 3 -- An enemy scout on the University of Connecticut campus this week would have taken an oath. Never before had this pastoral setting been shaken by so many 250-pound football players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -The index of primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 102.7 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended Aug. 31, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved down in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The state police rounded up and jailed today hundreds of leftists who were said to be trying to disrupt Brazil's Independence Day celebrations, to be held Tuesday.

ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Sept. 5 -- Jim Hall and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., and their Chevrolet Chaparrals finished 1, 2 in Road America's 500-mile sports car race today. But George Follmer of Pasadena, Calif., in an under-2-liter Lotus Porsche, placed fourth overall and supplanted Hall as the United States road racing champion with a final score of 60 points to 58.

QUINHON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The trap that caught the Vietcong in the rice-paddy area north of here was sprung by two reinforced companies of the Second Battalion of the Marine Corps' Seventh Regiment.

New York's air pollution experts find that there are currently four to five million dust particles in each cubic foot of the city's air. The normal -- almost as incredible -- is two million, and the increase is due to fewer street flushings during the water shortage.

HONOLULU, Sept 5 (AP) -- Rodney Fong, 22 years old, son of Hawaii's millionaire United States Senator, Hiram L. Fong, held a job at the Honolulu Post Office earlier this summer that the city's postmaster says was intended for needy students.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Hank Weddendorf sailed Mock Turtle to victory in a 19-boat final Thistle Class race and won the three-race series in the Tri Club Yacht Racing Association's Labor Day weekend regatta on Northport Bay today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 5 -- Pakistani forces have smashed within a few miles of the key Indian crossroad town of Akhnur in fierce Kashmir fighting, a Pakistani spokesman said tonight.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Tommy Helms's single in the ninth inning drove in Tony Perez today and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 10-9 triumph over the Philadelphia Phils.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 5. -- It has been many years since David played here on his harp, but the instrument is being heard in the land again.
MIAMI, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The second hurricane of the season, motionless for 24 hours, turned suddenly back to the south tonight and threatened the Bahamas and Florida with its 125-mile-an-hour winds.
OSLO, Norway, Sept. 5 -- Norwegians will choose a new Parliament next week, ending what is considered the country's most exciting and uncertain election campaign since World War II.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Thomas R. Young's highly successful 36-foot centerboard sloop Shearwater stowed away one of the juicier plums of distance yacht racing tonight in the annual event of the Stamford Yacht Club.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Aug. 25 -- Once a year, for about an hour, the policemen directing traffic on the Place du Casino, the hub of Monte Carlo, are withdrawn. Uniformed guards of a private company take over.

The president of the United Federation of Teachers said last night that he doubted whether sufficient time remained to head off the teachers' strike threatened for next Monday, the opening day of the new school year.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 5 -- President Johnson, like millions of other Americans, was relaxing over the Labor Day weekend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Job Corps experience has been found to suggest that businessmen run training centers more efficiently than officials of educational institutions and state bodies.

Western Pennsylvania and the cities of Chicago and Birmingham could become "depressed regions" if President Johnson's proposals for waterway-use charges are put into effect, according to a study released by the National Waterways Conference, Inc.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- The United Steelworkers of America ratified today a new contract that assures labor peace in the basic steel industry for nearly 35 months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- With the current fiscal year only two months old, the Treasury's receipts are already soaring far above expectations.

Her hatches battened down, the 8,000-ton freighter Largo Argentino slipped out of Pier 29, at Kent Street, Brooklyn, yesterday and made her way down the harbor. Serenely she moved past Ambrose Light out into the Atlantic, and all seemed promising for an orderly trip to Buenos Aires.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Fred Haney, the general manager of the California Angels, said today that Manager Bill Rigney would be rehired by the American League club for the 1966 season.

IT takes a kind of bravado to give black tie dinners for eight in a guest room with some of the guests seated on a bed, but William Pahlmann has figured out a way to do it in his apartment on Central Park South.
PARIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Pakistani Embassy here announced today that President Mohammad Ayub Khan had asked President de Gaulle to help re-establish peace in Kashmir.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 5 -- The first anniversary of President Eduardo Frei Montalva's victory in the presidential elections a year ago yesterday is being marked here by unyielding efforts by his Christian Democratic party supporters to overcome the coordinated tactics of opposition parties.
Nassau County reacted skeptically yesterday to a suggestion by City Controller Abraham D. Beame that New York might replenish its dwindling water supply by tapping underground sources on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee released today transcripts of testimony that indicated deficiencies in the supply and maintenance of equipment for Army units stationed in the United States and Europe.
MCAFEE, N.J., Sept. 5 -- A man and his dog were killed today by three incendiary bombs that blew up in his face on the back porch of his home.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 -- A new image of Gov. George C. Wallace as a statesman leading a reluctanct Southland into an age of "social revolution" is emerging in Alabama.

The International Longshoremen's Association has decided to halt further changes in the seniority status of the port's 20,000 dock workers for the life of its current contract.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Juan Marichal, pitching with only two days of rest, became the third hurler in the majors to win 20 games and Willie Mays hit his 43d home run today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4-2.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- The tenants in one of the city's most exclusive and handsome new buildings, on the Right Bank of the Seine facing the Ile St. Louis, will be painters and sculptors, engravers and architects, dancers and musicians, of different ages, achievements and nationalities.
WITH INDIAN FORCES, in Kashmir, Sept. 5 -- India's troops are battling to halt a Pakistani attack that has gained at least 12 miles in the last two days.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi of Communist China made another unscheduled halt today on his way to Mali when he accepted a Syrian Government invitation to stay here for two days.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Sept. 5. -- The Central Intelligence Agency's offer of a bribe in 1960 to Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's Prime Minister, is now a closed matter as far as the Singapore leader is concerned, informed sources said here today.

Dr. Albert Schweitzer wrought two monuments to himself: A system of ethics elaborating the principle of Reverence for Life and a jungle hospital compound in the Republic of Gabon. Both swathed him in controversy -- the philosophy because he equated it with religion, the hospital because it ignored medical advances. Crustily, stubbornly, Schweitzer brushed criticism aside.

Negotiations between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers are in their final, acrimonious stage. The teachers resort to truth squads underlines their feeling that their cause has been misunderstood.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5 -- Many of the 700 specialists from 70 countries at the population conference of the United Nations here are talking about birth control in a matter-of-course manner that was unthinkable not many years ago.
LINCOLN. Neb., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Two 40-foot steel towers supporting a cable car ride toppled on the midway at the Nebraska State Fair today, killing two persons and injuring 53 others.

LADENTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- A 5-year-old Old English sheepdog, Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, was selected as best in today's 845-dog Rockland County Kennel Club show.

From Ozone Park in Queens, where the Grand Old Man goes after his second million, to the foothills of the Sierra Blanca Mountains in New Mexico, where victory is worth almost $10,000 a second, labor and management today will unite in trying to solve an old, old problem: picking a winner.

The average home-owning family in the United States is able to meet its monthly mortgage payments without strain, according to the 1965 Savings and Loan Fact Book, published annually by the United States Savings and Loan League.

A tax on nonresidents was proposed yesterday by Representative William F. Ryan as he and three other contenders for the Democratic mayoral nomination lashed one another orally during an hour-long debate on WCBS-TV.

This Labor Day finds more of the country's workers enjoying higher wages and broader comprehensive benefits than ever before. The day is further brightened by the disappearance of two major threats to economic stability -- the scandalously long maritime strike and the danger of an industrywide shutdown in steel. Many troublesome local disputes persist, but the outlook is for a substantial period of relative tranquillity on the strike front.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank extended $1,859,000,000 in loans, guarantees and insurance to aid American exports in the fiscal year which ended June 30, the bank reported tonight.

LAMBARENE, Gabon, Sept. 5 -- Albert Schweitzer died last night in his jungle hospital here. He was 90 years old.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 5 -- Tension between the provisional President and high military officers appeared to be building up today as the new Government attempted to bring the armed forces under its control.

The following is supplementary list of over-the-counter stocks prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. It consists of securities less widely held or those that, for other reasons, do not appear on the daily Over-the-Counter list. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday. The asked quotations are adjusted upward by the N.A.S.D. it is sometimes possible to obtain lower prices on actual purchases.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 5 -- The Dutch Government may be a novice when it comes to the politics of oil, as officials here like to say, but industry executives wryly acknowledge that the Government seems to know how to play its hand.

Yesterday was the biggest day in the two-year history of the New York World's Fair. With the weather ideal and six weeks left before the final closing, the old attendance mark of 265,560 set last Memorial Day was surpassed at 4 P.M. By closing time, 317,310 had paid their way onto the grounds.

The Baltimore Orioles won their fourth and fifth straight games -- and the New York Yankees lost their fourth and fifth straight -- when the Orioles swept a double-header at Yankee Stadium yesterday, 2-1 and 6-2.

The ninth-round match between Bobby Fischer, the 22-year-old United States chess champion, and Gilberto Garcia of Cuba was adjourned last night after 41 moves. The match will be resumed today.
The World's Fair took in $800,000 at its ticket booths and parking lots during the Labor Day weekend, its highest revenue total for any holiday weekend.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6 -- A new Syrian Chief of Staff was appointed last night, culminating a power struggle between President Amin el-Hafez and the former Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen Salam Jadid.

Controller Abraham D. Beame proposed yesterday that the city make mortgage loans from its $3.8 billion pension fund to "counteract" discrimination against minority groups seeking to build housing in deteriorating areas of New York.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Union claimed a new first in space technology today -- "the world's first international school for training specialists in satellite tracking."

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Aubrey Gatewood's wild pitch with the bases loaded in the ninth inning of the second game gave, the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the California Angels and a sweep of their double-header today.
The appointments of Irb H. Fooshee and J. Howard Marshall as executive vice presidents of the Allied Chemical Corporation were announced over the weekend by Chester M. Brown, president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, announced tonight an intensive Congressional inquiry into the basic economic problems being raised for the nation by what President Johnson calls his Great Society program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- According to an old saying, there are "lies, big lies and statistics."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Steel union and industry leaders signed tonight a contract guaranteeing 35 months of labor peace and providing steelworkers with nearly 50 cents an hour in increased wages and benefits.

The maintenance of an "instant ready" reserve fleet of merchant ships for national emergencies has been proposed to President Johnson by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 -- Citizens here greeted the news that Indian troops had marched into Pakistan today with an enthusiasm that seemed to ignore the risks of war.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, calling for a strong majority government to deal with important national problems, announced tonight that a general election would be held on Nov. 8.

Fred Hechinger's Aug. 22 column was a fine statement of the growing problems of the arts in public schools. That music is one of the subjects now being "frozen out" of the curriculum in California and elsewhere is no surprise.

Secretary General Thant is on his way to Pakistan and India bearing the good wishes of a world which is facing a major calamity. He seeks only a cease-fire, not a political solution of the Kashmir dispute.
Worldwide contamination of the environment by lead from motor gasoline was reported yesterday to have reached "alarming" proportions.
Some 540 miles from the frenetic world of Madison Avenue there works a man who is making big waves in the advertising waters these days.

More than two months ago this club complained to the State Judicial Conference that substantial segments of law enforcement were knowingly and deliberately violating provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure (e.g., Section 165) requiring prompt arraignment of suspects, and that by doing so they were committing a felony under Section 1844 of the Penal Law.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Representative William F. Ryan asked Congress today to block any investment of Federal funds in the controversial Lower Manhattan Expressway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A resolution was introduced in the Senate today directing the Foreign Relations Committee to inquire whether United States treaties and the Export Control Act are violated by shipping restrictions on wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

Tomorrow's press conference of the Gemini 5 astronauts will be televised beginning at 1 P.M. by the American Broadcasting Company network. Lieut. Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. and Lieut. Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr., who completed an eight-day space flight on Aug. 29, will be questioned by reporters at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -Conservationists were assured of victory today in the long battle to block commercial development of Assateagum Island an uninhabited seashore wilderness in the Atlantic off Maryland.

Comalco Industries, Pty., Ltd., an Australian aluminum company, announced yesterday it had borrowed $25 million from a group of institutional investors in the United States in a loan payable in installments over the period 1971-1990.
BONN, Sept. 7 -- Herman J. Abs, a director of the Deutsche Bank, cold-shouldered today a United States proposal for the holding of an international monetary conference.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today and sent to the White House a bill designed to make it easier for American steel producers to compete in the stainless steel market.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 7 -- President Johnson today finished a long Labor Day weekend relaxing at his ranch 65 miles west of here.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 -- A Government spokesman said today that Pakistani Air Force planes destroyed 24 In dian fighters and bombers on the ground and in the air in a series of raids this morning in retaliation for what he described as Indian bombing attacks on major Pakistani cities.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Meadow Court, a 3-year-old chestnut colt owned in part by Bing Crosby, was installed today as the prohibitive favorite for tomorrow's St. Leger Classic.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 7 -- One night stands, catnaps on a plane chartered from the Air Force, the same speech in every city and even the same jokes.
A TOTAL of 45 days of duck gunning, split into two seasons, has been selected by New York State.
A third trial opened yesterday in a malpractice suit against Doctors Hospital.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Sales of leather garments in the United States today have exceeded the $100-million-a-year mark. The figure represents a tripling of business in the last three or four years.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Britain gave Pakistan a gentle "no" today in response to inquiries whether she would support Pakistan against India.

WILDWOOD, N.J. Sept. 7 -- This New Jersey seaside resort closed its season last weekend with a drive against narcotics traffic that had reached the proportions of a "nightmare," according to Mayor Ralph James, who is also director of public safety.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Hopes for a quick halt to the war between India and Pakistan were carried today on the shoulders of a short, neat, round-faced man, U Thant of Burma, Secretary General of the United Nations.

SZUMOWO, Poland, Sept. 7 -- A peasant who farms 17 acres in this region of eastern Poland said that he was generally pleased with the harvest this year. Heavy rain had helped the grain although it did hurt potatoes and the beets somewhat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Negroes with close ties to Mayor Richard J. Daley announced today a "community action" program that will conflict with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s plan for a civil rights movement in Chicago.

A 25-lear-old divorcee yesterday told a grand jury investigating whether the Mafia is moving in on legitimate businesses in Brooklyn that she was the sole owner of the Robbin Concrete Corporation. An investigator identified the company as "a subsidiary for a very well-known concrete firm."
LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the names of the second 10-man team of aquanauts scheduled to established residence Sunday for 15 days in Sealab 2.
A record number of persons were killed in traffic accidents in the nation during the three-day Labor Day holiday.

Richard D. Denison has been appointed to the newly created position of assistant to the treasurer of the Quaker Oats Company. Mr. Denison was formerly a partner with the investment banking firm Glore Forgan, William R. Staats, Inc.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes served an ultimatum on the World's Fair yesterday to take down six advertising signs that it had placed above highways in the vicinity of the fair.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Ranking officials of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeae Ohio Railways told Gov. Richard J. Hughes today that their sweeping merger proposal did not include picking up the tab for New Jersey's deficit-plagued commuter lines.

Cornerstones for the new art season are laid in the form of two major one-man exhibitions opening today in New York museums. They are "Orozco: The Later Years," at the Gallery of Modern Art in Columbus Circle, and a show of work by the contemporary American painter, Jean Xceron, at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Ray Oyler's two-out double in the seventh inning scored the tie-breaking run in the Detroit Tigers' 5--3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

Robert V. Roosa, the former Under Secretary of the Treasury who was responsible for the defense of the dollar, has made a fresh contribution with his own comprehensive proposals for reform of the international monetary system. Mr. Roosa recommends adoption of a new international currency unit, which would supplement gold and the dollar, as well as new long-term credits to help countries in balance of payments difficulties.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad plans to order 2,050 new freight cars and 50 new locomotives and to rebuild another 1,820 freight cars at a cost of more than $44,745,000, Downing B. Jenks, president of the line, announced yesterday.

James H. Meredith, the Negro whose enrollment at the University of Mississippi touched off racial violence on its campus, has been accepted by Columbia University Law School and will register on Monday.

Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., the only player of this country to reach the final of the United States amateur tennis championship since 1955, made his exit from the 84th tournament yesterday, and Rafael Osuna of Mexico, who beat Froehling in the 1963 final, survived only after 2 1/2 hours of punishing play.

As they often do, some commodity futures responded to war news yesterday with an upturn in prices. Traders in such key commodities as copper and sugar were keeping a close watch on news of the India-Pakistan war over Kashmir.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown scheduled today a special session of the Legislature for Sept. 20 to deal with reapportionment of the State Senate and Assembly.

THE new Lola-Ford entered by John Mecom Jr. and driven by Walter Hansgen and Mark Donahue posed the only threat to the supremacy of Jim Hall and Hap Sharp's Chevrolet-powered, automatic-transmission Chaparrals on Elkhart Lake's Road America last Sunday.
George MacCall of Los Angeles will continue as captain of the Davis Cup team in 1966 if Martin Tressel is re-elected president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
Dr. Timothy W. Costello criticized the Wagner administration yesterday for allegedly lagging in its plan to setup a halfway house for narcotics addicts.

The New York Yankees lost their second double-header in two days to the Baltimore Orioles, 4-2 and 9-5, yesterday and their third in four days. As a result, they find themselves one loss or one Twins' victory away from mathematical elimination from the pennant race. In reality, they have been eliminated for weeks.

Any argument against advertising usually brings up the charge that it creates a demand for goods that are not necessary. In the case of the Lampette high-intensity light, the Amprobe Instrument division of the Soss Manufacturing Company feels that it has an answer to that charge.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- Dr. Jacob Herzog, newly elected Chief Rabbi of Britain and the Commonwealth, will be unable to take up his post because of ill health, it was announced today.
PETERBORO, N.H., Sept. 7 -- Tufts and Boston University have their share of football problems this year.
PARIS -- Audrey Hepburn, back in Paris to film "How to Steal a Million Dollars and Live Happily Ever After," made a remark last week in the Boulogne film studio that should endear her to all women.
The appointment of George K. McKenzie as vice president-corporate planning of the United States Plywood Corporation was announced yesterday by Gene C. Brewer, president.
The presentation to Mayor Wagner of the first "School's Open -- Drive Carefully" poster yesterday opened the Automobile Club of New York's 20th annual school safety campaign.

The Democrats, after winning control of the State Legislature last fall for the first time in 30 years, are making a strong bid to retain their unaccustomed majorities in Albany. In the opening phase of this off-year campaign for 230 legislative seats, political authorities in both parties are inclined to agree that the Democrats will keep control of the Assembly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- U Thant left by air tonight on the first stage of his pilgrimage for peace on the Indian subcontinent. The Secretary General will arrive in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, on Thursday and will fly from there to New Delhi in his effort to halt the conflict that exploded over Kashmir.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7 -- A Marine Corps battalion commander was placed under investigation tonight for having used tear gas during a small United States operation early this week.

Many rare plants were destroyed last night by a fire at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The damage from the fire, which broke out in a shed, was estimated by garden officials at $250,000, mostly in the loss of plants.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Bronson La Follette, the Attorney General of Wisconsin, argued today that the Federal Court lacked jurisdiction in a suit brought against the state and Milwaukee County by the Milwaukee Braves.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 7 -- Eighteen political parties submitted lists of candidates today for the November general election. The rosters disclosed some political reshuffling.

SAIGON, Sept. 7 -- South Vietnamese marines and army troops reported killing 40 Vietcong apparently fleeing from the United States Marine Corps force that made an assault landing on the Batangan Peninsula today.

The election of David A. Orr, president of the Lever Brothers Company, as the company's chief executive officer was announced yesterday by Milton C. Mumford, chairman. Lever is the American arm of the British-Dutch Unilever organization.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., turned in record sales for the three, six and twelve months ended July 31, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Bruce A. Gimbel, president.

The new plan for reforming the international monetary system offered yesterday by Robert V. Roosa, one of the chief architects of the existing monetary mechanism, appears in its broad outlines to be a moderate version of other more radical plans.

A 6-year-old boy became wedged in a narrow space between two buildings in the Stapleton section of Staten Island yesterday, leading to an hour-and-a-half rescue effort that required the services of Police, Fire and Highway Departments.

American President Lines and the Maritime Administration announced yesterday the acceptance of a $13,189,265 bid by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation, Pascagoula, Miss., for a fifth ship of the "Seamaster" class.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Michael Langham, director of the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Ont., for the last 10 seasons, said today that he would leave that post in two years to assume direction in La Jolla of an ambitious new classical repertory theater company. He will finish the 1967 season at Stratford, where he succeeded Tyrone Guthrie in 1956.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Ambassador Chester Bowles assured American residents of the Indian capital tonight that the United States Embassy could evacuate them, but he doubted the need would arise.
Mayor Wagner personally intervened yesterday in the contract dispute between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Clifford Stanton Heinz 3d, an heir to the Heinz pickle and food packing fortune, died in Billings Hospital here last night of bullet wounds that the police said were self-inflicted. He was 26 years old.

DWG Cigar Corporation is being sued by three of its directors, Robert S. Gordon, chairman, announced yesterday in a letter to shareholders. The three directors are all nominees of the Allegheny Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company, Baltimore, which owns a 17 per cent interest in the cigar manufacturer.

The crisis in the Dominican Republic, and potential trouble elsewhere, suggest a new look at the political role of the inter-American system. A precedent now exists for the intervention of the Organization of American States when subversion or anarchy threatens a member nation.

Richard M. Nixon's sixteen-day tour of Asia, described as a "private business trip," has been accompanied by public statements at every stop calling for "victory" in Vietnam and denouncing proposals for peace negotiations. In a Saigon news conference the former Vice President said the Republican party would make a campaign issue out of Vietnam in 1966 and 1968 if President Johnson ended the war there by compromise.
Economists, taking their first look at the steel-labor settlement, described it yesterday as a good one.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday the completion of its purchase of all the outstanding shares of Press Wireless, Inc., by its subsidiary, ITT World Communications, Inc.

PEKING, Sept. 5 -- On his current trip to Africa, Foreign Minister Chen Yi will be making a strong appeal on behalf of the postponed African-Asian conference. Diplomatic sources think the Foreign Minister's surprise trip reflects Chinese determination that there should be no further delays or setbacks over the conference, which is now scheduled for Algiers on Nov. 5.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Vincente Saldivar, using a confusing southpaw attack, gained a 15-round decision over Howard Winstone of Wales tonight and retained the world featherweight boxing title before a sellout crowd of 18,000.
HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- Communist China charged today that India's military thrust into West Pakistan "constituted a grave threat to peace in this part of Asia."
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 -- One result of the tight National League pennant race is already assured: there will be considerable agitation to change baseball's rain-out rules before next season begins.

Barbra Streisand, star of "Funny Girl," who is suffering from a bad chest cold, may resume her role at today's matinee. Her manager, Martin Erlichman, said yesterday he would know at noon today whether her condition would permit her to go on.
LOCRI, Italy, Sept. 7 -- A 19-year-old girl, helped by five young men, kidnapped her former fiance, hoping to force him to marry her.
New York City's mayoral scramble may create a moist footnote in political history as the first important campaign since Prohibition in which all candidates jumped on the water wagon for votes.
BONN, Sept 7 -- Unemployment in West Germany has reached a record -- an all but unbelievable low of 85,000 workers.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan has told Secretary General Thant that if the armed struggle between India and Pakistan were to halted, then the right course would be for the United Nations, India and Pakistan to proceed immediately to fulfill the pledge of self-determination to the people of Kashmir.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- The transcript of a Central Committee meeting in which stinging personal criticism was addressed at former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was put on sale here today.
YONKERS, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- State Controller Arthur Levitt accused Governor Rockefeller today of juggling his financial reports to make deficits look like a surplus.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- Sir Laurence Olivier and his National Theater troupe received a 10-minute standing ovation today after a performance of "Othello."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Communist-led demonstrators invaded the grounds of the United States Consulate at Surabaja, East Java, yesterday, a United States Embassy spokesman announced.

Two candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination called yesterday, apparently in vain, for a Federal Communications Commission ban on a proposed television debate by Council President Paul R. Screvane and Controller Abraham D. Beame.

Narcotics traffickers in North America provide the subject of a book by Renee Buse, called "The Deadly Silence." The book begins with the gathering of high-ranking members of the gang at Apalachin, N.Y., in November, 1957, and ends with the conviction of Vito Genovese, "Big John" Ormento, Carmine Galente and "Pepe" Cotroni.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- A British Defense Ministry team arrived here today to examine the possibility of buying French Mirage IV jet bombers, instead of American F-111A's to succeed the Royal Air Force's obsolescent Canberras.

THE third New York Film Festival got off to a swinging start last night in the vast and glistening spaces of Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall. The film shown in the auditorium was Jean-Luc Godard's highly touted Berlin festival winner, "Alphaville," and this was followed by a gala reception that jammed the grand promenade.

Sears, Roebuck Co. scored the highest sales and earnings in its 79-year history in the three, and six-month periods ended July 31. The midyear report to 222,604 shareholders of the nation's biggest merchandising company was issued yesterday by Austin T. Cushman, chairman, and Crowdus Baker, president.

P. Lorillard Company announced recently it was more than doubling the size and production of its Hong Kong plant to keep pace with "rising cigarette demand in the expanding markets of Southeast Asia, Africa and the Middle East."

Although airlines keep reporting a boom in air cargo business, they still are attracting less than four-tenths of a per cent of the cargoes moved in overseas trade, the Committee of American Steamship Lines reported yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 7 (UPI) -- William Sterling Rosecrans Jr. told a Federal court today that he had pleaded guilty to a Federal indictment in the bombing of a Negro's home after being promised that more serious state charges would not be filed against him.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 5 -- Malaysia's new National Mosque, whose Malay motif and contemporary design break sharply with traditional Islamic architecture, is now open to Moslem worshippers.

A fast roll-on, roll-off ship powered by airplane type gas turbines and described by the Department of Defense as the first of its kind is to be built for military use by a steamship company and a shipyard.
Thieves broke into Grace Church, Broadway and 11th Street, Monday night, pried five amethysts from a $2,500 marble altar cross and removed a poor box, the church reported yesterday.

The International Ladies Garment Workers union established a new master agreement department yesterday to deal with the giant apparel companies that have burgeoned in the women's garment industry in recent years.

The substantial increase in spending for new plant and equipment by United States corporations this year will, in turn, lead to a need to raise an estimated $18 billion by external financing, an increase of $3.5 billion from the level last year, according to a study by Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange opened with gains yesterday following the three-day Labor Day weekend and then weakened in the afternoon in moderate trading.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -- Striking maritime engineers who have made 86 vessels of the Argentine state shipping line idle were mobilized today as the Government moved quickly to safeguard power supplies.
JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said tonight that she believed ugly neighborhoods had contributed to crime and rioting.
Mayor Wagner received a proposal yesterday to use four apartment buildings with 3,000 tenants in Elmhurst and Forest Hills, Queens, for a test of whether metering could save large amounts of water.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A bill to authorize the Government to retain permanently the rifle that was used to kill President Kennedy won House passage today.
ISTANBUL, Turky, Sept. 7 -- Pakistan has appealed to the Central Treaty Organization for support in her conflict with India, it was stated today at the organization's headquarters in Ankara.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Roosa plan was added today to the five-foot shelf of proposals for reforming the world monetary system.
After six consecutive weeks of declines, most Government bond prices were unchanged yesterday on trading volume that dealers described as extremely light.
Stock prices advanced yesterday for the third consecutive trading session, but the gains in the popular averages were not as impressive as expected.
ATLANTA, Sept. 7 -- Resistance to public school desegregation increased in scattered areas of the South as still more school systems open previously all-white classes to Negroes this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said tonight that the common strategy of all the world's communist powers is to win control of Asia, Africa, and Latin America and thus encircle and strangle the Atlantic world.

ONE flaw in the make-up of Buddy Parker is that he lets himself be swept away by his own impulses. Emotions play too strong a part in affecting his destinies. They carried him out of a job as coach of the Detroit Lions a few years ago and over the weekend they brought about his unwanted resignation as coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Sept. 7 -- The National Repertory Theater will return for its third annual guest appearance as a collective artist-in-residence at the University of North Carolina here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The National Education Association announced today it would send 36 educators into the South and border states to investigate the displacement of Negro teachers because of school desegregation.

The Los Angeles riot reflects a critical emergency in the need to develop a more immediate solution than has appeared on the horizon to date. The Negro community contains within it today elements that are tinder for a future blaze of violence. What makes up the tinder?
The new Federal Housing Act's easy terms for veterans are even easier than originally reported, the Federal Housing Administration has informed mortgage lenders.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had urged India and Pakistan to stop fighting and had offered Moscow's good offices in seeking a settlement of their dispute over Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, has told the Securities and Exchange Commission he is against plans for legislation to exempt stock exchanges from antitrust action.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union today accepted -- and the United States rejected -- a proposal by neutral nations for an unverified ban on large underground nuclear tests. The plan also called for a ban on smaller tests.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 7 (UPI) -- David J. McDonald, former head of the United Steel-workers of America, criticized the new steel industry contract tonight, particularly a section he said "emasculates" the 13-week vacation plan.

EAST GLACIER, Mont., Sept. 7 (AP) -- A heresy charge against Bishop James A. Pike of California was presented today to a newly formed theological committee here. The panel is expected to report tomorrow to the Protestant Episcopal Church House of Bishops.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The House passed a revised $1.7 billion bill on military construction today after defeating efforts to override a Presidential veto.
New York City was pictured yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission as a slovenly housekeeper who had begun to spend extravagantly and far beyond his means.
YONKERS, Sept. 7 -- Maria Burdova proved beyond a doubt tonight that she "belongs" on the track with top-flight men reinsmen.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- For years University of Pittsburgh officials have shown little sympathy for their football players in the way they make up the schedule. This season's schedule -- compiled probably five or more years ago -- is just as difficult as past ones.

THE Open Team Championship that ended the Knickerbocker Championships Monday night was won by S. Garton Churchill, of Great Neck, L.I., one of New York's great veteran players. His team-mates were all members of a more recent bridge generation: James Phillips and Tom Griffin, both of New York, and Robert Ewen, of Champaign, Ill.
KEY LARGO, Fla., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Motorists streamed up the Overseas Highway tonight, some driving like daredevils, to escape the fury of the hurricane.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- The discredited Lysenko doctrine in biology continues to haunt the Soviet Union.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 2 -- The Bavarian city of Augsburg is paying a tribute to Hans Holbein the Elder -- who may or may not have been a native son -- on approximately the 500th anniversary of his birth.

President Johnson's announcement of his nomination of Postmaster General John A. Gronouski as United States Ambassador to Poland is another important step in the development of an effective diplomatic corps.
NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- Indian forces crossed the West Pakistan border again in a drive apparently aimed at Karachi, Pakistan's largest city and former capital.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 7 -- President Jomo Kenyatta appeared tonight to have been embarrassed by a widely circulated report that he had offered to mediate in the Indian-Pakistani dispute and that President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan had accepted the offer.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 7 -- Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy showed up unexpectedly in downtown Santo Domingo this afternoon to plead with rebels there to disband.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- Legislative representatives from 60 Western, Communist and nonaligned nations meet here tomorrow for the 54th annual Inter-Parliamentary Union conference. About 800 persons are expected to attend.
The New York Jets yesterday placed John Huarte, their rookie quarterback from Notre Dame, on the waiver list with the intention of moving him to their taxi squad.

Hapoel Petach-Tikvah, six-time Israeli national soccer champion, will open a three-week ,tour of the United States and Canada tonight against a New York all-star team at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

New York City's increasingly serious financial situation can be briefly summarized. In the past decade its operating budget has more than doubled, from $1.7 billion to $3.8 billion; its net funded debt has soared from $2.6 billion to $3.9 billion; its real-estate tax rate from $3.85 per $100 to $4.56 -- all in a period of virtually stationary population. Not even the richest city in the world can continue such astronomical increases indefinitely.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Soviet Government, angry over a state tax levied on Soviet newsmen in New York, said today it would raise the taxes of all American correspondents here.
Dr. Catherine B. Hess, assistant health commissioner, narcotics control coordinator and executive director of chronic disease services, has resigned, effective Oct. 1.

One of the great adventure stories and mysteries 120 years ago concerned the disappearance of Sir John Franklin, his 129 men and two ships, the Erebus and the Terror, in Arctic ice while seeking the then-fabled northwest passage leading to the riches of the Far East.

IT WAS said that Isabella Stewart crawled out of a convent window in Paris to elope with Jack Gardner, that she lived in sin with John Singer Sargent and posed in the nude for the Swedish artist Anders Zorn. She was credited with receiving "best Boston" perched on the branches of a ceiling-high potted mimosa tree and with keeping lions in the cellar of Fenway Court, her Venetian "palace" near Boston's Museum of Fine Arts.

The Flying Tiger Line, a domestic all-cargo airline, announced yesterday it had entered the business of selling jet planes to businessmen. Robert W. Prescott, president, said the line had acquired dealership rights for the sale, lease or charter of the new Lear Executive Jet, a six-passenger craft with a price tag of $595,000.

MADRID, Sept. 7 -- The quickening exodus from the poverty-stricken countryside to the cities and to foreign lands reflects conditions in Spanish agriculture that often are neither "Christian" nor "human," according to a leading Roman Catholic churchman.

A NETWORK that cancels an entire evening's regular schedule for a three-and-a-half-hour consideration of United States foreign policy since World War II is bound to command respect for its earnestness in dealing with an issue of overriding moment.

Robert Moses charged yesterday that City Controller Abraham D. Beame, when a director of the World's Fair Corporation, had voted for the approval of two contracts that he criticized sharply last week in an interim audit report.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The New York City Ballet is often criticized for being virtually the choreographic monopoly of George Balanchine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Defense Department is reviewing the physical and mental standards required for military draftees and volunteers, officials said today.
W.R. Grace Co., diversified chemical producer, announced yesterday the appointment of Elwyn E. Winne as president of the polymer chemicals division to succeed T.T. Miller, who is retiring.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 A movement to save small historical Russian towns from decay and extinction gained the support today of Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.

HONG KONG -- At some point, President Johnson is probably going to have to come into this part of the world and try to use his political talents on the West's rapidly deteriorating position in Asia. There is nobody else in the world who is likely to make the effort.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Sept. 7 -- The Delta Ministry of the National Council of Churches announced today plans for the formation of a nonprofit corporation to seek Federal assistance for a 10-county area of Mississippi.
SAIGON, Wednesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Twelve B-52 jet bombers based on Guam pounded a jungle target less than 25 miles northwest of Saigon today.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The president of the Laurentide Financial Corporation, Ltd., expressed hope today that his company's bid for the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., would be the most acceptable of the three bids submitted.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 -- Sammy Ellis, the young right-hander who led Cincinnati's pitching staff the first half of the season and had become a struggling .500 pitcher since June, returned to form tonight and pitched the Reds to within a half-game of first place in the National League.

Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, won his ninth-round adjourned game yesterday against Gilberto Garcia of Cuba in the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament. The game was halted Monday night at the 41st move and upon resumption of play Fischer scored surprisingly quickly when Garcia sacrificed a piece unsoundly.
Prices closed mixed on the London Stock Exchange following a late rally that overcame earlier nervousness stemming from the Indian-Pakistan fighting.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 7 -- "To insure a stable Singapore we must now take some steps that may not always suit the United States. It is up to the Americans to understand this."
MIAMI, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- A hurricane began lashing the Florida coast late last night, sending the sea surging into the streets ahead of the storm's oncoming 140-mile-an-hour winds.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 7 -- A member of the Federal Power Commission said here today that a comprehensive review of the natural gas industry could be the vital link in development of a national energy policy.

RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Ten young women were presented at the annual Rumson Debutante Ball tonight at the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club. The debutantes received with their mothers in the clubhouse. The dinner and the ball were held in a pink and white striped marquee on the lawn.
SEPTEMBER has arrived and with it a new wave of imports. Two of the first stores to unveil their collections are Macy's and Altman's.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 -- The Justice Department brought the Ku Klux Klan in Bogalusa to trial in Federal Court today and encountered a shortage of records and a failure of memory among the organization's leaders.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today that if school dropouts continued at the present rate 32 million adults would be working without a high school education in 10 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States has suspended deliveries of military supplies to Pakistan and India for the duration of their current conflict, thus warning against attempts to fight a major war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Johnson called on the National Crime Commission today to work out creative and revolutionary recommendations for a campaign against crime.

New York State sold yesterday $72 million of bonds to finance highway construction in a sale that quickly brought forth arguments and counter arguments about the Rockeller Administration's financing methods.
Military observers in the United States believe that the limiting factor in the Indian-Pakistani conflict is supplies.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 8 -- India attacked Pakistan today in two new sectors, over 600 miles apart on the West Pakistan border.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 -- A United States marine unit killed 66 Vietcong guerrillas today in the blasting of their underground hideout with TNT.
