KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Three youths, on their way to Kearny High School, were killed today when they ran past one Erie-Lackawanna Railroad train into the path of another headed in the opposite direction.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 8 -- The Bantu Affairs Court, a low cement-block building with a corrugated iron roof next to the railway yards here, does not look much like a judicial institution.
Msgr. Paul Marcinkus of the Vatican Secretariat of State and Msgr. Pasquale Macchi, the Pope's personal secretary, arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday afternoon.
A Federal grand jury indicted two men yesterday for alleged fraud in selling paintings represented as the work of Jackson Pollock and Franz Kline.
ROME, Sept. 8 -- Pope Paul VI will fly to New York on Oct. 4 to deliver a peace appeal before the United Nations General Assembly and probably meet with President Johnson.

The Vivian Beaumont Allen Foundation has given $1.3 million to the Lincoln Center Repertory Company. Before her death in 1962, Mrs. Allen gave $3 million toward the construction of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Johnson signed today the long-sought congressional authorization for construction of a subway transit system to serve the District of Columbia and its Maryland and Virginia suburbs.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 -- The defendants in a Justice Department suit against the Ku Klux Klan admitted most of the Government's allegations today and diminished the impact of a legal assault on segregationist terrorism at Bogalusa.
MANILA, Sept. 8 -- Leaders of the Philippines and other non-Communist nations called today for more effective countermeasures against incursions by Communist China in Southeast Asia.
Pupils who are behind in reading may soon be spending up to 40 per cent of their school day on that subject, Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan said yesterday.

In a tightly guarded courtroom, four teen-age Negroes were sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment for first-degree murder in the knife slaying of a woman in her second-hand clothing store in Harlem.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a broad investigation into the affairs of the Equity Corporation and the Bell Intercontinental Corporation.
Most stock prices registered narrow gains in slow trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- Canada's Governor General, George P. Vanier, welcomed today delegates from Western, Communist and nonaligned nations to the 54th Inter-Parliamentary Conference.
The British pound was slightly weaker yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 8 -- The seven Roman Catholic Bishops in the Netherlands lifted today an 11-year-old regulation that threatened Roman Catholics with denial of the sacraments if they became members of Socialist labor organizations.

DAM construction contemplated in the lower Colorado River basin "would clear the way for further serious violations of our national park and national wilderness systems," Stewart M. Brandborg, the executive director of The Wilderness Society, said recently.

IN the seventh round of the current Capablanca Memorial Tournament in Havana, the United States champion, Bobby Fischer, as Black, again pinned his chances on a risky variation of the Sicilian Defense.
The city's parks, beaches and boardwalks are off-limits for campaigning, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee cleared away today two possible obstacles to adjournment.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Provoke trounced the heavily favored Meadow Court by 10 lengths today in the St. Leger Classic and registered one of the biggest upsets in English horse racing history.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8 -- The Labor and Social Democratic parties today nominated Francisco Negrao de Lima as their candidate for Governor of the state of Guanabara in place of former Marshal of the Army Henrique Teixeira Lott.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The 1965-66 Paris season opened tonight. Its first premiere was that of an American play, Ira Wallach's "Absence of a Cello," at the Comedie des Champs-Elysees.
ANYBODY who longed to get to Italy this summer but couldn't will be able to find solace of a sort on Monday at 33d Street and Broadway.

The following table shows maximum retirement benefits provided under the Social Security Act, as recently amended, to fully insured persons who retire in the year of attainment of full benefits (65 for men and 62 for women), in the year before attainment of full benefits, or in one of the four years after.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Secretary General Thant was greeted at the airport tonight by the Indian and Pakistani Ambassadors along with Premier Amir Hoveida of Iran, Acting Foreign Minister Ahmed Mirfendereski and United Nations officials. Mr. Thant conferred with Mr. Hoveida and the Acting Foreign Minister.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The price of stamped envelopes will go up Saturday, the Post Office Department announced tonight.

It took two hours, assorted color slides and a series of verbal exchanges between stockholders and officers to complete the annual meeting yesterday of the City Investing Company in the maroon-carpeted third-floor auction gallery of Parke-Bernet at 980 Madison Avenue.

THIS is the time when attention begins to concentrate on the pitchers who will become 20-game winners this season. But few fans pay the slightest heed to the equally hard-working unfortunates who will gain a somewhat dubious distinction in a slightly different direction. These are the ill-starred operatives who will become 20-game losers.
A tenfold increase in rates for war-risk insurance on cargo shipments to India and Pakistan was put into effect by London insurance underwriters yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today President Johnson's nomination of Postmaster General John A. Gronouski as Ambassador to Poland.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- North Vietnam has sent to the International Control Commission for Vietnam a charge that United States marines use "toxic gas" against South Vietnamese civilians, the Hanoi radio said today.

A consistent turf performer, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark's Lancastrian, came through with his fourth straight triumph on the grass when, despite some bumping, he won the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. The race, at 1 1/8 miles, had eight starters, and the outcome was hardly surprising to the crowd of 25,380.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 -- When the Common Market Executive Commission reconvenes tomorrow morning following its vacation recess, the minds of the members present will not be on the three-item agenda.

Net income of the Sheraton Corporation of America climbed to $1,085,434, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter ended July 31, more than double the $413,941, or 7 cents a share, earned in the corresponding period a year earlier.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 -- A series of battles was reported today to have broken out in central Vietnam.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 8 -- A general strike has been called for Oct. 1 in the midst of Government efforts to steer a course between increasing inflation and near bankruptcy.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 8 -- The controversial white-dominated Government of Rhodesia has told Britain that despite "certain threats," it plans to appoint independent diplomatic representatives to Portugal and to any other countries that will accept them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The conflict between India and Pakistan kept the Johnson Administration busy on three major fronts today. Officials were trying to guard against an expansion of the fighting, looking for a way to reimpose a truce and, closer to home, trying to prevent the foreign aid program to Asia from becoming one of the principal casulaties.
AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 8 -- In the last two seasons Vic Fusia has coached the University of Massachusetts football squad to an enviable record, 16 victories against one defeat and one tie.
Johnny Keane was rehired as manager of the New York Yankees yesterday to dispel any feelings that he was to blame for the team's worst showing in 40 years.

Pope Paul's forthcoming visit to the United States, which is such an obvious source of interest and satisfaction, stirs a natural and not irreverent thought: it is time that a Roman Pontiff came to the New World, especially since the trip by jet plane is so easy, comfortable and safe.

The biennial ritual of contract negotiations between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers appears to be following script to the letter. Presumably the Mayor's mediators have been working at resolving the so-called non-money issues, but have not yet been able to reach agreement on the amount of increases in teachers' salaries and other benefits. This is being saved for a breathless photo-finish.
Representative John V. Lindsay said last night that he did not foresee any reduction in the $500 million a year spent on public welfare programs in the city.

In a day of exciting competition that reached its most nerve-racking moments as darkness closed in, Chuck McKinley was beaten in the United States amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and Dennis Ralston, trailing at 1-3 in the fifth set, just barely survived his match with Ronald Holmberg.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8 -Three New England Governors pledged $1.7 million dollars in additional assistance to the New Haven Railroad today, so the line can maintain its passenger service between New York City and Boston for the next 18 months.
Bobby Fischer's important 10th-round game with Borislav Ivkov of Yugoslavia was postponed yesterday until 10 A.M. tomorrow because the huricane called Betsy severed teletype communication with Cuba.

AT the recent convention of the American Federation of Teachers in Los Angeles, Francis Keppel, Commissioner of Education, advised the union against striking. Albert Shanker, president of the New York local of the union, the United Federation of Teachers, said he thought the Keppel statement was "tremendous."

NEW DELHI, Thursday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Paratroops spread the India-Pakistani conflict to many points of the subcontinent today. Airborne and terrorist activity were reported from Karachi almost to Calcutta.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Efforts will be made next week to force House floor action on bills aiding the arts and humanities and stiffening a Federal law barring racial discrimination by unions.

WHEN the judging for the best borzoi was called at the Westminster show last February, 11 champions were paraded into the ring. Three had been bred by the Tam-Boer Kennels, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tamboer of Mahway, N.J. The winner was Ch. Ducies Wild of Tam-Boer, owned and shown by their daughter.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The United States and Pakistan took sharply conflicting positions today on conditions for a settlement of the fighting between India and Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today he had repaid with interest $1,806.80 earned in Federal Government summer jobs by his son and step-daughter.
The New York Yankees broke their longest losing streak in 12 years last night when Elston Howard's two-out single in the ninth inning defeated the Washington Senators, 6-5.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Johnny Callison and Dick Stuart combined to drive in five runs as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 6-5, tonight.
Cardinal Spellman dedicated and blessed yesterday the shrine of Blessed Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, founder of the Sisters of Charity of St. Joseph and the first native American to be beatified.

AN outdoor dance series of significance in many ways began at Delacorte Theater in Central Park last night. The Robert Joffrey Ballet gave a benefit preview program to introduce the four regular performances that are to get under way this evening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- After considerable deliberation and with some reluctance, the United States has decided to continue extending peaceful atomic assistance to Indonesia.

The recent student demonstrations in Korea against the Korean-Japanese "normalization" treaty just concluded between the two Asian neighbors requires some understanding and analysis rather than the label of another "annual ritual" that characterizes the recent political unrest in Korea, as well as in many other newly emerging countries.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept. 8 -- Provincetown public school pupils opened the academic year today with a lesson in dress and behavior.

Tidying up their football squad far the opening of the season, the New York Jets yesterday acquired two players and dropped one rookie. They claimed two men cut by the Buffalo Bills, Ray Abruzzese and Al Rtkinson, and to reach the maximum squad limit of 38 they moved Jim Hudson to the injured deferred list.
Roman Catholic schools in New York City expect an enrollment of 375,748 pupils, 5,600 more than last year, when the doors open Monday.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 8 -- Air Vice Marshal Nur Khan said today that Pakistan's air force "definitely" had not attacked New Delhi.
The election of Thomas B. Meek as vice president of Harris, Upham Co., Inc., was announced yesterday.

The situation in the Dominican Republic is at a critical stage, even though less than a week has passed since "peace" and the assumption of the Provisional Presidency by Hector Garcia-Godoy. The United States has an opportunity to get the country going in a way that will lead to what President Johnson says he wants -- a democratic government elected by a fair, secret ballot, with a wide range of choices.

A guard shot and critically wounded a patron in the Main Post Office, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, yesterday in a fight that grew out of a dispute over the patron's emptying his pipe into a waste-paper basket.

ROCKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Carl Lohren of North Shore and Arthur Rhodes, Huntington carded four-under-par 68's to tee for sectional medal honors among the Long Island qualifiers for the Metropolitan open at the Cedar Brook Golf Club today.
The appointment of Bernard Tabbat as president of the Seagram-Distillers Company was announced yesterday by Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the parent company, Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc.
The stock market continued its upward push yesterday as most major groups, with steels a notable exception, chalked up price advances.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 -- A special representative of President Johnson proposed a wide-ranging program today to enable individual Americans to help the victims of the Vietnamese war. The representative Dr. Howard A. Rusk, said at a news conference that despite the complexity of the war situation, some of the most severe problems were simple and human: for example, he said, the refugees need soap more than anything else.
THE fashion situation at the opening Tuesday night of the third New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center was as confused as the reaction to the film.
MIAMI, Sept. 8 -- A hurricane hurled its mighty winds and a destructive wall of water across southern Florida today, then moved into the Gulf of Mexico.
A test of new, "immediate delivery" procedures for air cargo arriving at Kennedy International Airport from abroad will get under way Monday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The decision by Pope Paul to address the General Assembly Oct. 4 could attract a number of political leaders to its 20th session.

Top officials of VTR, Inc., now a tire and soft-drink franchise business, consented yesterday to a Federal Court order to make full restitution for unauthorized withdrawal of funds from the company since 1958.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook scored 40, 36 -- 76 and won first prize on a match of cards in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament-today at the Sands Point Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Dr. George P. Cressman was appointed director of the Weather Bureau today and Rear Adm. James C. Tison was named head of the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
" My father invented before me, so now I invent," said Robert D. Smith of the Bronx, seated astride the wooden rollers of his massage machine.

KIRKENES, Norway, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Soviet border policemen have arrested a 27-year-old American who left his hotel here on a sightseeing trip last Saturday, the chief of police of this northern Norwegian town said tonight.

EFFORT, Pa., Sept 8 -- There has been nothing but hard work for the Pennsylvania football team during its stay at Camp Seneca Hunt in the Pocono Mountains. The training program under the new head coach, Bob Odell, has called for the usual two-a-day sessions on the field and skull sessions between workouts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Tony Palcaorolla, 68 years old, of Baltimore, said he was not excited when he sat in the Presidential office with President Johnson at the White House today.

AMBALA, India, Sept. 7 -- The Grand Trunk Road from Calcutta to the Khyber Pass has been closed by the Indian Army just west of Ludhiana. Civilians -- Indians and foreigners alike -- are barred from regions between Jullundur and the Pakistani border, which the Indian Army crossed in force Monday.

The three national television networks said yesterday they would present extensive coverage of the visit here of Pope Paul VI on Monday, Oct. 4. Pictures of the Pontiff are expected to occupy the television screen for several hours that day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The Roman Catholic Archidocese of Chicago offered today to pay $3 million to victims and the families of victims of the fire in Our Lady of Angels School in which 92 pupils were killed and 76 were injured in 1958.
ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- The leaders of Greece's two major parties failed again tonight to agree on a compromise for a prompt general election, and the government crisis entered its third month.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Don Wert's three-run homer in the sixth inning and the three-hit pitching of Dave Wickersham carried the Detroit Tigers to a 5-0 victory over Baltimore in the second game of a doubleheader here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The White House announced today that the international road company of the Broadway hit musical "Hello, Dolly!" would play next month in Vietnam for United States troops.

The hatred of citizens of the occupied countries for the Nazi conquerors and their work to undermine Nazi efforts is told by Albert Orban in "Duel in the Shadows." To be issued Sept. 17 by Doubleday, the book presents the heroes and heroines of the resistance forces in France, Denmark, Norway, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- President Johnson strolled out of the White House today and on the sidewalk met three students -- two from Pakistan and one from India.
The Commercial Credit Company announced yesterday that it planned to sell $75 million of 22-year notes later this month.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Scientific findings that may aid in the exploration of the "inner world" beneath the ocean are starting to emerge from the Sealab 2, a steel capsule submerged 210 feet below the ocean's surface off La Jolla.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday standards and procedures it was adopting to make certain that unqualified individuals were not at work in the securities business.

Completion of a $3.5 million improvement and modernization program of the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn Division has doubled the capacity of the facility, John T. Gilbride, president of the company, said yesterday
One block of Manhattan turned into a Hasidic festival last night as 3,000 guests crowded West 73d Street for a wedding.

The New York Botanical Garden, alarmed by an increase in costly attacks by teen-age vandals, said yesterday that it had been asking the city for more guards for four years and getting a deaf ear. Instead, its guard force was cut back last year.
The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers announced yesterday that it would begin distributing awards totaling $510,050 to 1,400 members next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Willie Mays hit his 44th and 45th homers of the season, driving in five runs, as the San Francisco Giants increased their lead in the National League race today with a 12-3 victory over the Houston Astros.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Federal officials indicated today that the days of free water and free sewage service in the big cities were numbered.
Directors of the Whitin Machine Works recommended to the textile-machinery company's stockholders yesterday that they accept an offer to merge with White Consolidated Industries, Inc., of Cleveland.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane proposed yesterday giving the City Commission on Human Rights additional powers and make it a full city department.
To Uri Karny, the burly Hapoel Petah-Tikvah manager, the 19 Israeli players clad in white uniforms looked a bit slow last night as they loosened up before game time.

The New York County grand jury investigating the multi-million-dollar paint contract scandal "definitely will indict" a labor union official accused of taking $800,000 in bribes since 1957, reliable sources reported yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stock holders of listed companies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Soviet Union today turned down President Johnson's invitation to send an observer to watch the next Gemini launching in October.

Since the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, the United States has followed a policy of neutrality with regard to the Kashmir issue. Presumably, we have been neutral because we have wanted to be on friendly terms with both India and Pakistan.
JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 8 -- Conservationists were told today that at last they have a key to effective political action.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 -- The number of American servicemen in Vietnam has passed the 100,000 mark and will soon reach the goal of 125,000 set by President Johnson in July.

Even the most fervent proponents of metering water supplied to apartment house dwellers expect that the water will be metered to the tenants. No person with any experience with tenants can expect that metering a landlord, which is relatively much simpler, would have any effect on tenant consumption.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 -- The Cincinnati Reds moved into a tie for second place in the National League, half a game behind the league-leading San Francisco Giants, by battering the New York Mets tonight, 11-2.
If Alexis Solomos has his way -- and he is confident that he will -- ancient Greek drama will "come alive" for American audiences next summer in Ypsilanti, Mich.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The stage was set today for a meeting between President Johnson and Pope Paul VI in New York on Oct. 4.

New York City received state approval late yesterday to draw 100 million gallons a day from the Hudson River as an emergency water supply, through a $7 million pumping station still to be built at Chelsea, north of Beacon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Jimmie Hall's two-run homer in the seventh inning led the Minnesota Twins to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- San Francisco's three newspapers will be reduced to two next week. The survivors will consolidate all production operations.
OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- Canadian newspapers joined Opposition party leaders today in criticizing as unnecessary the Canadian general election called for Nov. 8.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi called today on the world's nations to join Iran in devoting part of their military expenditures to a central world fund to fight illiteracy on an international basis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A high-level Republican study group suggested today a reduction of American forces in Europe and a smaller foreign-aid burden as ways to eliminate permanently the deficit in the nation's international payments.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Eighteen companies charged with price fixing in the sale of liquid asphalt to the state of Missouri pleaded innocent to the charges today.
I want to protest the too frequent criticisms directed at Commissioner Henry A. Barnes, of which the Aug. 12 letter "No Midtown Garages," written by Herbert Askwith, is typical.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Tony Horton hit a two-out, two-run homer in the 10th inning tonight, giving the Boston Red Box a 5-3 triumph over the Cleveland Indians.
" DON'T talk to me about atrocities," Lord Kitchener said to Lloyd George, who was demanding retaliation against the Germans, "all war is an atrocity."
The bond market got little to cheer about yesterday.
An attempt to end the power struggle between opposing factions in Haryou-Act was seen in the appointment yesterday of G. Douglas Pugh as associate executive director of the Harlem antipoverty agency.
Major airlines were resuming service last night to Miami and other Florida cities affected by the hurricane.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Seven young women were presented tonight at the fourth Bedford Assemblies at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club.

SAO PAULO, Sept. 8 -- Several European countries have warned that they will not participate in the next Sao Paulo Biennial of Contemporary Art unless the jury system is changed, it was reported today.
Dan River Mills, Inc., is negotiating to acquire Webco Mills, Inc., Burlington, N.C., producers of tricot fabrics.
Carmine G. De Sapio, who is making another comeback attempt, said yesterday that he had no higher political ambition than to unseat Edward I. Koch as a Democratic district leader in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Kennedy's opposition to Federal aid to parochial schools may actually have helped obtain such legislation this year, a political scientist said today.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The British Government banned today further shipments of arms to India. Several shipments that were due to leave British ports in the next week or two were canceled.

Jay Kramer, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, suggested to a group of 500 labors leaders yesterday that unions had a great and unfinished task in organizing the unorganized workers in New York State.
The sale of the Paramount Building on Times Square by the bankrupt Webb Knapp realty concern won final court approval yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 -- One of the most important affairs of state that President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz had to deal with yesterday was a boxing match in London.
A case to be heard by the Federal Trade Commission this month will provide a further indication of its current approach to Government regulation of advertising.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave formal public notice today of the fact that the First National City Bank of New York had filed application for permission to establish what would amount to a "no-load" mutual fund.

John V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, has raised and already spent more money on his campaign than the five other major candidates combined, according to statements filed with the Board of Elections.

W. Maxey Jarman, chairman of Genesco, Inc., said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating his company's public relations and corporate advertising practices but that it "has made no charges or allegations concerning Genesco."
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Dr. Boris V. Petrovsky, a noted Soviet heart surgeon, was appointed today as Minister of Public Health.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., asserted today that the labor federation had played no role in drafting the Administration's farm bill.

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo said yesterday he would seek to create a single entertainment license law to replace all the "archaic and incongruous" laws governing theater and cabaret licenses.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 8 -- Three Seattle companies have been awarded contracts totaling $1.3 million for construction of a new shipway here at the Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Administration forces decisively turned back tonight a drive by House Republicans to impose a statutory ban on economic and military aid to India and Pakistan.
ASBURY PARK was a magic name in the early days of bridge tournaments. From 1930 through 1941 the Summer National Championships were held there, and the famous players battled for supremacy.

A woman in a Chanel suit and white gloves dashed out of an apartment house, past the doorman and into a taxi on Sheridan Square yesterday afternoon. On the other side of the square, a young man and woman, both wearing dungarees and with long, dirty hair, sat on a stoop holding hands and reading together from a paperback edition of Sophocles.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Bert Campaneris of Kansas City played all nine positions tonight, but the California Angels spoiled the feat by beating the Athletics, 5-3, with the help of pitcher John O'Donoghue's wild throw in the 13th inning.
Although a few stocks made impressive gains yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, prices for most issues just managed to inch up in active trading.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Many of the country's business economists and statisticians expect the United States economy to continue its expansion through 1966.
Twelve major league baseball teams were represented yesterday as arrangements were made for the 1965 World Series.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 8 -- Former President Juan Bosch is scheduled to return from exile Sunday, in effect marking the start of the campaign for national elections next May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Moscow's abrupt decision to keep "Hello, Dolly!" off the boards in Russia is bad news. The official interpretation -- that the show was banned in retaliation against United States war policy in Vietnam -- is not taken seriously by people who understand relations between modern superstates.
Pope Paul VI's projected visit to the United Nations brought forth a flood of favorable comment from religious and civic leaders yesterday.
Negotiations aimed at averting a teachers' strike next Monday were reported yesterday to be "on the track and moving toward the final stop on the line."

YONKERS, Sept. 8 -- Maria Burdova is set to guide Apex Hanover in tomorrow night's $50,000 Transoceanic Trot at Yonkers Raceway. At least as much interest is being shown in the woman driver as in the American-bred horse, both of whom will represent the Soviet Union in the 1 1/4-mile race.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 8 -- A political rival of District Attorney William Cahn of Nassau County charged today that he had either lied under oath or had elicited false testimony about his relationship to Irving Holzman, a jukebox distributor with a police record.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Ron Nicol of Scarsdale Golf Club, Mike Krak of Wee Burn and Bill (Cotton) Dunn of Apawamis led the field today in Westchester sectional qualifying for the 50th Metropolitan open golf championship.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- President de Gaulle will make a major policy statement tomorrow on foreign and internal affairs.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- A Harvard University law professor has been accused here of having written a distorted interpretation of the Soviet legal system for anti-Communist motives.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Don. C. Silverthorne, a former bank president, was indicted today for misapplying more than $1 million in funds of the San Francisco National Bank, which has been closed by the Government.

With crime and lawlessness being on the rise, Americans should re-examine the concept of civil disobedience to see if it is consistent with respect for law and order. Justification for civil disobedience is found in the argument that a person is morally right in breaking a law if he is doing it to test the law in the courts or doing it for what he thinks will be the betterment of mankind.
Robert Moses told Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday to "keep your hair shirt on" and "do your homework."
Chain stores in August showed improvement over the corresponding month last year, according to the figures issued by a variety of store chains.
The American family has a broader foundation on which to build its financial program, thanks to the Social Security legislation approved by Congress and signed by President Johnson this summer.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- A prisoner who stole a pistol from a deputy sheriff escaped today on foot after two motorists in the business district of this city ordered him from their cars.
EAST GLACIER, Mont., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Protestant Episcopal bishops endorsed a greater role for Negro clergy within the church but kept two touchy issues locked in committees today.

As a citizen of Singapore I was greatly interested in the news articles in your issues of Aug. 31 and Sept. 3 concerning the blunder of the C.I.A. in Singapore and of the reaction of the United States Embassy in Malaysia and the State Department. [Editorial Sept. 3.]
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee unanimously approved today a highway beautification bill varying from the proposal of President Johnson.

HONG KONG, Sept. 8 -- Communist China strongly protested to India today against "military aggression and provocation" along the Chinese-Indian border. In a note to New Delhi, Peking demanded the withdrawal of Indian troops from contested points near the Himalayan state of Sikkim.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton crop would reach 15,134,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each. This is 1.5 per cent more than the August forecast of 14,916,000 bales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton told political specialists today that a victory by Representative John V. Lindsay in the New York mayoral race would help the Republican party -- even in Mississippi.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- One of the best-known hostesses in Portland is Mrs. Henry F. Cabell, a spirited, stately, outspoken woman who also has one of the most impressive collections of fine china on the West Coast.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- With an election-year flourish, President de Gaulle's Cabinet gave final approval today to a balanced budget for 1966 and sent it to the National Assembly's Finance Committee.

Commodity futures contracts, in heavy demand earlier this week because of the India-Pakistan conflict, were caught yesterday in the partial retreat that often follows a sharp advance in prices. Brokers generally attribute it to "profit taking." Copper, sugar and wool were among the staples showing losses.

With New York City's reservoirs down to 38.8% of their capacity, the lowest point at this season in their history, and with Federal experts warning that New York next year may face a "devastating emergency," it is only natural that the four Democratic candidates for the mayoral nomination have all been ardently campaigning in favor of more water.

Negotiators for The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York discussed a jurisdictional issue at a bargaining session yesterday at the regional office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 346 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- France continued to be the largest buyer of gold from the United States in the second quarter of this year, a Treasury report revealed today.

Kenneth B. Keating, court-appointed trustee for Yale Express System, Inc., said yesterday that the services being provided to the concern by a Denver Chicago Trucking Company management team would be "gradually" withdrawn.
The State Banking Board gave its approval yesterday for the organization of the first new state-chartered commercial bank in New York in five years.

The "galoshes war" in Washington demonstrates anew the damage a single protectionist industry can inflict on broader American economic and political interests in the world. The stiff tariff increase sought by the rubber footwear industry has not only angered the Japanese, the chief exporters, but has raised serious doubts in Europe about American intentions in the critical Kennedy Round of trade negotiations in Geneva.
BAYVILLE, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Mr. Magoo, a light-brown quarter horse, has been declared equine non grata by the Village Board.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Sept. 9 -- Thousands of Indonesian demonstrators wrecked the Indian Embassy here today. The attack came after Foreign Minister Subandrio of Indonesia said that India was committing aggression against Pakistan.

A nationwide committee of former high government officials, financiers, educators and business executives announced today its support of "President Johnson's proposals to bring about a viable peace in Vietnam."
Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and Societe Le Nickel of France announced yesterday the formation of two companies for the manufacture of nickel products in North America.

GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., Sept. 9 -- Bishop James A. Pike of San Francisco was absolved today of any heresy by the Episcopal House of Bishops. But he was given a mild rebuke on the subject of deaconesses in the church.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes advised Robert Moses yesterday that he was indeed keeping his "hair shirt on."

Terra Chemicals International, Inc., a newly formed company, announced yesterday it would build a $52 million chemical fertilizer complex to supply ammonia and nitrogen fertilizer to the Midwest. It said it would also supply the Great Plains and Rocky Mountains areas and parts of Canada.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A young Negro from Greenwood, Miss., told a Justice Department official today he believed his half-brother had been murdered as a warning against Negro voter registration.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., a major domestic builder of large steam generating units, is planning to acquire the National Tank Company, based in Tulsa, Okla. The proposed transaction, announced yesterday, would involve stock worth $53 million.
The massive increase in crime that has been going on in New York and elsewhere across the nation has made the twin issues of lawbreaking and public safety of prime importance in the current campaign.
PEKING, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- Indian diplomats walked out of a reception here tonight when Premier Chou En-lai bitterly accused their country of "armed aggression."
A fourth M -- music, in this instance -- has been added to the familiar 3M (Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company) line with the debut of a background music system called the "Cantata-3M 700."
The Alabama Power Company's $40 million issue of bonds was offered yesterday to investors at a price to yield 4.83 per cent, a new high this year for securities rated A by Moody's Investors Service.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., the nation's second largest publicly owned textile producer, achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 151-year history in the three and nine months ended July 31, according to a report issued yesterday by the company.

WHEN Arthur McBride founded the Cleveland Browns almost two decades ago as one of the charter members of the ill-starred All-America Conference, he virtually cornered the talent market. He had more good players than he could fit onto his roster.
Copper and sugar futures prices moved slightly upward yesterday in fairly active trading, but for widely different reasons.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 -- India bolstered her homefront today with clubs, flashlights and sandbags.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Fred Newman gained his 12th triumph of the season today as he pitched the California Angels to a 7-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Johnson Administration took its first official look today at the state of the economy following the step-up in Vietnam and the steel labor settlement, and found the outlook better than ever.
At the half-way point in the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament yesterday, Bobby Fischer of the United States. Borislav Ivkov of Yugoslavia: and Vassily Smyslov of the Soviet Union were on top.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A crowd of young Paktanis chanting "Yankee go home" ripped down the American flag from the United States Consulate today, marched two blocks and burned the flag in Post Office Square.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins blasted Joe Horlen for four runs in the first two innings today, then coasted behind the pitching of Jim Kaat and Al Worthington to crush the second-place Chicago White Sox, 10-4.

THE Robert Joffrey Ballet made its official New York debut at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park last night with four works new to New York. The company and its dances were accompanied by an orchestra under the direction of Maurice Peress, and by rain.
An ornate, gold-painted Victorian chair that has been reserved for 115 years will serve as the papal throne when Pope Paul VI visits Cardinal Spellman on Oct. 4.

" The Man Who Looked Like the Prince of Wales," a contemporary novel by Frederick Manfred, is scheduled for Sept. 23 by Trident Press. It deals with the conflict between a young man and the small rural town in which he lives.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 -- The hurricane advancing on this city intervened in a Federal Court lawsuit against the Ku Klux Klan today and reprieved a worried Klansman threatened with jail for contempt of court.

Robert Moses and William F. R. Ballard, chairman of the City Planning Commission, have become embroiled in a controversy over Mr. Ballrd's right to see highway plans being made under Mr. Moses' direction.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- Two close associates of former Premier George Papandreou accused him today of having plotted a military coup to force King Constantine to keep him in power. The accusations implied that the King had averted the coup because he had been warned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Juan Marichal made his first start today in Candlestick Park since his suspension was lifted and hurled the National League-leading Giants to a 4-0 triumph over Houston. The victory was the sixth in a row for the Giants.

HOUSTON, Sept. 9 -- The world's two most experienced space pilots said today they knew of nothing that should prevent man from making even longer flights than the eight days they spent aboard the Gemini 5.

New York City teachers will undoubtedly agree with Representative John Lindsay's compelling analysis of the current stalemate between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers reported in The Times of Sept. 2.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 -- For the first time in three days, the war did not appear to have expanded today.

The head of the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinic group in the United States asserted yesterday that, despite "minor cracks of light," the situation of Soviet Jews remained grave because of continuing suppression of religious and cultural privileges.
A Puerto Rican Mayor, who brought $3,126 in contributions, has intervened as a street campaigner in the contest for the Democratic nomination for Bronx Borough President.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- What may be a significant split among top Soviet ideologists came to light today as the editor of Pravda, the Communist party organ, accused Izvestia, the Government newspaper, of seeking to curtail intellectual freedom.

I would like to comment on the Aug. 24 news article "Louisiana Forms a Biracial Panel." I am a "second-class" citizen of Louisiana, former CORE project director, and I wish to speak out against the biracial panel.
Business loans at the 13 reporting commercial banks declined by $42 million during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The New York Mailers Union No. 6 broke off negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City yesterday and called a Sunday meeting of its membership.

The American Shakespeare Festival is undergoing reorganization. The post of artistic director will be abolished in favor of a team of three directors, it was disclosed yesterday by Joseph Verner Reed, who is in charge of the festival.
The Boston Maine Railroad shortly will file a petition with the interstate Commerce Commission asking to be included in the Norfolk Western-Nickel Plate System.

A complainant in a housing discrimination case and two landlords who had allegedly refused to rent her an apartment in Brooklyn reached a settlement yesterday through a consent order that pinned guilt on no one.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 9 -Near the end of last season, Alex Bell, head football coach at Villanova, found himself envisioning an unbeaten slate. His eleven had swept through its first six games convincingly and it seemed ready to go all the way.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane charged yesterday that John Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, was "trying to buy his way into City Hall."
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 9 -- The Board of Education removed Robert T. LeVine as principal of Hillhouse High School tonight "for failure to properly supervise the issuance of college transcripts."

New York's barge and tugboat industry is opposed to any legislation that would declare an area along the East River from East 17th Street to East 30th Street, Manhattan, as a nonnavigable waterway so that the stretch could be filled in for the erection of public and private buildings.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 9 --Mordecai Luk, the "man in the trunk," was convicted today of spying for the United Arab Republic. He could be sentenced to life imprisonment, which generally means 20 years here.
John K. Maitland has been elected a vice president of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc. He will also continue as president of Warner Bros. Records, Inc., a subsidiary of Warner Bros. Pictures.

The United Nations International School, which is seeking to erect a building to house classes for children of United Nations personnel on a pier in the East River, yesterday arranged to sell an Upper East Side parcel it had previously planned as the school site.
OTTAWA, Sept. 9 -- U Thant, the Secretary General of the United Nations, appealed again today for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations and to any world disarmament conference.

Available underground water sources in the five boroughs can supply 24.4 gallons a person here daily, according to a Health Department study that became public yesterday. Normal domestic use here has been variously estimated at 60 to 90 gallons a person daily.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 9 -- President Fernando Belaunde Terry said today that alarmists at home and abroad had "greatly exaggerated" the importance of Communist guerrilla activities in the Peruvian Andes.
The Franklin Society Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Century Federal Savings and Loan Association have been holding merger negotiations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 -- Standing 10 feet from Chief Justice Earl Warren and before a roomful of Federal judges, former New York Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy today accused the Supreme Court of "unduly hampering" the administration of criminal justice, while "vicious beasts" were loose on the streets.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9 -- Growing differences between Charles Evers, the Mississippi civil rights leader and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People may soon cost Mr. Evers his job with the organization, civil rights sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee, headed by 82-year-old Representative Howard W. Smith, Democrat of Virginia, buried today a bill for a study of conversion to the metric system.

Daniel D. Kinley has been appointed president of the McCann-Erickson Corporation (International), it was announced yesterday. Mr. Kinley's appointment marks his return to the McCann organization after nearly four years as executive vice president and general manager of H.P. Hood Sons.
ABOARD U.S.S. INDEPENDENCE, off South Vietnam, Sept. 9 -- The United States Navy taught Nguyen Cao Ky something about aircraft carriers today, and he taught it something about French dressing.

MOOSE, Wyo., Sept. 9 -- Laurance S. Rockefeller said today that five prominent conservation organizations were being merged for more effective action to preserve natural beauty and make it accessible to more Americans.
The two leading contenders for the Democratic mayoral nomination met in the first television debate of the primary campaign last night, and found themselves in entirely predictable disagreement.

The World Series once more poses a conflict in dates between baseball and professional football. The conflict centers on one game, between the Minnesota Vikings and the New York Giants, scheduled for Oct. 10 in Metropolitan Stadium, Bloomington, Minn.
The British pound renewed its firming trend yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

The construction of the proposed $110 million Lower Manhattan Expressway would be "a substantial detriment to the people of Manhattan," Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan, told Mayor Wagner in a letter yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- A Soviet general said today that the United States was developing a manned orbital space laboratory to be able to bombard the earth with nuclear bombs.
The nation's electric power production rose 2.9 per cent in the week ended Sept. 4, from the level in the 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
THE zeal of Walter Hoving, merchant, executive, civic-minded citizen and crusader for community causes, is sharply laced with grins -- as often as not directed at himself.

Massachusetts Superior Court Judge Frederick Pillsbury issued a temporary order yesterday restraining Whitin Machine Works, Whitinsville, Mass., from seeking shareholder approval of a proposed tender offer for its stock by White Consolidated Industries, Inc., Cleveland.
HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- A new Tibetan leader has emerged under Peking's sponsorship to replace the Dalai Lama and the Panchen Lama.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 10 -- United States marines killed 17 Vietcong in what was described as a "very fierce" fight yesterday afternoon.
The day that Mahatma Ganhi died a Pakistani delegate walked across the shabby lounge of the temporary United Nations headquarters at Lake Success and took the Indian delegate by the hand.
Until apprentice jockeys have a better day, yesterday will have to do as the day the bugs took over the Big A.
DIESEL-POWERED pleasure boats may never wind up smelling like roses, but a New Jersey company has developed a deodorant it says can at least make them smell like talcum powder.
PARIS, Sept 9 (Reuters) -Following, in unofficial translations, are excerpts from the news conference held by President de Gaulle today:

LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Henry H. Fowler, the United States Secretary of the Treasury, discussed international monetary problems for more than two hours today with Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan.
Prices turned mixed in dull trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Mercenary-led Congo Army troops secured an outpost today after killing 36 rebels in one of the bloodiest actions since last year's leftist revolt.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 9 -- An international conference on the future of the Danube River has been snubbed by the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Rumania.

The Willowbrook State School on Staten Island is the largest institution for mentally retarded patients in the United States -- a vast repository for feeble-minded and sometimes physically handicapped human beings, including some who have the minds of a 3-year-old in 45-year-old bodies.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9 The Senate gave its approval today to President Eduardo Frei Montalva's copper "Chileanization" bill, ending weeks of intense political tension and signaling the start of a new phase in fundamental reforms instituted by Latin America's first Christian Democratic administration.
Trading activity on the American Stock Exchange was the heaviest in almost three months yesterday although advances just barely outnumbered losses.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Parents in three predominantly Negro districts defied city authorities today by attempting to enroll their children in predominantly white schools in other areas of Boston.
BONN, Sept. 9 -- Defense Minister Kai Uwe von Hassel accepted for West Germany today the first new Leopard class tank to roll off the assembly line.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 9 -- Westchester's unusual countywide organization that solicits charitable gifts from countyiwide corporations for distribui tion to 15 communits: chests and funds in local municipaliIti,s set out today to obtain $3.150.000 for the current year. Ttiis is an increase of 18 per cent collected ill the county fund's recently completed first year of ope,'ation.

AREA A -- The fall decline appears to be setting in with some species, but the fishing for sea bass remains good out of Brielle. Some porgies, but blues are slow. Party boats making the long run offshore are taking cod and pollack over 20 pounds.
A $10 million fall and holiday advertising and sales promotion campaign was announced yesterday for the home-instruments division of the Radio Corporation of America.

I have read with interest your editorial and L.K. Edwards's letter, both in your Aug. 30 issue, regarding high-speed rail transit. It would appear that too much, not too little, emphasis is being placed upon unorthodox proposals and methods for alleviating the transportation mess in the Corridor and in other urban centers.
ROME, Sept. 9 -- Pope Paul VI will appeal to the "moral conscience" of the world for peace in his appearance before the United Nations Oct. 4, according to an authoritative Vatican voice.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 -- Concern is growing here about a possible Chinese Communist intervention in India's undeclared war with Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Johnson called today for a strengthening of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, both as a military shield and as an instrument of political cooperation.

President de Gaulle now has publicly confirmed all his private hints and warnings of recent months about the future structure of the West. He has declared "integration" anathema. And he has launched a massive assault upon all the imaginative institutions of European and Atlantic unity built over two decades to channel into constructive enterprises the parochial nationalisms that proved so destructive in the past.
A coffee expert, Andres Uribe Campuzano, has been named director of the newly established Colombian Center, 140 E. 57th St., it was anounced yesterday by the Colombian Government.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy charged yesterday that the state was failing woefully to provide proper care for its mentally retarded children. He said he had seen youngsters " slipping into blankness" in state institutions amid "dimness and gloom and idleness and stench."
INDIA'S Defense Minister, Yeshwantrao Balwantrao Chavan, is facing in the undeclared war with Pakistan a test of the principles that brought him to power.
THE third New York Film Festival scored its first hit last night with the showing of "The Shop on High Street," a Czechoslovak film.

Several letters have appeared in your columns recently decrying the actions of King Constantine as frustrating the democratic aspirations of the Greek people and supporting former Premier George Papandreou as the champion of "traditional democratic feelings."
JULLUNDUR, India, Sept. 9 -- Forty-five miles from the Pakistani border, timeless India seemed at peace today.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Professional football is the sport of the Johnny Unitases, the Jimmy Browns, the Joe Namaths. It is the sport of the talented, the skilled, the young capitalists.
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- President de Gaulle served notice today that after 1969 France would no longer accept an integrated Western defense system.

YONKERS, Sept. 9 -- Elaine Rodney, the American-bred. Italian-owned trotting mare may have been in some hard races during her long and illustrious career on both sides of the Atlantic, but tonight's $50,000. Transoceanic Trot was not one of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen put the Johnson-Administration on notice today that he would lead a bipartisan coalition "of at least 25 senators" to block enactment of a bill to repeal section 14 (b) -- the "right to work" clause -- of the Taft-Hartley Act.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- R.H. Macy Co. has acquired option on 80 acres in Bardonia, two miles south of New City, the county seat, for a large retail outlet to be opened late in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Johnson unveiled today a new five-cent Adlai Stevenson commemorative stamp and described the late United Nations representative as one who "skillfully and beautifully helped shape the dialogue of 20th century democracy."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Johnson signed legislation today creating a Department of Housing and Urban Affairs to help the nation's cities solve their mounting problems.
City mediators announced last night that representatives of the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers had reached agreement on all contract issues except "money matters."

Paramount Pictures Corporation has made an application to a Federal Court here to vacate an attempt by dissident directors, Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest H. Martin, to obtain depositions from nine of its directors and special counsel, Louis Nizer, before the determination of Paramount's suit against Messrs. Siegel and Martin.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- The Afrikaner businessman, a rising figure in the South African power structure, has broken through to the upper echelons of the gold mining industry.
In congratulating you on your fine news reports and editorial (Sept. 3 and 4) on Marshal Lin Piao's article, I urge that we meet Mao's challenge in Vietnam by waging a political war.
George Goodman, a real estate investor, has contracted to purchase the 22-story office and showroom building at 363 Seventh Avenue, northeast corner of 30th Street, for a sum in excess of $1,200,000.
ROME, Sept. 9 -- The Vatican today banned the loan of practically all of its works of art to anybody, anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Organized labor is waging an intense campaign on Capitol Hill against any change in the policy requiring that half of any wheat sales to the Soviet Union must be carried in American ships.
MIAMI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Residents of southeast Florida began today to clear the debris left by yesterday's hurricane.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 -- The United Nations Secretary General, U Thant, began discussions today with President Mohammad Ayub Khan and other Pakistani lead ers in a desperate effort to halt the undeclared war between Pakistan and India.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 -- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers pitched a perfect game tonight in a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs and became the first pitcher in baseball history to pitch four no-hitters in his career.

Although Robert Moses was once chairman of the City Planning Commission, he no longer loves it. When it politely asked him, as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, about his plans for improving the West Side elevated highway, he rejected the query with characteristic vehemence. Chairman William F.R. Ballard reminded Mr. Moses that the era of such arbitrary and unilateral planning is dead.
The election of three new vice presidents and a realignment on Oct. 1 of responsibilities of some other key management personnel were announced yesterday by the General Foods Corporation.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 -- Pakistani troops pushed back Indian thrusts in the Lahore area today and crossed into Indian territory at two points, official Pakistani spokesmen said.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Indian air force bombers raided Karachi tonight for the seventh time in three days, bombing the waterfront of the city, Pakistan's largest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Retail sales advanced 4 per cent in the week ended Sept. 4 and were 7 per cent higher than in the corresponding 1964 week, the Commerce Department announced today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The Indonesian Government apologized today for the sacking of the Indian Embassy and attacks on the information service and library building, but publicly applauded the demonstrators.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 9 -This year's sophomores appear to hold the key to Lafayette's football fortunes this season and for two additional seasons to come. This season they are expected to handle 50 per cent of the front-line work.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 9 -- King Mahendra of Nepal, in identical letters to President Sarvepalli Radhakrishanan and President Mohammad Ayub Khan, has appealed for peace between India and Pakistan. The King suggested that the United Nations Security Council resolutions provided a basis for peace.
ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- The marble monuments of the 2,400-year-old Acropolis made a spectacular setting for the exhibition of modern masterpieces of sculpture that opened in Athens yesterday.

Your front-page Sept. 5 news article on the continuing huge death toll of highway accidents in the United States was good in presenting the problem, but offered no definite solution. There is one immediately available to every American state and community: to increase substantially the number of police patrolling our streets and highways.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 9 -- Brig. Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin left the Dominican Republic tonight to become his country's consul general in Miami.

TEAM-OF-FOUR contests involving long head-to-head matches continue to increase in popularity. Several clubs in the metropolitan area now include such events in their schedules, and attract many entries.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Proceeds of a flea market, to be held in the Lord Taylor parking lot rain or shine on Sunday, will go to the national organization of the American Cancer Society for research, education and service.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 -- The Cincinnati Reds had to go all out to beat the New York Mets tonight and to retain their position half a game behind league-leading San Francisco in the National League pennant race.
NEW ORLEANS, Friday, Sept. 10 -- Hurricane Betsy slammed into New Orleans late last night, forcing thousands of residents to flee homes threatened with flooding.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Sept. 9 -- The American Motors Corporation, troubled by lagging sales and a paralyzing labor dispute, introduced its 1966 models here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A Senate-House conference committee reached a compromise today on a disputed proposal to restrict imports of "protective footwear" -- boots, galoshes and overshoes.

HICKSTEAD, England, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Marion Coakes and Allion Westwood, two of Britain's leading horsewomen, demonstrated their championship form to riders from three other countries today by taking the first three places in the first leg of the women's world show jumping championship.

Representative John V. Lindsay charged yesterday that his campaign had been the target of harassment that included the breaking of windows, the ripping out of telephones, the destruction of mail and the threatening of volunteer workers.

The biggest merger in the electric utilities industry since the days of the gigantic holding companies of the nineteen-twenties and thirties is being considered by Ohio's two largest electric utilities.

FIERY RUN, Va., Sept. 9 -- On a long flight from Vietnam to Virginia, there is time to reflect on the American war effort in Southeast Asia and the even more complex political crisis in Asia as a whole.

" SNAPPY" is Hazel Hotchkiss Wightman's word for the new tennis styles shown yesterday on the green lawns of Forest Hills Stadium. Mrs. Wightman, who "bats balls for her friends' great-great-grandchildren these days" (she teaches 20 pupils a week) ordinarily wears a proper tennis dress to her knees.

A decline of 3,468,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies totaled 187,103,000 barrels, compared with 190,571,000 a week earlier and 186,239,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A Senate-House conference committee reached a compromise today on a disputed proposal to restrict imports of "protective footwear" -- boots, galoshes and overshoes.

HICKSTEAD, England, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Marion Coakes and Allion Westwood, two of Britain's leading horsewomen, demonstrated their championship form to riders from three other countries today by taking the first three places in the first leg of the women's world show jumping championship.

Representative John V. Lindsay charged yesterday that his campaign had been the target of harassment that included the breaking of windows, the ripping out of telephones, the destruction of mail and the threatening of volunteer workers.

The biggest merger in the electric utilities industry since the days of the gigantic holding companies of the nineteen-twenties and thirties is being considered by Ohio's two largest electric utilities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The fighting between India and Pakistan over Kashmir is "perhaps the most serious conflict" between member states of the United Nations in the history of the organization, Arthur J. Goldberg warned today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -"Is there no top to the current expansion of the United States economy? How much longer can it last? Aren't we going to pay a price for these good times?"

COMEDY with the 007 label of James Bond and serious advancement of a tenet of the United Nations would seem uneasy thematic bedfellows in the same hour-long film. They are, at least as rendered in the Telsun Foundation's latest project, "Once Upon a Tractor."

Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which contains most of the Cleveland metropolitan area, made its first major bond sale since 1961 yesterday by selling $12,487,455 of securities to finance a variety of municipal facilities.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 9 -- More than 13,000 families in Kenya are threatened with starvation, Daniel arap Mois, Minister for Home Affairs, stated today.
THE 18th century will be revived for a week at Altman's starting Monday, when the store begins a series of craft demonstrations connected with the Williamsburg restoration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A Cuban exile, who used to go spearfishing with Premier Fidel Castro and who organized one of the Premier's early elite forces, has been arrested in Havana during a desperate attempt to rescue his wife and three children and take them out of Cuba.
The Pentagon is considering moving the 700-employe headquarters of the worldwide Army and Air Force post exchange from here to another city.
The stock market surprised both Wall Street and Main Street yesterday with its fifth successive advance, as prices moved up along a wide front in the heaviest trading since the end of June.

" I Spy," said to be the first weekly network television show to present a Negro as co-star in an integrated cast, has been accepted by more than 180 affiliated stations of the National Broacasting Company network. With what amounts to full network clearance, N.B.C. no longer need be apprehensive about the response of many stations, especially in the South.
Following are excerpts from Senator Robert F. Kennedy's statement yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation:

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Oscar W. Mellick of Round Hill and Mrs. Henry Kirkland of Apawamis took a one-stroke lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 12th annual Class A better ball of partners championship today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -Total business inventories rose by $850 million in July, the largest rise since March, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodger pitcher, Don Drysdale, said today he was considering a rich offer to play baseball in Japan.
The New York A.F.L.-C.I.O. called yesterday for a compulsory hospital insurance program for all workers in the state.

Hugh K. McGovern is president of U.S. Properties, which sold the four-story hotel at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 50th Street to Irving Maidman. Mr. McGovern was incorrectly identified as the broker in the deal, which was reported in these columns last Thursday.

SHAW wrote somewhere that the only good reason for depicting "real life" in a work of art was to introduce a new morality. This is a debatable dictum, but one that a certain distinguished strain of "realism" in American writing seems, nevertheless, to honor. In their exploration of resolutely plain settings and humble charac ters, the works of Edgar Lee Masters and Sherwood Anderson conveyed, if not a new morality.
KARACHI, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- A Government spokesman today reported new Pakistani Air Force raids in India's Punjab region. He dismissed Indian assertions of heavy damage to the Pakistani Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Johnson Administration, sensing a lack of force behind mediation efforts in the United Nations, is looking for ways to use economic sanctions to help end the conflict between India and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A political science analysis of the 1964 Presidential election, released tonight, challenged the view that the Republican party has slipped so far it may never recover enough strength to defeat the Democrats again.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Ben O'Meara, a one-time Brooklyn blacksmith, made the trek north for the first time this season today and promptly won an open jumper class as the North Shore Horse Show opened a four-day run at the Old Field Club.

Records of the Dart Realty Company of Brooklyn have been seized by District Attorney Aaron E. Koota in his investigation of Mafia activity in real estate, construction work and banking on Long Island, he announced yesterday.
It was a black day for the United States at Forest Hills in the national tennis championships yesterday.
The Port of New York is down to what may be its last grain cargo, the Port of New York Authority warned yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Briardale Farm's champion, Tosmah, out of competition since January because of injuries, today coasted to a nine-length victory in the seven-furlong feature race. Sam Boulmetis rode the 4-year-old filly.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The Imperial Chemical Industries issue of 50 million 8140 million loan stock was 21 times oversubscribed tonight by the time weary tellers had finished counting the huge stacks of applications.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Washington Senators won their 63d game tonight -- a record for their five expansion years -- when they defeated California, 4-1, and moved to within 2 1/2 games of the seventh-place Angels.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 10 -- A case that opened in a magistrate's court in Nairobi today is expected to leave exposed some of the rust that has gathered on the machinery of President Jomo Kenyatta's one-party state.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday a "stunning" decrease of 61.5 per cent in the number of nighttime arrests and complaints in the subways from last April 7, when extra policemen began patrolling all trains and platforms, to Sept. 7.

TWO record-breaking tournaments were staged in Chicago last month. Immediately following the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which set a world record for attendance at any tournament, was the annual summer tournament of the American Bridge Association, which has a predominantly Negro membership.

Bonn, Sept. 10 -- Karl Gunther von Hase, chief spokesman for the West German Government, said today that Bonn, like President de Gaulle, desired a "tightening" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The 27th Westchester Cotillion was held tonight at the Shenorock Shore Club for the presentation of 46 debutantes. In the ballroom, decorated with white flowers and garlanded with green leaves, the young women, each carrying a gardenia bouquet, were presented by their fathers to their mothers, who were seated at one end of the ballroom.

The Publishers Association of New York City said yesterday that if the Newspaper Guild struck The New York Times next week and The Times was unable to publish, the other member newspapers would close.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Retail sales, after rising strongly in July, fell back again in August, the Commerce Department reported today.
Profit taking hit the stock market yesterday, but not hard enough to prevent stock prices from moving up again to close out a week of gains.

Joseph Traficante, 50-year-old mandolin-playing minstrel of Washington Square Park, was found guilty yesterday of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest after a two-day trial in Criminal Court. However, he was found not guilty of violating Park Department rules, a charge of which he had been acquitted in a previous case.

United States importers of airborne merchandise are expected to save both time and money through the adoption of a new streamlined customs handling system at Kennedy International Airport, the Air Transportation Association of America said yesterday.

The head of the United States Trade Center in Frankfurt said yesterday that although West Germany was buying about $2 billion of American goods a year, there is still plenty of room to better that performance.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates took advantage of Joey Jay's wildness and rode Willie Stargell's three-run homer to a 7-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Willie McCovey, a pinch-hitter, smashed a tie-breaking grand-slam homer in the sixth inning tonight as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5-2, and clung to their slim National League lead.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- A special session of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association will be held here Oct. 2 and Oct. 3.
VAMPS don't slink any more. They look pure, rather cuddly and distressingly young -- according to Revillon of Paris, which is saying that boudoirs will reflect charm rather than the obvious.

Representative Lester L. Wolff, New York Democrat accused the trading-stamp companies yesterday of "disgraceful" conduct in declining to attend an informal hearing he had called to study the question whether stamps add to consumer costs.
THE first motion pictures made atop Mount Everest were shown last night in the National Geographic Society's Television debut on the Columbia Broadcasting System Network.
I would like to voice my support of the Pakistani position in the Kashmiri conflict, and suggest that perhaps too much has been made, incorrectly, of the legacy of Gandhi and Nehru.
The World Bank approved yesterday two loans totaling $45 million -- $25 million to help finance a toll expressway in Kobe, Japan, and $20 million for the Industrial Development Bank of Israel, Ltd.
United Presbyterians will devote two full days beginning Thursday to the Ecumenical Council Vatican II, scheduled to reconvene on Tuesday in Rome.

In January 1963 an official Board of Education bulletin on the Higher Horizons program noted that "If within a reasonable period of time the level of academic functioning has not been raised, then our effort must be adjudged largely a failure."

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Bank of England announced today that unspecified "new arrangements" had been made with the United States and nine other countries to bolster the recent improvement in the pound's strength.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Treasury emphasized today that the new package of standby assistance for the pound was put together "in an economic and financial environment very different from that of last November."
NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 -- The picture of the Indian-Pakistani fighting that emerged tonight was one of an inconclusive struggle along virtually all the Indian-West Pakistani border.
CAIRO, Sept. 10 -- About 25 Congolese Insurgents were flown out of Cairo early this morning in a United Arab Republic Government-chartered plane bound for Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

B.K. Nehru, Indian Ambassador to the United States, and Ghulam Ahmed, Pakistani Ambassador, will appear on television tomorrow to answer questions about the armed conflict between India and Pakistan. Separate interviews, to be taped earlier in the day, will be presented from 1:30 to 2 P.M. on "Issues and Answers" over the American Broadcasting Company network.
PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz of Poland expressed his gratitude to France tonight for having recognized the Oder-Neisse border between Poland and East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Communist China's military intervention in the conflict between India and Pakistan remains low on the list of Administration concerns at the moment.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, said today that the Indian-Pakistani conflict, coupled with the war in Vietnam, "still aggravates the situation in Southeast Asia."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Two Senators and two Representatives were honored tonight with the Congressional Distinguished Service Awards of the American Political Science Association.

Eleven thousand electrified, deliriously happy onlookers in the Forest Hills Stadium saw Arthur Ashe reach full maturity as a tennis player of the first class and defeat the world's ranking amateur yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 -- President Johnson flew here late this afternoon to inspect the sad wreckage of the hurricane.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Senate voted overwhelmingly today in favor of a major change in the nation's cotton program -- the first in the 30 years of farm subsidies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 11 -- A wave of United States B-52 bombers struck a suspected Vietcong concentration 325 miles northeast of Saigon yesterday in an area dominated for years by the Communists.
The H.J. Heinz Company achieved record sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended July 28, according to figures reported yesterday to stockholders at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh.

Because the majority of legislative districts in New York City are overwhelmingly Democratic, the outcome of Tuesday's Democratic primary contests, and not the November general election, will determine in many cases who will represent the city at Albany.
Directors of the Tidewater Company voted yesterday to discontinue consideration of proposals to purchase the Western company's marketing and manufacturing facilities.

The automobile industry was the target yesterday of lawmakers, civic-minded citizens, air pollution experts and a blonde actress who complained the city's air was so "grimy" that she worked overtime to wash it out of her hair.
The city will be paid more than $2 million a year from the operation of La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports under new leasing arrangemets announced yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.

THE second floor of Abercrombie Fitch has had its face lifted. It looks like the kind of woman preferred by Earle Angstadt Jr., its 39-year-old president: "well-groomed, neat, sophisticated, and with a touch of flair."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 (Reuters ) -- Pakistan reported gains today in three areas of the conflict with India. President Mohammad Ayub Khan called on his people to "throw the intruder from Pakistani soil and carry the fight to the enemy's country."
