The directors of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation voted yesterday to invite the company's stockholders to tender their common stock.

James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, decided not to press charges in Children's Court yesterday against five boys who stole money, two wristwatches and a diamond ring from a bureau drawer in his apartment Thursday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The richest running, insofar as victory is concerned, of the world's richest thoroughbred horse race will take place at Arlington Park tomorrow. A field of 102-year-old colts will compete in the $335,475 Arlington-Washington Futurity over the sprint distance of seven furlongs and the winner will earn the sum of $190,475, a world record for thoroughbred racing.

MADRID, Sept. 10 -- President de Gaulle's remarks on the future of Europe at his news conference yesterday seemed to offer little immediate hope that Spain's desire to become associated with the European Common Market was any nearer fulfillment.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 (AP) -- India strongly protested to the Indonesian Government today the sacking of the Indian Embassy and seizure of the Indian Information Center.
News of fresh support for the British pound raised prices on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and enabled many issues to close the day on their best levels.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Jim Turnesa and Jordon Krown of the Mill River Country Club, with 33, 32 -- 65, and Gil Cavanaugh and James Bostwick of the Meadow Brook Club, with 31, 34 -- 65, tied for low honors today in the Long Island Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament at the Rockville Links' par 72, 6,396-yard course.
Pepsico, Inc., formerly known as the Pepsi-Cola Company, is further diversifying its activities, but this time it is seeking to enter the finance field and the leasing of vehicles and equipment.
ATHENS, Sept. 10 -- King Constantine conferred with outgoing Premier Elias Tsirimokos today amid growing indications that a new Government will be named early next week.
Wishful thinking pushed up most potato futures prices yesterday in active trading, just as it had done the preceding day.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday "there is no doubt that restrictions' imposed by recent Supreme Court decisions "have made law enforcement more difficult."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- A new weapon in the United States arsenal for its perpetual struggle to keep the economy stable, healthy and vigorous -- the tax cut -- has met its first test.
NICE, France, Sept. 10 -- Something has changed in the world's most famous playground.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes decided yesterday to let Robert Moses have his way on the overhead highway signs urging people to visit the World's Fair before it closes.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Somewhere in the United States there is a pair of black alligator cowboy boots with the initials "LBJ" on them. But no one seems to know where they are.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- A Pravda editorial in which anti-Semitism is condemned is being given unusually wide circulation in the Soviet Union.
Maritime law experts from 23 countries will begin a weeklong conference Monday in an attempt to develop a uniform convention on maritime liens and mortgages on ships.
DALLAS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Judge Louis T. Holland refused today to grant a writ of habeas corpus that would have set aside the murder conviction of Jack Ruby.
Representative John V. Lindsay's chief political advisers are hoping that Paul R. Screvane will win the Democratic mayoral primary next Tuesday.
Indians and Pakistanis rubbed elbows amicably this week in the Kashmir Restaurant on West 45th Street while their countries' armies struggled for the state whose name it bears.

Robert Agger, Daniel Goldrich and Bert Swanson, authors of "The Rulers and the Ruled: Political Power and Impotence in American Communities," have received the Woodrow Wilson Foundation Book Award for the best book on government, political science or international affairs published in 1964.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that crop prospects increased nearly 1 per cent during August to put the indicated harvest 7 per cent above last year's, and 4 per cent above the record set in 1963.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 10 -- The first day's run of the annual invitation cruise of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club was sailed today in a moderate breeze of about eight knots. The 23 boats started in four divisions at mid-Sound Whistler Buoy 32 A in a light fog, which soon lifted, providing ideal sailing conditions.
THERE is no doubt about it -- the Robert Joffrey Ballet is a stunning company bristling with talent, imagination and the courage to be daring and different.
The New York Mets did not prove much of a stumbling block to the pennant hopes of the Milwaukee Braves in Shea Stadium last night.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Ken Harrelson drove in five runs with a pair of doubles and his 19th homer tonight to lead the Kansas City Athletics to a 10-5 victory over Baltimore after the Orioles had won the first game, 5-2, on three successive homers in the eighth inning.
Domestic news appeared more important to the bond market yesterday than international developments.
The British pound advanced sharply yesterday in response to the Bank of England's announcement of new arrangements designed to support sterling in case of a crisis.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 10 -- Dominican leftist leaders said today that the departure of Brig. Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin from the country was not a sufficient concession for the surrender of their arms to the provisional Government.

A Marine battalion commander in Vietnam is under investigation because he utilized nonlethal tear gas to clear a cave and tunnel system of suspected Vietcong, allegedly in violation of policy regulations established by the United States commander in Vietnam. It seems unlikely that the Marine colonel deliberately violated orders; if he did, disobedience cannot be defended.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Mickey Lolich's four-hit pitching and Mickey Stanley's two-run single to center in the fifth inning enabled the Detroit Tigers to beat the Cleveland Indians tonight 2-0.

YONKERS, Sept. 10 -- Great Pleasure, a 9-year-old mare who had only one horse -- and a "breaking" horse, at that -- beaten with little more than a quarter-mile remaining, rallied and sped between horses to win the $20,000 Rodney Trot Festival final tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
LISBON, Sept. 10 -- Vintage time has come early this year to Portugal, bringing with it the old merrymaking and new prospects for the wine industry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on the final text of a bill extending through July 31, 1967, the special tax on purchases of foreign securities.

The statement, "They should go to Vietnam, where we need soldiers to kill Vietcong," attributed in The New York Times of Sept. 7 to Criminal Court Judge Irving Schreckinger in the arraignment of two youths on a charge of murdering an East Side derelict, is an insult to the American service-men engaged in Vietnam.

Research aimed at preventing a blood disorder whose victims are unborn infants was described at a scientific meeting here yesterday. The meeting honored the man who discovered the ailment 26 years ago.

Alexander, it is said, wept when he had no more worlds to conquer. Architects, if this feeling be universal in the successful, must be feeling tearful now that they have solved almost every problem of modern living; but here could be a fresh field of endeavor to cheer them: the home visual arts room.

HICKSTEAD, England, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Kathy Kusner, an American Olympic rider from Arlington, Va., won the Hickstead Grand Stakes in a four-horse jumpoff today after advancing to second place in the over-all standing of the women's world horse show jumping championships on her first two rides.
THE trouble with many short stories is that they are too long. Their advertised brevity is inauthentic. A point a reader grasps in two minutes gains nothing by being nested in words for half an hour.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 -- Nguyen Thi Hoang, a winsome little 11-year-old, walked along one of this city's main streets tonight clutching in her hand a bamboo and cellophane lantern. It was in the shape of a tank.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy's charge that the state does not provide proper care for mentally retarded children is supported by the hitherto secret report of a special legislative team that made a four-month investigation a year ago.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 10 -- High Frontier, a 9-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Ward Acres Farm of Ridgefield, Conn., and handled by Dave Kelley, gained a tie for the open jumper lead at the North Shore Horse Show today.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 -- Pakistan stressed her adherence to the United Nations today, but she made it plain to the United Nations Secretary General, U Thant, that she would not consider a cease-fire in the undeclared war with India unless it carried a guarantee of a Kashmir plebiscite.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 10 -- Resorting to maneuvers that verged on slapstick, the security police managed today to sidestep two court orders to produce Isaac Heymann, the first man detained under a law that permits the Government to hold a possible state witness incommunicado for as long as 180 days.

Stanley Lowell, campaign manager for Paul R. Screvane, charged yesterday that an anti-Screvane flyer clearly violated the law. He called on District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to investigate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- A 39-year-old (plus) violinist was warmly welcomed today by 1,700 United Nations Secretariat workers at his debut in the flower-bedecked General Assembly hall.

Six and seven-million-share days, such as yesterday and Thursday -- or whenever they occur -- are by no means overlooked by the people at the New York Stock Exchange. They keep a particularly close watch on such active markets for evidence of speculative interest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Civil rights organizations began mobilizing their forces today against a move in the House of Representatives to dismiss a Mississippi seating contest.

Prospects appeared bleak yesterday for Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, in his postponed 10th-round match with Borislav Ivkov, the Yugoslav grand master, in the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament.
A new communications link between the United States and the Soviet Union was added yesterday with the opening by ITT World Communications, Inc. of telex communications between the two countries.

A new milestone in social attitudes is being reached by the Agency for International Development (AID), according to recent dispatches in The New York Times. The agency, it is reported, wishes to embark on a bold new program aimed at the eventual eradication of serious malnutrition among preschool children in the developing countries.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 -- Some observers felt tonight that India might be receptive to a cease-fire proposal that Mr. Thant is expected to bring with him from Pakistan.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 10 -- The Berkeley Jazz Band has an opening for a new banjo player, because Dr. Arthur Max Ross signed with a new combo in Washington. The name of the group may change, too, for the members have never really been happy, with dropping the former name, the East Lafayette March and Funeral Band.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 -- Hurricane Betsy dashed itself against lower Louisiana and Mississippi early today and ended a destructive journey that began 15 days ago in the Atlantic Ocean.
OMAHA, Sept. 10 -- The new New York Giants, who now list 22 players who did not belong to last year's team, will be exposed for better or for worse to a national television audience tomorrow.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 -- The danger that the Indian-Pakistani conflict would spread to East Pakistan increased sharply tonight with Indian reports of new ground and air clashes in the states of Assam and West Bengal.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Illinois State Water Survey received a patent this week for a method of reducing the transpiration of moisture by trees and plants.

Directors of the Marine Midland Corporation elected J. Peter Grace and Allen S. Rupley to the board yesterday. Mr. Grace is president of W.R. Grace Co., Inc., the big chemical and transportation concern, and Mr. Rupley is a director.
A 2-year-old Claiborne Farm filly was disqualified and placed last at Aqueduct yesterday after finishing fourth at 32-1, but today is another day.

The Board of Water Supply opened five thick envelopes containing bids for the rebuilding of the Hudson River pumping station at Chelsea, N.Y., yesterday and with Pleased surprise found that they were considerably lower than expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The New York Yankees hit the road tonight as the former champions of the American League and promptly exerted a bit of mischief into what was left of the pennant race by spilling the Chicago White Sox out of second place.

From 1946 to 1952, formative and fruitful years in the history of modern Japan, William J. Sebald occupied a key position in Tokyo as United States Political Adviser and senior State Department representative.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 -- Judging from the stringent security measures that are announced daily, the existence of this metropolis of two million people could be gravely threatened by the Indian-Pakistani war.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 10 -- Rumors sweeping Salisbury about an imminent Rhodesian declaration of independence from Britain intensified today. An impetus was given to the speculation by two unusual moves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Ewan Clague has resigned after 18 years as commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He will be replaced by Dr. Arthur Max Ross, a University of California economist.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10 -- One of Bogota's largest and busiest plazas, San Andresito, is not marked on the city maps. Nor does the two-square-block marketplace, in the heart of the city, exist so far as Bogota's officialdom is concerned.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Pope Paul VI will be received here Oct. 4 with honors greater than those accorded any chief of state except queen Elizabeth II of Britain, who visited the United Nations Oct. 21 1957.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Father Divine, founder and leader of the Peace Mission Cult, died at 2:20 A.M. today at Woodmont, the movement's 73-acre estate on the Philadelphia Main Line in Lower Merion Township.

The Adams Sponging Corporation of Boston and American-London Shrinkers of New England, Norwood, Mass., have joined forces to form the American London-Adams Bonding Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Faced with a worsening foreign trade and over-all payments situation, Mexico has begun a drive to increase exports, particularly manufactured goods.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Don Drysdale gained his 19th victory and tied a National League record by hitting his seventh homer of the season tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Houston Astros, 5-2.

Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., the second-ranking tennis player of the country, received the William Johnston Award yesterday.
AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 10 -- The principal attraction in the World Series of Golf, starting tomorrow, is a first prize of $50,000. It's the largest sum that any competitor in a golfing event can win.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 10 -- Hundreds of Negro and some white children are being barred from Mississippi's public schools this fall by a law that the State Legislature passed quietly this summer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, reversing an earlier suling, approved today sharply reduced grain-hauling rates for the Southern Railway from Mississippi and Ohio River crossings to points in the South.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Tidewater Oil Company has dropped a suit against three major oil competitors, accusing them of selling gasoline below cost in violation of the Rhode Island Unfair Sales Practices Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Johnson was told by his Water Resources Council today that emergency actions now under way should be enough to meet the "major water needs" of more than 25 million persons in the drought-stricken Northeast through next spring.
A new, interreligious organization, which will be called the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, was formed here this week to help Soviet Jews regain full religious freedom throughout the Soviet Union.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Radio music will be piped through a new intercom system at the recently renovated police headquarters building here for police personnel and prisoners in the cell block.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- A legislative committee was told today that convicted sex offenders in a state mental institution went to tea dances, ran a floating numbers and loan-shark operation, had affairs with college girls and mixed drinks in their ward.

DENVER, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Dedicating a university campus garden today, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said she hoped philanthropists would make "such wise and lasting donations to the beauty of the land and the joy of its inhabitants."
The American Stock Exchange ended the week on a strong note yesterday as most issues rose in moderate trading.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Negro parents expanded today the scope of their privately financed transportation system to move children out of crowded schools in their own precincts to predominantly white areas where classes tend to be smaller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Postmaster General John A. Gronouski was confirmed today by the Senate as United States Ambassador to Poland.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- The Roman Catholic draft declaration exonerating the Jews in the crucifixion of Jesus has been modified by elimination of the controversial word "deicide" from the text.

VILLANUEVA, DEL FRESNO, Spain, Sept. 10 -- A stark funeral service was held in this border town today for Humberto Delgado, the Portugese opposition leader mysteriously slain here last February.

New York City, threatened with traffic strangulation in its central business area, faces a fundamental decision. Should access of automobiles to midtown and lower Manhattan be encouraged by new expressways and parking garages, or should their entry be discouraged in favor of better mass transportation?

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- The directors of the Standard Products Company; at a special meeting today, authorized a general tender invitation to the shareholders, of 100,000 of the company's common shares at a price of $17.25 a share.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- British surgeons have succeeded in regulating a patient's heart beats by electrical pulses but without using direct wire connections.
TOKYO, Sept. 10 -- "Haro, Tokyo! Mata haro, Tokyo! Minnasan no utsukushi kuni ni kite ureshi. . . ."

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 -- Indian and Pakistani regular troops continued fighting today in a series of border regions extending from the Chenab River in the north to the Sutlej River in the south.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Johnson has ordered a two-year extension of active duty for Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, thus once again preventing the controversial developer of the atomic submarine from being forced into retirement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Rail freight carloadings in the week ended September 4 were the highest since the week ended June 26, Increases in grain, grain products and miscellaneous freight traffic raised the carloadings to their highest mark in more than two months.

Mayor Wagner, heeding a personal appeal from Daniel P. Moynihan, sought assurances from Queens Democratic district leaders yesterday that they would support Mr. Moynihan for City Council President in next Tuesday's primary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Administration laid the groundwork today for the expected abolition of a requirement that half of commerical wheat sales to Soviet Bloc countries must be carried in ships flying the United States flag.
KOSKOWO, Poland, Sept. 8 -- There is land enough to buy and money enough to buy it here in eastern Poland, but there is no one who wants to do the buying.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Babe Lichardus and Mrs. William Hockenjos of Baltusrol gained the semi-final round of the state pro-woman golf championship today at the Forest Hill Field Club.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 10 -- Officers of the State University of the New York told of arrangements here today for a $63 million branch in Westchester that will accent studies in the fine and performing arts.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Pope Paul's new encyclical, "Mysterium Fidei," is a traditional restatement of Roman Catholic doctrine on the Eucharist. It is of interest mainly to theologians. But, coming at a time when the Church's bishops are arriving in Rome for the final session of Ecumenical Council Vatican II, it is filled with practical significance.

EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Jo Ann Prentice of Pensacola, Fla., became the first woman pro in three days to break Eugene Country Club's par, shooting a two-under 70 today. It gave her a two-stroke lead going into the final round of the women's $10,000 Pacific Golf Classic. She had a 220 total.

THE veteran grand master, Dan Yanofsky of Winnipeg, Man., won the 56th Canadian Chess Championship recently over a strong 12-man field in Vancouver, B.C. Without losing a game outright in the round robin, Yanofsky won nine and drew two, for a total of 10 points.

IN the latter half of his life, Charles Dickens discovered a valuable talent: an ability to read movingly from his own work. Though enormously successful, these readings were of mixed benefits, serving as an outlet for his churning energies, releasing a Thespian side of his character and making him a great deal of money.

Six hundred and thirty passengers arrived back in New York yesterday after completing a trip to nowhere aboard the luxury liner Oceanic.

MARGUERITE YOUNG'S titanic novel has been in slow generation for more than 17 years. During this period, published sections of it have signaled, like surfaced bubbles, the dyamism of the submerged whole. Now it appears before us on 1,198 pages. What we behold is a mammoth epic, a massive fable, a picaresque journey, a Faustian quest and a work of stunning magnitude and beauty.

IT is only a matter of time before the portrait of the mid-20th-century mom as consumingly influential and monstrously ruinous will look as old-fashioned as Whistler's mother. There is enough scientifically documented theory on hand to allow us to propose that mother's pear-shaped shoulders have been unfairly burdened with blame for every last sour detail of her children's lives.

OAKLAND, Md. -- When Labor Day is done and the vacationists start heading home, summer seems to come into its own in the mountain territory around Deep Creek Lake. With boat traffic diminished, the lake is a wide-open space for swimming, water-skiing and fishing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Although progress sometimes seems agonizingly slow, the world may yet see some new kind of international money before this decade is finished.

IF the rest of the country takes to the Metropolitan Opera National Company as cordially as Indianapolis seems to be doing, the fledgling group's forthcoming tour will be a happy one. Rehearsals have been under way in this city's Clowes Hall -- pronounced Clues -- on the Butler University campus since Aug. 1, and citizens of Indianapolis have embraced the young artists and their project with enthusiasm.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Labor Government and the labor movement of Britain addressed themselves this week to the fundamental and excruciating question of how to increase productivity faster than prices in a free society. One of the city's oft repeated "tragic dilemmas" -- the relocation of a group of established and, in some cases, deeply rooted residents -- is taking place these days in an unlikely setting of affluence at Madison Avenue and 90th Street.

While doing their bit to keep the National League pennant race close, the New York Mets yesterday accomplished something no major league team had done in 48 years. They were held to one hit for the second game in a row as they lost to the Milwaukee Braves, 9-0, at Shea Stadium.

REPRESENTATIVES of 60 airlines will assemble in Bermuda next weekend for another in their series of fare meetings called by the International Air Transport Association. The association's last such conference, at which few agreements were reached, was held in Athens a year ago.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 -- Canadian editorial writers have made an overnight cliche out of the phrase, "the unnecessary election." The term is in vogue from Halifax to Vancouver to describe Canada's 27th general election, which was called this week for Nov. 8.

Re: "After Watts -- Where Is the Negro Revolution Headed?" by C. Vann Woodward (Aug. 29): Professor Woodward touches on, but not with sufficient emphasis, the recognition that the Negro revolution is unique among group struggles for equality in our history.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11 -- A team of four Manhasset Bay Resolute Class skippers defeated Indian Harbor Yacht Club Luders-16 Class helmsmen, 18 1/4 points to 18, today in their annual inter-fleet team match sailed on Long Island Sound in Luders-16 Class sloops.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 10 -- Lehigh managed to win one football game in 1964 and the Engineers were ripe for a coaching change. The new man heading this year's staff is Fred Dunlap, who has spent several seasons as a defensive assistant to Tom Harp at Cornell.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Out of the obscurity of the past, a once familiar figure -- the charmingly eloquent, politically forceful Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek -- arrived here this week in her private railroad car on a mission wrapped in feminine and perhaps diplomatic mystery.

THOUGH spring gardens have long known the "never quiet joy of dancing daffodils," recent advances in breeding have produced flowers of exquisite beauty. They are almost unbelievably perfect in form, with striking color contrasts and the most delicate and subtle color variations.

THREE hundred years ago, in the sultry late summer of 1665, London was a city of gloom and terror. Instead of the cheerful din of tradesmen crying their wares to the passers-by, housewives calling to each other from upper windows, carts and coaches rattling over the cobblestones, an oppressive stillness brooded over the city, broken by the lugubrious rhythm of church bells toiling for the dead.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Problems of the Labor Government's political survival and of Britain's economic survival will be topics of daylong discussions tomorrow at an unprecedented Cabinet meeting at Chequers, the Prime Minister's country residence.

Until now help has been proffered only after speculative attacks on the pound threatened to undermine the entire international financial network.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Australis, who has clinched the national high score award for the year, rallied today to win the open jumper championship at the North Shore Horse Show.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Sept. 12 -- Two Governors proposed today an interstate conservation compact to prevent the "ravages" of strip mining in the Appalachians, the Ozarks and other mountain ranges.

LANGHORNE, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The 250-mile national championship for United States Auto Club drivers was rained out today at the Langhorne Speedway, but not before 13 drivers had broken the world record for a mile paved track in the qualifying trials.

GLASTONBURY, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Nicki Everett of Mount Carmel, Conn., won the American Horse Shows Association hunter seat medal class and then went on to capture the hunter seat championship of the fourth annual Elks horse show here today.

Carmine G. De Sapio, challenger for the Democratic district leadership in Greenwich Village and north to Duffy Square, and Edward I. Koch, the incumbent, took part in a lively debate on community issues yesterday.
MAHWAH, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Two men from New York State have been charged by the police here with the Aug. 28 murder of a service station owner.

NEWARK, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Remnants of the fortune accumulated by Anthony DeAngelis, central figure in a $150 million soybean-oil scandal, will be sold at public auction tomorrow in United States District Court.
A Presbyterian minister invited members of his congregation yesterday to take an active part in "updating" their church's basic theological tenets.
At a service today in San Francisco's Grace Cathedral, the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California, will confer ministerial status on Deaconess Phyllis Edwards.

OSLO, Sept. 12 -- A crowd of 3,000 was in the square for the Norwegian Labor party's final election rally tonight. Overhead was a huge banner saying, "Bourgeois Government? No!" PARIS, Sept. 12 -- French authorities, official and otherwise, are offering assorted ex-plantations -- mostly political -- for President de Gaulle's refusal to cooperate further in support of the British pound.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 12 -- The French Government is trying to recruit several thousand Colombians to work on its missile and space center in French Guiana, it was learned today. Construction of the center, which is outside the capital of Cayenne, is said to be a year behind schedule because of a shortage of labor.
ATHENS, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- King Constantine is expected to call on former Deputy Premier Stephan Stephanopoulous early this week to form a new Government, informed sources said today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12 -- A new 35-foot steel-hull fishing trawler, the first vessel of this type on the Tennessee River, is being put into research use by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- Gary Player won the World Series of Golf today to complete what he said was his best year. A concluding 69 for a 36-hole total of 139 brought the little South African a three-stroke victory and a $50,000 check.
The recently liberalized Social Security Act will have great economic impact on the lives of many women.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 12 -- Army Engineers closed a 40-mile stretch of the lower Mississippi to shipping today as they searched for a barge loaded with 600 tons of poisonous liquid chlorine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The profit margins of manufacturing corporations widened considerably in the second quarter of this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 12 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants rocketed to a two-game lead in the National League race today by turning back the Chicago Cubs, 4-3 and 9-2, and extending their longest winning streak this season to 10 games.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Ohio Bell Telephone Company and the Communications Workers of America agreed on a 14-cent hourly wage and fringe benefit increase for 16,000 employes.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Christian communities in the Syrian town of Aleppo organized a procession today to protest the Ecumenical Council's document concerning the Jews' part in the crucifixion of Jesus.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The heart of the Indian-Pakistani dispute lies in differences over how United Nations resolutions on Kashmir were to have been carried out.

A study of the feasibility of an East Side subway extension from the Battery to connect with existing subway lines in Lower Manhattan has been started, the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, Inc., announced yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- The Allegheny Observatory, threatened with closing because of its expense, will continue in operation for at least another year and its activity may be expanded.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Prime Minister Wilson conferred with his Cabinet today at his official country residence, Chequers. Afterward he was described looking like "a university don who has heard some good essays."
Customs collections on sea-borne imports in New York last month were $10 million higher than in August, 1964, despite the strike that immobilized almost 50 United States-flag cargo ships.

On housing, too, with nearly a fifth of the dwelling units substandard or deteriorating, the Mayor's attitude is crucial.

He is a tall and gangling Muscovite named Vladimir Kochetkov.
